HEADLINE: A City Takes Steps to Get Back in Touch With Its Festive Side 

BYLINE:  By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
WATERBURY has certainly seen its share of troubles during the last few years.
 Philip A. Giordano, the former mayor, is being held in a prison on Federal charges of child sexual abuse; the state oversight board has managed the city's finances since 1996; and, like several other cities, Waterbury has been plagued with its share of urban problems. 
 To combat the hard times, the current administration decided it was time to unify everyone in a citywide extravaganza.
The Committee for a New Waterbury, sanctioned by Mayor Michael J. Jarjura, set up Waterbury Festival America 2002, which will be held in Library Park on Friday and Saturday. All events are free. 
"It has been a very tough past 12 months for the citizens of Waterbury," Mr. Jarjura said. "Festival America 2002 is a celebration that will help restore a sense of pride and unity to the people of Waterbury. This festival is a chance for everyone to relax, have fun and enjoy all the great things that Waterbury and its citizens have to offer."
When Mr. Jarjura took office in January, he quickly followed up on a campaign promise to revive an annual festival.
At his inaugural ball, amid a cheering crowd, he vowed to bring back the Waterbury Festival, an event that served as a catalyst for the community in the 1980's.
Frank Davino, a co-manager of the mayoral campaign, was quickly enlisted to coordinate Waterbury Festival America 2002.
Mr. Davino, who coordinated previous festivals in Waterbury, mobilized forces that include 28 committees made up of 245 volunteers, plus members of several city departments and organizations.
"Every group has given someone to work with us," said Marty Scully, a mayoral aide. "Waterbury Youth Service is involved, Waterbury Teachers and the Federal Credit Union. The Mayor's office came up with the idea and asked Mr. Davino to revitalize the city."
Mr. Davino was the executive director of economic development for 32 years and started the Taste of Waterbury festival in 1985. "In that capacity I envisioned that Waterbury needed community pride," he said. "In 1985, we had 125,000 people attend the event over three days. It was massive, to everyone's surprise and joy."
He retired in 1988. The festival grew smaller and was discontinued in 1990.
Mr. Davino said: "Michael Jarjura said it was vital to instill a sense of pride, togetherness and community, which had been there before the last terrible six years. The festival was always held in mid-September, and what better time to pay homage to New York City firefighters and rescue people."
Waterbury Festival America 2002 will start Saturday at 10 a.m. with a parade, which will begin on Meadow Street and wind its way to City Hall.
Mr. Davino said he was getting calls every day about the America Heroes Parade. Representatives of the New York City fire and police departments and the Port Authority will lead the parade, along with the Waterbury Police Pipers and the Mattatuck Marching Band. There will be local police and fire departments, community groups, private organizations and other marching bands, too.
Governor John Rowland will also be present.
The parade route will be decorated with a red, white and blue patriotic theme on every storefront.
Upon arrival at City Hall there will be an opening ceremony and police officers and firefighters from New York City will receive a special rubber stamp depicting the twin towers with the American Flag and the Statue of Liberty.
The festival will move to Library Park, across Grand Street from City Hall, where 25 food booths will open at noon. At 1 p.m., a performance by Sparkle the Clown will begin. At 2 p.m., a car show with 400 antique and vintage models will take place.
Several children's activities will continue throughout the day. There will be several performances by groups, including George Avak with the National Country Band, Swing Shift, Crossed Eyed Cat and Blues Classic Rock.
At 8 p.m., KC and the Sunshine Band take the spotlight.
"The Mayor hit a major grand-slam home run with this," Mr. Davino said. "All the funds have come from private donations, all the city departments and volunteers are working together, and the people get all this for free. They only have to pay for food and beverages."
On Sunday, the festivities will continue with a children's showcase at noon, sponsored by the City of Waterbury Park Department.
A skateboarding exhibition will start at 12:30 p.m., and several bands will perform throughout the afternoon, including the Arizona May Band, the Otto Y Sabrose Swing Meringue Band, and the Marty Q Jazz Trio.
At 8 p.m. the Andy Nichols Band will take the stage.
During the closing ceremonies starting at 7 p.m., 150 children from the Waterbury and Cheshire schools will sing a tribute to the heroes of Sept. 11 and 150 white doves will be released.
The Andy Nichols Band will play "The Star-Spangled Banner," "God Bless America" and "Proud to Be an American." During the last selection, the students will reappear with red, white and blue lanterns to sing along. Twenty minutes of red, white and blue fireworks will follow.
Mr. Davino expects 40,000 to 50,000 people to attend the two-day event.
The city has 4,000 parking spaces available to accommodate guests. Shuttle buses will run continuously to the city's two major museums, the Mattatuck Museum and Timexpo, where admission will be free both days. The bus ride to the museums also includes a tour of new downtown development and the restoration of the Palace Theater.
"All the city departments have been tremendous," Mr. Davino said. "The volunteers are all working together. This will bring the community together again. Waterbury is alive and well and the people are together. We're back."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Westchester; 
Signs of an Upturn in Downtown White Plains

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
FOR two decades, Leon Silverman, the owner of 300,000 square feet of downtown retail and office space here, watched helplessly as many property values plummeted. After some of the larger stores migrated to malls in the 1980's and 1990's, many of the smaller merchants in the heart of the downtown shuttered their businesses. By the late 1990's, the area of the city that was once known as Little Fifth Avenue barely resembled the one Mr. Silverman first invested in 30 years earlier. 
 Today, by contrast, the phones are ringing frequently in the offices that Mr. Silverman shares these days with his daughter and business partner, Bonnie Silverman, they say, adding that they have few vacancies. 
 Many of the property owners downtown -- like Silverman Realty, Halpern Real Estate Development and Caspi Development -- say they are already feeling the effects of an recovery in the heart of the city. "Everyone's jockeying for space before things get too expensive," Ms. Silverman said. For now, annual rents are holding steady on the Silverman properties at $25 a square foot and up, depending on location. Ms. Silverman predicted they would rise as new construction in the city progressed. 
About 1,700 new apartments are planned, along with a $300 million City Center that will house a 15-screen movie theater, a Westin Hotel and stores like Target and Circuit City. And long in need of a major supermarket, the city is finally getting a $6 million, 70,000-square-foot Super Stop and Shop.
The new development has prompted at least one developer who left during the slow times to return. Caspi Development, once active in the county, pulled out of the Westchester office market a decade ago. During the 1980's and early 1990's, it renovated a building on Court Street in White Plains, turning the rundown two-story structure into a four-story office building. Also during that period, it built two apartment buildings on Barker Street near the railroad station.
In addition, the company owned the 100,000-square-foot Sutton Park, an office building in Valhalla, which it later sold to the Louis Dreyfus Property Group. Caspi built the Classic at Hartsdale, a $35 million 168-unit condominium, and it renovated the 75,000-square-foot Sanborn Map Building in Pelham, turning it into a modern office complex.
After the development company turned away from White Plains, where office vacancy rates continued to rise, and Westchester in general, it focused on hotel properties in Manhattan, specifically the Holiday Inn Midtown on 57th Street and the Chambers on West 56th Street off Fifth Avenue. 
Last month, though, in response to the new activity in downtown White Plains, Caspi bought 235-45 Main Street, a 158,000-square-foot office and retail complex across the street from the future City Center. It acquired the property from Reckson Associates Realty, which is focusing its portfolio on larger properties, for $18.45 million.
"We perked up when we saw all the new construction in White Plains," said Joshua Caspi, director of new project development for the third-generation family business. His father, Steven, is president of the company, which is based in Purchase. 
The company is planning to refurbish sections of the Main Street building for office tenants using 2,500 to 5,000 square feet, as well as to upgrade retail space at the street level.
"Things are looking up in White Plains," Joshua Caspi said, "and we may want to do even more in the city." 
Halpern Real Estate Development, a property owner in White Plains for the last 20 years, is similarly planning its next moves in the city, said Jason Halpern, managing director for the company. Halpern has the right to build up to 600,000 square feet on the corner of Mamaroneck Avenue and Church Street, where its property covers 120,000 square feet of ground space. The company also owns buildings covering 90,000 square feet of ground space on Mamaroneck Avenue, which if built to the maximum allowed under current zoning laws, could amount to 500,000 square feet.
For now, Mr. Halpern said, the company is watching and waiting "and is not in a rush to build." The company is considering developing one or both sites for residential or retail use. Mr. Halpern also said that the firm, which is developing a Marriott Residence Inn in Baltimore, might build a hotel on either of its two White Plains properties.
"We're ecstatic about what's happening in the city, but instead of rushing into anything, we're watching and weighing our options," he said.
AMID all the upbeat projections for White Plains, there is the worry that the new development -- and in particular, the City Center -- might have a negative effect on the older real estate downtown. That is what happened when the 889,000-square-foot Galleria mall opened in the early 1980's, and the Westchester, a mall with a 1.1 million square feet, opened in 1995.
"On one side of the city, the Galleria sucked off retailers and shoppers, and on the other side, first Bloomingdale's and then the Westchester did the same," said Carl Austin, who owns Austin Corporate Properties in Rye Brook. "The result was that everything in between died."
The recession of the late 80's and 90's worsened the problems, as many corporations based in the city downsized and a 30.2 percent office vacancy rate ensued. As of this year's second quarter, the vacancy rate in the central business district was 21.6 percent, according to Insignia/ESG, a commercial real estate company. The county rate, meanwhile, is 15.5 percent.
Pivotal to the well-being of the downtown is the future of a mostly empty 52,000-square-foot retail property that was home to Woolworth's in the previous decade. Foot Locker occupies about one-sixth of the store, which is owned by Silverman Realty and has 100 feet of frontage on Mamaroneck Avenue, directly opposite the site where the City Center is rising, along with another 100 feet of frontage on a parallel street that faces Macy's in the Galleria mall. 
The goal is to lease the space to a retail tenant that will be capable of luring shoppers and an estimated 25,000 moviegoers a weekend out of the City Center and onto Mamaroneck Avenue.
"We know that what happens with this storefront is critical," Mr. Silverman said. "Our goal is to lease the entire store, not just part of it, so we're looking for a tenant like a T. J. Maxx department store or a Gap." He said that a strong retailer would attract not only shoppers but also other retailers as well, much as a major anchor in a shopping mall does.
Downtown property owners said they also expected the 1,700 new apartments and the influx of new residents to help to revitalize the downtown retail economy by creating the need for more service businesses in the storefronts lining the streets. Now, the $1 bargain stores that have occupied those storefronts are being replaced by businesses like restaurants, a dance studio and a gym, said Kathleen Gunn, executive director of the nonprofit White Plains Downtown District Management Association. 
Mr. Austin, who brokered the recent Caspi acquisition, agreed that White Plains must become "a walking city." It was designed in the 1970's to move commuter traffic in and out of the city on workdays, with little concern for foot traffic.
George D. Gretsas, the city's executive officer, conceded that White Plains "has not been pedestrian-friendly" in recent decades. It also does not have sufficient parking now to support a future resurgence of retail activity along Mamaroneck Avenue.
To address such concerns, the city is studying how to expand existing parking lots, perhaps by adding new levels to the them. It is also tearing out old sidewalks and building new ones, improving crosswalks and renovating a small park and fountain at the junction of Main Street and Mamaroneck Avenue, in front of the Galleria, to attract more shoppers to the street.
"The trend is for more nationally based, large retailers to move into downtown locations," Mr. Gretsas said. "And when they're ready to consider White Plains, we want to be ready for them."

HEADLINE: Graffiti as Art. As a Gang Tag. As a Mess. 

BYLINE:  By MARC FERRIS 

 BODY:
TO most people, graffiti is scrawl on the wall, defacement of property. To others, it can be a form of artistic expression. For some local police officers versed in deciphering the modern hieroglyphics, graffiti can track gangs and help determine the identities of their members. 
 However it is regarded, graffiti is spreading in Westchester, on playground equipment in Dobbs Ferry, a white wall of a historic villa along the Old Croton Aqueduct trail in Irvington, the back of a building in downtown Ardsley that faces the New York State Thruway, and the side of a house under construction on the Yonkers-Greenburgh border. 
 It has also appeared with a vengeance on street signs and local highways, where bridge pillars and retaining walls beckon like big blank canvases. New markings cover several layers of faded scrawls along the concrete barriers at the hairpin turn leading from the Cross County Parkway into the southbound Hutchinson River Parkway, for instance. And in Greenburgh, the yellow and black signs along both sides of Jackson Avenue indicating a curve in the road at the intersection of Old Jackson Avenue are persistent targets for a vandal wielding red spray paint. 
"It's a never-ending battle and it's very frustrating," said Colleen McKenna, a spokeswoman for the New York State Department of Transportation, which spends $400,000 a year in Westchester to combat graffiti through a contract with ELQ Industries of Mamaroneck. "We clean it off one day and it seems like a day or two later, it's back." 
Sometimes, the cleanup itself is unsightly. Each batch of concrete comes out a different color, so no one shade of paint can match every surface. Cleanup crews often cover patches of graffiti with blotches of paint rather than an entire new coat. 
Graffiti is becoming a more common part of the suburban wallpaper, perpetrated not just by gang members but teenagers of all social echelons. "It was more prevalent in the cities, but it appears to be migrating," said Lieut. Don McArthur of the Westchester County Police, which patrols the parkways. "There are no numbers to back that up, but it's a constant battle. We've arrested kids from Scarsdale painting graffiti on bridge abutments. It doesn't know any economic strata." 
In Putnam County, officials have been vexed by vandals who persistently cover an abandoned railroad bridge visible on Route 6 with large white letters. After a crew painted over the word "Brewster," preceded by an expletive, someone circumvented a secure fence and put up the name "Andrew" to memorialize Andrew McArdle, a high school student who died in a car crash in January. Graffiti covering a nearby fence read "Miss you, Andrew's Bridge," and "#68," his football jersey number. 
Retaining walls and buildings along Metro-North tracks also attract taggers, graffiti perpetrators who put up their tags, or signatures. "You can see the various places where they've put graffiti that they were taking their lives in their hands," said Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority police, which patrols Metro-North property. "Where there's a will, there's a way. They cut holes in fences and put their stuff up in the middle of trestles. The only way someone could do that is by dangling over the side." 
Catching graffiti vandals in the act is difficult. "If we get graffiti, they'll stake it out," Mr. Kelly said. "If we have a problem, then you sense from the patterns when a particular wall is getting hit. If it's not there at 9 o'clock and it shows up at 10, then we'll take an unmarked car and we'll watch, but usually, it's a hit-and-miss kind of thing." 
One evening last month, at 10 o'clock, a 14-year-old Yonkers resident whose alias is Chubbs and did not want his name used, went with a few friends down to the Ludlow train station with spray paint and wide-tip markers. By Chubbs's account, they had the run of the place for an hour before the police arrived. 
Though he said he is only a dabbler, Chubbs's friends are teenagers for whom graffiti is integral to their lives. 
"All the kids do it at school," he said. "They write on the walls in the bathroom, scratch their initials in the glass. You walk by and you're like, 'Yeah, that's me right there.' " 
Chubbs was arrested for putting up graffiti that night. If he is caught at it again, he will go to jail, where he has already spent two days for stealing a car for a joy ride. 
MOST graffiti is done by hit-and-run guerrillas who enjoy playing cat-and-mouse with the police and revel in their rebel image. In certain areas, however, the messages carry more sinister meanings. 
For Kenneth Davis, a Yonkers community police officer, who has been tracking graffiti for the last decade, the wall markings offer a useful barometer of gang activity. He teaches his techniques to new recruits at the Westchester Police Academy in Valhalla and has given PowerPoint presentations on graffiti to many groups; last month, for instance, he spoke at a conference in Chicago sponsored by the National Gang Crime Research Center. 
On a recent tour of Yonkers neighborhoods, in a doorway just west of Ashburton Avenue and North Broadway, Officer Davis pointed to scribble that read BHW, which stands for Body Hurtin' Warburton, a local gang that haunts Warburton Avenue. The tag also included a list of members -- Burgah, Blaque and Kid -- who pledge allegiance to the crew. Along Lawrence Street and its tributaries in the city's southwest corner, the Lawrence Posse marked their territory with their distinctive TLP tags. At Bruce Avenue and Lawrence Street, the group also put up a roll call. Officer Davis will be seeking information from his sources about Boy Boy, Demo and Murdock, three names new to him. 
Community police officers in Greenburgh also track gang activity through graffiti. Black felt tip pen markings covering a sign at the entrance to the Greenburgh Housing Authority property at 9 Maple Street included the initials CK with an arrow pointing down, which stood for Crip Killers, along with a roll call of nine names. 
Some groups that claim an affiliation with national syndicates like the Bloods and the Crips are like Little League teams that name themselves after the Yankees, Mets or Cubs but have no official connection, though bonafide members of the Bloods and Crips have infiltrated parts of Westchester, according to Greenburgh police officers. Whether local or national in scope, gangs often turn to violence to protect their turf. The Greenburgh police have compiled a list of 25 suspected gang members who are responsible for at least 250 felonies. 
Knowing how to translate gang markings makes it easier to track suspects.
"Once I get the groups, the individuals start coming out," Officer Davis said. "The hardest thing is finding their true identity, because they hide behind so many street names, but with the graffiti, I can identify core members, monitor recruiting and departures, and predict the strength of a gang. They don't think we realize what their markings mean, but no one said they were rocket scientists." 
WHETHER graffiti is gang messages or random scribbling, the best way to stop graffiti in a particular area, say those on the front lines, is to clean it up as soon as possible and the taggers will move on. The White Plains Business Improvement District removes it immediately and the city's downtown is relatively graffiti free. 
"Graffiti is a quality-of-life issue that needs to be addressed immediately," said Kathleen Gunn, the organization's executive director. "Fortunately, we don't have that big a problem, partly because we have a lot of police presence here, but it's like the broken-window theory: when it does appear, it needs to be controlled." 
Yonkers has also made headway by going after the writers and by serving notice to property owners, who have 24 hours to remove the mess. After that time, Richard Fedor, graffiti coordinator for the city's Department of Public Works, will have his three-man crew clean it up and send a bill. "I try to cut them some slack," he said. "If they call me right away, and it's not a real big job, I'll do it for nothing. But if they leave it up and it becomes worse, then I have to charge." 
The biggest job he ever tackled was at the New York City water-treatment plant on Palmer Road. It took his crew 10 hours and the bill came to $1,600, which the agency was happy to pay, he said. 
Mr. Fedor's crew uses a chemical called Scram-It, which is brushed on and then removed with a power-washer that sprays a concentrated blast of hot water. 
Last month, Insane and Fens, two vandals whose marks can be found all over the city, left their calling cards in two-foot-high silver letters on the side of a brick building at 209 Riverdale Avenue in Yonkers along with the initials FSV, which stood for Famous Subway Villains. Erol Liguori, the building's owner, called Mr. Fedor, who removed it that afternoon. 
"My attitude is that every day it's here, they're gaining more air time, so I say hit it right away," said Mr. Liguori, owner of Prolific Art Galleries, which has its offices in the building. "A lot of landlords don't have my attitude and the city ends up looking terrible." 
Mr. Liguori had no control over the graffiti that surrounded his building on the corner of Downing Street. "Sexy thug wuz here" and "Murderuz," written with a black felt tip pen, marred a lightpost that stands a foot away from his building's wall. On the same post, Oz and Fane engaged in a subtle game of one-upmanship. Oz put his tag up first, but Fane crossed it out with a green slash, then put his signature next to his handiwork as if challenging his rival. The mailbox on the corner showed evidence of being painted over several times and someone wrote the almost illegible mark ECKS on the doorway of the building across the street. 
Officer Davis, an art major in college who has studied graffiti like a scholar, marvels at the resilience of wall painting. "It's been around since the first signs of civilization," he said. "Today, it channels the basic instincts of communication and self-worth. It will be on the first lunar station. I don't think it can ever be stopped, but it can be managed." 

Spray-Paint Artists Who Create Open-Air Galleries, Legally
OUTLAW graffiti scribblers tarnish the reputation of legitimate graffiti artists, who put up their pieces with property owners' permission. Carlos Lopez, director of Off the Wall, an AIDS education and awareness program founded 10 years ago by Ken Davis, a Yonkers community police officer, and run by the Yonkers Community Action Program, tries to channel the creative impulse into constructive outlets and frames his message in a form that youths can relate to. 
Though they have created more than 30 large-scale murals around town, the group suffers from the stigma attached to graffiti art. 
"I have approached established artists to work with us and when they found out they would be working with graffiti, they turned us down," Mr. Lopez said. "We're not like kids off the street, tagging up on anybody's stuff. We're doing something positive and working on a higher level, but the knuckleheads ruin it for everybody." 
Graffiti art emerged as a key component of hip-hop culture in the mid-1970's. Though break dancing faded, rap and the distinctive styling of spray-paint artists endure as an expression of inner city youth, despite being co-opted by mass marketers, Mr. Lopez said. 
Off the Wall has helped turn parts of Yonkers into an open-air art gallery. The group makes "masterpieces," large works known as "pieces," which take several hours of planning and execution, along with dozens of cans of paint. Financing for the program, which has a budget of $69,000 a year, comes from the New York State Department of Health, the AIDS Institute and a New York State Community Service block grant.
Across from the group's headquarters on Ashburton Avenue and Jones Place, in a rundown part of town, stands a 10-foot-high, 30-foot-wide antidrug mural that is almost as pristine as the day Alexis Hiraldo (whose tag is Nekst), 18 years old, and Daniel Gomez (Blame), 17, created it two months ago. The main section depicts a boxing ring. The message: "Don't Get in the Ring with Hard Hitting Heavyweights." Off the Wall's logo, emblazoned in bold letters in the lower left corner, along with amoeba-like splotches of color, add abstract flourishes. 
In the mid-1990's, Off the Wall helped transform hundreds of square feet along a concrete walkway in the Vark Street Playground into a showcase. Eighteen artists put up their tags along 4-by-6-foot sections of the wall, which have faded and chipped over the years. Only a few neighborhood youths have added unauthorized tags and irreverent remarks over the years, though one artist's work has been completely crossed out. 
Mr. Lopez plans to hold an event later this fall that will wipe the slate clean and put up new work. He is inviting some of the region's best-known artists to contribute and give local teenagers something to strive for. "Some people use graffiti in a destructive manner," Mr. Lopez said. "It can be constructive, too."
Mr. Lopez offers the ultimate incentive: $400 to $650 for a mural, and he pays artists to give school presentations.
"Once kids sit down and meet my artists, they know we came from the same streets," he said. "Once I grab them and get them in here for 15 minutes, I've got them for the whole year and we can do AIDS education, job-training and college preparation." MARC FERRIS

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Thomas Leonard, Chris Lione

 BODY:
Thomas William Leonard and Ralph Christopher Lione will declare their commitment today in a ceremony aboard the Yankee Ferry, a floating museum docked at Pier 25 in Lower Manhattan. A group of six friends, led by Cherrene Horazuk, executive director of the Committee in Solidarity With the People of El Salvador, or Cispes, will present a series of readings and personal observations about the couple. 
 Mr. Leonard (above, right) is 38. He is the fund-raising director for Cispes, which is based in Manhattan and works for economic and social change in El Salvador. He graduated from Haverford College and received a master's degree in mathematics from the University of Washington. He is a son of Joan and William Leonard of Wynnewood, Pa. His father, who is retired, was an economics professor at St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia. 
 Mr. Lione, 47, is known as Chris. He is a senior art director at Newsweek magazine in Manhattan. He also designs costumes for the theater, and some of his creations were used for "The Countess," an Off Broadway play presented in 1999 and 2000. He is a son of Ruth and Ralph Lione of Lakewood, N.J. His father, who is retired, worked at Fort Monmouth in New Jersey, designing electronic communications systems for the Army.

HEADLINE: Prices Continue Robust Upward March 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
HOUSE hunting has been somewhat less frenzied so far this year than in the last several years in the New York City area, brokers say, although brokerage executives and buyers alike complain of a shortage of inventory. Prices have continued to climb, with average increases registering in double digits in many communities, especially the suburban ring immediately around the city, although the average increases for apartments in Manhattan were in single digits. 
 The median selling price of existing single-family homes in New York State was $170,000 this June, a gain of 19 percent from $142,900 in June 2001, the State Association of Realtors reported. Based on local reports, in Westchester County, the median price of a single-family house rose 12 percent in the second quarter of this year, to $520,000; in Nassau County, the median was up 21 percent, to $333,000; and in Suffolk, 20 percent, to $265,000. 
 In New Jersey, the median price of an existing single family home had risen 17.8 percent at the end of second quarter to $242,500 compared with $205,800 on June 30 last year, according to the New Jersey Association of Realtors. In Bergen County, the median sales price through June had soared 25.7 percent, to $366,300, while in Essex County it was up 9.2 percent at $298,000. In Hudson County the median sales price was higher by a hefty 15.4 percent at $189,400, and in Morris County the median sales price had risen 12.5 percent to $355,200.
Although there is no statewide listing service in Connecticut, local listing services reported that as of June 30, the average sale price for a single-family home in Darien had risen 6.5 percent from a year earlier, to $1,120,000; in Greenwich, 10.6 percent, to $1,786,000; in New Canaan, 8.6 percent, to $1.5 million; in Stamford, 5.7 percent, to $573,000; and in Norwalk, 13.2 percent, to $480,000.
While prices at the high end of the market have followed the general pattern of increases, real estate specialists say the demand for homes in the luxury class has moderated somewhat. In contrast with recent years, the comparatively plentiful high-end inventory has been selling, on average, at discounts to asking prices. 
In the rarefied $4-million-and-over category, Insignia Douglas Elliman, the Manhattan brokerage concern, calculated the gap between asking and sales prices at just over 3 percent in the second quarter of this year. In Westchester, P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the county Board of Realtors, estimated the average discount on houses listed at $800,000 or more was as much as 10 percent. 
The median sales price for luxury condos and co-ops in Manhattan -- defined as the top 10 percent of all co-op and condo sales -- was $2.4 million from April through June of this year, down from $2.45 million a year ago, according to the Insignia Douglas Elliman report, which was prepared by the Miller Samuel appraisal company. The survey put the average length of time on the market for luxury apartments at 163 days, compared with 132 days a year earlier. Time on the market for all apartments averaged 117 days in the second quarter, down from 132 days in the same quarter in 2001.
The survey also found that the median sales price of a Manhattan co-op in the second quarter of this year was $419,000, 4.2 percent more than the median in the prior quarter, $402,000, and 0.5 percent above the corresponding quarter last year. 
The median price for Manhattan condominiums in the second quarter increased to a record $750,000, 6.4 percent more than in the previous quarter and the price per square foot increased 2.3 percent, to $699. The median price at the end of the second quarter of 2001 had been $701,500. 
"One of the most significant differences over last year is the decrease in the supply of apartments," said Jonathan Miller, the president of Miller Samuel. "Although the number of listings actually increased by 422 apartments over last quarter, the number of sales increased by 628 apartments, resulting in a net loss of 206 apartments."
That decrease, combined with the much larger net loss in the prior quarter of 1,842 apartments, Mr. Miller said, was attributable to reactions to Sept. 11 as well as to underlying economic forces. "By the end of the year," he said, "buyers were quick to react in order to take advantage of the Fed having dropped the rates, but at the same time, sellers were slow to put their apartments on the market for fear that they'd sell them for less than they were worth.
"But when it became apparent in the first quarter of 2002 that apartment prices were rising, by the second quarter more properties came back on the market."
The time required to sell a property usually depends on its price, condition and size, real estate specialists say, and therefore varies markedly. In New Canaan, Conn. -- where the average house sold for $1.5 million during the first six months of this year and 30 houses sold for more than $2 million -- the average time on market was 193 days. By comparison, the Staten Island Board of Realtors reported that during the same period single-family detached houses, which sold for an average $329,025, were on the market an average of 75 days. 
As in most other areas within commuting distance of Manhattan, residential real estate sales have been strong throughout Staten Island. Including attached and semiattached one- and two-family homes, as well as condominiums and co-ops, there were 1,782 sales on Staten Island through June of this year, compared with 1,456 a year earlier. The median price the first half of this year was $271,920, up from $239,000 last year, a 13.8 percent increase. "Condos have been selling tremendously," said Richard Schulhoff, the spokesman for the board, referring to the 222 condos that went to closing in this six-month period, compared with 166 a year ago. 
In New Jersey, Charleen Martinelli, a broker with Coldwell Banker in Hoboken, said 90 percent of her sales are for condos, and most of the buyers work in New York. 
Norma De Ruggiero manages the residential division of Robert De Ruggiero Real Estate from the Hoboken office. When she tells prospective buyers that they can buy a condo with about 1,300 feet, two bedrooms, two baths and a parking space for a little more than $400,000, "if they've been to New York," Mrs. De Ruggiero said, "they come to us with open arms."
Alison and David Seidenfrau, for example, had lived in an apartment in Manhattan for six years before his job took them to London for six months. When they returned in January 2001, Mrs. Seidenfrau was pregnant. "With a child on the way, we knew we would need more space and we didn't want to pay Manhattan prices again," she said, "so we rented in Hoboken for a year and a half." Now, Mrs. Seidenfrau and her husband, the director of application development with a software company in Manhattan, have purchased a two-bedroom, two-bath Hoboken condo for $475,000.
Farther away from New York, in Middlesex County, N.J., prices are somewhat lower. Still, said David Fialk, the owner of Choice Realty in Iselin, N.J., because most of the county's communities are only a half-hour or so from Manhattan, "there is so much demand for housing that there is virtually no vacant land."
Single-family houses in the county in the second quarter of this year sold for an average of $252,800, while condos sold for an average of $172,871. During the previous quarter, a one-family house sold for an average of $247,888 and condos for $168,566.

North of New York City
'There's Still Competition'
North of New York City, the median price of a single-family house in Westchester County in the second quarter, $520,000, was an all-time high, compared with $465,000 a year ago, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service. In that same period, the median price of a condo rose 26 percent, to $215,000, and co-op prices rose 14 percent, to $95,000. 
Over Westchester's northern border in Putnam County, the average price of single-family houses rose 13 percent, to $283,000, in the second quarter, and condo and co-op prices increased 8 percent, to $190,500. 
"I've been hearing that buying activity slowed this summer, as it always does in July and August," said Mr. Mercurio of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. "We expect buying activity will be slower in the third quarter, but no slower than usual. There's still competition, and pricing is holding up except for properties of $800,000 and over."
Donna Tierney, an agent with the Armonk office of Holmes & Kennedy real estate, said demand was still strong. "The average price of a home is about $1 million," she added, "as it is in most of the executive areas in Westchester County." 
While million-dollar properties were once associated with the titans of great wealth, realtors say it is not uncommon for young adults, usually with two incomes, to buy a million-dollar-plus condo, co-op or house. 
"They buy these historic properties with lovely views of the Hudson River, and they don't seem to mind the one-and-a-half to two-hour commute by train," said Ann Garti, the executive officer of the Greater Hudson Valley Multiple Listing Service, covering Orange and Rockland Counties, adding that $1.5 million properties in the valley are no longer rarities.
The median price of a single-family house in Rockland County midway through this year was $340,000, compared with $299,900 in the first six months of last year, while the median in Orange County was $215,389 in the second quarter of this year, compared with $175,100 a year earlier.

Long Island
Demand Up, Inventory Down
Joseph E. Mottola, the chief executive of the Long Island Board of Realtors, said the average home price jumps of 20 percent and more in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in the first half of this year resulted from increased demand, reduced inventory and favorable mortgage rates. Asked what trends he foresaw, Mr. Mottola replied, "I think you're going to see a leveling off at the higher end of the market, where residences are not selling as rapidly as in the past."
Prices continue to rise on Long Island, according to Dr. Robert Campbell, professor of real estate at Hofstra University, because of the limitation on developable land. "In Connecticut and New Jersey," he said, "you can keep going farther out, but on Long Island you run into the ocean."

Queens and the Bronx
Appreciation Across the Board
In Queens, prices and unit sales have both risen, but not through the roof. According to the Multiple Listing Service of Long Island, which also tracks the Queens residential real estate market, the median closing price of a single-family home during the first half of this year reached $260,000, up from $235,000 a year ago..
"Everything that comes on the market sells quickly, unless it's really overpriced," said Barbara Frechter, the president of Glenjay Realty in Forest Hills, Queens, and a past president of the Long Island Board of Realtors. "But our big problem is one of supply and demand. We don't have enough product to go around at any price." 
Residential real estate prices also continue to rise in parts of the Bronx. Around the Grand Concourse in the Fordham section, prices have risen as much as 15 percent since April, according to Floyd Cooper, president of the Cooper Group.
In Riverdale, "prices in our building are up at least 20 percent in the last 12 months," said Ted Procas, the chairman of the Association of Riverdale Co-ops.
"Everybody was concerned about what the reaction would be after Sept. 11," said Susan E. Goldy, who has a real estate firm in Riverdale. "They were worried that real estate values would go down or people here would move away. Neither happened. Instead, real estate continued to appreciate, across the board."
The Riverdale real estate market was virtually dormant after the attacks, as were many other markets in the metropolitan area, but it picked up by year's end and remained strong through this spring. "Then we were faced with Enron and WorldCom," Ms. Goldy said, "and when the stock market fell, the economy weakened and after that there was a simultaneous slowdown in sales." This fall, she added, echoing comments made by a number of brokers, "we don't anticipate that we'll be overly busy with sales."

Economists and Bubbles
'Credit Spigots' Are Wide Open
Some scholars who study real estate feel somewhat the same, not only about sales but prices as well. Robert J. Shiller, an economist at Yale, said he would not be surprised if residential real estate prices eventually fall in some cities. "It does seem to me there's a bubble going on, but that doesn't mean it's going to burst soon," he said, adding, "I tend to be in the camp that thinks a double-digit recession is possible. Low interest rates are supporting the housing market now, but that's only part of the story. I think it's connected to the stock market, and I'm still bearish about the stock market."
Dr. Campbell at Hofstra University is also concerned about eventual weakness in the real estate market, but said it would come from the decline in the stock market that has already occurred, not from a further drop in stocks. "The effect of the previous decline is what economists call the 'wealth effect,' " he said, "meaning that people are less likely to make major investments when they do not feel as wealthy, even if the mortgage lender says they can afford it."
Dr. James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, noted that "during the acceleration of housing prices from 1999 to 2002, people took their capital gains out of the market and put them in housing." He continued, "Now, there are no more capital gains to be taken." 
Keith T. Gumbinger, a vice president of HSH Mortgage in Butler, N.J., said, "It would defy logic to think that the real estate boom could continue year after year, even though interest rates are the lowest in about 36 years and the credit spigots are as wide open as I've ever seen. 
"If you can breathe, you can get a mortgage," he added, "but it's very unlikely that interest rates will stay where they are."

$4-Million-Plus City Homes
A Weakness Above $10 Million
A report completed last month on the $4 million-plus co-op and town house market in Manhattan, researched by Kirk Henckels, the director of Stribling Private Brokerage, said that last year the total dollar sales of co-ops in that category dropped 33 percent to $466.6 million from $699.3 million in 2000, and the sales of town houses in that period were off 58.1 percent, to $195 million from $465 million in 2000. The decline was attributable not only to the terrorist attacks, Mr. Henckels said, "but also to a pre-existing and pervasive wait-and-see attitude on the part of buyers, due to a declining economy and real estate market."
But as interest rates dropped and a somewhat improved economic outlook was predicted, a turnaround ensued. Through the first half of this year, there were 51 closings for co-ops in the $4-plus million range, compared with 44 in the first half of both 2001 and 2000, the peak of the market. Nevertheless, only four of the co-op sales were over $10 million, including one for $13 million. That compared with eight sales over $10 million in both 2001 and 2000, including a top sale of $15 million in 2001 and $18 million in 2000.
The reason for fewer sales of co-ops above $10 million this year, Mr. Henckels said, is that the very high-end market consists mostly of buyers with multiple residences. The Enron scandal, continued talk of terrorism and a falling stock market combined to transform the very-high-end co-op market into the weakest segment of the market.
By contrast, he said, a renewed trend toward single dwellings helped high-priced town houses to regain their luster. In the first half of this year, 24 town houses of $4 million and over were bought, up from 15 in the first two quarters of last year, and four of the 24 sold for $10 million and more. 
As with co-ops, condominiums between $4 million and $10 million sold briskly during the first half of this year, but sales declined sharply for condos above $10 million, Mr. Henckels said. "The under $10 million market seems to be driven by people who live and work in Manhattan, while the over $10 million market has a decidedly more foreign presence."

Fairfield County
'Occasionally Getting Bidding Wars'
Fairfield County, Conn., has long been synonymous with luxury homes and high prices, and this year has been no exception. Of the 376 single-family homes that changed hands in Greenwich so far this year, 110 sold for more than $2 million. So did 18 of the 155 homes in Darien, and 30 of 147 in New Canaan, according to the multiple listing services for those towns.
While the buying frenzy in Fairfield County has largely abated, according to Nancy Apgar Winship, a broker at Country Living Associates in Darien, it has not disappeared. "We're still occasionally getting bidding wars," Ms. Winship said, adding that the bids are usually no more than about 10 percent higher than the offering price.
Vicky Fingelly, who is with Nicholas H. Fingelly Real Estate in Southport, said several sales sparked bidding wars that ended in offers about 5 percent over the asking price, while a handful of others resulted in bids 15 percent over. 
After living in a one-room apartment in Manhattan the past two years, Andrew and Dorinda Bonanno began looking for a house in Fairfield County. Mrs. Bonanno, who was born and raised in Australia, wanted to live among greenery, and Mr. Bonanno had commuted from Manhattan to his job with GE Equity in Stamford for six years. After looking for a home in Fairfield County for more than a year, Ms. Winship showed them a two-story, 2,400-square-foot Cape Cod house with four bedrooms in Darien, and they fell for it on the spot. 
"We worried about the price," Mr. Bonanno said of the house, which cost $690,000, far less than the average in the town. "But all the real estate we looked at was expensive, and we absolutely loved this house." No wonder. In addition to lots of greenery on the property, Mr. Bonanno's commute to GE Equity is now 10 minutes.

Washington Heights, Harlem
Drawing 'Displaced West Siders'
In Washington Heights in upper Manhattan, the price of co-ops is estimated by brokers to have risen about 10 percent over last year. Because a two-bedroom co-op can be bought for $250,000 to $350,000, according to Gus Perry, owner of Stein-Perry Real Estate, a lot of what he refers to as "displaced West Siders" and people from Chelsea and Greenwich Village have moved in. Many newcomers have bought two apartments and put them together, he added. 
Harlem also remains a hot residential market, according to Vie Wilson, a vice president at the Corcoran Group. But, "there's not enough supply for demand," she said. A few weeks ago a two-family five-story brownstone in the Mount Morris Park section sold for $1 million. "Depending on condition, size and location," Ms. Wilson added, "you can buy a brownstone in Harlem from $500,000 to over $1 million." 
Sales in Harlem through June of 2002 are not yet available, she said, but their numbers and their prices have been regularly increasing in the last few years. Midway through 1998, the Corcoran Group had sold 58 houses in Harlem for an average of $296,000, according to Ms. Wilson. In the same period in 1999, it sold 67 houses, for an average of $303,000. Midway through 2000 her agency sold 117 homes for an average price of $391,000. And although the agency's sales dropped to 66 midway through last year, the average sales price rose to $412,000.

Brooklyn
Multiple Bids For Every Sale
Residential real estate sales and prices in Brooklyn have remained strong much of this year, particularly around Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope and other historic neighborhoods. 
"Against all odds and some logic, this is the strongest spring for sales and price that I can ever remember," said Christopher Thomas, senior vice president for Brooklyn of the William B. May Company real estate office. From shortly after July 4 through August, there was the usual summer slowdown, Mr. Thomas said, possibly compounded by the stock market decline. 
In recent weeks, however, "every one of our sales has had competitive bids or multiple bids," he said, adding that average prices are up 8 to 10 percent. But prices for midmarket properties, those between $500,000 and $800,000, the strongest part of the market, have increased as much as 12 percent, Mr. Thomas said, and relatively affluent young singles have been actively buying in the $200,000 to $400,000 range. 
Strong sales have also been reported elsewhere in Brooklyn, including in the South Shore, Midcounty and Bay Ridge-Bensonhurst. Gerard Longo, the president of Madison Estates and Properties as well as chairman of the South Shore Multiple Listing Service, said the average sales price for a one- to four-family house in the South Shore through August of this year had risen to $339,932, from $288,030 in 2000. In neighborhoods across the middle of Brooklyn, single houses sold for an average of $286,509 through August of this year, according to the Midcounty Multiple Listing Service, up from $238,388 two years ago. And the Bay Ridge-Bensonhurst Multiple Listing Service said prices there had risen to $415,525 through this August from $360,454 in 2000.
Although the frenzy to buy a home has generally subsided, brokers say, there are still some prospective buyers who jump at the first property they see. "We had one recent sale of a four-family house in East Williamsburg over Labor Day, where the asking price was $575,000 and now it's in contract for over $700,000," said Suzy Kline, the owner of Kline Realty in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. "So few properties come on the market that we've had people say, 'Even if isn't perfect or the price is too high, I want it and I'll take it.' " 
When Ms. Kline showed a three-story, $565,000 house in Williamsburg to Bill Palmore and Peter Sturmey, "it was the only place we looked in, in that neighborhood, and we wanted it from the get-go," said Mr. Palmore, an architect who teaches at New York Institute of Technology. He and Mr. Sturmey, a psychologist who teaches at Queens College, liked the house and also the neighborhood's mix of residents, including Hasidic Jews, Italians and Poles. 
Another attraction was that they could park their car outside the house. "And because Peter's from England," Mr. Palmore said, "he needs adequate pub life, and the neighborhood has lots of pubs and great restaurants." He added, "We've already colonized three pubs."

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES/CBS NEWS POLL; 
For Most, City Grass Is Green Enough

BYLINE:  By MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
 Given a choice, most New Yorkers say they would prefer to live in New York City than anyplace else, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll. Fifty-seven percent of the 1,008 respondents hope to still be living in New York four years from now, while 42 percent would just as soon leave. 
The percentage of people who wish to relocate has risen in the short term up from 31 percent in a poll taken less than a month after Sept. 11. But far more people want to stay in the city now than in 1991. During that time of recession and high crime rates, only 37 percent wanted to remain and 60 percent wanted to leave. MARJORIE CONNELLY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN/LOWER EAST SIDE; 
Few Kind Words Are Heard for a Proposed Economic Zone

BYLINE:  By KELLY CROW 

 BODY:
On Aug. 28, the city's Department of Business Services mailed to the office of Gov. George E. Pataki 470 pages of reasons why the state should create an Empire Zone out of an 18-block-wide patch of Chinatown and the Lower East Side.
 Few may be surprised at that heft. The area was hit hard by Sept. 11; unemployment there is 25 percent now, according to Asian Americans for Equality, a watchdog group. The wisdom of an Empire Zone, a designation that offers tax credits and lower utility rates for businesses, may seem clear. 
 But the proposed zone, which would extend from Broadway east to Clinton Street and from Houston south to South Street, has in fact sparked tensions, and not just because the state will choose only 6 of the 26 bids filed statewide. 
For one, Councilwoman Margarita Lopez and Community Board 3, which includes the proposed zone, have complained about the timing of the application. 
The state, they say, called for bids in June, but set the deadline for applications on Aug. 30. The City Council voted to approve the Chinatown application on Aug. 15, only hours after it held its only public hearing on the matter. 
"The extremely short time period for outreach to and comment by the public is completely unacceptable for a program that could have such far-reaching effects on the future of these neighborhoods," wrote Harvey Epstein, the chairman of Board 3, in an Aug. 21 letter to the city.
"It appears to many in the community that the fast track this designation has been placed on is influenced more by election-year politics than by the economic condition of the Lower East Side and Chinatown."
Moreover, Ms. Lopez said, the proposed zone omits several needy patches of the Lower East Side, including Montgomery Street near the Vladeck Houses and several blocks north of the Williamsburg Bridge. All suffered greatly after Sept. 11, said Rosie Mendez, the legislative aide to Ms. Lopez.
"Chinatown needs help, but when you looks at this zone, there are glaring omissions," Ms. Mendez added. "And the thing that really upsets us is that for years we've been trying to get these incentives, and now a lot of struggling areas are being left out."
But the borders can be expanded later, said Mark Newhouse, assistant commissioner of the Department of Business Services. The current borders were simply dictated by assessing potential for business development, he said, and too much of the area east of the proposed zone was residential. But he said the city will consider stretching the boundaries to the east and north upon approval by the state, which is scheduled to decide on the bids next month.
"Getting the application to the state is like getting our foot in the door," he said. "We can always go back and try to open it up a bit farther." KELLY CROW

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for DAVID J. OLSON; 
If Longshoremen Strike, Which Businesses Will Suffer?

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
FOR months, the nation's businesses have worried about a labor dispute that threatens to shut down 29 West Coast ports that handle $300 billion in cargo a year. The International Longshore and Warehouse Union has warned that 10,500 dockworkers might strike or engage in a work slowdown at ports from Seattle to San Diego, while the employers' group, the Pacific Maritime Association, has threatened to lock out the workers, a move that would shut down the ports.
 The longshoremen's contract expired on July 1, and the two sides have bargained on and off since then, with the threat of a stoppage hanging over the talks. 
 David J. Olson, a professor of political science at the University of Washington, is an expert on ports and the longshoremen's union. He has served as a consultant to many ports and port associations and was founding director of the Harry Bridges Center for Labor Studies at the university. He spoke on Thursday about the dispute and its implications. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

Q. Some economists have warned that even a short work stoppage would disrupt the economy. What would be the impact of a short or a long stoppage?

A. A short stoppage would directly and immediately affect the three port centers of the West Coast -- the Puget Sound, San Francisco Bay and San Pedro Bay near Los Angeles. It would severely affect those companies that depend on just-in-time inventory.
If a stoppage lasted a month or two, the impact would be very significant. It would affect shippers across the country, and given that we're in the pre-Christmas shipping season right now, the nation's retailers would be importantly affected.

Q. Which industries or businesses in the United States would be hurt the most by a shutdown of the ports, and what effects would such a shutdown have overseas?

A. A stoppage would affect the whole gamut of merchandisers, from Wal-Mart, Target, Home Depot to Sears and Circuit City.
Manufacturers would also be affected. The container box is the warehouse for modern-day business. The ports handle millions of parts needed for assembly or manufacture. Auto dealers would also be affected. They'd definitely feel it if a stoppage went on for two weeks.
The nation's manufacturing export sector would also be affected. We're not talking only about goods flowing into the country, but also goods flowing out of the country. 
As for the effects overseas, the whole international financial community would be disrupted because many banks do trade lending. They monitor worldwide cargo flows like a hawk.
Secondly, most members of the Pacific Maritime Association and most of the steamship lines are foreign-owned, and they would be affected significantly. The Asian economies could also be dramatically affected, from South Korea to Singapore.

Q. Increased use of technology seems to be a sticking point in the negotiations. Why, given that the employers have guaranteed that no longshoremen would be laid off?

A. The technology being considered is complex. It requires deliberation, discussion. I don't think the union is resisting new technologies. They want to discuss them to make sure the jobs created by the newly implemented technologies fall within union jurisdiction. They don't want those jobs to be nonunion.
In the past, the West Coast ports have been innovative and adaptive regarding new technology. Both sides have benefited remarkably. The shipping companies have profited handsomely, productivity has increased dramatically and union members have been well compensated.

Q. Businesses that rely on West Coast seaports have had a few months to prepare for a stoppage. Have businesses been stocking up, or have they made alternative plans to import through Mexico, Canada or the East Coast?

A. The shipping community considered alternative routes. Canada won't work because the dockworkers there are affiliated with the I.L.W.U. Mexico won't work because it doesn't have the port, rail or road infrastructure. The Panama Canal was considered and rejected because many of today's cargo ships are larger than that canal can handle. The stockpiling of inventory was considered, but not really followed, because of the just-in-time nature of modern-day business.

Q. Longshoremen don't earn as much as baseball players, but with an average wage of $80,000, according to the union, they are still paid extraordinarily well compared with other blue-collar workers. For that reason, wouldn't a slowdown or strike be a public relations mistake?

A. I think lesser-paid workers admire the longshoremen. They view the longshoremen as having earned this compensation level. Being a longshoreman is a very dangerous job. Injuries and fatalities rank it just behind mining. Additionally, this is a highly skilled and trained work force. I don't see envy out there.
If a work stoppage hurts the economy or Wall Street, I'm sure we will hear complaints from the business community and President Bush about these well-paid longshoremen. But we won't hear that from other workers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David J. Olson says a closure of 29 ports would have quick and significant effects.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Despite Sales Gains, Rocky Road For Durables

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
OVER the last year, conditions have been just about perfect for manufacturers of "white goods," consumer durables like refrigerators and ovens, washers and dryers. 
 But many investors have been focused on the inevitable moment when such perfection ends. Interest rates won't always be at 40-year lows. The housing boom will slow. And relentless pressure to cut costs will most likely bring in new competitors. 
 Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst at Prudential Securities, talked last week about what he sees as a rocky future for the Whirlpool, Maytag and G.E. appliances of the world. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Why weren't appliance manufacturers hurt in the aftermath of Sept. 11?

A. This industry benefited, because people decided to spend money on their homes, not on traveling. And last year's tax cut, the home mortgage refinancing boom and zero-interest financing created a sonic boom. Unit sales were up about 10 percent last year, which is huge. But that creates a problem, because as a consequence the year-over-year comparisons for the second half of this year are pretty tough. We think unit shipments this year will be flat to up 1 percent.

Q. Why are you concerned about these companies?

A. These are classic, interest-sensitive cyclical stocks, even though we have been told for the better part of the last decade that this is not so.
We are all panned out on interest rates. At the margin, we are going to see weaker consumer spending: debt service as a percentage of disposable income has been rising for more than five years. At some point we are going to reach the high end of the arc. We will slowly, gradually ease off on the real estate side. And some of these companies are pretty levered up: Whirlpool has got record debt-to-total-capital ratios of 66 percent. Maytag is at 88 percent. 

Q. Are we in a housing bubble?

A. Home prices have probably gotten into a bubble on a regional basis. A decline in home prices is a possibility. Hopefully, it will be a gradual decline. But inventories are pretty low and there has been a lot more consolidation of home builders.
But resales of homes and new housing starts will definitely slow if interest rates go up. If interest rates go up 200 basis points, or two percentage points, there will be some serious brakes on this market. 
A lot of people have bought second and third homes not for shelter, but to shelter their money. If home prices start to go down, people will start selling.

Q. What would hurt appliance makers more, a drop in resales or in housing starts?

A. For the past few years, resales have been the real jet fuel behind white-goods sales.
On average, you get 1.4 new appliances with a new home. But you get 2.3 new appliances with a resale. 
And residential resales have been running at a 5.5 million annual rate. In the early 1990's, resales were running at a 3 million to 3.5 million annual rate. The change in the tax laws that allows people to keep a big chunk of the gain they realize from the sale of their home pushed that number up.

Q. Of the stocks you cover in this group, General Electric is the only one you recommend. Is that based on its appliance business?

A. G.E. sells a little over $6 billion worth of appliances, which is not bad, but it is less than 5 percent of total sales.
The value of the appliance business to G.E. is to generate cash to reinvest in higher-growth, higher-return businesses. 
I think the odds are extremely high that G.E. will be out of the appliance business in a year or so, even though in terms of market share they are No. 2. Jeffrey Immelt the G.E. chief executive needs a business with an aftermarket he can earn tremendous margins on. Servicing contracts on appliances is not a high-margin business. So the returns are diminishing for them.

Q. Has the stock market fully discounted a downturn in business for these companies?

A. At the moment, we are priced at the midpoint of the valuation zone, with prices trading at around 9 to 10 times earnings. Historically, the stocks bottom with a price-to-earnings ratio of 6 to 7 times earnings. They are not cheap enough to buy. In fact, with the exception of Maytag, management at every company in this industry has been selling stock since February. Maytag insiders have been buyers.

Q. What is your attitude about the other stocks?

A. First, I don't own any of the stocks and Prudential doesn't do any investment banking business with these companies.
We have a hold rating on Maytag and Electrolux. Whirlpool is rated a sell.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Heymann 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
As Portfolios Shrink, Retirees Warily Seek Work

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
MOST of the patients seeking help at the SLS Wellness Center in Brewster, N.Y., suffer from addictions or behavioral or psychological disorders. But lately, Dr. Michael Nuccitelli, the executive director of the clinic, has been seeing a steady number of job seekers, particularly former retirees who have had to go back to work because of financial reversals. Many of them, he says, are looking for ways to improve their memories and stamina so that they can better compete in the workplace.
 "They're apprehensive about having to compete for positions with younger workers who may be more technologically advanced," Dr. Nuccitelli said. "And they're worried they won't past muster when they do get a job." 
 Such concerns are facing more and more retirees who re-enter the work force after absences of years or even decades. Many of these people had hoped to spend their advanced years in traditional retirement pursuits: hobbies, for example, or volunteer work. But because of the slide in the stock market over the past two and a half years, they are finding that they can no longer live off their investment portfolios. 
Since 2000, retirees' portfolios have shrunk by about $678 billion, according to a recent study by the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan. About 20 million older Americans rely on investment income for part of their living expenses, said William Rodgers, an economics professor at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., and a former chief economist for the Labor Department.
He estimated that retirees who ranked in the top 20 percent in earnings during their careers typically have more than one-third of their assets tied up in the stock market, and another 20 percent in pension funds. Those who were in the bottom 20 percent, he said, are less likely to need to return to work, because about 80 percent of their income comes from Social Security.
"It's the higher-income retirees who are out seeking jobs," Professor Rodgers said. 
The number of people 55 and older in the work force rose by more than 7 percent, to around 20 million, in the 12 months ending in July, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, while the number of workers in all other age groups declined.
Career experts say many retirees returning to work can expect a rocky road. "In many fields, retirees are considered washed up," said Jeff Kaye, president and co-chief executive of the Kaye/Bassman International Corporation, an affiliate of Management Recruiters International, based in Dallas. Mr. Kaye said troubled industries like telecommunications and technology might be particularly difficult for retirees to penetrate. 
"The people who used to work in these fields aren't even getting in to see recruiters," he added. "They're getting jobs ripping tickets at movie theaters or punching the clock at a Wal-Mart."
JOSEPH TURNER, a former senior service account manager at Nortel Networks in Schaumburg, Ill., knows what the search is like. In May 2001, at the age of 55, he took an early retirement package. But seven months later, after his 401(k) plan, invested almost exclusively in Nortel stock, lost about two-thirds of its value, Mr. Turner realized that he would have to return to work.
After failing to get even one interview in the telecommunications field, he broadened his search to account management positions in other industries. "I eventually just started looking for any job that dealt with customers," said Mr. Turner, who lives in Crystal Lake, Ill. After two interviews that proved fruitless, he took another path.
"I finally read the writing on the wall," he said. He began doing odd jobs for neighbors and has gone into business for himself as a carpenter. He works 8 to 12 hours a day and earns about half his former Nortel income.
Although age discrimination is illegal in the workplace, career experts say older workers may fall victim to some type of it: companies may favor hiring younger workers who are starting out or at the peaks of their careers. Employers, they add, may also be wary of investing in workers whose primary reason for returning to work is financial.
"Nobody wants to hire somebody who they think is just temporary," said Dennis A. Ahlburg, associate dean of the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. 
Dr. Ahlburg advises older job seekers to avoid citing financial troubles as a reason for returning to work. "Don't say you're out of money," he said. "Say that you were bored in retirement and you want to be an active part of the labor force. You want to solve the potential problems of an employer, not add to them."
Retirees should accentuate the experience and attributes that they can bring to the workplace, said Bill Coleman, senior vice president of salary.com, a Web site that provides compensation information for job seekers. For example, he says, many are willing to work part time and do not need the salaries that younger workers require.
"Position yourself as a bargain," Mr. Coleman said. "Tout the fact that you have 40 years' experience, but you can work on a project basis, so they don't have to pay you what they might pay someone else."
Focus on experience and level of maturity, he added. "Don't say, 'I'm old, but. . .'," he said. "By doing that, you're admitting a defect that's probably not even there."
Retirees returning to work should also try to build a network of former colleagues and other professionals to call upon for help, experts say. Such people may know about specific leads for jobs, including temporary or consulting positions.
Even retirees who land good jobs may have trouble making the transition back to the working world. Some have problems with the fact that they will probably accept less senior positions than they once held. Others cannot get past paychecks that are only a small fraction of what they used to earn. 
"It's difficult to stomach, psychologically," said Andrew Schultz, president of PrO Unlimited in Boca Raton, Fla., which advises companies about how to use contingent workers, including retirees. He said he is placing more former retirees in temporary and consulting positions, especially in manufacturing.
Another challenge is getting up to speed in new technologies. Barbara M. Morris, 73, a supermarket pharmacist from Escondido, Calif., and author of "Boomers Really Can Put Old on Hold" (Image F/X, $16.95), says older pharmacists who leave the field, even for only a few months, often have problems returning. Although it is usually not hard for such workers to find jobs, because of a nationwide shortage of pharmacists, "what I see is not encouraging," she said.
"Those who return after retiring have lost a lot of skills," she added. "Their thinking slows, their response time is slower, and they just can't grasp the technological changes."
Ms. Morris recalls one recent case in which a former retiree at her store was not able to work on Sundays because that was the day the computer technician was out: "He was a liability, and as a result, his hours were cut."
Mr. Schultz, too, says technology can be a big hindrance for seniors who go back to work. One of his clients in the manufacturing field sends retirees on consulting jobs abroad. Such workers have to book their own travel over the Internet, and many have had trouble doing so. "They're used to dealing with travel agents," he said.
Ms. Morris and Mr. Schultz advise retirees to audit a computer course at a local college to gain confidence in new technologies.
Stamina can also be an issue. Some returning older workers may worry that they do not have as much energy as their younger counterparts. Dr. Nuccitelli of the SLS Wellness Center said he recently coached a 62-year-old former lawyer who had returned to the working world for financial reasons. While the man did not have trouble finding a job, he had difficulty adjusting to the around-the-clock work schedule, which included evening client meetings and networking dinners. With Dr. Nuccitelli's help, the lawyer developed an exercise regimen that helped him increase endurance.
To help with memory and to lighten the work load, Dr. Nuccitelli also advises retirees to buy a personal organizer to jot down important meeting dates, "to do" lists and other on-the-job details.
Dr. Lois Breen, 73, a former dean of psychology at National University in Costa Mesa, Calif., who retired in 1996 and returned to the school eight months ago as a part-time professor, says she stayed sharp during her absence by reading professional journals and traveling to Japan once a year to train Japanese psychotherapists. As a result, she says, she felt that she was able to adjust quickly to her new position.
"My transition has been easier than it might be for others, because I always kept up on my field," said Dr. Breen, who began teaching again after her stock portfolio fell about 25 percent in value.
FOR Norman Dorosin, who retired four years ago at the age of 59 as a pharmacist at a nursing home, the challenges of working again have been mostly psychological.
Mr. Dorosin had planned to spend most of his time relaxing in his new dream house in Mobile, Ala., and acting in community theater productions. But after the value of his retirement savings fell 40 percent, all of that was delayed. He went back to work this year, as a pharmacist at a local Walgreens drugstore. His arthritis is beginning to bother him, and he is not fond of having to stand for hours at a time. But "as physically taxing as this job is, it's more of a mental struggle," he said.
"Most days at work, I just sit here thinking, 'I would rather be home,' " he added. "That's a little bit depressing."
