HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Can a Test Gauge the Value of an M.B.A.?

BYLINE:  By MAGGIE JACKSON 

 BODY:
ROB FREYTAG, a part-time M.B.A. student at DePaul University in Chicago, believes that hard-to-measure qualities like a well-rounded personality are more important in landing a management job these days than getting the right answers on some standardized test. Nevertheless, he plans to be one of the first to sign up for a new M.B.A. certification exam that he hopes will narrow the competitive edge enjoyed by students at name schools like Harvard and Wharton.
 Mr. Freytag's attitude captures the widespread ambivalence of business school students, deans and corporate recruiters toward this first national test to evaluate M.B.A. students' mastery of core business topics. The test, called the Certified M.B.A. Exam, was announced last week and will make its debut in April; it will contain 300 multiple-choice questions and last five hours. 
 More than 100,000 people receive M.B.A.'s each year, and the exam raises a question: Do students need an impartial seal of approval of their competency, or do their degrees and resumes speak for themselves? 
"An exam might level the playing field," said Kathleen Trexler, director of the M.B.A. program at Lehigh University's College of Business and Economics in Bethlehem, Pa. "We have a small school with individualized attention. That doesn't get the prestige factor of the big schools."
Even so, she and others say the voluntary test will be of limited use because management success depends on elusive traits like creativity and team-building. "It will test the tools of the trade, so to speak, but it takes much more than that to make a business leader," Ms. Trexler said.
The exam was developed by the International Certification Institute, a private company in Mocksville, N.C., that was formed in January. 
The test will be administered by the Thomson Corporation, a provider of legal, financial and educational information that also oversees the Graduate Record Exam, or G.R.E., and other well-known tests. The new test, which will cost $450, will be offered at centers where students take the Graduate Management Admission Test used in admissions for most M.B.A. programs.
Although the certification exam is pass-fail, students will also receive a ranking of their results in different subjects. Registration for the exam has not yet begun, the institute said, although students began signing up in August for a trial test.
A sample question: A company's net income in its entire life totaled $10 million. It paid dividends of $3 million, built a new plant for $4 million and increased its inventory by $2 million. What are its retained earnings? (The answer is $7 million.)
The company contends that the exam is a long overdue tool to assess proficiency in business basics of the growing numbers of students in part-time or full-time M.B.A. programs in the United States. In 2000, some 112,000 people received the degrees, up from 26,000 in 1970, according to the most recent data from the Department of Education. The number of accredited business schools rose to nearly 400 from 330 in 1998, according to the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.
"Given the wide variety of programs, it is an inference that people have mastered a common body of knowledge in the core curriculum," said Michael Mebane, managing director of the International Certification Institute. "There's no measurement to know this has happened."
The exam comes amid questions about the value of the degree and the quality of many programs. Jeffrey Pfeffer, a Stanford business professor, recently said in an article that M.B.A. graduates at all but top schools did not advance faster than executives without the degree.
PETER NAVARRO, an associate professor of business at the University of California at Irvine, has long supported the idea of an M.B.A. competency exam. "Far too many M.B.A. grads don't have the skills that a degree should ensure," he said.
Still, Mr. Navarro said that an exam based only on multiple-choice questions would fail to test fully the broad range of skills that M.B.A. students need. "Certification is only as good as the test," he said.
The M.B.A. degree is increasingly popular because it is viewed as a salary booster and as ammunition in a tight job market. But as interest has grown, job offers have been scarcer in a soft economy. This year, one-quarter of graduating M.B.A. students seeking jobs received or accepted offers by March, the Graduate Management Admission Council said.r That is down from 41 percent in 2001, partly because fewer students were being interviewed.
Jeffrey Brown, a Lehigh M.B.A. student, knows it may be tough to get a job when he graduates next spring. Yet he doubts that a largely unknown certification exam would help. "I'm at a small school, but I think my background is strong enough that it may not be necessary," he said.
Mr. Freytag, however, doesn't want to take any chances, even though he currently has a job in sales at the International Paper Company. "I'm going to have to take this test," he said. "I want to be as competitive as the next person. If you graduate from Harvard or Wharton, you're going to have an advantage."
Sixty percent of corporate recruiters cited "reputation of the school" among the top criteria in hiring new M.B.A.'s, according to the Graduate Management Admission Council. That is one reason some deans and students predict the test will attract mostly students from non-accredited and lower-ranking schools. "Our program is sufficiently rigorous so that our students are way above a minimum test like this," said Paul Danos, dean of the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth. "The degree itself says something about a student's ability. I don't think that a little test like this will add more."
The test's creators say it is meant to be just one of many criteria for judging M.B.A. students, but Mr. Danos and others worry that it may be used as a shortcut in the interviewing process, which involves internships, multiple interviews, transcripts and at times internal exams.
Corporate recruiters are cautious. "Hiring encompasses so many factors in addition to education," said Jeri Calle, the partner in charge of university relations at the accounting firm KPMG, which recruits only at accredited M.B.A. schools. "I'm not sure how much of an edge this would give students."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Brian Matthews; 
Payden Core Bond Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
BRIAN MATTHEWS, lead manager of the $250 million Payden Core Bond fund, describes himself as an old-fashioned bond manager.
 "If you want go-go numbers, invest in stocks or junk bonds," he said from his office in Los Angeles, adding that such potential returns, of course, come with heightened risk. 
 Instead, Mr. Matthews focuses on solid, investment-grade corporate and government bonds, a conservative strategy that has yielded excellent results. The fund returned 9.5 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, placing in the top 6 percent of funds that buy intermediate-term bonds, which returned 7.8 percent, according to Morningstar Inc. The fund returned 11.8 percent in the last 12 months, versus 6.8 percent for its group. 
Mr. Matthews, 41, is a managing principal of Payden & Rygel, the fund's investment adviser, which manages about $40 billion for institutions and individuals. 
He works with five sector analysts to pick the 75 to 100 issues in the fund from about 750 issuers in the Lehman Aggregate Bond Index, which tracks investment grade bonds, those rated BBB- or better by Standard & Poor's.
The fund buys securities from American issuers, but Mr. Matthews also evaluates the global economy. "What happens in Thailand or California can have a big impact on the U.S. capital markets," he said, "because capital flows across borders more quickly and easily than any time in history."
The American economy is "very fragile," he said, adding that "the consumer is the only thing keeping the economy above water, and it's unclear how long that will last." He projects an uncertain economy until the end of this year or early 2003. To reduce risk, he has taken several steps, like sticking with higher-quality, more liquid bonds. He is also avoiding the telecommunications and energy industries, concentrating instead on finance, banking and consumer staples. And he has shortened the average duration of the portfolio securities to about four years, in line with the Lehman index. Bonds of shorter duration are less sensitive to interest rate shifts. 
Mr. Matthews also works with eight credit analysts to pick individual bonds. They create their own ratings for potential purchases, comparing them with those of ratings agencies and focusing on issues they consider undervalued.
The credit analysts also work with Payden equity analysts, sharing information gleaned on company visits. "Management will give them an equity-friendly story," Mr. Matthews said, "which is often different from the fixed-income holders' perspective." For example, he recalled, a big company once promised credit analysts at a conference that it would use cash flow to pay down debt. Several weeks later, he said, it told the fund's equity analysts that cash flow would be used to buy back shares.
He reviews bonds for sale when shares of an issuer's stock decline significantly more than the overall market, or when the issuer's financial picture deteriorates.
In June, Mr. Matthews bought a Kraft Foods bond with a 6.25 percent coupon and due June 2012; it is rated A- by S.& P. He paid $107.55 for each $100 in face value; the bond now trades at $109.82. 
Kraft has strong brand-name products, from Oreo to Toblerone, he said, and is guided by a strong management team with a clear growth strategy. 
In July 2001, he bought a Wells Fargo bond that has a 5.875 percent coupon, is due in August 2008 and is rated A+ by S.& P. He paid $99.95; the bond now trades at $108.34. 
Wells Fargo has a strong revenue base, he said, and its business and geographic diversification have provided consistent profitability. While it has exposure to commercial real estate lending that could make earnings more volatile, he said, management's conservative underwriting and strong risk management contribute to asset quality.
HE also likes the Coca-Cola Company because of the strength of its brand name and worldwide market share. "Coke's international opportunities and geographic diversity support long-term growth prospects and add to its earnings stability," he said. 
Despite consolidation in Coke's global bottling system, which has created debt and increased leverage, the company has strong cash flow and healthy debt protection, he added.
In November 2001, Mr. Matthews bought a 5.75 percent coupon bond due March 2011. He paid $104.07; the bond now trades at $107.80. The issue is rated A+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Rebound From Ruin, if Not From Distrust

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
THINK back to one year ago. Think of all that has occurred since 9/11/01 in the financial markets, in corporate America, in your own portfolio. That is how the end of an awesome innocence looks.
 Having endured a year of almost unceasing tumult, investors can certainly consider themselves grown up in 2002. At the same time that all Americans were forced to confront the fact of their country's vulnerability, investors were also made to understand how much about the markets and the companies they owned had been illusory in recent years. 
 Now, one year later, the euphoria that characterized investing in the late 1990's is gone; that wide-eyed acceptance of every word corporate executives uttered, of every financial statement they released, of every outlandish projection an analyst made has been replaced by a sense that trust must once again be earned, that skepticism is a worthy trait, that the advice of analysts can be costly.
Is it a coincidence that the confidence-shaking scandals at Enron, Adelphia Communications, WorldCom and elsewhere began exploding on the scene after Sept. 11? Perhaps. The companies certainly would have collapsed sooner or later; each was a house of cards. 
But it may not be happenstance that investors discovered only after the World Trade Center attacks how shaky some companies were. As the notion of an impregnable nation was lost, so finally were the myths of the ever-increasing stock market and the productivity miracle that many people considered the American economy to be.
Investors can be proud of their performance during the past scandal-plagued year. Immediately after the terrorists struck, even as New York City was still in triage, investors showed an admirable indomitability. No matter what kind of hatred the terrorists threw at the United States, the American investor would prevail. Take aim at Wall Street, the world's capital of capital, and know this: We will not be moved. We will be back tomorrow, buying and selling securities, financing new enterprises and hoping to prosper from our efforts. Capitalism may not be perfect, but it is far superior to the alternatives.
One of the first lessons investors learned in the last 12 months is how to assess the risks that a terror-filled world poses to their holdings. Investors in some companies, like Walt Disney, whose operations include American icons that could be considered prime terrorist targets, quickly saw that their shares held greater risk than before. Alternatively, investors recognized that insurance stocks would benefit from rising premiums charged to anyone with an asset to protect.
But perhaps a more significant lesson learned by investors is that, fearful though we all are of future attacks, a far greater risk to our continued prosperity and economic strength comes from within our shores, not without. That risk emanates from the people in positions of power at corporations who cheat their shareholders, lie to investors and make millions in outsized compensation or well-timed stock sales just before their games are exposed.
A throng of telecommunications titans fit this description, as do the executives at Enron, a company that was really just a facade. But the list of unindicted co-conspirators should also include the huge financial institutions -- including J. P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup -- that appear to have helped companies hide their true financial positions from investors, earning handsome fees for their efforts.
"Only capitalists can destroy capitalism," said Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier and a former ambassador to France. "Populist capitalism of a type is very beneficial to the vast majority in our system, but an ethical tradition is needed to make it all work. When you have senior people walking away with hundreds of millions, leaving everyone else in the dirt, that is hugely depressing and very dangerous."
Mr. Rohatyn, like many believers in capitalism, is especially dismayed by the role that venerable financial institutions played in the scandals that are still unfolding. And, he argued, because these financial pillars are at the heart of the Enron and WorldCom debacles, the problems they may have helped create have a greater and longer-lasting impact on the economy.
That is one element that makes the current scandals different from their predecessors. In the 1970's, when many Wall Street firms collapsed, the cause was technological incompetence and lack of capital, Mr. Rohatyn said. The closing of the firms had little impact. Even the failure of Drexel Burnham Lambert, which ruled Wall Street in the 1980's only to evaporate in 1990, seems small when judged against today's messes. 
In both earlier periods, the effects of the scandals were relatively muted. "They didn't cost 50,000 jobs, people's savings and a decline in market value of trillions of dollars," Mr. Rohatyn said. Now, however, the corruption in the financial system looks more endemic, he added. "This is not about a bunch of rogue C.E.O.'s. Once this sort of thing gets to the establishment of the financial community, then you'd better stop and say, 'Wait a minute, what's happening here?' "
BUT while the nation's law enforcement officials work to protect the citizenry from future terror attacks, investors are pretty much on their own. They may have to figure out their own set of defenses against fraud. 
So far in this election year, Congress has seemed willing only to parade the miscreants before the people, rather than institute reforms that might work to correct what is wrong. Doing away with the Glass-Steagall Act -- which forced financial institutions to choose between banking and investment banking -- helped get us to where we are today, but building up new barriers to eliminate the conflicts of interest now rampant in the largest financial institutions will be difficult indeed.
Some investors believe that the worst is over, that no other scandals will erupt. But even so, the damage to investor confidence has been done.
"Does the system work to spread the wealth in some way that's reasonably fair?" Mr. Rohatyn asked. "Clearly at this point, the answer has to be no, and that's not tolerable."
The loss of lives on Sept. 11 remains an unspeakable horror. There will be no getting over it for the families and friends left behind. But the nation has proved it can bounce back from devastating terrorism. Recovering trust in Wall Street and corporate America is a taller order.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Numbers Look Better, but Markets See the Worst

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE stock market is still in the doldrums. But economic data are looking a lot better and may mean that the summer slow-growth scare, which sent stocks to a five-year low, is over.
 The numbers for July and August already appear to be adding up to third-quarter growth that is three times the pace of the slow second quarter. Employment data released on Friday matched expectations, showing the creation of 39,000 jobs last month. Given the recent fears of a second, or double-dip, recession, all this ought to be good news. 
 The sell-off in all three major stock indexes last week, however, seemed to show that investors are seeing only the worst in new data. Although manufacturing is weak, it is still not in reverse. And in the past, the overall economy has managed to grow when manufacturing was in decline. The broader services sector was also weak but still growing in August.
So modest third-quarter growth -- if confirmed in the coming data -- may not be enough to revive the outlook for stocks, especially if that growth does not translate quickly into a revival in corporate earnings. Modest doesn't seem to work with investors who have been schooled in the boom of the 1990's and the bust of the new millennium.
And if the rebound in growth ensures that the Federal Reserve will not cut short-term interest rates further, investors may worry more about the outlook.
Though Fed policy makers have said they will trim rates further if necessary, their recent statements indicate that they do not think a cut is needed. They appear less willing than in the past to use an extra rate cut as insurance for the economy. Investors who expect a rate cut, even if it signals that the economy is weak, appear to be a little happier than those who do not.
The brighter economic numbers include a 13.5 percent surge in August automobile sales, reported last week, and a 1 percent jump in July consumer spending, reported the previous week. Some analysts now say the spending jump indicates that personal consumption expenditures, which account for about two-thirds of economic growth, could grow 4 percent this quarter. Automobile sales, running at an annual rate of 18.7 million vehicles, bolster these forecasts because they show that spending is holding up.
Then there are inventories, which are expected to rise, adding to third-quarter growth.
The pace of growth could be hurt by rising foreign imports, which detract from growth of the gross domestic product. This buying from abroad, rather than at home, may explain why the American manufacturing sector was weak in both July and August.
Still, even with that import drag, the economy should be able to grow at an annual rate of 3 to 4 percent in this quarter. This is slower than the normal pace for a recovery, but a lot better than the anemic 1.1 percent annual rate in the second quarter.
But investors may just ask, "Can this pace continue?" Some automakers warned that the sales pace in August, could not be maintained, even with incentives. Oil prices around $30 a barrel could also slow growth. And the inventory buildup could be a drag in the fourth quarter if consumers slow down at the end of the year.
MAJOR retailers, including Wal-Mart Stores and Target, said their sales were sluggish last month because consumers were frugal. So the overall retail sales report for August, due Friday from the government, will be an important measure of third-quarter vitality. 
Louis Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson Associates, argued that the data on the gross domestic product overstated the weakness in the second quarter and could overstate the strength of the third quarter because of problems in the way the data are collected.
If Wall Street's consensus for third-quarter G.D.P. growth jells at around 3 or 4 percent, "it would not mean that the economic concerns that gripped the market's attention at the start of the quarter were a mirage," Mr. Crandall said. Nor, he said, would it mean that companies and investors will enjoy the profit growth that they are longing for.

HEADLINE: Reform in Iran 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Reviving Reform in Iran" (editorial, Sept. 3): 
 The viability of President Mohammad Khatami's reform efforts depends on his ability to simultaneously pursue economic liberalization and political institutional reform. Mr. 
Khatami's recent attempt to weaken the clergy-dominated Guardian Council and to strengthen the presidency represents critical turning points in the country's postrevolutionary political process. Reforms of this nature contribute to the regime's longevity by enhancing the present system of checks and balances. 
 Mr. Khatami's reform agenda can be set back by a United States war on Iraq, which is likely to create a national emergency inside Iran. A peaceful environment is an essential condition for deliberative democracy, especially in the turbulent Middle East.

KAVEH L. AFRASIABI
Binghamton, N.Y., Sept. 3, 2002

The writer is senior associate, Center on Democratic Performance, SUNY at Binghamton.

HEADLINE: After the 'Darkest Year,' a Changed Wall St. 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
PHILIP J. PURCELL, the chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley, still chokes up when he talks about the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. His eyes grew misty last week, during an interview in his Times Square office, as he recounted how he had watched on television as a jumbo jet smashed into 2 World Trade Center, where 2,700 Morgan Stanley employees had worked. Seven of them, along with six consultants to Morgan, died that day.
 "That was my home for a long time," Mr. Purcell said. Framed on his office wall is his World Trade Center identification badge. 
 Until a year ago, misty eyes were scarce on Wall Street, especially on senior executives like Mr. Purcell, a button-down, strategy-obsessed manager who engineered the merger of Dean Witter and Morgan Stanley in 1997 and has survived his share of corporate power struggles. 
But Wall Street is a different place today -- emotionally, financially and physically. Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, calls the last 12 months "far and away the darkest year in our history."
By aiming at the World Trade Center, the terrorists struck at the most visible symbol of American capitalism, a complex that not only was just a few blocks from the stock exchange, the heart of the financial system, but also was the communication and transportation hub connecting Wall Street to the rest of the world.
They killed nearly 3,000 workers, devastated and dispersed hundreds of companies and shut down American financial markets for several days.
Amazingly, there was no crash. The system recovered quickly -- completely reopening for business by Sept. 17 -- and so did stock prices, only to be laid low by a series of corporate and accounting scandals.
After the stunning collapse of Enron in November, the recovery started to unravel. The accounting debacle that brought down Enron, then its auditing firm, Arthur Andersen, and then WorldCom, gradually crushed investors' faith in the American financial system, leaving them distrustful of financial statements and the people who create them.
As investors withdrew from the stock market, prices plunged, resuming the slide that began in early 2000. The market, measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, has dropped 23 percent this year.
On the New York Stock Exchange, trading volume has rebounded to high levels, but there's a catch: most of that activity involves professionals, many of them making big, short-term bets. The masses of individual investors who flooded into the market during the boom years of the 1990's have curtailed their trading sharply and pulled billions of dollars out of individual stocks and mutual funds. In July alone, investors withdrew $49 billion from stock mutual funds, more than in any other single month in history.
"We were very proudly proclaiming in the 1990's the merger of Wall Street and Main Street, with 85 million Americans having become investors," Mr. Grasso said. "Now they've been disappointed. We're in a period of trust rebuilding in our business not too much different than after the great crash of '29."
In all, the current bear market has wiped out more than $6.5 trillion of the value of American stocks.
As if the corporate scandals weren't damaging enough, Wall Street is reeling from self-inflicted wounds. Much of the money lost by shareholders was invested in companies that had been recommended by Wall Street analysts, whose motives have become suspect amid several investigations into conflicts of interest.
In the last year, two of the most influential stock analysts, Henry Blodget of Merrill Lynch and Jack B. Grubman of Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney unit, have left the business amid allegations that they pumped up the stocks of their firms' banking clients. Dozens of lesser names have also fled, and the taint has spread to the entire industry.
Mr. Grubman's fall accelerated after his testimony before a Congressional committee investigating the accounting scandal at WorldCom. The inquiry has since expanded to cover Salomon's practice of handing out shares of hot stock offerings to chief executives, including Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chairman of WorldCom, and has moved beyond Congress to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Federal and state prosecutors are also investigating Wall Street's practices.
In response, brokerage firm managers and securities regulators have been rewriting the rules of the road on Wall Street. Congress joined in by passing the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, a law intended to reform corporate accounting and governance, but that Mr. Purcell and some other Wall Street executives contend makes it harder for them to compete with foreign banks. That is making a bad business climate even worse.
"The overall degree of difficulty of the past year has been unmatched in my 34 years on the Street," said David H. Komansky, the chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch. Mr. Komansky has said that he will step down as chief executive in December, more than a year ahead of schedule.
Mr. Komansky said that decision had little to do with Sept. 11 and the disruption it caused to Merrill's business and the lives of its employees, three of whom died in the attack. But he said the lingering sadness had been compounded by the firm's financial straits. Merrill has eliminated about 25 percent of its jobs in the last 18 months.
"We had people put forth superhuman efforts to get us back in business, and then they got caught up in the downsizing," he said.
Like its competitors, Merrill is suffering through a slump in revenue and profit that started well before Sept. 11. Already in decline after 18 months of falling stock prices, securities firms are now struggling to raise morale even as they eliminate jobs and cut much of the pay and the perks that have always been their primary lure.
ALL told, securities firms earned pretax profits of $10.4 billion last year, half the record $21 billion they made in 2000. The Securities Industry Association's latest forecast of pretax profits for 2002 is $10 billion, less than the totals for five of the last six years.
To adapt, the firms have cut costs, and on Wall Street the biggest costs are its people. Securities firms have eliminated 43,000 jobs in the last year alone, dropping total employment to 726,600, and more layoffs are on the way.
So if the financial world has shaken off the dust from the trade center's collapse, it remains a gloomy place. The spirit of cooperation that prevailed in the days and weeks after Sept. 11 has faded, and Wall Street's rough-and-tumble nature has re-emerged.
"These firms are as competitive with one another as they can possibly be," Mr. Grasso said. "I can't say they are any less competitive than they historically were. But I think they have a better perspective on how to compete and recognize that you can compete very aggressively and you don't have to be unpleasant about it."
Still, with many individual investors showing no signs of returning to the stock market anytime soon, investment banks and brokerage firms will continue to cut costs; for some, there is not much left to trim but payrolls.
Falling interest rates have fueled corporate bond sales and reduced costs for Wall Street firms, allowing them to postpone trimming payrolls in proportion to their decline in revenue. But the slack has been exhausted: with long-term interest rates at 30-year lows, securities firms have started laying off people who would have been considered untouchable a few years ago.
Morgan Stanley, for example, recently dismissed about 20 managing directors in its investment banking operation. In July, FleetBoston Financial shut down Robertson Stephens -- an investment bank based in San Francisco that helped finance the technological revolution in Silicon Valley -- after failing to find a buyer. The Charles Schwab Corporation, which prides itself on the loyalty of its employees, is considering more job cuts after eliminating 27 percent of its staff in less than two years.
"To me, it's been a year from hell," said Thomas W. Jones, the chairman and chief executive of Citigroup's global investment management division. "It's been an incredibly difficult year, starting with Sept. 11 and all of the trauma associated with it, relocating many of our people, the really negative equity market environment, not to mention angry customers who have lost a lot of money." 
Mr. Jones's annus horribilis started when he followed 1,200 employees of his division out of their headquarters in 7 World Trade Center hours before it burned and collapsed. Since then, they have regrouped in offices around Manhattan and in Stamford, Conn., but remain unsettled. Mr. Jones has been running the business from temporary quarters in the Citicorp Center on Lexington Avenue in Midtown, but he will soon move to new offices in Citigroup's headquarters nearby, on Park Avenue.
Citigroup itself, the biggest financial services company in the world, has tumbled into a cauldron of troubles that have tarnished the once-shimmering reputation of its chairman and chief executive, Sanford I. Weill.
Weighed down by fears of the company's liability in scores of investor lawsuits, Citigroup's stock price has dropped 35.7 percent this year, to $30.28.
"This has been a lousy period to go through," Mr. Weill said at an investors' conference in New York on Friday. 
He said some of the firm's actions might look inappropriate in hindsight, but, he added, "Nothing has come to anybody's attention that we have done anything illegal."
Like Mr. Weill, Mr. Komansky asserted that the finger-pointing at Wall Street had gone too far and had become counterproductive. "It's devastating to the professionals in this business to have to go through one after another of these issues," he said.
WHETHER or not the intense scrutiny is deserved, it is being felt. Morale and self-esteem on Wall Street are depressingly low, said Alan M. Johnson, managing director of Johnson Associates, a pay consulting firm.
"The most remarkable thing is how little has changed, not how much has changed," he said. "This is milder than prior downturns. It just feels so awful."
Inevitably, some Wall Streeters have re-evaluated their lives. Caught up in a swirl of sometimes conflicting emotions -- anger, defiance, perseverance and patriotism among them -- more are engaging in charitable activities, said Frank Fernandez, chief economist at the Securities Industry Association. Only a few, however, have left the securities industry. After a lot of talk about walking away from their high-paying jobs, most have stayed on.
They are no longer so proud, though. Two years ago, people still bragged at cocktail parties about being investment bankers, Mr. Johnson said.
"Nobody would say that now," he added. "I don't remember a time when you had to feel bad about being an investment banker."
Physically, too, Wall Street has changed -- probably forever. Firms have moved thousands of employees out of Lower Manhattan, some as far away as suburban Westchester County, central New Jersey and Connecticut.
"Lower Manhattan is nowhere near being back to normal and may never be back to normal," said John Thain, co-president of the Goldman Sachs Group.
Goldman, one of the few major investment banks still based downtown, is building an office tower across the Hudson River in Jersey City. But Mr. Thain said the firm had no intention of leaving Lower Manhattan altogether, as Lehman Brothers, another big investment bank, did this spring. Lehman moved its headquarters, which had been in the damaged World Financial Center, to a new building north of Times Square.
Mr. Thain said, "If we hadn't been building that building before Sept. 11, we probably wouldn't build it today." Goldman is not growing anymore; it, too, has shrunk.
Most Wall Street executives said they learned from the attacks the risk of having their employees and operations concentrated in one area. In the future, the industry will be even more spread out, as firms like Morgan Stanley carry out plans to move thousands more jobs out of the city, they said. Even the New York Stock Exchange is planning to create a second trading floor outside Manhattan.
Those moves may alleviate the risk of another market shutdown, but they will not remove the threat of another attack, said Mr. Purcell, the Morgan Stanley chairman.
"New York is going to remain the world's financial capital," he said. "So, yeah, New York's going to be a target." Like everyone else in the city, Wall Street is learning to live with that.

HEADLINE: War of Secrets: Word for Word/Redesign; 
Getting the Intelligence Services a Vulnerable Nation Needs

BYLINE:  By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
IF anything changed after Sept. 11, it was America's sense of invulnerability. Suddenly, this became a nation under threat, a nation without security. What needs to be done, what can be done -- short and long term -- by the intelligence services to protect the United States against future attack? 
 The answers to that question from a number of counterterrorism, security and public policy experts cover a wide spectrum and suggest both that there is much to do and that intelligence alone is not the answer. 
 There is broad agreement that all the intelligence and law enforcement agencies -- national and local -- must find ways of sharing information and resources. 
Some believe an entirely new domestic security agency should supplant the F.B.I. in intelligence gathering, leaving the bureau to its traditional tasks of law enforcement and evidence gathering. 
Others are troubled by a possible threat to civil liberties posed by the increasing emphasis on domestic security, especially since, they say, it is a goal that can never be fully achieved. RALPH BLUMENTHAL

Stansfield Turner, retired admiral; professor, School of Public Affairs, University of Maryland; Director, C.I.A., 1977-81:
The most important thing is to put somebody in charge of intelligence. The Director of Central Intelligence defers to the Secretary of Defense. But the military threat is no longer the primary threat, so the military shouldn't be in charge.
The law created a Director of Central Intelligence to command all 14 intelligence agencies, but it didn't give him any authority. He doesn't have the authority to ensure an exchange of information between the F.B.I. and C.I.A. 
Similarly, the electronic reconnaissance people and the human intelligence people at the C.I.A. need to work together. One clue leads to another. 
President Carter gave me more authority than any other director -- I coordinated the collection effort and the budget -- but it's all evaporated since. It worked so well the Defense Department got scared and took back the power. The homeland security bill does not address this. The president ought to do something to straighten it out.
Last summer we began to get leaks out of the Scowcroft Commission a review of the nation's intelligence services ordered by President Bush, that called for giving the C.I.A. director broader budget authority over the intelligence community, including at least some military elements. 
It recommended taking the National Security Agency and the National Reconnaissance Office, now in the Defense Department, and giving them to the Director of Central Intelligence. 
I agree with Scowcroft. One person can't both run the C.I.A. and collect central intelligence. If you're the head of one, all will think you're not sharing information fully.

Gregory F. Treverton, senior policy analyst, the Rand Corporation; vice chairman, National Intelligence Council; C.I.A., 1993-5:
The first necessity is to get on with the Department of Homeland Security to provide a domestic intelligence and analytical capability. 
Shockingly, there's no place in the government where they're trying to put together data from domestic and foreign sources, a sort of domestic C.I.A. 
The counterintelligence people do a good job but they're pretty operational and, by their charter, foreign only. The F.B.I. never puts the dots together. With all the trials, cases against terrorists, the first necessity is to connect the domestic dots. Beyond that, the world is pushing traditional intelligence and law enforcement together. The distinctions during the cold war don't work in fighting terrorists -- law enforcement and intelligence, public and private. 
We don't want to repeat the abuses of the 1930's and 50's and 60's, the sort of thing the F.B.I. did to Martin Luther King Jr. We don't want to do that again. But we need to know what's going on in the mosques.

Robert B. Oakley, visiting professor at the National Defense University in Washington; former director of counterterrorism for State Department, 1984-6; ambassador to Pakistan, 1988-91:
There needs to be what the military would call a fusion center for military analysis of intelligence with the C.I.A., F.B.I., State Department and National Security Agency. All have to share more than they do now, pool their analytical ability. They're working at this, but the F.B.I. and C.I.A. are working on their own capability. There's too much separateness and competition, not enough pooled analysis. 
What can we do against terrorists? In the short term, we can disrupt them, that's the best we can do. Longer term, we can work with other countries, help them reform, like we just gave Pakistan $100 million to reform education, so they're not dependent on the madrasas, the religious schools. Socioeconomically, we can help create jobs. We can't solve all their problems, but we can reduce them. My advice? Don't overplay the threat and don't be panicked. Terrorism, after all, is about what? Terrifying you.

Richard J. Kerr, intelligence consultant; deputy director, C.I.A., 1988-92:
We are going to have to become aggressive in the use of intelligence before anything happens, not after. 
Overseas, but also in this country, we have to become very intrusive, following where the money goes, where the terrorists gather, what they talk about. We've been taking some action to stop them. You don't hear about it and you shouldn't. 
Sometimes it means stepping on people's toes. We'll make mistakes that when exposed make people uncomfortable, lawyers and civil rights people. There will be penetration of organizations likely to be places where plots are supported. Sort of like they went after the Communist Party in the 1930's.

Yossi Melman, writer for Haaretz in Israel and frequent commentator on security and intelligence subjects:
America has to change completely its intelligence mentality and attitude. It really needs to rely more on human sources. The war in Afghanistan showed how that was needed, to do preparatory work. It's so difficult to recruit Americans who would be ready to spend time under disguise. How many are ready to do it? 
In the short term you need to increase your cooperation and share intelligence. Many intelligence organizations feel they're asked by Americans to give information, like subcontractors, but it takes give and take to create in your allies a real sense of cooperation.

Jeffrey H. Smith, partner Arnold & Porter, Washington; general counsel to the C.I.A., 1995-6; general counsel Senate Armed Services Committee, 1986-88:
We should consider creating a new domestic security agency, like London's MI-5, take the counterintelligence and counterterrorism functions out of the F.B.I. and C.I.A., and create a new agency reporting to the attorney general, with no law enforcement functions. 
The U.S. does not have an agency to collect and analyze intelligence on domestic security. I do not believe law enforcement and intelligence work well together in a single agency. They have such competing functions. The missions are so different. They don't mix well. There's inherent tension between the two. It's like putting diplomacy under the War Department.

James K. Kallstrom, senior adviser on counterterrorism to Gov. George E. Pataki; assistant F.B.I. director in charge of the New York office, 1994-7:
We need to close security loopholes in our borders and gateways and ports. What do we know about the people we give visas to? Basically we're a wide-open society. We need to engage the 700,000 state and local police with training and relevant information as to terrorists so they can be eyes and ears for terrorist task forces in the U.S. Here in New York State we have 150 officers in the task force and 70,000 police officers so you can see there's a tiny, tiny amount in the task forces.

William P. Kinane, vice president, Guardsmark; former F.B.I. legal attache, United States Embassy, Moscow:
Al Qaeda -- they're the enemy. Right now we should be dedicating all our resources to finding and eradicating them. Every time you pick up the paper you see another cell discovered. They're out there operating in places where nations don't have the resources to pursue them. 
We got lackadaisical when the cold war ended, put our resources into technological things instead of people, recruiting, the dirty work of recruiting lowlifes to help us. I don't like this idea of spending a fortune. No matter how much we spend, they'll find some vulnerability. Let's just go out and get them. It's a simple solution.

Stephen J. Schulhofer, professor of law, New York University; former consultant to United States Sentencing Commission; specialist in criminal law and criminal procedure:
We absolutely need to have a comprehensive, independent assessment of intelligence failures prior to 9/11 like that ordered after Pearl Harbor. That it's not already underway is incomprehensible. We know mistakes we made, but we don't know the scope. 
Second, we need to assess whether proactive counterterrorism initiatives should be centered in the F.B.I. or a separate agency. The decision apparently made by the administration to reorient the F.B.I. to make counterterrorism its No. 1 job poses major problems for civil liberties. Historically, the F.B.I. was oriented overwhelmingly toward finding admissible evidence for producing convictions in court. That's a different mentality. There is no sense these issues are being thought about. 
The restrictions on communication between detainees and their lawyers in many cases impedes our antiterrorism effort -- it's counterproductive. Traditionally, a lawyer serves as an intermediary with a plea or substantial assistance agreement, getting information and moving up the ladder. If a defendant is talking directly to the prosecutor he can't say anything. If he's talking to his lawyer, the lawyer can say, "If he would talk, here's what he would say" and it can't be used against him. It's a much better way to move forward.

William J. Bratton, senior consultant, Kroll Associates; New York City Police Commissioner, 1994-6:
It's not so much coming up with new ideas but taking what's been discussed and analyzed exhaustively and following through. Here in New York City, Commissioner Kelly, for example, has been beefing up the city's capacity for early warnings. He's expanded the emergency response units. Each precinct has an intelligence detective. He's placed several officers overseas.
American police chiefs have voiced concerns at the lack of information sharing by the federal government, and we've got to enlist the two and a half million security officers in the private sector to work better with police and federal agents.

Coleen Rowley, chief division counsel, Minneapolis office of the F.B.I., who criticized the bureau's handling of the case of Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged with involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks:
The F.B.I. needs clearer, more workable guidance on sophisticated intelligence-gathering techniques, especially in smaller offices. The larger offices have seen more terrorism-type cases. In the future we're going to see things like that popping up all over the country. 
Procedures have to be simplified. The laws and guidelines are susceptible to varying interpretations, then we have attorney general guidelines and then we have policy. It gets more and more complicated, more susceptible to not operating smoothly.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
A Forecast for Uncertainty

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer 

 BODY:
Robert J. Shiller, the Yale economics professor who coined the phrase "irrational exuberance" in the stock market bubble, has been monitoring a decline in investor confidence this year.
 Professor Shiller has directed a Yale survey of investor behavior since 1984, and for the last 12 years the effort has produced a series of investor confidence indexes. 
The indexes show that since the beginning of this year, the market's decline has led investors to believe that stocks are more fairly priced. 
 "People are reasonably confident in the value of the market but are not as confident that it will rebound or will not crash," Professor Shiller said. "The data also suggests that Americans are not sure about the short run."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Tax Break for Homes Affected by Sept. 11

BYLINE:  By Jan M. Rosen 

 BODY:
People affected by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks who felt forced to sell their homes may qualify for a tax break, even if they lived in those homes only a short time, the Treasury Department and Internal Revenue Service decided late last month.
 Generally, homeowners who have used a home as a principal residence for at least two of the last five years can exclude capital gains of up to $250,000 -- or $500,000 for a couple filing jointly -- from taxable income. 
But the law provides that people who do not meet the two-year test can exclude a proportionate amount of any gain if the sale is for reasons of health, change in employment, or, to the extent provided by I.R.S. regulations, "unforeseen circumstances." 
 Although regulations for unforeseen circumstances have not been issued, Pam Olson, acting assistant Treasury secretary for tax policy, said that under that clause, those affected by Sept. 11 are entitled to exclude the proportionate gain from the sale of their principal residence. 
The Treasury Department said a taxpayer would be considered eligible for the capital-gain exclusion if, for example, a spouse or person living with the taxpayer was killed as a result of the terrorist attacks, or if the taxpayer's principal residence was damaged. Also qualifying are those who became eligible for unemployment compensation because of Sept. 11, or had a change in employment that made it difficult to handle basic household expenses.
More information on the decision is available on the Web site for the National Association of Tax Professionals, at www.taxprofessionals.com. Jan M. Rosen

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
For Comfort, Friends and Family Dined Out

BYLINE:  By SETH W. FEASTER 

 BODY:
 In the last decade, Americans increasingly used restaurants and fast-food merchants as extensions of their kitchens, ordering prepared food and taking it with them. But in the months after Sept. 11, the number of people who sat down to dine at restaurants rose sharply. 
For the three months from December to February, the increase was 5.6 percent from the period a year earlier. 
"There appeared to be a need to be together with friends and family, to be with them at restaurants over meals," said Harry Balzer, vice president of the NPD Group, a marketing research firm.
But Mr. Balzer said that Americans have been returning to their old habit of taking out food. "That trend will reassert itself," he said. SETH W. FEASTER

 Widespread fears after Sept. 11 that the economy would fall into deep recession have not been realized. Instead, a mild recession appears to have ended near the end of last year, thanks largely to the resilience of consumers and a surge in government spending. But growth remains meager, with businesses reluctant to invest in new equipment, and a few sectors, including airlines, still suffering greatly.

HEADLINE: Cutting Corporate Costs, Or Playing With Fire? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Cost-Cutting Can Start a Ruinous Circle" (Economic View, Aug. 25), in which Louis Uchitelle described how corporate layoffs and other measures would cause the affected workers to make fewer or smaller purchases, possibly restarting a cycle of less production and even more layoffs: 
 In the current season of company announcements to lower costs, increase productivity and raise the bottom line, an additional point could be made: Workers who escape the ax this time may well worry that they will not be as lucky in the next round of cutbacks. 
Naturally, these workers then reduce their spending, too. This means that companies may again cut production and the workers' fears may be realized. 
Not until the return of job stability, exemplified by steady and large-scale hiring, will at-risk workers or those who have lost their jobs loosen their purse strings.

CLAUDE M. GRUENER
Austin, Tex., Aug. 26

HEADLINE: Cutting Corporate Costs, Or Playing With Fire? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 As the column says, everyone in the economy loses when companies act in their own perceived short-term interest. Drastic cutbacks in buying capital goods and in employment cause a drop in demand that, if it continues too long, can lead to the downward spiral toward recession or depression. 
 The most important requirement for a stable and prosperous economy is a job at reasonable pay for everyone who wants one. When this occurs, demand increases, and everyone, including the wealthy, can fare better. 
In our recent history, the closest we came to this was from the end of World War II until about 1973 -- a period when a rising tide really did lift most boats.

WILLIAM F. SCHREIBER
Cambridge, Mass., Aug. 26

The writer is a retired professor of electrical engineering at M.I.T.

HEADLINE: Waiter Who Lost Job on Sept. 11 Struggles to Get By 

BYLINE:  By LYDIA POLGREEN 

 BODY:
There are days when Sultan A. Salim wishes he had gone to work on Sept. 11. As a catering waiter at Windows on the World he probably would have perished, as surely as his 72 colleagues did, in the inferno and collapse of the World Trade Center.
 "If I had died, my family would be O.K.," Mr. Salim said, his voice flat and matter of fact. "They would have a million dollars and they would be fine. They would not have me, but what good am I now?" 
 More than 3,000 people died in the terrorist hijackings and attacks on Sept. 11. But that day also had many other victims. Mr. Salim, who lost his job and has struggled since that day to make a living in a tough economy, is one of them. 
"Sometimes I think everyone forgot about us, the ones who survived but still struggle," he said in a recent interview. 
At 36 he is his family's sole breadwinner, responsible for his wife, a 3-year-old daughter and a 70-year-old father with many health problems. They live together in an apartment in Parkchester, a neighborhood in the Bronx. 
Mr. Salim said he used to make about $70,000 a year at Windows on the World. He began working there in 1996, and has worked in catering since 1990, when he came to the United States from Bangladesh.
When the towers collapsed, Mr. Salim lost close friends and a lucrative livelihood. After nearly a year of unemployment, he is working again, at a hotel in Jersey City. 
"But I make less than one-third what I was making," Mr. Salim said. "I can't cover my expenses. I pay $6 each way for transportation. When I can, I work many hours to make up for how little money I am being paid. This is my life now."
After Sept. 11 his family got some help, from Catholic Charities, which helped with bills, and the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which helped with the rent. But all Mr. Salim wanted was a job.
"I kept asking, please, help me find a job," Mr. Salim said. "But I think it is easier to give away money than it is to help someone find a job."
Jobs like the one Mr. Salim held at Windows on the World -- unionized, with high pay and benefits -- are hard to get. He said he had high hopes when he attended a job fair for the new Westin hotel opening near Times Square, but he did not get a call back. He has sent 200 resumes to hotels and restaurants across the region.
"Maybe because I have a Muslim name no one wants to hire me," Mr. Salim said. 
He had been saving to buy a house, but now that money is gone. "I am starting again from zero," he said. "I used to give money to charity. Now I need charity. This is very hard to accept."

HEADLINE: FOLLOWING UP 

BYLINE:  By Joseph P. Fried 

 BODY:
A New Day May Dawn, But It's Taking Awhile
 They were the grandes dames of the old borscht belt, until newer generations of vacationers spurned them and their less prominent like for trendier destinations. 
 The Hamptons and the Caribbean and Europe were in. The Concord and Grossinger's and the other resorts of the Jewish Catskills were increasingly passe, and by the late 1970's most of them had as much of a future as the fallen leaves on their grounds. 
Grossinger's, with 600 rooms in Liberty, N.Y., closed in 1986. The 1,200-room Concord, in Kiamesha Lake, held on until 1998.
A Westchester developer, Louis R. Cappelli, above, envisioned more for the sprawling sites than nostalgic memories of sumptuous artery-clogging meals and entertainment by Danny Kaye, Milton Berle and Eddie Fisher. In 1999, he and associates bought the two old resorts at bankruptcy auctions, and he has been planning new ventures that would appeal to a modern, multiethnic generation of vacationers and conventiongoers.
Like traffic to the Catskills in the days before superhighways, things have been moving more slowly than Mr. Cappelli had hoped, leading skeptics to cite failed revival efforts in the economically battered region, and local government officials to hope he overcomes the hurdles. 
An early financing proposal for the first phase of the $500 million redevelopment at the Concord fell through. The $180 million needed for that phase is still not in hand, Mr. Cappelli said last week.
"But we have two large pension funds and insurance companies right now looking at a proposal" to provide the $180 million, he added, "and we should hear back in the next two weeks."
The first Concord phase would include the construction of 525 rooms in the two sections of the hotel where the steel and concrete framework is being retained. Later phases, Mr. Cappelli said, include 1,000 rooms and a convention center in newly built structures. 
At Grossinger's, he said, the plan, in the design stage, is for a spa and golf resort. 
He attributed the financing delays to the effect of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on travel and the hotel industry. Still, he said, many people prefer to vacation closer to home these days and that should help his projects' prospects.

A Show of Confidence In a Time of Uncertainty
The promise of a rejuvenating new home has been snatched away. On Friday, its director is to depart, and no successor has been hired. Yet optimism is on display at the Museum of the City of New York.
In March, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rescinded an offer that the museum move from its outmoded quarters at Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street, above, to the historic and elegant Tweed Courthouse, behind City Hall.
Mr. Bloomberg decided to use the expensively renovated courthouse as the school system's new headquarters. The museum's longtime director, Robert R. Macdonald, resigned soon afterward, effective at the end of this week.
The museum's chairman, Newton P. S. Merrill, said last week that he was not concerned about the absence of a new director. "I'm optimistic we will have a decision within 60 days" on a successor, he said.
Of the museum's on-again, off-again merger talks with the New-York Historical Society, he said, "There are still very general discussions, nothing specific."
Still, "with or without" a merger, he said, "our focus" is a new home in Lower Manhattan.
