HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/MOVIES; 
Hannibal to Hobbits, Pinochet to Pinocchio

BYLINE:  By DAVE KEHR (Compiled with the assistance of SUZANNE O'CONNOR) 

 BODY:
 September

THE PINOCHET CASE -- Gen. Augusto Pinochet's arrest for rights abuses committed while he was the military ruler of Chile, and the effort to bring him to trial, are the subject of this documentary by Patricio Guzman, whose "Battle of Chile" was one of the most widely seen political films of the 1970's. Wednesday.

ALIAS BETTY -- From Claude Miller, a French psychological thriller about a promising young novelist (Sandrine Kiberlain) whose orderly suburban life is destroyed when her young son dies in an accident. But wait, there's more: her deeply disturbed, abusive mother (Nicole Garcia) moves in and decides that Betty needs another child to care for -- so she kidnaps one. From a novel by Ruth Rendell, "The Tree of Hands." Friday.

BARBERSHOP -- A barbershop on Chicago's South Side becomes the gathering place for an assortment of neighborhood characters, including the crusty veteran barber (Cedric the Entertainer), a self-regarding college student (Sean Patrick Thomas), an ex-con trying to stay out of trouble (Michael Ealy) and a street-smart woman (the rap star Eve) who still isn't tough enough to tell off her double-dealing boyfriend. Ice Cube is the uncertain owner, who's inherited the shaky business from his father. Directed by Tim Story. Friday.

CHILDREN OF THE CENTURY -- The tumultuous love story of two French literary icons of the early 19th century: the novelist George Sand (Juliette Binoche) and the poet Alfred de Musset (Benoit Magimel, of "The Piano Teacher"). Things fall apart in Venice, where de Musset is distracted by drugs and Sand by a handsome Italian doctor. With Stefano Dionisi and Karin Viard; Diane Kurys ("Entre Nous") directed, departing from her usual autobiographical mode. Friday.

ELVIRA'S HAUNTED HILLS -- Cassandra Peterson brings her bosomy vampire character Elvira, Mistress of the Dark, out of retirement for a horror spoof set in Translyvania. Directed by Sam Irvin, it's said to be a send-up of the Vincent Price-Edgar Allan Poe horror films of the early 60's. Friday (midnight shows only).

IGBY GOES DOWN -- Kieran Culkin is Igby Slocumb, a restless 17-year-old from a decaying patrician family. Sent to a military school by his uncomprehending parents (Bill Pullman and Susan Sarandon), he soon breaks out and makes for New York, where he finds refuge at the bachelor pad of his swinging godfather (Jeff Goldblum). He meets his godfather's clotheshorse girlfriend (Amanda Peet) and an oversophisticated young woman (Claire Danes), who teach him a few things about life. Written and directed by Burr Steers; with Jared Harris and Ryan Phillippe. Friday. A related article is on Page 33.

MAHAGONNY -- The musicologist and experimental filmmaker Harry Smith shot this avant-garde feature from 1970 to 1972, drawing on downtown friends like Patti Smith, Allen Ginsberg and Jonas Mekas to create a vision of daily life in New York City set to Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht's 1930 opera of the same name. Friday.

QUITTING -- A dramatization of the true story of the Chinese actor Jia Hongsheng, who plays himself. A rising star in Chinese television, Jia drifted into drugs and despair and was rescued when his parents (who also play themselves) arrived from the country to take care of him. Directed by Zhang Yang, who made the gentle, crowd-pleasing "Shower." Friday.

STEALING HARVARD -- After the controversial comedy "Freddy Got Fingered," the MTV comic Tom Green returns to the big screen, partnered with the affable Jason Lee in a romp about a young man who turns to crime to finance a Harvard education for his niece. With Seymour Cassel, Dennis Farina, Richard Jenkins and John C. McGinley; the director is the once and future Kid in the Hall Bruce McCulloch. Friday.

SWIMMING -- Lauren Ambrose of "Six Feet Under" plays a sexually uptight teenager working in her father's diner in Myrtle Beach, S.C. She opens up when she befriends an older, more experienced girl (Joelle Carter). Robert J. Siegel directed and co-wrote the script (with Lisa Bazadona). Friday.

TED BUNDY -- Michael Reilly Burke plays the notorious serial killer of the 1970's, who claimed to have murdered more than 35 women. Directed and co-written by Matthew Bright (a specialist in the material -- his last film was "Ed Gein," about another prolific murderer), the film is told from Bundy's point of view. Friday.

THE TRANSPORTER -- Jason Statham, one of the lads in the British crime film "Snatch," plays a mercenary hired to kidnap the daughter of a Hong Kong crime lord whose specialty is smuggling immigrants into France. The French fantasist Luc Besson ("The Fifth Element") produced and co-wrote; the director is Cory Yuen, who worked with Mr. Besson on "Kiss of the Dragon." The Hong Kong sexpot Shu Qi makes her English-language debut. Friday.

DAS EXPERIMENT -- In Oliver Hirschbiegel's German film, Moritz Bleibtreu of "Run, Lola, Run" is a journalist who infiltrates a psychological experiment. Twenty paid volunteers will be locked up in a mock prison, where each will be assigned a role either as a guard or as an inmate; their only instructions are to stay in character for two weeks while a team of psychologists observes them. That, of course, is not as easy as it sounds. A big commercial success on its home turf. Mr. Hirschbiegel is to direct the next chapter in the "Blade" series. Sept. 18.

APOLLO 13: THE IMAX EXPERIENCE -- Ron Howard's 1995 drama about the problem-plagued moon mission of 1970 has been blown up to the giant-screen Imax format, using computer technology to enhance the images. It continues to star Tom Hanks, Kevin Bacon, Bill Paxton, Gary Sinise, Ed Harris and Kathleen Quinlan; Mr. Howard directed from a screenplay by William Broyles Jr. ("Cast Away") and Al Reinert. Sept. 20.

THE BANGER SISTERS -- Bob Dolman's film follows the widely different fates of two dedicated groupies from the 1960's. One, played by Goldie Hawn, has ended up a barmaid in Los Angeles, consumed with nostalgia for her colorful past; the other, Susan Sarandon, is a social climber in Phoenix, desperate to keep her past a secret. With Geoffrey Rush as a helpful hitchhiker and Eva Amurri, Ms. Sarandon's daughter, playing one of her character's offspring. Sept. 20. A related article is on Page 33.

DON'T ASK, DON'T TELL -- A 1954 low-budget science fiction film, "Killers From Space," recut and overdubbed a la Woody Allen's "What's Up, Tiger Lily?" into a zany comedy about a race of gay men from outer space, on a mission to turn all earthlings into homosexuals. Conceived and written by Tex Hauser; directed (the new version) by Doug Miles. Sept. 20.

8 WOMEN -- Several of France's biggest female stars -- Danielle Darrieux, Catherine Deneuve, Isabelle Huppert, Emmanuelle Beart, Fanny Ardant and Virginie Ledoyen -- team up for a campy comedy by Francois Ozon ("Under the Sand"). Based on a play by Robert Thomas, the film is set in a provincial mansion in the 1950's where Ms. Deneuve's husband has been found stabbed in his bedchamber. Every woman within a five-mile radius appears to have a reason for wanting him dead. Sept. 20.

THE FOUR FEATHERS -- Another go-round for A. E. W. Mason's often-filmed tale of heroic British troops battling in the Sudan of 1898. Heath Ledger is Harry Faversham, an officer who resigns his commission and loses his honor. Branded a coward by his friends and fiancee (Kate Hudson), he goes off to the desert to redeem himself. Perhaps the director, the Indian-born Shekhar Kapur ("Elizabeth"), can bring a new perspective to the classic imperialist adventure. With Wes Bentley and Djimon Hounsou. Sept. 20. A related article is on Page 34.

HIS SECRET LIFE -- When her husband dies, an Italian housewife (Margherita Buy) is astounded to discover that he had a longtime male lover (the suddenly ubiquitous Stefano Accorsi). But instead of being outraged, she becomes a passionate defender of the lover's world of sexual outcasts. Directed by Ferzan Ozpetek, whose "Steam: the Turkish Bath" has become a gay cult favorite. Sept. 20.

INVINCIBLE -- The true story of Zesha Breitbart (Jouko Ahola), a Jewish blacksmith who billed himself as the Strongest Man in the World on Berlin's vaudeville circuit in the early 1930's. Tim Roth co-stars as a clairvoyant who becomes a favorite of Hitler. Werner Herzog, the enfant terrible of the New German Cinema of the 1970's, directs. Sept. 20.

LAWRENCE OF ARABIA -- The restoration expert Robert A. Harris produced this 70-millimeter reissue of the David Lean classic of 1962, with Peter O'Toole as the enigmatic desert warrior. Sept. 20.

SECRETARY -- One of the hits of this year's Sundance Film Festival, Steven Shainberg's dark comedy tells the story of a young woman (Maggie Gyllenhaal) just out of a psychiatric hospital who gets a job with a dominating lawyer (James Spader). Their employer-employee relationship takes on a sexual, sadomasochistic charge. With Jeremy Davies and Lesley Ann Warren; Erin Cressida Wilson wrote the script. Sept. 20.

SLAP HER . . . SHE'S FRENCH -- Jane McGregor as a popular Texas teenager who finds her social dominance threatened by a French exchange student (Piper Perabo). The actress Melanie Mayron ("Thirtysomething") directed. Sept. 20.

SNIPES -- Two Philadelphia teenagers enter a world of violence when they stumble across the aftermath of a bloody shootout in a recording studio. Rich Murray directs Sam Jones III, Nelly and Zoe Saldana. Sept. 20.

SPIRITED AWAY -- Perhaps the greatest living practitioner of traditional hand-drawn animation, Japan's Hayao Miyazaki ("Princess Mononoke") directed this story of a young girl who travels to the land of the gods in an attempt to rescue her parents, transformed into pigs by an evil wizard. The Disney company has dubbed over the Japanese soundtrack with American voices, including those of Lauren Holly, Suzanne Pleshette and John Ratzenberger, but nothing happens to his films without Mr. Miyazaki's control and consent. Domestically, it's Japan's highest-grossing film of all time at more than $200 million. Sept. 20.

TRAPPED -- When their diabetic daughter is kidnapped, a Mississippi couple (Stuart Townsend and Charlize Theron) are told not to go to the police or the girl's insulin will be withheld. Kevin Bacon and Courtney Love are the bad folk; Luis Mandoki ("Angel Eyes") directs. Sept. 20.

DAYDREAM BELIEVER -- Valerie Kempson is an aspiring actress who impulsively leaves her small Vermont hometown and moves to New York City to pursue her dream. Debra Eisenstadt directed this digital video feature. Sept. 25.

THE TRIALS OF HENRY KISSINGER -- Working from the book by Christopher Hitchens, the filmmaker Eugene Jarecki looks into Mr. Kissinger's role in Chile, Vietnam and East Timor. Witnesses include Alexander Haig, William Safire, Seymour Hersh and William Shawcross. Sept. 25.

BALLISTIC: ECKS VS. SEVER -- The unwieldy title refers to two rival government agents, Antonio Banderas and Lucy Liu, who have been assigned to kill each other but discover they share a common enemy. Is it Ray Park, the British agent on their trail? Wych Kaosayananda, a Thai director who uses the more wieldy pseudonym Kaos, is the director. Sept. 27.

BIGGIE AND TUPAC -- Nick Broomfield, the --aggressive British documentary maker behind "Kurt and Courtney" and "Heidi Fleiss: Hollywood Madam," examines the still-unsolved killings of the rappers Biggie Smalls and Tupac Shakur. Sept. 27.

CRAZY AS HELL -- Eriq La Salle of "E.R." directed this adaptation of Jeremy Leven's novel "Satan," about a new patient (Mr. La Salle) who checks into a state medical hospital claiming to be the Devil incarnate. Michael Beach is the psychiatrist who must cope not only with his troublesome new patient, but also with the continuing trauma of the deaths of his wife and child, and with a television crew, headed by John C. McGinley, that is filming him for a documentary. Sept. 27.

DARK BLUE -- This represents a departure from sports themes for the writer-director Ron Shelton ("Bull Durham"). It's a police thriller, set in the racially charged atmosphere of South Central Los Angeles just before the Rodney King beating, where a cynical veteran cop (Kurt Russell) instructs his green partner (Scott Speedman) in the ways of the street as they investigate a quadruple homicide. Sept 27.

JUST A KISS -- Part animated and part live action, Fisher Stevens's film features Taye Diggs, Ron Eldard, Kyra Sedgwick, Marley Shelton and Marisa Tomei as New Yorkers who, somehow or other, are allowed to go back in time and rectify their complicated love lives. Script by Patrick Breen. Sept. 27.

MOONLIGHT MILE -- Brad Silberling's loosely autobiographical film presents the gifted and hard-working Jake Gyllenhaal as a young man who is effectively adopted by the parents of his girlfriend, who was killed at the restaurant where she worked as a waitress. But even as he fulfills his role as a live-in memory for the grieving parents (Dustin Hoffman and Susan Sarandon), he finds himself falling in love with a bartender (Ellen Pompeo). A good cast, including Dabney Coleman, Richard T. Jones and Holly Hunter; Mr. Silberling ("Casper," "City of Angels") wrote and directed. Sept. 27. A related article is on Page 33.

SHANGHAI GHETTO -- Martin Landau narrates this documentary about European Jews who found refuge in China during World War II. The directors, Dana Janklowicz-Mann and Amir Mann, accompanied two survivors to Shanghai, where they clandestinely filmed the surviving Jewish ghetto. Sept. 27.

SKINS -- Two Lakota Sioux, played by Eric Schweig and Graham Greene, find their lives much changed when they return to the reservation after serving in Vietnam. Chris Eyre of "Smoke Signals" directed, filming on location at the Pine Ridge Reservation. With Gary Farmer. Sept. 27.

SWEET HOME ALABAMA -- The unsinkable Reese Witherspoon, as a Deep South refugee who reinvents herself as a New York socialite (anybody here seen "Breakfast at Tiffany's"?). Her dashing boyfriend (Patrick Dempsey) is the son of the mayor of New York (Candice Bergen); when he proposes, she returns home to tell her folks the good news, only to have her parade rained on by Josh Lucas, the husband she left behind. The romance specialist Andy Tennant ("Ever After") directed. Sept. 27.

THE TUXEDO -- Jackie Chan's variation on "The Sorceror's Apprentice." He's a limo driver who borrows the fancy tuxedo that belongs to his mysterious boss (Jason Isaacs), only to find that it's actually a high-tech defense system, wired with a million secret devices. Jennifer Love Hewitt is Jackie's partner and love interest; Peter Stormare, the soul legend James Brown and Ritchie Coster co-star under the first-time director Kevin Donovan. Sept. 27.

WASABI -- From the commercial side of the French cinema, here's a thriller about a Parisian police detective (Jean Reno) who is summoned to Tokyo to deal with a surprising inheritance. Directed by Gerard Krawczyk ("Taxi 2") and produced by Luc Besson. Sept. 27.

BIG SHOT'S FUNERAL -- Feng Xiaogang's comedy garnered a lot of press last year as the first Chinese film to employ major Western actors. Donald Sutherland stars as a famous American filmmaker who travels to Beijing to shoot a historical epic, but discovers that he's about to die just as the film goes into production. His crew pitches in to finance a funeral for him, slipping product endorsements from Chinese companies into his feature. With Paul Mazursky and Ge You ("To Live"). September.

October

BETWEEN STRANGERS -- Edoardo Ponti directs his mom, a certain Sophia Loren, in a three-part tale of women in Toronto (the other stars are Mira Sorvino and Deborah Kara Unger) who must face up to dark secrets in their pasts. With Gerard Depardieu and Malcolm McDowell. Oct. 4.

BLOODY SUNDAY -- The tragic events of Jan. 30, 1972, in the Northern Irish city of Derry, when a protest march led by the civil rights activist Ivan Cooper (James Nesbitt) was fired on by British paratroopers, leaving 13 dead and 14 wounded. Paul Greengrass is the writer and director. Oct. 4.

HEAVEN -- Working from a script by the Polish filmmaker Krzysztof Kieslowski and his writing partner Krzysztof Piesiewicz ("The Decalogue"), Tom Tykwer, director of "Run, Lola, Run," tells another tale of frantic flight -- that of a young Englishwoman (Cate Blanchett) accused of a terrorist act in Turin, Italy, and the young Italian policeman (Giovanni Ribisi) who is convinced of her moral innocence and helps her to escape. Oct. 4.

JONAH: A VEGGIETALES MOVIE -- The first theatrical spinoff of the popular direct-to-video series of animated films with Christian themes. Directed by Mike Nawrocki and Phil Vischer, it's a retelling of the story of Jonah and the whale, with the biblical figures played by talking vegetables. Oct. 4.

THE MAN FROM ELYSIAN FIELDS -- Andy Garcia as a failed Los Angeles novelist who moonlights as a gigolo for the Elysian Fields escort service, owned and operated by Mick Jagger's character. One of his clients (Olivia Williams) turns out to be the wife of a best-selling author (James Coburn), and some curious networking begins. Directed by George Hickenlooper, of "Hearts of Darkness: A Filmmaker's Apocalypse." Oct. 4.

PIPE DREAM -- The indie stalwart Martin Donovan as a New York City plumber who decides he'd have a better chance meeting women if he were a filmmaker. So he steals a script from a one-night stand (Mary-Louise Parker), sets himself up with a casting agent and starts auditioning actresses. With Rebecca Gayheart and Guinevere Turner; John Walsh, who made the likable "Ed's Big Move" in 1996, directed. Oct. 4.

RED DRAGON -- Hannibal Lecter, America's favorite serial killer, made his first appearance in Thomas Harris's 1981 novel "Red Dragon," which was filmed by Michael Mann in 1986 as "Manhunter," with Brian Cox in what was then a minor role. The material has been reconfigured by the screenwriter Ted Tally, who adapted Mr. Harris's "Silence of the Lambs" in 1991, and is now being presented as the "prequel" to "Silence," with Anthony Hopkins returning to his most famous role. Edward Norton is the F.B.I. profiler played by William L. Petersen in "Manhunter"; Ralph Fiennes takes over from Tom Noonan as the rival killer, Francis Dollarhyde. With Harvey Keitel, Emily Watson, Mary-Louise Parker and Philip Seymour Hoffman rounding out the cast, it arrives under the direction of Brett Ratner, of "Rush Hour" fame. Oct. 4.

TAKE CARE OF MY CAT -- The romantic and professional frustrations of five young women living in the Korean port city of Inchon, from one of the few female filmmakers working in Korea, Jae-eun Jeong. Oct. 4.

WELCOME TO COLLINWOOD -- Another remake of Mario Monicelli's great Italian comedy of 1958, "Big Deal on Madonna Street," about a bunch of bumbling small-time crooks who decide to knock over a jewelry store, with disastrous consequences. Produced by George Clooney, who makes a bit appearance as a wheelchair-bound safecracker, and featuring Jennifer Esposito, Luis Guzman, Michael Jeter, William H. Macy, Isaiah Washington, Sam Rockwell and Patricia Clarkson. Joe and Anthony Russo ("Pieces"), who are brothers, wrote and directed. Oct. 4.

WHO'S YOUR DADDY? -- Andy Frickman's teen comedy casts Brandon Davis as a high school senior whose wildest dream comes true: he inherits an adult magazine empire. Colleen Camp, Kadeem Hardison and William Atherton co-star. Oct. 4.

HOW TO DRAW A BUNNY -- A portrait of the New York artist Ray Johnson assembled through the recollections of his friends and colleagues, including Christo, Chuck Close, Roy Lichtenstein and Judith Malina. John Walter directed. Oct. 9.

BELOW -- The gifted action director David Twohy ("Pitch Black") is at the helm of this horror film about a World War II submarine that finds itself trapped between Nazi U-boats above and a big, fat, mysterious thing below. With Bruce Greenwood and Olivia Williams; Darren Aronofsky ("Requiem for a Dream") contributed to the script (and was at one point supposed to direct). Oct. 11.

BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE -- A new film from Michael Moore ("Roger and Me"), which blends social commentary with prankster comedy in his patented style. The subject this time is the American love affair with firearms, an issue Mr. Moore traces from the first colonists to the teenage boys who went on a murderous rampage in a Colorado high school. Mr. Moore pays surprise visits to the corporate headquarters of Kmart, the chain from which the Columbine boys bought their bullets, and the president of the N.R.A., Charlton Heston. Oct. 11.

BROWN SUGAR -- Taye Diggs is an executive at a hip-hop record company; Sanaa Lathan is a magazine editor who was his childhood pal. But now that they're grown-ups, can they remain friends or will that "When Harry Met Sally" thing happen? Directed by Rick Famuyiwa; with Queen Latifah and Mos Def. Oct. 11.

THE DEBUT -- The Americanized son (Dante Basco) of a proud Filipino immigrant (Tirso Cruz) comes into conflict with his father over his sister's elaborate 18th-birthday party. Gene Cajayon directed. Oct. 11.

FAMILY FUNDAMENTALS -- A documentary by Arthur Dong ("Coming Out Under Fire") about the tensions that arise in three fundamentalist Christian families with gay members. Oct. 11.

THE GREY ZONE -- Tim Blake Nelson directs his own play about the Jewish prisoners forced to man the crematoriums at Auschwitz. With Harvey Keitel, David Arquette, Natasha Lyonne, Mira Sorvino, Steve Buscemi and Henry Stram. Oct. 11.

KNOCKAROUND GUYS -- The screenwriters Brian Koppelman and David Levien ("The Rounders") move into directing with the tale of four Mafia brothers (Vin Diesel, Seth Green, Barry Pepper and Andrew Davoli -- surely one of them must have been adopted) who are sent by their capo dad (Dennis Hopper) to pay off a corrupt sheriff in Montana. This one has been sitting on the shelf for a while, but now that Mr. Diesel ("XXX") is red hot, here it is. Oct. 11.

ON GUARD! -- From the French veteran Philippe de Broca ("King of Hearts"), an 18th-century swashbuckler about a physically challenged swordsman (Daniel Auteuil) out to revenge the murder of his aristocratic best friend (Vincent Perez). Oct. 11.

POKEMON 4EVER -- The Pokemon franchise moves over to Miramax for the fourth feature film drawn from the popular children's characters. A new creature -- Celebi, "the voice of the forest" -- makes its appearance in this outing, alongside the venerable Pikachu. Directed by Kunihiko Yuyama and Michael Haigney. Oct. 11.

PUNCH-DRUNK LOVE -- Paul Thomas Anderson steps back from the epic visions of "Boogie Nights" and "Magnolia" to fashion a comic miniature about a gentle but hot-tempered Los Angeles businessman (Adam Sandler) who impulsively follows the woman of his dreams (Emily Watson) to Hawaii. With Luis Guzman and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Oct. 11.

THE RULES OF ATTRACTION -- Bret Easton Ellis's novel of sex, drugs and moral blindness at a small New England college in the 1980's gets a high-octane adaptation by the writer-director Roger Avary ("Killing Zoe"). With James Van Der Beek as Sean Bateman (younger brother of Patrick Bateman from "American Psycho") and Shannyn Sossamon, Ian Somerhalder and Jessica Biel. Oct. 11. A related article is on Page 34.

SWEPT AWAY -- Lina Wertmuller's 1975 Italian sex comedy, about a randy communist sailor stuck on a desert island with a frigid rich woman, reimagined by the director Guy Ritchie as a vehicle for his struggling actress wife, Madonna. Adriano Giannini plays the sailor; his dad, Giancarlo, starred in the original. Oct. 11. A related article is on Page 31.

TUCK EVERLASTING -- A teenager (Alexis Bledel) finds that the Fountain of Youth is located in the backyard of her eccentric next-door neighbors, the Tucks (William Hurt and Sissy Spacek). It's a Disney film, so we can assume some significant life lessons are learned. Directed by Jay Russell, of "My Dog Skip." Oct. 11.

WHITE OLEANDER -- After her mother (Michelle Pfeiffer) goes to prison for murder (committed with a dose of the poisonous flower of the title), little Astrid Magnussen (Alison Lohman) embarks on a journey from foster home to foster home. Peter Kosminsky directs; with Renee Zellweger, Robin Wright Penn, Billy Connolly, Patrick Fugit and Noah Wyle. Oct. 11. A related article is on Page 33.

ABANDON -- Stephen Gaghan, who wrote the Oscar-winning screenplay for "Traffic," directs his first feature, an adaptation of Sean Desmond's novel "Adam's Fall." Katie Holmes is a college student traumatized by the disappearance of her boyfriend; Benjamin Bratt is the police detective, and recovering alcoholic, who discovers some disturbing new leads in the case. Oct. 18. A related article is on Page 43.

AUTO FOCUS -- The unsavory life and untimely death of the television star Bob Crane, who used his "Hogan's Heroes" celebrity to seduce hundreds of women, recording his encounters with an early home video camera. Greg Kinnear is Crane; Willem Dafoe is Crane's technical adviser and sidekick, Johnny Carpenter. Paul Schrader directed, in what amounts to a blackly comic variation on his 1997 "Affliction." With Rita Wilson, Maria Bello, Ron Leibman, and Kurt Fuller as Werner Klemperer. Oct. 18.

THE BUSINESS OF FANCYDANCING -- Two American Indian boys, the best of friends during high school on the reservation, find their paths separating when they leave for college in Seattle. One becomes a gay poet, the other an embittered activist. With Evan Adams and Gene Tagaban; Sherman Alexie directed from his own short story. Oct. 18.

FIDEL -- Fidel Castro reflects on his 40 years in power in interviews conducted by the director Estela Bravo, an American who lives in Havana. Oct. 18.

FORMULA 51 -- Released in England last year under the self-deprecating title "The 51st State," this British neo-noir imagines Samuel L. Jackson as a kilt-wearing drug chemist who comes to Liverpool to play golf and make a $20 million deal with the local mafia. But his American master, Meat Loaf, doesn't like the idea and sends a hit lady (Emily Mortimer) to take him down. With Robert Carlyle, Sean Pertwee and Rhys Ifans. Ronny Yu directed. Oct. 18.

HANSEL AND GRETEL -- A new treatment of the Brothers Grimm fairy tale, with Delta Burke as the evil stepmother who hopes to rid herself of the title children by luring them into a dark and menacing forest. A cameo-heavy cast includes Howie Mandel, Bobcat Goldthwait, Tom Arnold, Sinbad and Lynn Redgrave; directed by Gary Tunnicliffe. Oct. 18.

HUSH! -- From Japan, a comedy about a young woman who wants a baby and hires a gay man to help her out. Ryosuke Hashiguchi directed. Oct. 18.

LOVE IN THE TIME OF MONEY -- Just as every generation requires its own remake of "Big Deal on Madonna Street" (see "Welcome to Collinwood," above), here is the inevitable update of Arthur Schnitzler's bittersweet Austrian play "La Ronde." This time, the chain of lovers includes Steve Buscemi, Rosario Dawson, Adrian Grenier, Michael Imperioli, Carol Kane and Jill Hennessy; Peter Mattei adapted and directed. Oct. 18.

NAQOYQATSI -- The filmmaker Godfrey Reggio and the composer Philip Glass, who collaborated on the New Age documentaries "Koyaanisqatsi" (1983) and "Powaqqatsi" (1988), continue their wordless examination of the world's ills with this blaze of digitally enhanced images, subtitled "Life as War." Oct. 18.

REAL WOMEN HAVE CURVES -- An East Los Angeles teenager, Ana Garcia (America Ferrera), learns about life during a summer spent working with her mother in a garment factory. Though she's been offered a full scholarship to Columbia University, her family is too dependent on her income to let her go. Patricia Cardoso directed; it's her first feature. Oct. 18.

THE RING -- Gore Verbinski ("The Mexican") directs the Hollywood remake of Hideo Nakata's 1998 Japanese horror film, a cult hit throughout Asia. The mystery centers on a short, enigmatic videotape, which causes everyone who watches it to die. Naomi Watts, Chris Cooper and Brian Cox star. Oct. 18.

THE RISING PLACE -- An interracial friendship between two young women (Laurel Holloman and Elise Neal) causes talk in a small Mississippi Delta town in the early 1940's -- and more when one of them becomes pregnant by a soldier. Tom Rice wrote, directed and produced. Oct 18.

RUSSIAN ARK -- Alexander Sokurov's film covers 200 years of Russian history in a single 90-minute take, as his camera drifts through the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, moving in and out of elaborately staged historical tableaux. Oct. 18.

SAFE CONDUCT -- Bertrand Tavernier's film, set during the German occupation of France, is based on the experiences of the screenwriter Jean Aurenche (Denis Podalydes) and the assistant director Jean Devaivre (Jacques Gamblin) as they struggle to balance their filmmaking ambitions with underground activity. Oct. 18.

TEKNOLUST -- Lynn Hershman-Leeson, who wrote and directed the feminist science-fiction film "Conceiving Ada," returns to the genre with the satirical story of a geneticist (Tilda Swinton) who creates three female clones, only to discover that they need male fluids to survive. Jeremy Davies, James Urbaniak and Karen Black co-star. Oct. 18.

THE TRUTH ABOUT TULLY -- Afraid of turning into his emotionally isolated father (Bob Burrus), young Tully Coates (Anson Mount) becomes a compulsive womanizer -- until he meets the strong-willed Ella (Julianne Nicholson). A first feature from Hilary Birmingham. Oct 18.

DERRIDA -- Kirby Dick, the documentarian who brought you "Sick: The Life and Death of Bob Flanagan, Supermasochist," returns with a profile of the French philosopher Jacques Derrida, one of the founding figures of postmodernism. Oct. 23.

GHOST SHIP -- Steve Beck, who directed the remake of "13 Ghosts," returns to the horror genre with the story of a mysterious ocean liner, missing since 1953, that turns up in the Bering Sea. With Julianna Margulies, Gabriel Byrne, Ron Eldard and Isaiah Washington. Oct. 23.

ALL OR NOTHING -- A British ensemble drama from Mike Leigh ("Secrets and Lies") set in the drab poured-concrete confines of a London housing project. Timothy Spall plays a downtrodden taxi driver; Lesley Manville is his wife, a supermarket checkout clerk, and their disaffected kids are played by Alison Garland and James Corden. Their lives plod along, until one day a tragic event changes everything. Oct. 25.

ALL THE QUEEN'S MEN -- Possibly the world's first transvestite heist movie. Matt LeBlanc stars as an American O.S.S. agent who, with the help of some British colleagues, must infiltrate the Berlin factory where the Nazis manufacture the Enigma coding device -- and where all the workers are female. Eddie Izzard is a professional tranny who offers the men some tips. Stefan Ruzowitzky, a talented Austrian filmmaker ("The Inheritors"), directs. Oct. 25.

FRIDA -- The life and times of the Mexican painter and feminist icon Frida Kahlo, as portrayed by Salma Hayek. Julie Taymor ("Titus") directed this wide-ranging film, which documents Kahlo's stormy but resilient relationship with the muralist Diego Rivera (Alfred Molina), her fling with Leon Trotsky (Geoffrey Rush) and her lifelong struggle to paint despite her severe physical handicaps. Edward Norton pops in as Nelson Rockefeller; Antonio Banderas, Ashley Judd and Roger Rees are also in the cast. Oct. 25. A related article is on Page 41.

JACKASS: THE MOVIE -- Johnny Knoxville brings his MTV series -- in which he attempts absurd and/or dangerous stunts -- to the big screen. Jeff Tremaine, a co-creator and director of the television version, returns to the big chair. With Henry Rollins, Tony Hawk and the director Spike Jonze (an early contributor to Mr. Knoxville's legend). Oct. 25.

PAID IN FULL -- A fateful delivery to a gangster's moll leads a dry-cleaning clerk (Wood Harris) into the dangerous world of drug dealing in 1980's Harlem. Mekhi Phifer and Kevin Carroll play Mr. Harris's best friends; Charles Stone directed. Oct. 25.

ROGER DODGER -- A womanizing Manhattan advertising executive, played by Campbell Scott, takes his naive Midwestern nephew (Jesse Eisenberg) under his wing, intending to teach him a few things about life. But, in a reversal that strongly suggests "Come Blow Your Horn," the exec ends up learning more from the boy. With Isabella Rossellini, Elizabeth Berkley and Jennifer Beals. The newcomer Dylan Kidd wrote and directed. Oct. 25.

THE TRUTH ABOUT CHARLIE -- Stanley Donen's 1963 thriller, "Charade," is the basis for Jonathan Demme's new film, which stars Thandie Newton in the Audrey Hepburn role as a woman who finds her husband mysteriously murdered. Mark Wahlberg fills in for Cary Grant as the enigmatic maybe-cop, maybe-crook who comes to Ms. Newton's aid when three of her husband's underworld cronies come after her in Paris. The evil three are played by Joong-Hoon Park, Ted Levine and Lisa Gay Hamilton; Christine Boisson is the French police inspector assigned to the case and Tim Robbins is the United States embassy official who provides some ambiguous assistance. Oct. 25.

WAKING UP IN RENO -- Jordan Brady's blue-collar sex comedy finds two Arkansas couples (Patrick Swayze and Charlize Theron, Billy Bob Thornton and Natasha Richardson) sharing an S.U.V. on their way to a monster truck rally in Reno. All goes well until Mr. Thornton's character yields to temptation with Ms. Theron's. Oct. 25.

COMEDIAN -- Jerry Seinfeld on the big screen in a revealing documentary as he hits the road, making his return to the world of stand-up comedy. October.

November

THE CORE -- Aaron Eckhart is a geophysicist who leads a team of "terranauts" deep into the earth's core, in an attempt to correct a temperature shift that threatens to knock the earth out of orbit. Hilary Swank is the captain of the "deep earth" ship provided by NASA; the crew -- you can bet there's a traitor among them -- consists of Bruce Greenwood, Richard Jenkins, Tcheky Karyo, Alfre Woodard and Stanley Tucci. Jon Amiel, a reliable Briton ("Copycat"), directed. Nov. 1.

FAR FROM HEAVEN -- Set in suburban Connecticut in 1957, Todd Haynes's film is an homage to Douglas Sirk's pointed 1950's melodramas. Julianne Moore is the happy homemaker whose world is turned upside down when she discovers that her husband (Dennis Quaid) has been keeping a big secret from her. With Dennis Haysbert, as the gardener to whom Ms. Moore turns for comfort. Nov. 1.

I SPY -- The 1965-68 series that helped break the color bar on network television -- with Robert Culp and Bill Cosby as globe-trotting C.I.A. agents -- is reimagined by the director Betty Thomas, who previously rehabbed "The Brady Bunch." Now it's Owen Wilson as an agent who recruits a celebrated boxer (Eddie Murphy) to help him recover a stolen fighter plane. Malcolm McDowell and Famke Janssen provide the villainy. Nov. 1.

THE SANTA CLAUSE 2 -- Tim Allen returns for a sequel to his 1994 family hit, about a suburban dad recruited to be the new Santa Claus. With Elizabeth Mitchell, Wendy Crewson, Judge Reinhold and Molly Shannon; the television veteran Michael Lembeck directs. At the moment, there are six credited screenwriters. Nov. 1.

THE WEIGHT OF WATER -- A reporter (Catherine McCormack) becomes fascinated by the tale of two Scandinavian immigrants murdered on a desolate North Atlantic island. With her husband (Sean Penn), her brother-in-law (Josh Lucas) and his overheated girlfriend (Elizabeth Hurley), she takes a voyage to the murder scene, and discovers -- as the past begins to echo in the present -- that there are more secrets than she ever imagined. Sarah Polley, Katrin Cartlidge and Ciaran Hinds are among the islanders appearing in flashbacks. Directed by Kathryn Bigelow ("K-19: The Widowmaker"). Nov. 1.

STRANGE FRUIT -- Joel Katz's documentary tells the history of the title song, a work of social protest recorded, most famously, by Billie Holiday but written by Abel Meeropol, a public school teacher from the Bronx who, under the name Lewis Allan, composed socially conscious operas. Nov. 6.

BLUE CAR -- This American indie is the first film by the writer-director Karen Moncrieff. Agnes Bruckner plays a vulnerable 18-year-old whose relationship with her English teacher (David Strathairn) begins as solace but develops into something more dangerous. Margaret Colin and Frances Fisher star. Nov. 8.

8 MILE -- The title of Curtis Hanson's film refers to the street -- Eight Mile Road -- that separates economically devastated Detroit from its prosperous suburbs. The rapper Eminem makes his movie debut in a story loosely based on his own experiences growing up on Motown's mean streets. Kim Basinger (an Oscar winner for Mr. Hanson's "L.A. Confidential") co-stars as the Eminem character's mom; with Brittany Murphy, Mekhi Phifer and Taryn Manning. Nov. 8.

ETOILES: DANCERS OF THE PARIS BALLET -- Nils Tavernier, son of the French filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier, filmed this documentary on the junior dancers of the famed Paris Opera Ballet. Nov. 8.

FEMME FATALE -- From his new home base in Paris, Brian De Palma presents a thriller centered on a mysterious and frequently undressed woman (Rebecca Romijn-Stamos) whose marriage to the American ambassador to France is threatened when a freelance photographer (Antonio Banderas) discovers her criminal past. Nov. 8

GOD IS GREAT, I'M NOT -- Audrey Tautou ("Amelie") is back, as a fashion model on a spiritual quest. She falls in love with Francois (Edward Baer), a secular Jew who resents her attempts to reawaken his religious feelings. Pascale Bailly directed; in French. Nov. 8.

LAWLESS HEART -- Three love stories, set around a funeral in a small English town. Josephine Butler, Clementine Celarie and David Coffey star; this British production was directed by Tom Hunsinger and Neil Hunter. Nov. 8.

NO NEWS FROM GOD -- An angel (Victoria Abril) and a devil (Penelope Cruz) struggle for the soul of a professional boxer in this comedy from Spain, directed and written by Agustin Diaz Yanes. Nov. 8.

ARARAT -- From Canada, Atom Egoyan examines the continuing effects of the mass killings of Armenians by Turkish forces during World War I on a group of contemporary characters, including a French film director (Charles Aznavour) making a fictional film on the subject, an academic of Armenian heritage (Arsinee Khanjian) and her son, and a customs official (Christopher Plummer) who is unable to accept his son's homosexuality. With Eric Bogosian and Brent Carver. Nov. 15.

THE GUEST -- Ashton Kutcher of "That 70's Show" as an eager young man whose boss asks him to house-sit; for Mr. Kutcher, it's a chance to get close to his boss's daughter (Tara Reid), long the object of his desire. With Molly Shannon and Andy Richter; David Zucker directs. Nov. 15.

HALF PAST DEAD -- Can an undercover F.B.I. agent (Steven Seagal) stop a criminal genius (Morris Chestnut) before he breaks into (yes, into) the newly refurbished Alcatraz prison, where he hopes to persuade a condemned man to tell him where $200 million in gold is hidden? Directed by Don Michael Paul. Nov. 15.

HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS -- Daniel Radcliffe returns as the apprentice sorcerer for Chris Columbus's adaptation of the second installment of the wildly popular children's book series. Most of the cast of the first episode is back -- including Sean Biggerstaff, Robbie Coltrane, Rupert Grint, Richard Harris and Alan Rickman; newcomers include Kenneth Branagh as Gilderoy Lockhart and Jason Isaacs as Lucas Malfoy. Script, once again, by Ron Kloves. Nov. 15.

HELL HOUSE -- George Ratliff's documentary takes us inside the fright houses created by fundamentalist Christians in the South, filled with modern day horrors like AIDS and abortions. Nov. 15.

PHONE BOOTH -- The 70's horror ace Larry Cohen ("It's Alive!") returns with his original screenplay about a New York publicist who impulsively answers a pay phone, only to find that he's pinned down by a sniper (Ron Eldard) who tells him he'll shoot if he tries to leave the booth. Colin Farrell plays the lead, under his "Tigerland" director Joel Schumacher. With Katie Holmes, Ray Liotta and Radha Mitchell. Nov. 15.

STANDING IN THE SHADOWS OF MOTOWN -- Paul Justman's documentary recounts the history of Motown Records, home of the Supremes, Marvin Gaye, Stevie Wonder and many other soul music superstars, from the point of view of the Funk Brothers, the back-up singers who appeared on many of Motown's hits. Nov. 15.

THE BURNING WALL -- An oral history of East Germany, related by some of those who participated in the state's psychological warfare against its citizens and some others who were on the receiving end. Hava Kohav Beller directed. Nov. 20.

DIE ANOTHER DAY -- Halle Berry becomes the first Oscar-winning actress to play a Bond girl in this latest installment of the granddaddy of all franchises. (Kim Basinger won a supporting-actress Oscar 15 years after she appeared in "Never Say Never Again" in 1983.) Pierce Brosnan returns as James Bond, this time in globe-hopping pursuit of an archvillain played by Toby Stephens, who, living in an ice castle near the North Pole, has come up with yet another plan for world domination. The director is the talented New Zealander Lee Tamahori ("Once Were Warriors"); the supporting cast includes Judi Dench as M and John Cleese as Q. Nov. 22.

THE EMPEROR'S CLUB -- A beloved classics professor at an exclusive East Coast prep school, Mr. Hundert (Kevin Kline), finds himself challenged by a charismatic, undisciplined rich boy (Emile Hirsch), who threatens to steal his students' loyalty. Michael Hoffman ("One Fine Day") directed Neil Tolkin's adaptation of Ethan Canin's short story "The Palace Thief." With Embeth Davidtz, Roger Rees and Harris Yulin. Nov. 22. A related article is on Page 41.

THE FRIDAY AFTER NEXT -- The "Friday" series of urban comedies continues, with Ice Cube and Mike Epps back as the hapless buddies. This time, they're security guards faced with a burglar who steals Christmas presents disguised in a Santa Claus suit. Directed by Marcus Raboy. Nov. 22.

PERSONAL VELOCITY -- Three intertwining tales of young women, adapted by Rebecca Miller from her book of short stories. Kyra Sedgwick is a young mother in upstate New York who, after suffering for 12 years in an abusive relationship, takes a dramatic step to break free; Parker Posey is a cookbook editor divided between her unfulfilling career and her unsatisfying marriage; and Fairuza Balk is an accident victim who has a visionary experience. With Wallace Shawn, Ron Leibman and David Patrick Kelly. Nov. 22.

TALK TO HER -- From the Spanish director Pedro Almodovar ("All About My Mother"), the story of a reporter (Dario Grandinetti) and a nurse (Javier Camara) who develop a deep friendship when they discover they are both in love with women in comas -- the journalist with a bullfighter (Rosario Flores), the nurse with a dancer (Leonor Watling). Full of Almodovarian surprises, including a silent movie interlude. Nov. 22.

VERONICA GUERIN -- The story of the Irish journalist Veronica Guerin (Cate Blanchett), who was killed in 1996, apparently in retaliation for a series of articles about Dublin's drug dealers. The hard-working Joel Schumacher (see "Phone Booth," above) directed this adaptation of a 1996 GQ article; with Colin Farrell, Ciaran Hinds and Brenda Fricker. Nov. 22.

ADAM SANDLER'S EIGHT CRAZY NIGHTS -- Mr. Sandler assumes animated form in this cartoon feature directed by Seth Kearsley. Featuring an "expanded edition" of Mr. Sandler's "Chanukah Song," it's an inspirational holiday tale of a dissolute young man who is offered a choice between going to jail and coaching a youth basketball team. Also, it's got burping. With the voices of Jackie Titone, Austin Stout, Kevin Nealon, Rob Schneider and Jon Lovitz. Nov. 27.

SOLARIS -- The unlikely alliance of Steven Soderbergh ("Ocean's Eleven") and James Cameron ("Titanic") is behind this ambitious remake of Andrei Tarkovsky's enigmatic 1979 classic of Russian science fiction. George Clooney plays a psychiatrist sent into space to investigate the disappearance of the crew of the space station Prometheus. On his arrival, he enters a world that mingles dream and reality, the dead with the living. With Natascha McElhone and Jeremy Davies. Nov. 27.

TREASURE PLANET -- The trailer suggests an unusual combination of old-fashioned hand animation and 3-D computer graphics, laid over an updated version of "Treasure Island," shifted to a distant planet and equipped with a skateboarding hero. Ron Clements and John Musker, the team behind "Aladdin" and "Hercules," directed; voices include those of Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Brian Murray, David Hyde Pierce, Martin Short and Emma Thompson. Nov. 27.

RABBIT-PROOF FENCE -- Between 1905 and 1971, the Australian government carried out a policy of taking Aboriginal children from their families in the outback and sending them to cities to be trained as servants. Philip Noyce's film is based on the true story of three girls who attempted to escape. Nov. 29.

UNTITLED JIM SHERIDAN PROJECT -- The studio is still making up its mind, but the writer-director Jim Sheridan ("My Left Foot") has called it "East of Harlem." It tells of an Irish family, headed by Samantha Morton and Paddy Considine, trying to find a foothold in New York City --without papers. They move into a racially mixed building in Harlem. Nov. 29.

EXTREME OPS -- Another extreme-sports-loving hero, following in the great tradition of "XXX." Here we've got Devon Sawa as a snowboarder who, while filming a commercial in the Austrian Alps, stumbles into the lair of a Serbian war criminal (Klaus Lowitsch, a former member of the Rainer Werner Fassbinder stock company). Christian Duguay, of "The Art of War," directed. November.

INTERSTATE 60 -- Bob Gale, who was Robert Zemeckis's longtime writing partner ("Back to the Future," "Used Cars"), makes his first film as a director. It sounds ambitious: a young man embarks on a journey along the title highway -- a highway, he soon discovers, that does not in fact exist. With James Marsden, Gary Oldman, Kurt Russell, Michael J. Fox and Chris Cooper. November.

MORVERN CALLAR -- From the gifted young Scottish filmmaker Lynne Ramsay ("Ratcatcher"). The title character, played by Samantha Morton, is a check-out clerk who finds the illusion of freedom while vacationing in Spain. November.

REVOLUTION NO. 9 -- Led by schizophrenia to believe that a television director (Spalding Gray) is trying to control his life, a young New Yorker (Michael Risley) poses as a journalist to get close to him. Adrienne Shelly is the troubled young man's girlfriend; Tim McCann ("Desolation Angels") directs. November.

December

MASSOUD, THE AFGHAN -- The assassination of Ahmed Shah Massoud, the leader of Afghanistan's Northern Alliance, at the hands of agents of Osama bin Laden is the subject of an investigative documentary by Christophe de Ponfilly. Dec. 4.

ADAPTATION -- Impossible to summarize, which seems to be the point of this wild comedy from the screenwriter Charlie Kaufman and the director Spike Jonze, the men behind "Being John Malkovich." Nicolas Cage stars as a screenwriter named Charlie Kaufman who is struggling to adapt the Susan Orlean book "The Orchid Thief" -- which itself forms a film within the film, or something, starring Chris Cooper as a plant dealer with a scheme to peddle cloned orchids to collectors. With Meryl Streep, Catherine Keener, Tilda Swinton and Jane Adams. Dec. 6.

ANALYZE THAT -- Harold Ramis's sequel to his 1999 hit "Analyze This," about a Mafia don (Robert De Niro) and his cringing psychiatrist (Billy Crystal); it opens with the De Niro character getting out of jail and seeking gainful employment as a gangland commentator for television. Mr. Crystal, meanwhile, has inherited his father's practice and is up to his neck in unwanted responsibilities. Cathy Moriarty plays a rival mobster (mobstress?) looking to take over Mr. De Niro's turf. Dec. 6.

BLACKBOARDS -- A teacher tries to bring the gift of reading and writing to a group of young Kurds, but they have no time for him. Samira Makhmalbaf directed this allegorical drama, a follow-up to her warmly received debut film "The Apple." Dec. 6.

EQUILIBRIUM -- Set in a future world where all emotions have been deadened by antidepressant drugs and a ban on all art, Kurt Wimmer's thriller casts Christian Bale as a government official who begins to question the system when he falls off his medication. Emily Watson co-stars, with Taye Diggs and William Fichtner. Dec. 6.

EVELYN -- Stepping back from James Bond, Pierce Brosnan plays a single dad in 1953 Ireland whose children are taken away and placed in orphanages. With the help of friends and family, he goes to court to win them back, challenging both the Irish state and the Roman Catholic Church. Bruce Beresford ("Driving Miss Daisy") directed; the cast includes Aidan Quinn, Julianna Margulies, John Lynch, Stephen Rea and Alan Bates. Dec. 6.

TOOTH FAIRY: FEAR OF THE DARK -- When an evil force invades a small town, only the local outcast (Chaney Kley) can save the citizenry. Filmed in Australia by the director Jonathan Liebesman. Dec. 6.

MAID IN MANHATTAN -- Jennifer Lopez as a housekeeper in a four-star hotel who meets and falls in love with a Kennedyesque politician (Ralph Fiennes). He thinks she's from a wealthy family, an impression she's reluctant to shatter but knows she must. John Hughes wrote it, Wayne Wang directed it. Dec. 13.

SHANGHAI KNIGHTS -- Jackie Chan and Owen Wilson return in a sequel to "Shanghai Noon," as, respectively, a Chinese martial artist and a Western gunslinger. When Mr. Chan's father is killed by a Chinese revolutionary, he and Mr. Wilson take a slow boat to London, where they team up with Mr. Chan's long-lost sister (Fann Wong) to take revenge. David Dobkin ("Clay Pigeons") directs. Dec. 13.

STAR TREK: NEMESIS -- Patrick Stewart leads much of the cast of "Star Trek: The Next Generation" on the latest excursion for this venerable franchise. They're off for the planet Romulus, where, instead of a peace conference with the traditionally hostile Romulans, they find a new threat to Earth's survival. With Brent Spiner, LeVar Burton, Jonathan Frakes, Whoopi Goldberg and Ron Perlman; Stuart Baird directs. Dec. 13.

DEVILS ON THE DOORSTEP -- Re-edited since its quiet reception at Cannes in 2000, Jiang Wen's historical drama takes place during the Japanese occupation of China. Two anti-Japanese freedom fighters are arrested and turned over to a provincial authority who has no idea what to do with them. Only one man in the village can translate: a collaborator who sees in this opportunity his chance for salvation. Dec. 18.

THE LORD OF THE RINGS: THE TWO TOWERS -- The perilous second installment of the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy, as directed by Peter Jackson and written by Mr. Jackson, Frances Walsh, Philippa Boyens and Stephen Sinclair. Ian McKellen returns as the wizard Gandalf (who gets to morph into Gandalf the White, a ferocious warrior, in this installment) and Elijah Wood stays on as Frodo. Among the new characters are Grima (Brad Dourif), Eowyn (Miranda Otto) and Gollum (Andy Serkis). Dec. 18.

THE ANTWONE FISHER STORY -- Denzel Washington directed and stars as a Navy psychiatrist who helps a young sailor, Antwone Fisher (Derek Luke), cope with his troubled childhood. A true story, one assumes, since Mr. Fisher is also listed as the film's producer. Dec. 20.

NARC -- Joe Carnahan's police drama had its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival. A maverick Detroit narcotics detective, Nick Tellis (Jason Patric), has been put on probation following an incident in which a baby was killed. But when an undercover cop is murdered, Nick is put back on the street to investigate, working with the dead cop's ex-partner (Ray Liotta). Dec. 20.

TWO WEEKS NOTICE -- Hugh Grant, as a billionaire C.E.O. who is just too distracted and Hugh Grantish to notice that his chief counsel, played by Sandra Bullock, is his perfect mate -- until she threatens to leave for another company, and hires her own predatory replacement (Alicia Witt). Written and directed by Marc Lawrence (the writer of "Forces of Nature"). Dec. 20.

THE WILD THORNBERRYS -- The big-screen debut of yet another Nickelodeon cartoon series, about an American family that travels the world making nature documentaries. Daughter Eliza (voiced by Lacey Chabert) can talk to animals, but can't reveal her secret -- even when she discovers that poachers are about to massacre a herd of African elephants. Jeff McGrath and Cathy Malkasian, both veterans of the television version, directed. Dec. 20.

ABOUT SCHMIDT -- Jack Nicholson in a rare nonsmirking role as a Midwestern insurance executive whose life falls apart after his retirement and the death of his wife. He plans to spend some time getting to know his estranged daughter (Hope Davis), but she's both too busy, with her impending marriage to Dermot Mulroney, and too angry to grant him the forgiveness he seeks. A rich, finely observed, uncondescending social drama from Alexander Payne ("Election"). Dec. 25.

CATCH ME IF YOU CAN -- There are no flies on Steven Spielberg these days: after opening "Minority Report" this summer, he's back for the December holidays with the true story of Frank W. Abagnale (played by Leonardo DiCaprio), a young man who successfully assumed a series of false identities -- a doctor, a pilot, an assistant attorney general -- in the 1960's. Tom Hanks plays the F.B.I. agent on his trail. With Martin Sheen and Christopher Walken. Dec. 25. A related article is on Page 64.

GANGS OF NEW YORK -- Probably the year's most anticipated film, Martin Scorsese's epic vision of early New York stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Amsterdam Vallon, an Irish immigrant who, as a boy, saw his father murdered by Bill the Butcher (Daniel Day-Lewis), the vicious leader of the Native Americans, an anti-immigrant gang that controlled the notorious Five Points district of Lower Manhattan. Amsterdam's quest for revenge leads him into a rival gang, the Dead Rabbits, and into the arms of a streetwise pickpocket (Cameron Diaz). The climax comes during the 1863 draft riots, one of the bloodiest episodes in the city's history. With John C. Reilly, Henry Thomas and Jim Broadbent. Dec. 25. A related article is on Page 34.

THE LION KING -- You'll be stuck with "Hakuna Matata" in your head all over again as Disney reissues its 1994 coming-of-age-in-the-African-veldt animated feature in the gargantuan glory of Imax. Directed by Roger Allers and Rob Minkoff. Dec. 25.

PINOCCHIO -- Not the animated Disney perennial, but a new live-action adaptation of the Carlo Collodi novel directed by and starring the Italian imp Roberto Benigni -- who might strike some observers as a little long in the tooth to be playing the long-nosed wooden boy, but hey, that's what digital effects are for. Nicoletta Braschi, Mr. Benigni's longtime companion and his "Principessa" in "Life Is Beautiful," lends her fine features to the Blue Fairy; the veteran Italian actor Carlo Giuffre is Geppetto. Dec. 25.

SPIDER -- The horrible drabness of postwar England figures heavily in David Cronenberg's psychological thriller, adapted from a novel by Patrick McGrath. Ralph Fiennes is the title character, a man freshly released from a mental institution and plagued by involuntary memories of his traumatic childhood. With (in flashback) Gabriel Byrne as Spider's abusive father and Miranda Richardson as his long-suffering mother. Dec. 25.

THE 25TH HOUR -- Spike Lee tells the story of an Irish-American drug dealer (Edward Norton) and his attempt to patch things up with his father, a fireman (Brian Cox), in the days before he starts a seven-year prison term. With Barry Pepper and Philip Seymour Hoffman; the script is by David Benioff, from his novel. Dec. 25.

CHICAGO -- The Kander and Ebb hit musical finally arrives on screen, under the direction of Rob Marshall (who shot the television adaptation of "Annie") and with a script by Bill Condon ("Gods and Monsters"). Catherine Zeta-Jones plays Velma, the nightclub star imprisoned for killing her unfaithful husband; Renee Zellweger is Roxie Hart, the small-town innocent who also ends up in prison, for dispatching her abusive boyfriend. They share a slick lawyer (Richard Gere) but little else as they compete for the heart and attention of the city through its tabloids. Queen Latifah, Lucy Liu, John C. Reilly and Christine Baranski round out the cast. Dec. 27. A related article is on Page 43.

CONFESSIONS OF A DANGEROUS MIND -- Chuck Barris's "unauthorized autobiography" reaches the screen as directed by George Clooney (yes, the actor) from a script by Charlie Kaufman, of "Being John Malkovich" fame. Sam Rockwell stars as Mr. Barris, a celebrated game show producer ("The Dating Game") and host ("The Gong Show") who, it says here, was recruited by the C.I.A. to become a hit man. With Drew Barrymore, Julia Roberts, Fred Savage and cameos from Matt Damon, Brad Pitt and Mr. Barris himself. Dec. 27.

A FEW GOOD YEARS -- Three generations of a prosperous New York family, the Grombergs, portrayed by three generations of a prosperous Hollywood family, the Douglases (Kirk, Michael and one of Michael's sons, Cameron). The eldest Gromberg is struggling with the specter of his impending death, the youngest with a debilitating drug problem, while the middle Gromberg tries to hold the cantankerous clan together. With Rory Culkin and Bernadette Peters; Fred Schepisi directed this comedy-drama from Jesse Wigutow's script. Dec. 27.

THE HOURS -- Three intertwining tales: Virginia Woolf (Nicole Kidman) struggles with her writing and thinks about killing herself; a Los Angeles housewife (Julianne Moore) in 1950 feels dissatisfied with her middle-class existence; and a Greenwich Village intellectual (Meryl Streep) cares for a difficult friend, an angry artist (Ed Harris) with AIDS. With Toni Collette, Allison Janney, John C. Reilly, Eileen Atkins, Stephen Dillane and Claire Danes; the director is Stephen Daldry, of "Billy Elliot." Dec. 27.

LOVE LIZA -- A Web site designer, Philip Seymour Hoffman, falls into a tailspin following the death of his wife. Kathy Bates is his sympathetic mother-in-law; the actor-turned-director Todd Louiso worked from a screenplay by Mr. Hoffman's brother, Gordy Hoffman. Dec. 27.

MAX -- John Cusack plays a dashing, successful Jewish art dealer in post-World War I Vienna. When an aspiring young artist named Adolf Hitler (Noah Taylor, of "Shine") approaches him for advice, he brushes him off, thus setting into motion a major chain of events. With Leelee Sobieski and Molly Parker; it's the directorial debut of Steven Spielberg's longtime screenplay collaborator Menno Meyjes. Dec. 27.

NICHOLAS NICKLEBY -- Charles Dickens's novel of a young man's struggle to support himself, his sister and his widowed mother in 19th-century London, brought to the screen by the writer-director Douglas McGrath ("Emma"). Charlie Hunnam plays the title character; the supporting cast includes Nathan Lane, Christopher Plummer, Tom Courtenay, Alan Cumming, Barry Humphries, Timothy Spall and Juliet Stevenson; Jim Broadbent is the wicked schoolmaster, Wackford Squeers. Dec. 27.

THE PIANIST -- Roman Polanski's Holocaust drama won the grand prize at Cannes this year. It's based on the autobiography of Wladyslaw Szpilman, a Polish composer and violinist who survived the Holocaust by hiding in the Warsaw ghetto. With Adrian Brody as Szpilman; Thomas Kretschmann is a music-loving German officer. Dec. 27.

2003

MADISON -- An Indiana air-conditioner repairman lives his dream of flying a hydroplane in a world title race. Jim Caviezel is the eager Hoosier; with Brent Briscoe, Bruce Dern and Mary McCormack. William Bindley directs. Jan. 31.

DREAMCATCHER -- Lawrence Kasdan, generational spokesman ("The Big Chill"), tries his hand at a Stephen King thriller with this feature about a group of hunting buddies who discover something strange and sinister in the woods. With Timothy Olyphant, Damian Lewis, Thomas Jane and Jason Lee. Feb. 7.

DAREDEVIL -- A blind lawyer, played by Ben Affleck, fights crime in court during the day but takes to the streets at night, disguising himself as a mysterious figure known as Daredevil. From the Marvel comic book. He battles postpunk miscreants in what the trailer makes look like a dark, "Matrix"-ish world. With Jennifer Garner, Michael Clarke Duncan and the hard-working Colin Farrell. Feb. 14.

X2 -- More of those misfit Marvel superheroes, here in Bryan Singer's sequel to his 2000 "X-Men." They're troubled teenagers in a home run by the benign Professor Xavier (Patrick Stewart), who sends his supernaturally gifted charges out to battle evil. With Hugh Jackman, Ian McKellen (the villain, Magneto), Halle Berry, Famke Janssen, James Marsden, Rebecca Romijn-Stamos and Anna Paquin. May 2.

THE MATRIX RELOADED -- The supersecret sequel to the generation-defining science fiction hit of 1999. It is, according to the producer Joel Silver, actually a single film that will be shown in two parts: "Reloaded," scheduled for May 15, and "Revolutions," set for November. Keanu Reeves is back as the hacker hero; Laurence Fishburne, Carrie-Anne Moss and Hugo Weaving are taking another turn as well. New additions to the cast include Monica Bellucci and Jada Pinkett Smith. The Wachowski brothers, Andy and Larry, wrote and directed. May 15.

THE HULK -- Ang Lee ("Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon") turns his fine hand to the Marvel comic book character, a scientist (Eric Bana, of "Black Hawk Down") who turns into a big green monster when he gets his dander up. Some cast: Jennifer Connelly, Nick Nolte, Sam Elliott, Josh Lucas and Lou Ferrigno (who played the Hulk on television). June 20.

CHARLIE'S ANGELS 2: HALO -- The Angels -- Drew Barrymore, Lucy Liu and Cameron Diaz -- are called in when government-protected witnesses begin to be murdered at an alarming rate. Demi Moore joins the series as a "fallen angel" who's gone over to the dark side. Directing again is the filmmaker known as McG. June 27.

ONCE UPON A TIME IN MEXICO -- Robert Rodriguez began his "Mariachi" series with an ultra-low-budget, essentially homemade film in 1992; a decade later, the series achieves epic proportions with this entry, with a title that directly challenges the great Sergio Leone. This time, the Mariachi (Antonio Banderas) is assigned by a maverick C.I.A. agent (Johnny Depp) to assassinate a drug lord who may be contemplating a coup. July 2.

TERMINATOR 3: RISE OF THE MACHINES -- Arnold Schwarzenegger returns to the series that made him a star, playing a friendly cyborg sent from the future to protect a budding revolutionary. Details are unavailable, but it seems that Edward Furlong's feisty 10-year-old protagonist has grown into 20-year-old Nick Stahl. And the bad guy this time might be a bad girl -- a superadvanced cyborg called the Terminatrix. Directed by Jonathan Mostow. July 2.

THE FAST AND THE FURIOUS 2 -- The star Vin Diesel and the director Rob Cohen both opted out of this sequel to their 2001 hit about race car drivers who double as car thieves, leaving Paul Walker to carry the ball under the coaching of the director John Singleton ("Boyz N the Hood"). Summer.

KILL BILL -- If all goes well, Quentin Tarantino will have his new film ready for Cannes in May, with a United States release planned for October. Uma Thurman stars as a professional assassin known as the Bride, whose entire bridal party is mowed down by persons unknown at her wedding. She alone survives, and she sets out for revenge, traveling to Japan and Mexico. Based on Mr. Tarantino's own novel; with David Carradine, Jacqueline Bisset, Vivica A. Fox, Daryl Hannah and Lucy Liu. October.

THE FOUNTAIN -- Darren Aronofsky, who made the resourceful, low-budget "Pi" and "Requiem for a Dream," looks to have a few more dollars at his disposal on this science fiction epic, shooting in Australia with Brad Pitt and Cate Blanchett. December.

All dates are subject to change.

 CORRECTION:
An annotated list of films in the New Season issue on Sept. 8 included an erroneous credit for Matthew Bright, director of "Ted Bundy," which opened on Sept. 13. He did not direct "Ed Gein"; it was directed by Chuck Parello.
The listing also misstated the given name of the writer of "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets." He is Steven Kloves, not Ron.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Who's Next At the Fed? A Look At the Field

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
ALAN GREENSPAN has just completed 15 years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, and at 76 he is still going strong. His current term, his fourth, runs until June 2004, and he could very well be appointed to a fifth if he feels up to it.
 But Fed watchers have been detecting signals for some time that Mr. Greenspan may be preparing to go. He engineered the appointment of his closest adviser, Donald L. Kohn, to the central bank's seven-member board of governors, giving the board a storehouse of institutional knowledge should Mr. Greenspan depart. 
 He has left some friends and economists outside the Fed with the impression that he is beginning to think about the end of his tenure. Last month, at the Fed's annual conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo., his speech about stock market bubbles struck many in the audience as a defense of his legacy.
Speculation about Mr. Greenspan's stepping down is almost as common in Washington as handicapping the next presidential race. But whether just a parlor game or the early stages of winnowing the field for one of the world's most powerful jobs, talk of a successor is heating up and focusing on a half-dozen candidates who would most likely be acceptable to a Republican president. Although many names are circulating, none of them is an overwhelming favorite.

MARTIN S. FELDSTEIN -- An economics professor at Harvard and the president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, he has an impeccable academic reputation. Even liberals who disagree with him on policy matters say he is smart, a good communicator and well informed about the range of issues he would face as Fed chairman.
He is a conservative. But one factor complicating his prospects is lingering resentment on the Republican right about his tenure as chairman of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers during the Reagan administration. Mr. Feldstein angered some supply-siders by focusing on the dangers of the growing budget deficit and disputing the idea that tax cuts could pay for themselves.
Odds: 4-1.

ROGER W. FERGUSON JR. -- The vice chairman of the Fed, Mr. Ferguson won high marks for his cool performance on 9/11, when Mr. Greenspan was out of the country. Among his biggest fans is Mr. Greenspan, who went to bat for him when President Bush dithered over whether to reappoint him. It could be to Mr. Bush's political advantage to select Mr. Ferguson, who would be the first black Fed chairman.
But Mr. Ferguson's background is in banking rather than monetary policy, and he is a Democrat. He has rarely stepped into the limelight or deviated much from Mr. Greenspan on his view of the economy, and administration officials have little sense of whether he has the right leadership skills.
Odds: 6-1.

R. GLENN HUBBARD -- The chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Mr. Hubbard is perhaps the only one of Mr. Bush's top economic advisers whose stature has grown since coming to office. He could benefit from Mr. Bush's propensity for choosing people with whom he is personally comfortable.
But he is little known on Wall Street and has spent most of his career focusing on taxes rather than monetary policy.
Odds: 8-1.

JOHN B. TAYLOR -- The undersecretary of the Treasury for international affairs, Mr. Taylor is one of the world's foremost monetary economists, and he came to Washington from Stanford last year as the front-runner to succeed Mr. Greenspan.
But his performance at the Treasury has left White House officials underwhelmed, and the conventional wisdom is that his chance of getting the Fed job has faded.
Odds: 8-1.

LAWRENCE B. LINDSEY -- Mr. Bush's chief economic policy adviser and a former Fed governor, Mr. Lindsey would be an obvious choice by the president.
But after bonding with Mr. Bush during the campaign and overseeing the development of his tax-cut plan, Mr. Lindsey has seen his influence wane, and he is regarded by Democrats as too partisan.
Odds: 8-1.

ROBERT D. McTEER JR. -- The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, Mr. McTeer is the favored candidate of those who believe Texas connections have a big influence on Mr. Bush. Like Mr. Bush, he is folksy, optimistic and conservative, and favored by supply-siders.
But he does not have any particular stature on Wall Street, and he could face some uncomfortable questions in a confirmation hearing. Earlier this year, he arranged a conference at which a speech by a conservative author was criticized by some Fed officials as offensive to blacks and gays.
Odds: 10-1.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Follow Dividend Yields With Care

BYLINE:  By J. ALEX TARQUINIO 

 BODY:
YIELDS have been climbing on many large-capitalization stocks, not because they have raised their dividends but because their prices have fallen sharply.
 More than 50 companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index yield more than 4 percent, rivaling the yield on long-term Treasury bonds. In February, the yields of only three companies in the index were that high. 
 There are reasons to love dividends. In a flat or falling stock market, dividend-paying stocks usually have better total returns; in addition to the income they generate, high-yielding stocks tend to have better price appreciation, or at least shallower declines. Through Thursday, dividend-paying stocks in the S.& P. 500 were down 10.57 percent this year, on average, while those that didn't pay dividends were off 34.61 percent. 
Many high-yielding stocks, including names like J. P. Morgan Chase, Bristol-Myers Squibb and FleetBoston Financial, are viewed by analysts as solid investments. But high yields in themselves may not necessarily be desirable, said Richard Bernstein, chief United States strategist at Merrill Lynch. 
"High yield can mean two things," he said. "It can mean an opportunity, or it can mean the dividend is going to be cut and the market is anticipating that" -- and prices have therefore fallen for a good reason. 
Nevertheless, Mr. Bernstein said he thinks some classic value investments can be found in the high-yield group, particularly among pharmaceutical stocks. He warns investors to be careful, however, about high-yielding financial companies because of potential problems with bad loans and the possibility that the economy may be weakening again. But individual investors have one advantage over the professionals: time. "As an individual investor, you can buy early and you don't have to worry about quarterly performance," he said.
Among financial companies, share prices of Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase have dropped the most sharply -- with corresponding yield increases -- since the week of July 22, when bank executives appeared before a Congressional panel investigating the companies' roles in the Enron debacle. Citigroup now trades at $30.28, giving it a 2.38 percent yield, and J. P. Morgan is at $23.91, for a yield of 5.69 percent.
Though both companies have a long history of annual dividend increases, J. P. Morgan has now gone six quarters without one. "I strongly suspect that if there's no more bad news, they can maintain the dividend, said Donald Taylor, manager of the Franklin Rising Dividend fund. "But there's very little margin for error." 
FleetBoston has a yield of 5.96, but Mr. Luftig said he expects that its annual earnings growth rate over the next five years will be 4 to 5 percent. "We're not interested in stocks that have a higher yield where growth expectations are low," he said. He prefers Bank One and Washington Mutual, two expanding, regionally based banks with yields above 2 percent, and estimated annual growth rates of at least 8 percent.
THOMAS J. HUBER, manager of the T. Rowe Price Dividend Growth fund, favors pharmaceutical stocks. "They embody everything I like to see in a company: cash flow, high margins, a good dividend that grows over time."
Shares of Bristol-Myers have fallen since the end of July, when management acknowledged a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into wholesale sales incentives that might have inflated 2001 revenue by as much as $1 billion. The incentives created an inventory glut that management acknowledges will hurt earnings this year. 
Nevertheless, he regards Bristol-Myers as a classic value stock. The company has been the subject of persistent rumors that it is an acquisition target, and with a yield of 4.44 percent , shareholders are being paid to wait, Mr. Huber said.
Plenty of dividend opportunities are found in telephone and electric utilities, historically some of the highest-yielding stocks, but the group has many minefields, said Richard Behler, co-manager of the Morgan Stanley Dividend Growth fund.
Shares of the Baby Bells tumbled after one of them, BellSouth, cut earnings estimates for the fourth time this year on Aug. 29. BellSouth now trades at $22.67, for a yield of 3.53 percent. Verizon trades at $29.83 and has a yield of 5.16 percent.
Mr. Behler said the phone companies would need time to sort out consumer demand for a range of services, from wireless to broadband Internet. In the meantime, there will be pressure on profit margins.
Electric utilities, once called safe income investments for widows and orphans, are now widely regarded as risky if they have delved into any energy trading, Mr. Behler said. "Pure-vanilla utility stocks probably aren't too risky, but the valuations aren't extremely low, either," he said.
One utility company that Mr. Luftig recommends is Teco Energy, based in Tampa, with a yield of 8.70 percent and a price-to-earnings ratio of 7.07. Its stock closed at $16.33 on Friday, down 37.8 percent this year.
"The dividend is very secure," Mr. Luftig said. The company pays investors $1.42 a share, and he estimates that 2002 earnings will be $2.10 to $2.20 a share. He expects earnings of $2.10 a share in 2003, but new plants should bolster earnings 5 percent to 6 percent a year after that, he said.
Although there are exceptions, for most stocks a yield of much more than 7 percent may signal an impending dividend cut, said Arnold Kaufman, editor of The Outlook, a newsletter published by Standard & Poor's. "You should probably settle in the 3 percent to 6 percent area, particularly if you want some growth potential," he said.
Such rules of thumb are meant to apply to the current market, in which relatively low yields are commonplace. It wasn't always this way. In 1982, at a market bottom, the average yield of the S.& P. 500 was 6.7 percent; it is below 2 percent today. 
Shaky earnings have generally pushed dividend payments lower. Companies in the S.& P. 500 cut dividends 2.5 percent in 2000, on average, and 3.3 percent in 2001 -- the first back-to-back annual declines since 1951 -- and they have cut dividends an additional 1 percent so far this year.
DIVIDEND-PAYING stocks tend to be left behind in a bull market, when investors typically want companies to use profits to expand their businesses. Many young investors see dividend stocks as stodgy, said Dee Lee, a financial planner in Harvard, Mass. Ms. Lee said she might recommend General Electric to investors looking for growth. It now yields 2.54 percent. "I tell them, 'That's a bonus,' " she said.
Dividends are taxed at an individual's top marginal tax rate, making them less tax-efficient than long-term capital gains. One way around that is to hold dividend stocks in a tax-deferred account, like a retirement or college savings account.
But Ms. Lee says many dividend-paying stocks are such good investments that it makes sense to hold them in a taxable account. "Too often, people are driven by a desire to beat Uncle Sam," she said.
Arguments that dividends are tax inefficient contributed to their slide from grace. In the late 90's, rather than paying dividends, many companies chose to buy back stock, often at inflated prices. "That tax angle dovetailed nicely with the inflated use of stock options," Mr. Taylor said. "Buying back stock is a nice way to prop up the value of options." It was also necessary to keep the options from diluting outstanding shares, he said.
Will dividends ever return to their historical importance? Mr. Huber thinks so. "Unfortunately, we may get there the hard way," he said. "I think total returns are just going to be lower."
