HEADLINE: NYC; 
The Forecast Is the Usual But Different

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
IT'S warmer today than it has been of late. The temperature has climbed to the mid-80's, and the skies are overcast. They say it will rain before the day is through. Well, we could use it.
 It has been fairly quiet. But you know how it is. There's always something going on -- some of it serious, some of it silly. A lot of it is the kind of stuff you hear all the time. 
 Clothes seem to be on people's minds, judging from what's in the news.
Teachers and principals are not happy with the way many kids are dressing for school. What else is new, huh?
It seems girls are showing way too much skin, from their navels on up or on down, depending on where your eyes go. And the boys! Forget about the boys. For some reason, they want to look as if they're ambling through Cellblock D at Attica, with pants drooping down and underwear showing.
School districts are talking about the need for new dress codes, to crack down on what some see as runaway sexualization.
There's runway sexualization, too.
The designers have put their latest women's collections on display. Two of them have come up with a dress that has cords wrapping around the body and seams that suggest quilting. It says here in the newspaper that these two have a knack for "chaste dressing that still leaves their fashion sisters free to assert their sexuality." There's nothing like freedom, is there?
And can you ever get enough of the Trumps? Ivana Trump has just ended a summer vacation aboard her yacht. But it wasn't all play, no sir. She would rise before dawn to work on a book she is writing about women in business. "It's much easier to write fiction," she says, "because you can just make everything up." Hard to argue the point.
Let's see, what else is going on today? 
There's the same old same old. The Yankees have left the Red Sox in the dust, and the Mets are going nowhere again, never mind that they manage to win a few in a row now and then. Pete Sampras made it to the finals at the United States Open, and, naturally, so did the indomitable Williams sisters.
The Israelis and the Palestinians are still killing each other with depressing regularity. President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe is under attack for the way he is confiscating and redistributing land held by white farmers. 
A congressman is in big trouble politically for not coming clean about what he was up to. In Washington, leaders in both major parties are debating the wisdom of further tax cuts in this shaky economy.
Then there's a sex-discrimination suit that a bond saleswoman filed today in federal court in Manhattan. She says a high-profile Wall Street firm denied her the extra pay and the promotion that she deserved. Don't mean to sound ho-hum about a serious matter. But alleged sexism on Wall Street -- what a shocker!
There are some unusual things swirling today, though.
A primary is upon us in New York. In North Carolina, Elizabeth Dole is running for the United States Senate. She has quite a resume: presidential candidate, cabinet secretary, president of the American Red Cross. It's hard to imagine that having the Red Cross as a credential could hurt.
A FGHANISTAN is getting more attention than usual. There is a short article today about an attempt to kill an important opposition leader in the country's north. This man was injured, it says. If he dies, it could complicate the situation over there. It's sticky enough as it is.
If you want to feel your skin crawl, you may want to glance at a new book by Bill Ayers, a leader of the old Weathermen. That's the group on the loony left that was bombing government buildings three decades ago. There is "a certain eloquence to bombs," he now says, "a poetry and a pattern from a safe distance." Charming, no?
People can say and do unbelievable things. Take what's happening today in New York. Hospital workers are caring for a newborn girl who was left on the ground, wrapped in a blanket, in Central Park. The placenta was still attached.
Probably, someone called 911, the emergency number.
Of course, what else could those numbers, 9 and 11 mean? There is but one definition, the same as "ground zero" means the area directly below or above the point where a nuclear bomb goes off, "Connect the Dots" is a game book for children, and "footprints" are what you leave in the sand.
Anyway, that's how it is today, Sept. 10, 2001.
Tomorrow will be cooler, with azure skies, they say. It should be a beautiful day.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
SNAP-ON SAYS THIRD-QUARTER EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Snap-on Inc., a tool maker, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings would fall short of forecasts as weak economic conditions in North America and Europe cut into demand for its products. 
The warning sent Snap-on shares plummeting almost 13 percent. The company, based in Kenosha, Wis., said it was being hurt by lower sales and increased bad debts in July and August. Snap-on, a maker of hand tools and auto diagnostic equipment, said it now expected net income for the third quarter, ending Sept. 28, of 32 cents to 35 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected, on average, earnings of 48 cents a share in the third quarter.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Siebel Systems picks up the pieces from the bubble by salvaging sunken options.

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
ONE leftover of the burst bubble in technology stocks is the existence of millions of employee stock options that are far out of the money. Such options provide little in the way of incentive for employees to stay, and companies have looked for ways to change that without outraging existing shareholders.
 Now an innovative plan is being offered by Siebel Systems, a software company that remains profitable but whose revenue has fallen this year along with its share price -- to $8.60, down 93 percent from its 2000 peak of $119.88. The step means that Siebel is likely to shed a lot of those options at the cost of providing employees with a substantial windfall. 
 The plan allows employees with options that have exercise prices of $40 a share or higher to sell them back to the company for $1.85 an option. That price will be paid in restricted stock for employees with options worth more than $5,000 and in cash for those with less.
 If all eligible employees take up the offer, 32 million options will be canceled. The employees who take the offer will be better off with this plan unless the share price rises substantially, but the company will benefit by having less potential dilution of its stock.
 While some of the restricted stock that will be issued can be sold immediately, other shares cannot be sold for up to four years. And in an unusual requirement, Siebel bars employees from hedging their positions by buying options or other devices until the shares can be sold. That will force the employees to maintain a stake in the company.
 The plan, announced late last month, appears to be unique. Thomas M. Siebel, the company's chief executive, said he conceived it and knew of no other companies that had made similar offers.
 The plan drew cautious praise from Charles M. Elson, the director of the Center for Corporate Governance at the University of Delaware, who said it seemed appropriate for lower-level employees, assuming the value of restricted stock was reasonable. "An option that is so dramatically underwater becomes a disincentive," he said. But he said he would oppose offering such a trade to senior executives who had the power to negotiate option grants and who had known of the risk the share price would decline. At Siebel, the only current employees not eligible for the exchange are those who serve on its board.
Siebel has been a generous issuer of options over the years. According to its most recent financial report, it had 477 million shares outstanding and options outstanding to issue 228 million more shares. In an interview last week, Mr. Siebel said the company had historically relied on options for a substantial part of compensation.
 Because it has so many options outstanding, Siebel was not in a good position to use either of the tactics some companies have used in the last couple of years to provide new incentives for option holders. One tactic, pioneered by Sprint, offered employees the choice of canceling some existing options and then receiving new options six months and a day later at the market price.
 Were Siebel to do that, it would cause an enormous dilution for existing shareholders, and it would devastate earnings-per-share calculations if the stock recovered even slightly. That is because accounting rules would require the company to count some of those shares as outstanding as soon as the price rose above the exercise price.
 Another tactic, used by companies like Microsoft and General Electric, would have been to issue a second round of options in a year. That would raise the threat of substantial dilution and would have further increased the number of options outstanding at Siebel.
 Recently, however, Siebel has been reluctant to grant options. Its practice has been to give options to all new employees and issue options to outstanding existing employees each January. But it issued no options to existing employees this year, and Kenneth A. Goldman, Siebel's chief financial officer, said in an interview that the company would not issue new options in the next six months to any employees who accepted the current offer, which expires Sept. 30. He said the company might not issue any options at all to existing employees.
<gfbullet> One issue for Siebel is whether it will be forced to treat the value of newly granted options as an expense. In the past, it has been profitable only because accounting rules allowed it to ignore the value of options it granted in calculating its profits.
 Had it treated the cost of options as an expense -- as accounting rules encourage but do not require -- its profits of 49 cents a share in 2001 and 24 cents in 2000 would have turned into losses of $1.02 and 29 cents, respectively.
 Those losses reflect calculations of the values of options when issued, calculations that are based on the Black-Scholes formula. Mr. Siebel and Mr. Goldman said they thought that that formula might overstate values because it relied so heavily on stock-price volatility, which has been been high for Siebel and many other technology stocks.
 Nonetheless, Siebel used Black-Scholes calculations to determine the value it will pay for the options in the current offering. Mr. Goldman said the options with $40 exercise prices had a current value of about $1.85 each by that model. He said that the ones with higher exercise prices were worth less but that the company had nonetheless decided to offer the same price for them. 
 If accounting rule makers were to force companies to count options as an expense, Mr. Goldman said, the company would almost certainly move in the direction of issuing more restricted stock to employees. It would also issue performance-based options, where employees would be able to exercise the options only if their unit met certain performance goals, he said.
 Current accounting rules force both restricted stock grants and those of performance-based options to be treated as an expense. That has encouraged the use of conventional stock options, which ensure a profit for the holder if the stock price rises over the 10 years after the option is granted.

HEADLINE: Inventories Rose in July And Shoppers Added to Debt 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 

 BODY:
Wholesale inventories rose in July for a second consecutive month, the first back-to-back increase in 19 months, the government reported today.
 Inventories gained 0.6 percent, to $284.2 billion, the Commerce Department said, led by increases in cars, machinery and clothing. That followed a 0.4 percent rise in June and was the biggest increase since June 2000. Sales at wholesalers rose 0.6 percent in July, to $231 billion. 
 Machinery inventories, the largest category in the report, increased in July for the first time since May 2001, rising 0.9 percent after declining 0.2 percent in June.
"The recovery will proceed at the slow pace we're seeing for a while, with a gradual pickup in capital spending, and employment growth through the end of the year," Cathy Minehan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, said in a speech today.
The inventory-to-sales ratio for wholesalers, a measure of how long goods remain unsold, held at 1.23 months, where it has been since April.
Stockpiles at wholesalers of durable goods, which include furniture, computers and electrical equipment, rose 0.5 percent after increasing 0.2 percent in June, the report showed. Sales of durable goods fell 0.1 percent after rising 0.5 percent.
Wholesale inventories of nondurable goods rose 0.9 percent after rising 0.8 percent in June. Sales of nondurable goods rose 1.2 percent in July.
In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said today that consumer debt rose in July at the fastest pace in eight months as credit card purchases increased the most since November.
Personal borrowing, excluding mortgages, rose at a 7.6 percent annual rate, or $10.8 billion, in July, the Fed said. In June, debt rose at a 6.2 percent pace, or $8.9 billion. Total consumer debt rose in July to $1.724 trillion from $1.713 trillion in June. 
Nonrevolving credit, which includes car loans, rose $4.4 billion in July after rising $5.3 billion in June, revised from a $4.6 billion increase. Credit card and other revolving debt rose $6.5 billion, after a $3.5 billion increase in June, previously reported as a $3.8 billion gain.

HEADLINE: Democrats, Using Finesse, Try to Neutralize the Gun Lobby's Muscle 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 

 BODY:
Senator Jean Carnahan, the Missouri Democrat, pulled out her 20-gauge Browning Citori shotgun the other day and fired off a few rounds as part of a skeet-shoot benefit for a home state research center.
 In Alaska, Lt. Gov. Fran Ulmer, the Democratic candidate for governor and owner of a permit to carry a concealed weapon, went gun shopping in July with reporters in tow. Ms. Ulmer, who owns eight firearms, mostly rifles, told The Anchorage Daily News that she needed something to make her feel safe on the campaign trail -- and that she did not own anything small enough to fit in her purse. 
 In New Mexico, Bill Richardson, the Democratic candidate for governor, was a member of the Clinton cabinet and former ambassador to the United Nations. Although his voting record in Congress was generally pro-gun, his association with the antigun Clinton administration is enough to worry the gun lobby. Anticipating such concern, Mr. Richardson is marketing himself as "the choice for New Mexico gun owners and sportsmen."
These Democrats and others nationwide are well aware that gun owners cost Al Gore crucial votes in a handful of states in the 2000 presidential election, including Tennessee, his home state. They are also aware that Mark Warner, a Democrat who was elected governor of Virginia in 2001, neutralized the gun issue in his campaign by reassuring white male voters in rural areas that he did not want to take their guns.
As a result, many candidates this year are eagerly emulating the Warner model. Across the country and across party lines, candidates -- many of whom are running on a big day of primaries on Tuesday -- are supplicants to their pro-gun-rights constituents. They may not be advancing the agenda of the National Rifle Association, but they do not want to alienate the powerful gun lobby. Rather, they are trying to inoculate themselves against the N.R.A.'s Election Day forces.
The association endured organizational problems in the 1990's but has since rebuilt its fund-raising and remains an important force in the Republican Party.
Now, Democrats are so eager for the gun lobby's endorsement that the rifle association is involved in three times as many Democratic primaries this year as it was during the 2000 elections, said Andrew Arulanandam, a spokesman for the association.
Gun control advocates concede that some candidates need to assuage their constituents who own guns. But, they argue, that does not reflect the sentiment in most of the country.
"There is no question that candidates running in rural areas -- Democrats and Republicans -- find themselves forced to cater to the gun lobby," said Michael Barnes, a former Democratic representative from Maryland and now president of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, formerly Handgun Control. "And you've got such a pro-gun administration -- Bush, Cheney, Ashcroft are all so extreme on the issue -- that there's more focus on it."
But, Mr. Barnes cautioned, "the N.R.A. is running against the tide of demography in the United States."
Wayne LaPierre, executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, countered: "There's been a sea change on this issue since the 2000 election. Democrats are running away from gun control like the plague, and we are just not being attacked. If they're not agreeing with us, they're silent. They're either looking for the N.R.A. endorsement or they're making sure the N.R.A. doesn't do anything against them."
The rifle association will not endorse candidates until late October. But it is leaning toward giving its blessing to more Democrats than ever before.
"Because more Democrats are restructuring their position, that may happen," Mr. Arulanandam said. "But our endorsement process is fairly rigid. We're concerned that we might have a lot of fair-weather friends. These people are obviously paying attention to the changing political winds and right now everyone is currying favor with the N.R.A., but will they be there when something bad happens and we need their vote?"
Mr. Barnes said Democrats for gun control needed to hold their ground.
"Democratic members of Congress might be saying the party has to focus on rural white males, but my response to that is, if you believe the future of American politics is winning the votes of rural white males, you're crazy," he said. "The future is the suburbs, especially women."
The affluent suburbs of big cities are still among the most reliably antigun strongholds in the country. In suburban Maryland, all five candidates -- four Democrats and the Republican incumbent -- for the House support gun control. Mark K. Shriver and Christopher Van Hollen Jr., both Democrats, are each running television commercials declaiming their antigun credentials; the winner of their Sept. 10 primary will face Representative Constance A. Morella, a Republican who is already advertising the fact that she has been endorsed by the Brady Campaign.
Such jousting in the suburbs, however, seems to be the exception. 
Not far from Ms. Morella's suburban Maryland district is a rural House district where Representative Wayne T. Gilchrest, a six-term moderate Republican, is being challenged by a conservative Republican in the Sept. 10 primary. Mr. Gilchrest is running commercials calling himself a "Marine hero, longtime N.R.A. member who understands the need to protect our Second Amendment rights." (Officials from the gun lobby say Mr. Gilchrest joined their organization only in June.)
In Tennessee, where Mr. Gore lost in 2000 to George W. Bush by 47 percent to 51 percent, several Democratic candidates are similarly casting themselves as the sportsman's friend. These include Lincoln Davis, running for the House seat where Mr. Gore began his political career. He has the backing of the former vice president and the gun lobby.
Steve Rosenthal, political director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said that in 2000 the labor movement was "extremely antsy" about the gun issue because the gun lobby was making inroads with union members based on their cultural affiliation with guns.
"We had to say, 'It's not about guns; it's about your family's economic security,' " Mr. Rosenthal said. "And we'd say, 'Gore doesn't want to take away your gun, but Bush wants to take away your union.' 
"In places where we took them head-on, we won," he said, adding that 58 percent of union members who own guns voted for Mr. Gore, while 37 percent voted for Mr. Bush.
This year, Mr. Rosenthal said, "our folks are encouraging candidates to keep the spotlight off the gun issue."
This season, gun control has vanished from the Democrats' agenda on Capitol Hill. The Senate and the House have bills that would give gun makers federal immunity against civil lawsuits, but analysts predict there will not be any votes on major gun legislation before the election.

Ms. Ulmer, a Democrat who owns several firearms, said she needed a gun small enough to carry in her purse while she campaigned. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE NORTHERN BORDER; 
Bush and Chretien Discuss Easing Customs Delays

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 9 

 BODY:
President Bush and Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada met today at the continent's most active border crossing for trade and announced new steps to reduce customs delays for authorized truckers and travelers while remaining vigilant against terrorists.
 In a 30-minute session with Mr. Chretien, Mr. Bush continued to make his case for urgent action against Iraq, and he reiterated a concern that Iraq might be close to developing nuclear arms, officials said. Mr. Bush did not provide Canada with new evidence, and did not ask for anything from Ottawa, the officials said. 
 Mr. Chretien, who has voiced skepticism about the American strategy, said he urged Mr. Bush to act through the United Nations. "I told him that we were asking them to go through the United Nations first before taking any other action," Mr. Chretien told reporters after returning to Canada.
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Bush was consulting with world leaders in preparation for his speech on Thursday before the United Nations General Assembly.
Over the course of the day, Mr. Bush spoke with Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey; Secretary General Kofi Annan; Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen of Denmark, who currently holds the presidency of the European Union; Lord Robertson, the secretary general of NATO; and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia. He was also to talk with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Mr. Fleischer said.
The White House expressed optimism today that its campaign to focus on the dangers posed by Iraq might be making progress. Without commenting directly on a new two-stage proposal by President Jacques Chirac of France, Mr. Fleischer said, "It does appear that a movement is budding to put some force to previous U.N. resolutions." 
In an interview over the weekend, Mr. Chirac proposed giving Iraq one more United Nations deadline to permit weapons inspections, then seeking a resolution permitting an attack if Baghdad refused. 
Mr. Fleischer declined to say whether President Bush would embrace Mr. Chirac's call. But White House officials appeared gratified at the proposal from France, which has a veto on the Security Council and has been strongly opposed to a go-it-alone American attack against Iraq.
Mr. Chretien adopted a stance similar to Mr. Chirac's, which appeared to leave the door open for Canadian support of a multilateral campaign against President Saddam Hussein. He spoke warmly of the pride his nation felt in taking part in the ousting of the Taliban from Afghanistan.
"I agree that Saddam Hussein is somebody who has done terrible things in the past," Mr. Chretien said, referring to the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq in 1990 and Mr. Hussein's use of chemical weapons against Iraqi separatists. "But at this moment there is no plan that has been given to me by the president and no request for Canadian assistance." 
Mr. Fleischer said the positions of Canada and other nations would become more apparent after Mr. Bush laid out the case against Iraq on Thursday. "After Thursday's speech, you'll start to see where the world community lies," Mr. Fleischer said.
In Iraq today, allied warplanes attacked an air defense command-and-control site about 170 miles southeast of Baghdad, the United States Central Command said. The command described the strike as "a self-defense measure in response to Iraqi hostile threats and acts."
American and British planes have carried out 37 attacks this year in the no-flight zones of southern and northern Iraq, according to Pentagon statistics.
On a sweltering day, Mr. Bush and Mr. Chretien surveyed their common border, the longest nonmilitarized border in the world, and pledged to find ways to keep security concerns from impeding $475 billion a year in two-way trade. The two countries are carrying out a 30-point plan to develop a "smart border," one that avoids trade-crippling backups and frustrations for frequent travelers, they said, but that recognizes threats as they arise.
The White House highlighted two programs today. 
The first would offer expedited clearance for shippers and exporters engaged in "low-risk, legitimate trade" who have previously enrolled with American or Canadian authorities. 
Under that procedure, businesses may register their vehicles and drivers and notify United States customs agents of their cargo's imminent arrival at the border. The truck would then be able to travel through a dedicated lane, and customs agents would identify and clear the shipment with a radio device. 
"Stop times will be reduced from a few minutes to seconds, and that's important," Mr. Bush said.
The other measure allows screened travelers who are considered low risk to pass through the border here with little or no delay by using a special photo-identification card. A similar program is already in place on the border between Washington State and British Columbia.
The trading relationship between the countries is the world's largest, with one-third of that commerce moving through Windsor and Detroit. More than 7,000 trucks cross the Ambassador Bridge between the cities. Today, that suspension bridge was festooned with American and Canadian flags and a banner that declared "United We Stand."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Jean Chretien and President Bush at the Ambassador Bridge in Detroit yesterday. The leaders met to discuss tightening security against terrorists while keeping the border open to trade. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: In Defense of Deterrence 

 BODY:
The suddenness and ferocity of last September's terror attacks tore the United States free from the foreign-policy moorings that had served the nation well for more than five decades, including the central notion that American military power could by its very existence restrain the aggressive impulses of the nation's enemies. In its place, the Bush administration has substituted a more belligerent first-strike strategy that envisions Washington's attacking potential foes before they hit us. That may be appropriate in dealing with terror groups, but on the eve of the anniversary of Sept. 11 there is still an important place in American policy for the doctrine of deterrence. 
 Deterrence is diplomatic parlance for a brutally simple idea: that an attack on the United States or one of its close allies will lead to a devastating military retaliation against the country responsible. It emerged as the centerpiece of American foreign policy in the early years of the cold war. Some of the debates that preceded its adoption sound strikingly similar to arguments being made today. During the Truman administration, some strategists suggested attacking the Soviet Union while it was still militarily weak to prevent the rise of a nuclear-armed Communist superpower. Wiser heads prevailed, and for the next 40 years America's reliance on a strategy of deterrence preserved an uneasy but durable peace. 
 One advantage of deterrence is that it induces responsible behavior by enemies as a matter of their own self-interest. Even dictators tend to put certain basic interests above all else -- pre-eminently their survival in power, with their national territories and a functioning economy intact. Aggression becomes unattractive if the price is devastation at home and possible removal from power. By contrast, the threat that America will strike first may give foes an incentive to use their military forces, including unconventional weapons, before they lose them.
The logic of deterrence transcends any particular era or enemy. It has worked, for example, to restrain further North Korean aggression since the Korean War. A decade ago, a clear message of deterrence delivered by the first Bush administration persuaded Saddam Hussein not to use his chemical and biological weapons against America or Israel during the Persian Gulf war. 
In the wake of Sept. 11, President George W. Bush has made a convincing case that international terrorist organizations, which have no permanent home territory and little to lose, cannot reliably be checked by the threat of retaliation and must be stopped before they strike. Whether Saddam Hussein falls into that category is a question that the country will be debating in the days ahead. But by and large, we believe that deterrence can still be a powerful force in managing many of the threats the United States faces. Protecting America's security requires weighing all available policy options and choosing the wisest. Deterrence, the least risky and most time-tested tool in America's national security arsenal, should not be hastily discarded.

HEADLINE: Oil Companies Receive Saudi Ultimatum 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia has moved to end a yearlong deadlock with the world's biggest oil companies over a $25 billion project to develop some of its largest natural gas fields, asking the companies to decide by early October whether to continue talks under new, arguably more risky, conditions.
 The Saudis and the major oil companies have dealt in ultimatums before over the gas project, exchanges that analysts have shrugged off as the posturing bred by complex negotiations. But some industry experts say that the Saudis are now tiring of inching toward compromise. That view stems from a letter that the Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, sent to the companies last week and comments earlier this summer by Crown Prince Abdullah that he wanted the matter resolved quickly. 
 "I don't think this is more of the same," said Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, an industry-financed group. "This is a little bit like the baseball strike, when you decide when to walk out or not. And I think the Saudis are getting closer to the deadline and are playing hardball."
The letter, which offers less promising fields than those initially proposed, is ratcheting up the tension in negotiations between the Saudis and oil companies, including Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell, BP and TotalFina Elf, at a time when relations between the kingdom and the United States are particularly strained. 
Saudi Arabia's ties to Al Qaeda and, more recently, its opposition to any American attack on Iraq, have engendered bipartisan criticism of the kingdom in Congress and division in the Bush administration about how to manage relations with the Saudis.
But industry experts who spoke on condition of anonymity said that while politics may have played a role in the Saudis' tougher stance, economic and financial considerations are at the heart of the unresolved negotiations.
"I think politics is complicating it, though I don't think it is the reason," said one former oil industry executive who is tracking the talks. "There are people on both sides of the fence in the royal family. For those who oppose opening the fields to foreigners, the strained ties gives them another chip."
The letter was first reported yesterday by The Wall Street Journal.
About two years ago, the Saudis invited foreign oil companies to draw up plans to develop some of the kingdom's largest natural gas reserves. For Western oil companies, the invitation promised the first such opportunity in Saudi Arabia since the 1973 oil crisis. According to industry analysts, they hoped that the gas projects would eventually lead to invitations to help develop Saudi Arabia's vast oil reserves, by far the largest in the world.
Over time, though, the natural gas project has lost much of its allure, industry analysts said. Months ago, the best natural gas fields, which held huge proven reserves, were taken off the table by the Saudis, who now want foreigners to find new fields, not develop existing reservoirs. The companies were instead offered areas where reserves are not clearly established: one area south of the enormous Ghawar oil field; another by the Red Sea; and a third, called Shaybah, in the south of the country. The recent letter adds more acreage with reserves that are uncertain.
"They're relatively far from large, proven gas fields," Thierry Desmarest, the chairman and chief executive of the French oil concern TotalFina Elf, said in an interview yesterday. "We're concerned that after working for a few years, we won't have enough gas."
Moreover, the oil companies, organized into three groups, want a greater return on their investment than the Saudis have been willing to offer. The companies sought something like 15 percent to 19 percent, industry experts said, while the Saudis offered 10 percent to 12 percent. 
But Mr. Desmarest and some Saudis with ties to the project said they were optimistic that the foreign oil companies and the kingdom would reach an agreement. "It is important to keep contact and find ways to implement this initiative," Mr. Desmarest said, "even if the project is not the same size as was initially expected."
The oil companies are studying the Saudi proposals. Whether the gas project will survive may become apparent early next month, when they make their counteroffers. People in the oil industry say that it is common to begin talks with a country aimed at snagging one project only to end up with another.
But for many months now, the relationship between the foreign oil companies and the Saudis has been cool. "Often in these projects, there are huge disappointments," one oil company official said.
Opening Saudi Arabia's largest natural gas fields to foreign exploration is widely seen as a pet project of Crown Prince Abdullah, who effectively rules the kingdom because of the failing health of King Fahd, his half-brother. 
His aim, analysts say, is to improve the country's energy industry while setting into motion huge projects that would put jobless young Saudis to work. The oil companies would not only extract natural gas, but develop operations that the gas would feed, including water desalination and power plants. 
But the initiative has divided the Saudi elite into those who back the project and the economic reforms it could bring and those who oppose it, either to protect their particular interests or for fear of signing over the country's best gas properties to foreigners. The latter camp has been shaped by the state oil company Aramco, analysts said, but it also includes leading members of the ruling al-Saud family. 
The expectation, of course, is that the companies, eager to be in place to pump oil one day, ultimately will go along with what the kingdom offers.
If the project falls apart, it will prove an acute embarrassment to Crown Prince Abdullah, industry analysts said. But given the tinderbox the kingdom has become, he may be willing to risk that to keep the peace within the royal family, they said. 
'Abdullah may not want internal debate right now, " one industry executive said.

HEADLINE: THE BATTLEFRONT; 
Gratitude And Doubt In New Life Of Afghans

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: GHAZNI, Afghanistan 

 BODY:
IN this nation of 23 million people, just about everyone has an opinion on the changes since American military power toppled the Taliban. But there are few places where enthusiasm runs higher than along a potholed back street in this crumbling outpost 90 miles southwest of Kabul.
 Once the capital of an empire sweeping from Persia to India, Ghazni has been a deeply conservative backwater since it was razed by Genghis Khan nearly 800 years ago. Its capture by the Taliban in 1995, without a shot fired, was an important step toward gaining control of Afghanistan. But last November, local people were quick to haul down the Taliban's white flags as soon as American bombing brought the mullahs' repressive rule in Kabul to a sudden end. 
 At that moment, Ghazni stood as a symbol of an Afghanistan that had rejected the Taliban. But at the end of July, Taliban die-hards struck back, leaving their new redoubts in the mountains to bomb the yard of a girls' school, one of thousands reopened since the lifting of the Taliban's ban on education for girls. Nobody was hurt, but leaflets scattered nearby threatened death to any women or girls who returned. 
Ghazni's leaders responded by posting armed guards at the school and carrying right on with classes.
Since then, 2,500 girls in black cotton uniforms and white head shawls have packed the school each day, attending in two shifts. The students are blithely unconcerned that they have almost no desks or chairs, and that supplies of notebooks and pens are inadequate. The joy of one group of 10- to 12-year-olds, sitting on the floor, was infectious, and a visitor had only to ask whom they credited for their change of fortune to set off a cheerful chorus.
"America! America! America!" they cried, and then, "George W. Bush!"
Across Afghanistan, the joy of freedom regained is evident wherever a traveler goes: in the bazaars, thriving with an instinctive Afghan entrepreneurship that withered under the Taliban; in the cheerful traffic jams that choke cities like Kabul, where emptied streets echoed just a year ago; aboard trucks bearing some of the 1.5 million refugees returning home after years as refugees in Pakistan and Iran; and among the millions whose livelihoods, and simple pleasures, the Taliban repressed.
Women work again. Traders fly off to cut deals in Karachi and Delhi and Dubai. Families argue over which television programs to watch on their new satellite systems. People play music again and sing traditional Afghan ballads. Old men parade caged birds, and small boys fly kites.
Any fair reckoning of what America has accomplished here since Sept. 11, and what it has not, does well to begin with these liberties, for they are the starting point for Afghans when they are asked about the past 12 months. Most say the country has known nothing like the air of possibility ushered in with the Taliban's defeat since the days before the Communist coup in 1978.
Just as surely, many Afghans proceed to a litany of hopes and promises they consider unredeemed, and for which, fairly or not, they hold the United States to account.
The list varies little in details: the bounty of Western aid that has yet to flow in ways that help ordinary people; jobs not yet created in a country where 70 percent of able-bodied men are unemployed; thousands of villages and neighborhoods that still lie in rubble; ruined highways that slow even the toughest jeeps to a crawl and turn short distances into journeys that last days; barely functioning hospitals and water and power systems that remain pretty much as they were when the Taliban fled.
The contending views of America -- gratitude for driving out the Taliban, deep disappointment at the slow pace of reconstruction -- are everywhere.
In Ghazni, the headmaster, Abdul Samad, 56, beamed as he listened to the girls bubbling with enthusiasm for America. But then took a visitor aside to offer a sober sentiment: "Please tell America we feel very sorry for happened on Sept. 11, because thousands of innocent people were killed. But please tell them, too, that Sept. 11, for us, was a starting point, and not the end.
"This time, we need America to stay with us, and not to run away."
Such appeals echo the pledge made by President Bush after the Sept. 11 attacks were linked to Osama bin Laden's network in Afghanistan. It was a promise born of the United States' past involvement here, as the principal backer of the Muslim guerrillas who drove off Soviet occupation forces: that this time, America would remain committed until Afghanistan was rebuilt and would not lose interest as it did after the Soviet defeat in 1989, leaving a ruined land that was easy prey for the Taliban.
Above all, Afghans speak of the failure of the new American-backed government of President Hamid Karzai to have much effect beyond the limits of Kabul, and of its failure even to establish a convincing climate of security in the capital. The bomb blast on Thursday that killed 30 people and injured 170 others on a crowded Kabul street, and a failed attempt on the same day to assassinate Mr. Karzai in Kandahar, only reinforced the deep sense of uncertainty.
For this, too, many Afghans hold the United States primarily responsible, saying that in its determination to hunt down the remnants of Al Qaeda and the Taliban, it has defined its military role here too narrowly. They say that creating the lasting peace Afghanistan craves will require more than teams of Green Berets and Apache helicopters combing distant villages and the country's impenetrable mountains.
American military strength in Afghanistan stands at about 7,800 troops, but their mission, and that of about 3,500 other troops from allied nations including Australia, Britain and Canada, has been defined by Washington as the pursuit of what remains of Al Qaeda and the Taliban.
The most visible foreign military contingent is the International Security Assistance Force, commanded by a Turkish general, which includes 4,800 soldiers from more than a dozen nations. Its role has been limited to Kabul.
THESE arrangements have left almost all Afghanistan outside the capital in the control of warlords who offer only nominal fealty to Mr. Karzai's government.
The result for millions of Afghans has been that they have swapped the medievalism of the Taliban for a life under armed bands who recognize only the warlords' authority. Some of the warlords, like Gul Agha Shirzai in Kandahar and Ismail Khan in Herat, have governed better than others and have won a measure of popular support. But the absence of law, and the rife banditry outside Kabul, has been a major impediment for the United Nations and relief agencies eager to begin the reconstruction work the country so desperately needs.
The lack of security outside Kabul has also provided many of the nations that pledged a $4.5 billion reconstruction fund for Afghanistan at a Tokyo conference in January with a grounds for delay.
To meet those concerns, the United States is taking the lead role in training a new national army, but it could be as long as five years before the Kabul government will have a credible force of its own. Senior Bush administration officials, in a major reversal, recently abandoned their opposition to Mr. Karzai's calls for an expansion of the international peacekeeping force beyond Kabul, but they added what could be a disqualifying condition -- that other nations step up with the necessary troops.
In the meantime, of the $1.8 billion pledged to Afghanistan for this year, barely $600 million has arrived. Almost half of that, $290 million, has come from the United States. Many other nations have been miserly, even as officials from those nations who hold many of the top positions in international aid groups blame the United States.
Other critics say that Washington, in spending $1 billion a month on military operations here, about 40 times what it will spend on economic aid, has got the balance wrong. "The military side is far too expensive," said Lakhdar Brahimi, the former Algerian foreign minister who is the United Nations' top official here. "If you spent a little bit more helping the people of Afghanistan, it would certainly do much better in helping them to stop the use of their country as a breeding ground for terrorism."
At least half of the international aid that has arrived has gone to providing emergency assistance, primarily in the form of food, shelter and medical care for the most vulnerable Afghans. That leaves little for the kind of rebuilding projects that will give Afghans tangible evidence that the world, this time, intends to help the country revive.
On top of these problems, the United States has endured criticism for putting together a government in Kabul that is ethnically unbalanced, overly dependent on the United States, and prone to factionalism and jockeying for power.
Mr. Karzai was, in effect, chosen for leadership by Washington, which found in him many desirable qualities, including his close American ties, his photogenic nature, and the fact that he is an ethnic Pashtun, the country's largest ethnic group and the one that predominated among the Taliban.
But many Afghans say his principal recommendation was that, without any strong political base, even among Pashtuns, he was weak enough not to threaten the new government's real power brokers -- a group of ethnic Tajik ministers from the Northern Alliance, America's partner in fighting the Taliban. The result, these Afghans say, is a government that is inherently unstable, at least until elections scheduled for 2004.
As a counterpoint, the relief that swept the country after the assassination attempt against Mr. Karzai failed offered a compelling argument for his importance.
"Weak he may be in political terms, but without him, the government would lose all credibility in the Pashtun heartland, and that's exactly why the Taliban wanted him dead," one Western ambassador said. "After Kandahar, a lot of Afghans are going to think again and give thanks for the government they have instead of bellyaching about the one they don't."
Among those who hold views like those, the United States' balance sheet at the end of a tumultuous year in Afghanistan is well into the black. "Our promise at the outset was that we would get rid of the Taliban and Al Qaeda and make sure that they didn't come back, and we're well on the way to accomplishing that," Robert Finn, the American ambassador, who has won wide admiration among Afghans for his efforts to speed up the flow of aid, said in an interview last month. "But we're at the beginning, not in the middle, and not at the end. In the meantime, there are many more things that are going right in Afghanistan than are going wrong."
But even Mr. Karzai, by nature an optimist, is finding it hard to wait. During a visit last month to the northern city of Kunduz, he sat alone in the rear of a British military transport plane, playing with a loop of prayer beads. On arrival, he asked a crowd if they were frustrated by the lack of progress in rebuilding the country, especially the roads. Amid cries of assent, he shouted back: "Let me tell you, so do I. When I am driving outside Kabul, I get so frustrated I feel like jumping out, grabbing a shovel and filling some of the potholes myself."

HEADLINE: COMPANIES; 
For Towers' Refugee Businesses, a Year of Struggle and Change

BYLINE:  Reporting for this article and the related chart was provided by Kevin Flynn, Robert F. Worth, Terry Pristin, Elissa Gootman, Yilu Zhao, Jennifer Bayot and Michelle O'Donnell. 

 BODY:
WHEN the World Trade Center towers fell, they took more with them than human lives. A huge segment of the downtown economy collapsed with the falling steel and concrete, and the disaster encompassed far more than the large financial firms that are most often identified with the Sept. 11 attacks.
 The trade center was home to hundreds of diverse companies, a polyglot village spanning everything from Asian food importers to graphic designers to dentists. Many had inhabited the towers for decades. 
 Those companies, more than half of which had fewer than 20 employees, became refugees on Sept. 11. Some have folded, overwhelmed by the deaths of owners or employees or undone by a lack of cash. Others have eked out a living in kitchens and basements. Some have relocated to Florida or Texas, while others have insisted on staying within a few blocks of ground zero. Some, miraculously, have flourished, growing even as the local economy foundered. 
The New York Times set out to chronicle the fate of the complex's tenants as they struggled to re-establish themselves over the past year. After compiling lists of tenants from several sources, The Times estimates that about 700 companies and organizations occupied the trade center buildings. Defining a more precise number, however, is difficult because so many of the companies were subtenants whose occupancy did not appear on official lists.
A team of seven reporters tracked the whereabouts and recorded the accounts of more than 500 businesses that had offices or stores in the trade center on that morning. Of those businesses, 39 no longer exist. Another 30 are working out of private homes, striving like Kasadel, a computer consulting firm, to make a go of it in cramped quarters until they can lease new offices. Kasadel, which once occupied a 15th-floor office in the south tower, has relocated its 18 employees to a basement donated by a friend in Hollis, Queens.
Most of the companies have chosen to stay in Manhattan. More than 350 have relocated to new offices there, including eight that moved into the Empire State Building. More than 80 picked locations south of Chambers Street, within blocks of ground zero.
Forty-nine companies moved some or all of their operations to New Jersey. Fourrelocated some employees to Connecticut, and 17 moved to areas of New York State outside the city. Several companies based overseas withdrew their employees to those countries.
With its constant foot traffic, the trade center's concourse was a powerful draw for retailers, including several dozen independents and 57 chain stores, like Cole Haan and J. Crew. Only a handful of the chain stores, including Nine West and Duane Reade, have opened new stores in Lower Manhattan over the past year, although several opened outlets elsewhere in the metropolitan area.
The problems the businesses have encountered this year are as varied as their products. Relocation posed a particular problem for independent retailers like Minas Polychronakis, whose shoe-repair store had thrived on the trade center's perpetual tide of shoppers. He says he will probably never find a location that is its equal.
Other companies have struggled to do business after having records destroyed. Everything from legal contracts to client lists went missing in the rubble. Some of the records were essential to prove that the companies even existed for grant applications and insurance claim settlements. Indeed, a year later, many companies remain entangled in red tape. Some are locked in legal battles with insurers who have been reluctant to pay claims or make advances without proof of the companies' assets.
World Trade Center Dental, the only dentists in the complex, considered shutting down when it lost its medical records. Then a consultant revealed that he had fished a computer diskette from the trash -- with most of the firm's patient information on it. 
"I was ready to quit, but we kept getting calls from patients encouraging us to go on," said Dr. Angelo Longo, one of the group's four dentists. 
Many small-business owners complain that they have not been fairly compensated for their losses and are angry at the city and state for classing them with other downtown businesses when handing out grants.
"We are a distinct group, because our offices were completely destroyed," said Michael Koulouroudis, the owner of an import-export company and the leader of a small-business advocacy group. "Yet we find ourselves on the same footing as businesses that were a few blocks away and were just shut for a few weeks."
Like many other former trade center tenants, Mr. Koulouroudis has faced a peculiar problem. Eager for help, he is also reluctant to draw too much attention to his needs, fearing that his clients may smell failure and bolt. As a result, Mr. Koulouroudis said, he is sometimes shy about acknowledging that he now works from home.
"Image is extremely important. That's why we were there," he said of his former offices at the trade center.
All the former tenants have grappled with some form of emotional trauma from the attacks, from lasting grief to the lingering anxieties of those who awoke to find their offices gone. To get some sense of the range and nature of these experiences, The Times focused on five of the more than 500 companies that have spent the past year trying to rebuild their business lives.

Murray Surety Bonds
Margo Murray and Sonia Espinoza sat at a conference table at the office of a friend of a friend in Berkeley Heights, N.J. In front of them lay all their professional belongings: a new yellow legal pad and a pen.
It was Monday, Sept. 17, less than a week after the towers' collapse. Although still dazed, both women hoped the workday routine would return normalcy to their lives. The only problem was that their company, Murray Surety Bonds, like hundreds of other businesses at the trade center, had lost all its records, even its backed-up data, making the return to business for the two-person firm virtually impossible.
For many of the businesses, the only things to survive the collapse were millions of sheets of paper that fluttered to the ground only to be scooped up and thrown away in the aftermath. Business owners would have seemed callous asking rescue workers to stop their desperate dig for human remains to collect the papers. Yet without the files, many businesses lost decades worth of records. They were suddenly and entirely dependent on the shaken memories of their employees.
The women sat silently for a few minutes. Then Mrs. Espinoza, seven months pregnant, her belly pressed against the table, remembered the name of a lawyer they once dealt with. She grabbed the pen and wrote down the name. Ms. Murray remembered another name and wrote it down. The company had several thousand clients and business associates. By day's end, they had written down the names of about 20. 
Over the next few weeks, every workday in the barren, borrowed space began with the same brainstorming session. Sometimes they learned of bonds when a lawyer would call out of the blue to close an account, and they would excitedly ask him to fax a copy of the entire file.
A year later, they have located all but 90 of their 2,000 clients, whose premiums the company continues to pay.
The office's newest arrivals, in addition to a framed photo of Mrs. Espinoza's infant son, are two file drawers nearly full of thin manila files.
"Look at all we've got," Ms. Murray said. "It's amazing."

Intera Corp.
His old long-distance phone bills had to be somewhere in the mess of files he had strewn across his carpet, Meyer Feig later recalled.
He had been searching for several days. Without those bills, it would be impossible to apply for a $10,000 grant to help restore his business, Intera Corp., the computer staffing firm he had operated on the 18th floor of the south tower. Even if he found them, Mr. Feig remembers thinking last October, what would $10,000 do to help reconstruct a $900,000-a-year business?
And how many other grants would he have to secure? Each one would require him to call grant or loan officers. He had already had his fill of business-recovery forums, consultations with his bank, number-crunching sessions with his accountant, and the hassle of coaxing business records from swamped phone and utility companies.
"When you first sit down with a grant application, it's like you're sitting down for a final exam or the SAT's," Mr. Feig said recently. "Actually, it's really worse -- there's so much riding on it.'
Mr. Feig was beginning to run the gantlet that many business owners had to survive after the towers' collapse. The city, state and federal governments, as well as private foundations and a microlender, were offering grants or loans. But each required a different application, and grant administrators were asking for documents that everyone knew had been lost. Business owners spent weeks obtaining original paperwork from various public offices.
For Mr. Feig, the process became so arduous that on three occasions he resolved to quit applying. Eventually, however, he completed seven applications, driven to rebuild a business he had been operating on his family's behalf for five years. To date, he has received $45,000 in grants. He anticipates $53,000 more.
But he said the biggest payoff had been helping other small businesses to secure their own grants. He has founded an association of former businesses of the World Trade Center, and the 75 members have come to believe, he said, that there is some peace of mind, if not strength, in numbers.
Mr. Feig said he found it therapeutic "being with other people who've gone through the same experience, the same frustrations, the same concerns and issues."

Cornucopia
When Larry Fox opened Cornucopia, his health food store, in the World Trade Center in 1977, it was a pioneering move. The complex was new and untested, and shops like Cornucopia were still a novelty.
The store went on to become very successful. But now, Cornucopia is one of at least 39 businesses in the complex that have not been able to resurrect themselves. Some have gone under because a key executive died in the attack, others because they lost equipment they could not afford to replace. In Mr. Fox's case, he is unwilling to start over at age 65 and is trying to find an existing business to buy.
Mr. Fox remembers struggling in Cornucopia's early years, leaving his home in Melville on Long Island at 5 a.m. each morning to open the store. It was along a corridor near the south tower, between Minas Shoe Repair, which was still there last Sept. 11, and M. H. Lamston & Company, the defunct five-and-dime store chain that left years before.
Toward the end, however, many stores on the concourse were replaced by fancier retailers, and the mall became one of the country's most lucrative shopping centers.
Cornucopia grew to reap annual sales exceeding $1 million. Vitamins were the biggest seller, but the store also carried whole-wheat wraps, salads, health shakes and organic coffee. Mr. Fox spent $250,000 to spruce up his 1,900-square-foot space not long before the collapse.
"It was my life," Mr. Fox, 65, recalled recently. "I had a great store and a great manager, and I didn't have to kill myself."
Mr. Fox did not know the names of most of his customers, but after Sept. 11 he recognized many faces on the missing-persons fliers. "I saw so many people that I knew," he said. "I'm not a crier, but I cried."
After Sept. 11, Mr. Fox helped some of his 12 employees find jobs with his wholesalers. But he himself is more tanned and rested than he wants to be. If he has no deal in place by the Sept. 30 deadline for applying for a Small Business Administration loan, he will have to look for a job, he said.
Mr. Fox still has the Battery Park City condominium he bought in 1986, but he said he can no longer afford the other trappings that went along with his six-figure income and has traded his Jaguar for a Toyota.
Still, he said, "whatever hand is dealt me, I'll have to accept it."

Clearforest
On Sept. 12, Barak Pridor went back to work. He spent the day trekking up and down Manhattan to find temporary space for his company, Clearforest, a software firm. On Sept. 13, Mr. Pridor and his staff contacted each of their customers, telling them, "Clearforest is still alive." On Sept. 14, they were operating from new offices and buying new supplies.
By late fall, the company had added the federal government to a client list that already included General Motors, the World Bank and Kodak. Now, a year later, the company has 25 employees -- five more than it did when the towers collapsed. It has moved to a permanent office near Union Square that has 6,200 square feet -- 600 more than the old office in the north tower.
Dozens of companies dissolved after the terrorist attack.
But Mr. Pridor's company is one of several that actually grew in the following year, thanks in part to a product that was bound to do well in a more complicated world: software that can read 18 languages including Arabic, distill core information from vast numbers of documents, and aid in the response to terrorism.
Mr. Pridor is an Israeli who moved from Tel Aviv two years ago. He credits some of his resolve to having had previous encounters with terrorism.
"Being an Israeli doesn't make you more resilient," Mr. Pridor said. "But you know what's going to follow the trauma. The nightmares, the need to be around somebody all the time, the need to be listened to."
He knew he needed to both push and pull to get Clearforest through. When some of his employees refused to report to work on Sept. 14, the Friday following the attack, he was the iron-fisted boss who insisted on prompt arrival. But that day he brought in a clinical psychologist to talk to everyone. In the months after, he patiently listened to his employees recounting their escape from the melting towers "hundreds of times."
"Working was actually very therapeutic," said Karin Herrmann, one of the company's lawyers, who walked down the stairs from the company's 47th floor office the day of the attacks.

R. S. Properties
For Rolen Sabet, finding a new office for his R. S. Property Company was not so much a matter of fear, cost or convenience as of principle.
"It was an honor, a pleasure to be in such a building," Mr. Sabet, 71, said of the trade center, where he worked on the 46th floor for almost 28 years, importing and exporting car parts and later managing real estate -- sometimes with his brother or a son to help. "If I move to another, smaller building, it looks that they threw me out of my house and put me in a smaller apartment."
So in April, after a disappointing tour of Lower Manhattan office buildings, Mr. Sabet settled into an office on the 44th floor of the Empire State Building. "When your number is up," he explained, "it's up."
Mr. Sabet's pluck may be striking, but it is not unique. While most trade center tenants ended up in low-profile buildings, eight relocated to the Empire State Building. Seven are at One Penn Plaza. Three moved to the Woolworth Building.
After the attacks, 32 business owners or managers are still working from home. Mr. Sabet tried this, but found work could not compete with the temptation to have coffee with friends in his neighborhood of Forest Hills, Queens, or take a nap after lunch.
Even with the new office, where a photograph of the trade center sits by a window with sweeping views of Lower Manhattan, Mr. Sabet does not have much hope of truly reviving his businesses, including the Auto Imperial Company and R.S. Property Company. That is not to say he is giving up.
"If I don't have much business," he said, with a survivor's smile and a wave at the window, "I have at least a good view here."

GRAPHIC:  The data shown in the maps, charts and tables on these pages were compiled by 15 reporters, graphic artists and researchers who set out to learn what happened to the tenants of the World Trade Center in the year since it was destroyed. The team used tenant lists provided by the Port Authority, by the landlord, Silverstein Properties, and by Westfield America, which operated the concourse mall. Relocations were plotted on the basis of more than 900 interviews and data collected from the United States Small Business Administration, the Empire State Development Corporation, the New York City Department of Business Services, the World Trade Center Small Business Association, the World Trade Center Tenants Association, TenantWise.com, the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council and Seedco. The task of identifying the precise number of trade center tenants was complicated by the destruction of the official business records for the complex. The surviving records, which had been maintained off-site, did not list many subtenants and included the names of many other tenants who had previously moved from the buildings. But the number of office tenants appears to have been somewhere between 600 and 700. That estimate does not include the hundreds of commodities brokers who operated from the trading floor at 4 World Trade Center or the dozens of companies and organizations whose only presence at the buildings was their rental of space for storage or equipment. The Times was able to locate 506 tenants from the lists. Another 65 of the listed tenants could not be found. Of those that were located, 39 businesses have either ceased operations or have shut down their New York offices. Another 57 tenants were identified as affiliates of chain retailers. Their relocations, if any, were not plotted because in most cases new store openings were not made in direct response to the demise of a trade center outlet.
