HEADLINE: AMERICAN CULTURE; 
And Now, Back to Our Regularly Scheduled Programming

BYLINE:  By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
IN the uncertain days after 9/11, one of the few things asserted with absolute certainty was that our culture would be indelibly altered. A year later, very little has changed.
 Irony thrives. Gratuitous film and television violence rules. And instead of a kinder, gentler, more high-minded society, we are given Anna Nicole Smith lolling about her bedroom, Playboy bunnies doing "Fear Factor" stunts, and celebrities boxing. 
 Though movies like "Collateral Damage" with Arnold Schwarzenegger were initially postponed, the big screen has since been awash in blow-'em-up extravaganzas, including "The Sum of All Fears," a No. 1 hit that showed us the nuclear destruction of Baltimore. While Barney, the annoying purple dinosaur, is trying to make a comeback in what many predicted would be a more family-oriented environment, prurient shows like "The Bachelor" and "Meet My Folks" have turned sexual commerce into prime-time entertainment, and Darwinian competition and sophomoric mean-spiritedness continue to thrive on "Dog Eat Dog" and "Spy TV." 
The glossy magazines are once again filled with pieces deconstructing J. Lo's wardrobe and Tom Cruise's love life; shark stories were a summer staple again on television; and Ashleigh Banfield has returned from her peregrinations in the Middle East to report on child kidnappings in the United States.
Thus far, the events of Sept. 11 and the current economic downturn have not produced a cultural U-turn, but simply turned up the heat on trends, both bad and good, that were already on simmer. More car-wreck TV. More escapist fluff. But also, perhaps, a waning of political correctness (even Eminem's last album failed to elicit the usual howls of protest that have accompanied his work in the past) and a growing impatience with the sort of suburban angst and urban Seinfeldian navel-gazing that was so fashionable in the 90's.
More lasting cultural changes, however, will not be visible for years. Because we still do not know where the war on terrorism is headed, we do not know whether 2001 will be seen in retrospect as a truly epochal year, as Arthur C. Clarke predicted (though in a different context) in his sci-fi classic, or whether the much ballyhooed New Normal will turn out to be very much like the Old Normal, as it has so far.
As for the changes that occur eventually, they will not be the boldfaced ones commentators were so quick to predict, but more subtle ones dealing with the subliminal mutations that 9/11 produced in the national consciousness. After all, that day rocked many of the preconceptions that have informed the country's identity since its inception: from a sense of Manifest Destiny and historical immunity, conferred by the blessings of America's geography (bounded on either side by oceans and far from the bloody battlefields of the Old World), to an often Pollyanna-ish faith in progress and technology. A new sense of vulnerability, wrought by 9/11, is sure to ripple through artists' work, as will a new awareness of limitations, galvanized not only by the terrorist attacks but by current economic woes as well.
HOW will this state of affairs affect artists' work in the long term? The horrors of World War I gave birth to the fragmentations and elisions of modernism. Political adversity and turmoil in Eastern Europe and Latin America led to the blossoming of magical realism. And the cold war and nuclear fears promoted black humor, noirish drama and sci-fi nightmares. But while the social confusions of the Vietnam era gave rise to a golden age of filmmaking in America, many novelists turned, turtlelike, to solipsistic mappings of their own inner weather; in the 60's, they started feeling overwhelmed by a reality that, in Philip Roth's words, stupefies, sickens, infuriates and acts as "a kind of embarrassment to one's own meager imagination" -- and this, with nothing remotely approaching the shock of seeing New York's tallest buildings collapse on live television into a mass cemetery.
It's too soon to tell whether the fallout from 9/11 will goad some artists into an imaginative retreat -- withdrawing, as Matisse did during World War II, into the serenity of a Nice hotel room (stocked with tropical birds and plants), where he could produce his prettily colored fantasies of a more idyllic world -- or whether it will push more of them into tackling broader social canvases. It's too soon to tell whether it will encourage a more pared-down, self-abnegating prose style -- similar to the chastened one that Edmund Wilson says the Civil War helped promote -- or whether it will nurture more expansive, hyperbolic narratives that attempt to capture the surreality and horror of a world in which men fly airplanes into buildings in order to kill as many people as they can. 
Will artists remain true to their own internal compasses or increasingly feel pressure to create willfully relevant works? Will the defiant antiestablishment poses of bands like Rage Against the Machine lose their allure, or will the bubble-gum pop of Britney Spears and 'N Sync be renounced as trivial and dated? Will the recent flood of war movies like "Black Hawk Down," "Behind Enemy Lines" and "Hart's War" (which went into production long before 9/11) continue, or will people flock in growing numbers to escapist comedies and musicals, as they did during the Depression?
Sept. 11 changed the context in which we live, and so it percolates beneath artists' choices and audiences' expectations in myriad, unseen ways. It's there in Bruce Springsteen's new songs memorializing the victims, but it's also there in the lumbering suspense of the Mel Gibson thriller "Signs," which plays to our anxiety about the unknown, and the Jodie Foster movie "The Panic Room," which suggests that there is no place safe to hide.The title of the second film installment of the Tolkien trilogy, "The Two Towers," has taken on an unwanted collateral meaning, and in the case of the Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine musical "Into the Woods," the plot -- involving an angry giantess who menaces the show's fairy tale community -- now resonates with new associations. When the show was first staged 15 years ago, it reverberated with the threat of the AIDS crisis; today, it is terrorism that lurks in the giantess's shadow.
NOT surprisingly, Americans' responses to art, in the first year of the 9/11 era, have been highly contradictory. On one hand, the Grammy Award-winning "O Brother, Where Art Thou?" soundtrack, with its gentle, down-home celebration of American roots music, enjoyed an unexpected success; on the other, "The Eminem Show," from Detroit's bad boy of rap, sold more than five million copies. And while the last year has produced a flood of jingoistic country music tunes like "Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue" and "Where the Stars and Stripes and the Eagle Fly," it has also produced hip-hop songs like "My Country" and "Home of the Brave" that question the war in Afghanistan and the American way of life -- protest songs that mark a sharp departure from rap's recent focus on sex and money and a return of sorts to more socially conscious roots.
With movies, television and Broadway shows, it's often less a question of what artists are thinking or what the public wants than what second-guessing producers think will sell. Given the shrinking economy, there is now an even more pronounced tendency to go for the tried and true (franchise sequels, star vehicles and remakes of old hits) and low-cost programming like reality TV or, as in the new version of "The Beverly Hillbillies," a combination of recycling and reality TV all in one.
In the wake of the blockbuster success of "Spider-Man" this spring, studios have jumped on the comic-book bandwagon; there are more than a dozen superhero movies in development or production, including ones about the Incredible Hulk, the Fantastic Four, Daredevil, Iron Man, Catwoman and Ghost Rider. Much like the Harry Potter franchise, they are movies meant to generate good clean escapist fun, while dramatizing President Bush's good vs. evil language and neatly evading the complexities of depicting the real world.
Spy movies, which run the gamut from the ancient James Bond franchise to the anti-Bondian "XXX" to spoofs like "Undercover Brother," are also enjoying a renaissance not seen since the heyday of the cold war. In fact, at the very moment when the C.I.A and F.B.I. are coming under fire for intelligence failures, their operatives are being portrayed by an array of high-priced movie stars. Ben Affleck ("The Sum of All Fears"), Matt Damon ("The Bourne Identity"), Chris Rock ("Bad Company") and Al Pacino ("The Recruit") all play C.I.A. operatives, while Tommy Lee Jones ("The Hunted"), Tom Hanks ("Catch Me if You Can"), Edward Norton ("Red Dragon") and Antonio Banderas ("Ecks vs. Sever") have been cast as G-men.
The other thing Hollywood and Broadway producers have decided Americans want is nostalgia -- the logic being that people in times of trouble will gravitate toward comfort entertainment that reminds them of simpler, happier times. In much the same way that "American Idol" recalls the old Ted Mack "Amateur Hour" and Ed McMahon's "Star Search," the candy-colored Broadway musical "Hairspray" and the much hyped new NBC show "American Dreams" draw on fond remembrances of the "American Bandstand" era.
Broadway, which gave this year's Tony for best musical to the thoroughly insipid "Thoroughly Modern Millie," has a lineup of forthcoming shows tilted toward revivals, including "Man of La Mancha," "Gypsy," "Flower Drum Song" (albeit with a revamped book), "Little Shop of Horrors," "Nine," "Dinner at Eight" and "Our Town."
Television is in full-time travel mode as well. After a Carol Burnett special drew a startling 30 million viewers last fall, television executives began hustling out tributes to old favorites like "The Honeymooners," "The Mary Tyler Moore Show," "Laverne and Shirley," Bob Hope and Bill Cosby, as well as some truly lame exercises in recycling like "The Rerun Show," which features actors recreating episodes of television shows like "The Partridge Family" and "Saved by the Bell."
This fall, ABC and the WB network are both scheduling shows in which grown-ups travel back to their high school days in the 1980's. NBC and Fox are both doing family-based shows set in the 60's, a more innocent era in many ways, but also one informed by such traumas as the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, the Cuban missile crisis and the Vietnam War. And CBS is working on an assortment of made-for-TV movies about such 50's and 60's icons as Lucille Ball, Jackie Gleason, and Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis.
In the last year, old favorites like "Friends" (which blithely tried to act as if 9/11 never happened) have thrived, as have crime series like the "Law and Order" franchise and the forensic drama "C.S.I." And a host of new crime and medical shows are on the way this fall, including "Without a Trace," a procedural drama about the Missing Persons Squad of the F.B.I.
The appeal of such shows, particularly in unsettled times when the threats to our nation feel both intractable and amorphous, is akin to the appeal of old-fashioned detective stories: something terrible, be it a crime or an accident, occurs, and then order is reassuringly restored through the application of reason and expertise. A similar sense of control and safety underlies the growing popularity of home improvement and "fix-it" shows, which, like cookbooks, appeal to the post-9/11 "cocooning" impulse.
In the last year, a lot of art was also produced in direct response to the terrorist attacks of 9/11: an outpouring of photographs, drawings and collages, exhibited around New York City; poems, reminiscences and meditations by well-known and not so well-known writers, collected in an assortment of books; songs by Paul McCartney, Neil Young and a bevy of country music singers; and a variety of theatrical works and performance pieces based on the events of that day.
This month, the Toronto Film Festival will screen the film version of Anne Nelson's 9/11 play, "The Guys," and "11'09"01," a series of short films from 11 directors including Sean Penn, Claude LeLouche, Ken Loach and Danis Tanovic. John Adams's piece for chorus and orchestra "On the Transmigration of Souls," with a text drawn from cellphone transcripts and firsthand accounts of 9/11, will premiere later this month at the New York Philharmonic, and Neil LaBute's new play, "The Mercy Seat," a drama of adultery set in Manhattan on September 12, 2001, will open later this fall.
THERE was a raw eloquence and immediacy to many of the amateur artworks produced in response to 9/11 -- some were exhibited in gallery shows opened to contributions from the general public -- and like the many homemade shrines that sprang up around the city, these works attested to the therapeutic and documentary uses of art, while pointing to a democratization of the cultural machinery.
Other artistic projects, however, reeked of exploitation or, at the very least, bad taste. In a performance piece at the Museum of New Art in Detroit, a New York artist, Amy Shapiro, poured flour over herself (to symbolize ashes), then wrapped herself in an American flag and donned a gas mask. And in a new video, which MTV declined to air, the metal group Disturbed used apocalyptic images of buildings crumbling and bursting into flame -- images that seemed deliberately evocative of the destruction wreaked on Lower Manhattan last September.
Such works raise important questions (first addressed by the critic T. W. Adorno in reference to the Holocaust) about the morality of artists' trying to depict an "unimaginable ordeal": while art can bear witness to history, it can also trivialize and demean it.
Thus far, much of the art created in direct response to 9/11 has been thoroughly mediocre. With only a year's time, it is difficult to achieve detachment or understanding of that terrible day, and many rapid-response works have tended either to reiterate, heavy-handedly, what we all know -- that the firefighters were brave, that the victims who died will be missed -- or to issue facile calls for transcendence.
Bruce Springsteen's hit album "The Rising," while heartfelt in its calls for redemption, sounds trite and curiously abstract, compared with his best work of the past. "The Guys," by the first-time playwright Anne Nelson, is similarly well-intentioned, but often labored and sentimental in effect. And the Maya Angelou poem "How Do We Heal Ourselves?" is little but a maudlin greeting card verse about heroic acts healing "a wounded heart."
No doubt artistic treatments of 9/11 will grow increasingly metaphorical in the years to come.
As literature about the Holocaust, Hiroshima and AIDS shows, the earliest responses to a traumatic event tend to be autobiographical accounts that pay witness to history; the fictional works that ensue tend to evolve from somewhat didactic, explanatory accounts into stylized ones, in which the tragedy is universalized, or woven into the fabric of ordinary life, as ripples from the event, rather than the event itself, assume center stage.
It will take time -- and emotional distance -- for artists to achieve perspective on Sept. 11, 2001. Tolstoy wrote "War and Peace" some 60 years after Napoleon's invasion of Russia. Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem," memorializing World War II, was not heard until 1961. And John Corigliano's "Symphony No. 1," the so-called AIDS Symphony, did not premiere until 1990, a decade after the composer began losing friends to the illness.
In the case of last year's terrorist attacks, novelists, filmmakers and other artists are still gestating or working on projects informed by 9/11, trying, in Don DeLillo's words, to "understand what this day has done to us," and to give "memory, tenderness and meaning to all that howling space" at ground zero.

HEADLINE: AN ALTERED LANDSCAPE; 
The Capital as 3 Cities, Each One Now a Fortress

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE 184 deaths at the Pentagon were modest compared with the toll at the World Trade Center, and the damage did not spread beyond part of one building. But no other city was more heavily subjected than Washington to the apocalyptic refrain of pundits and politicians that everything had been changed by the terrorist attacks, and that nothing would ever be the same again.
 Washington is really not just one city. It is three. The world knows political Washington, where policy is made by the prominent. Americans of all ages know symbolic Washington, where they come to witness their government and honor its marbled past. Only Washingtonians themselves know the city where hundreds of thousands who have never been mentioned on television or in a guidebook live and work. 
 In all three Washingtons, much has changed but much has also drifted back to where it used to be, or never changed at all. Alice M. Rivlin, a Brookings Institution fellow and former vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve Board, said, "I think much less has changed than many of us, including myself, thought would change at the time it happened." She said there was no sense of a need to "have a whole new look at how our government operates, or how we shore up our economy." Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, said: "This was not a Pearl Harbor. It was a jolting, terrible moment, but not one which changed our lives in depth."
Fewer tourists have visited. Security has been tightened in public areas, evident in an epidemic of roadway barriers, monstrous pseudo flower pots, yellow tape, wire fences and shabby guard shacks growing up around federal buildings and monuments.
Some of the most profound changes have been less visible. Jessica Tuchman Mathews, the president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said: "We did have this illusion of living apart from, of being different from the world, of being a city on the hill. Technology and globalization had turned that into an illusion, and 9/11 tore that away."
For many ordinary Washingtonians, there is a continual sense of anxiety. To some, the changes have been merely inconvenient: being barred from getting up to go to the bathroom on a shuttle flight to or from New York, for example. To others, like waiters or security guards, the changes have altered lives. Some are unemployed, the others working compulsory overtime. 
More guards and fewer tourists are seen. For security, much of the capital has been disfigured. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the retired senator, said, "Capitol Hill looks like a crime scene." He warned: "You don't want to manifest fear in your public places. We have defensive concerns, yes, but we are not fearful."
In political Washington early last September, President Bush seemed to lose the initiative after Senator James M. Jeffords's support gave the Democrats a Senate majority. Norman J. Ornstein, a Congressional scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, noted: "We were heading at Labor Day last year to a major confrontation over budget issues. But it wasn't at all clear that Bush and the Republicans would emerge stronger."
But after Sept. 11, the president reached out to Democrats and they embraced his determination and leadership. Carla A. Hills, a Republican trade expert, said the Bush presidency was transformed. "His popularity was in the middle range" before the attack, she said, but "the real turning point was his speech to the joint houses of Congress" on Sept. 20.
Mr. Ornstein recalled that evening as offering "an image that suggested a radical change -- President Bush coming down off the podium and embracing Tom Daschle."
BUT the bipartisan spirit did not last until Christmas, except over foreign issues. Donna Brazile, who managed Al Gore's presidential campaign, said: "For a moment we went through a great renewal. Party labels didn't matter, race, background, almost as if it was a new religion." Now, she said, "We're back drawing up partisan lines again."
Inside the executive branch, influence has shifted toward the military and toward law enforcement. That has brought a concern about threats to civil liberties -- a concern that Dick Armey, the conservative House majority leader, shares with the American Civil Liberties Union.
Catherine E. Rudder, a professor of public policy at George Mason University, said, however, that those concerns were less prominent among ordinary Americans. "One thing 9/11 did was to make Americans a little less reflexively supportive of civil liberty," she said. "That has emboldened the administration." She cited closed immigration hearings, and prisoners being denied attorneys.
But Ms. Rivlin struck a more cautious note, saying that while concerns might be appropriate, "To say that liberties are imminently threatened would be alarmist."
The weak economy has been a part of the problem for symbolic Washington, one of the reasons the tourist industry has suffered, though fear was probably a bigger element. Some local officials contend tourism has rebounded, but Tom Mack, head of the Tourmobile system that takes visitors from one site to another, said, "Clearly our ridership is down, significantly down." 
The only sites that keep good track of visitors are the Smithsonian Institution's museums. They had 2,844,615 visitors in August, down 7 percent from last year, after many months of 20 percent declines. At the world's most visited museum, the National Air and Space Museum, the drop-off in April, the peak month for school visits to Washington, was 52 percent. 
Two of the most popular tourist destinations, the Capitol and the White House, are no longer easy to visit. The White House is closed to everyone except school groups scheduled in advance. Access to the Capitol is much more limited than it used to be, and the alternatives are getting a representative's or senator's office to organize a staff-led tour, or to line up for one of a few hundred daily tickets for a guided tour. 
FOR most permanent working Washingtonians, the changes may not have been dramatic, but they matter. Dwight R. Bowman, president of Local 2463 of the American Federation of Government Employees at the Smithsonian, said the aftermath of the attacks "made the people that I represent much more anxious, not only worrying about a terrorist attack." He added, "Tempers are much shorter, there is a feeling that they are underappreciated." For security workers, he said, things are worse. Compulsory overtime means "they are unable to schedule their lives, plan day care, go to school at night, work a part-time job." 
Even when the immediate burdens are no more than wearing identification cards or passing through metal detectors on the way back from lunch, said Larry Drake, a government employees' union official at the Department of Labor, there is the added stress of feeling like a target. "You figure you're at ground zero," he said. 
Patricia McGuire, the president of Trinity College here, said she thought people in the city now "are more cautious, a little more suspicious, more watchful of neighbors or people who don't look like us." She added, "People are walking around with this low-level headache because of relentless warnings that something is going to happen." 
Those problems don't compare to those of workers in the tourist industry. Tom Snyder of the hotel and restaurant workers union said as many as half its 5,400 members here were out of work last fall. On one day the union distributed five tons of food to its workers. Even though things have picked up quicker than "anyone would have expected last September," he said, "we have a permanent job loss of 500 to 1,000 members." 
For those outside government, Ms. McGuire said, Sept. 11 made the federal presence much more dominant. With street closings and opaque warnings, she said: "The F.B.I., the Secret Service and everyone else took over the city. We were reminded, very rudely at times, that this is not our city at all."
But she also rejoiced in a change that did not happen; her college, like others here, worried that fearful students would stay away from a terrorist target city. She said, "In fact we're going to enroll the largest freshman class in 20 years." 
There is one unarguable change that affects all three Washingtons -- the way the city looks.
Richard L. Friedman, the Cambridge, Mass., developer, headed a National Capital Planning Commission study that this summer produced designs to show that security from truck bombs was attainable without scarring the city if architects and not bureaucrats designed the barriers. He acknowledged that the security plague began some years ago, but was "catapulted into orbit" by Sept. 11. 
"To me," he said, "It's appalling that the capital of the free world looks like a fortress or like a third-world country. We have this image of a nation in fear which is unacceptable." For all three Washingtons, he said, "You can't cut off arteries on the city and have the city function."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The look of Washington today, with its visible signs of increased security. (Photographs by Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IMMIGRANTS; 
Going by 'Joe,' Not 'Yussef,' but Still Feeling Like an Outcast

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich. 

 BODY:
AT a recent meeting of the Wednesday Club, two dozen Arab-American businessmen traded bawdy jokes across a table laden with plates of fettoosh and flaming platters of broiled meats, until Ahmad Chebbani interrupted with an announcement.
 "If you're a green card holder, you have to file a change of address within 10 days," Mr. Chebbani, a tax accountant, read from an e-mail message he had received that afternoon. "It's an old law. Now they just want to implement it." 
 Someone muttered something about how overwhelming this would be in Arizona and California, places flooded with immigrants from Mexico. 
"No," corrected Nasser Beydoun, executive director of the American Arab Chamber of Commerce. "It's just for Arabs."
For the men of the Wednesday Club, as for many in the nation's growing Arab and Muslim communities, this has been the year the American dream descended into nightmare. What began as a backlash of hate crimes immediately after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has stretched through months of suspicion and losing friends. Domestic and foreign policies, especially on Afghanistan, Iraq and Israel and particularly those about civil liberties, have exacerbated feelings of alienation.
"It's like abuse," said Nazih Saad, 41, an engineering consultant. "In a bad marriage, if a husband abuses the wife, she starts to feel she deserves the beating. That's the same thing, you start to feel there must be something horrible about being Arab."
Here in Dearborn, a Detroit suburb where a third of the 100,000 residents are of Middle Eastern descent, the largest concentration of Arab-Muslims in the country, the scars are evident. 
For nine years, the Wednesday Club has been a monthly respite, a night out to catch up with old schoolmates between puffs on imported cigars and belts of arak, the Lebanese liquor.
But now, like most everything here, the social club has taken on a more serious tone, as a support system and information network for a group increasingly under stress and scrutiny.
They still tell jokes, poking equal fun at Attorney General John Ashcroft and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat. But they also swap stories of being singled out at airports -- or of choosing driving vacations to avoid the humiliation at airports. They share concerns about children who have surprised them lately with questions like "Are we Arab?" and struggle together over whether to change their names from Yussef to Joe, Muhammed to Mike, as so many neighbors and colleagues have done. 
They talk of buying homes in the old country, just in case, and imagine, only half-laughing, playing cards at an internment camp somewhere in Louisiana.
With 750 Middle Eastern immigrants having been detained without explanation, and at least twice that number interviewed at random by the authorities, many here find themselves wondering who is listening in on their phone lines, and whether they might be the next to be named an enemy combatant.
"After Sept. 11, we worried about being targeted, being suspected," said Hassan Jaber, deputy director of the Arab Community Center for Economic and Social Services, known as Access. "A year has made it clear that Arab-Americans are the targets, Muslim-Americans are the targets." 
Complaints to the Council on American-Islamic Relations -- from verbal abuse to violence, job loss to denial of access to public facilities -- increased threefold this year, to 1,516. This summer, nearly half the 945 Muslims that the group surveyed said their lives had deteriorated over the last year. A poll in May by the Arab American Institute Foundation found 40 percent of Arab-Americans knew someone who had been discriminated against since Sept. 11; one in five -- mainly the young, Muslim or foreign-born -- said they had experienced discrimination themselves.
Some community leaders do see an upside: the public's increased interest in Islam has allowed them to forge bonds with other faith groups. Apathy has given way to activism, with a surge in voter registration and turnout motivated by the perceived threat to civil liberties. 
Still, many say they feel doubly victimized, first suffering along with the rest of the nation during the attacks, now feeling hated both by Americans and by Muslims abroad.
Ismael Ahmed, executive director of Access, said requests for mental health services were up at least 10 percent. "It's not just that more people need more help, it's what they're saying when they come in to get help," he explained. "People suffering from depression talk about racism. People suffering from psychosis, the person chasing them around is F.B.I. or C.I.A."
For some, the impact has been more direct -- and more devastating. Ahmed Esa lost his job. Dean Hachem lost his profit margin. Saleh Almansoop lost his father.
Ali Almansoop's name will not be read at any of the memorials on the anniversary of 9/11. His picture will not appear among victims' photos in the newspapers. Instead, it tops the mantel in the modest home here where Saleh, 26, a restaurant dishwasher and busboy, is now responsible for the $1,500 mortgage, a $420-a-month car lease, and the care of his mother and three younger siblings, who arrived recently from Yemen.
Ali Almansoop, who had lived in America for 32 years, was killed Sept. 19 in one of a dozen murders nationwide attributed to anti-Muslim sentiment after the attacks. Among the victims were Sikhs mistaken for Muslims. Brent Seever, who was convicted of the shooting in June, said he was incensed at Mr. Almansoop's relationship with his former girlfriend, but also told the police, "I was motivated by all this terroristic activity."
Saleh Almansoop said of his father's slaying: "Same terrorists, this is the same. Same New York, same killed my dad. I lose my dad, I lose everything."
LIKE Ali Almansoop, Ahmed Esa came from Yemen without his wife and children, in 1976. He worked as a welder in a factory for 15 years -- until Sept. 12, when his boss sent him home, screaming, "Go pray," and, "Go to your leader." Mr. Esa is now suing the company, IW&S.
Paul Rokoczy, the company president, said that he sent Mr. Esa home mainly because he had little for him to do that day, and because "the religious activity bothered me, because of the bombing."
Mr. Esa, 53, refused to return the following week. He eventually found a job as a security guard.
Dean Hachem had always felt welcome in the heavily Jewish suburb of Orchard Lake, where he opened his restaurant, the Sheik, in 1996. 
But on Sept. 11, an e-mail message spread like cholera saying that employees at the Sheik were seen celebrating in front of the television that noon. Though security videotapes showed no such thing, the ensuing boycott has ruined Mr. Hachem's business; he is closing his second restaurant, in a nearby mall, this month; receipts are still down 30 percent at the original restaurant.
"You feel like you've been stabbed," he said on one recent dinner hour, when 30 of the 39 tables sat empty. "When you get accused of something, you have nothing to do with it, you cannot focus your mind."
Such a response was expected, and perhaps inevitable, in the weeks after the attacks. What is surprising is that it has not subsided. Just last month, a woman came into Play Ball, the sporting goods store that Mohamed Odetalle owns in suburban Westland, looking for a Red Wings jersey. She left without buying, only to head for the Play Ball store in a mall across the street -- which Mr. Odetalle also owns but never works at -- where she paid $10 more for the jersey.
"I knew the lady was uncomfortable; she and her husband were whispering," Mr. Odetalle said, shrugging. Other customers, he said, have told his manager at the mall that they would rather pay extra than do business with the foreigner across the street.
Basim Alkhateeb was in his native Jordan, where he is a major in the military, on Sept. 11. He came to the United States in January to pursue a Ph.D. in electrical engineering at Oakland University. On June 20, Mr. Alkhateeb was on his way to take a final exam when, he said, an undercover police officer pulled a gun on him in suburban Waterford.
"The first question, 'Are you Arabic?' " Mr. Alkhateeb, 36, remembered. "I told him, 'Yes, I'm Arabic.' He pushed me to the ground."
Mr. Alkhateeb added: "He began to beat on my back and my leg. He still had his gun against my head and my face. I didn't understand him. I'm just waiting for his gun to explode."
Mr. Alkhateeb was not arrested; he is planning to file a lawsuit -- and to return to Jordan. "I feel we are not welcome here, everybody hates us," he said. " "It may happen in my country. It may happen in any country, but in America? It's incredible."

 The New York Times

SECTION: Section G; Column 1; A Nation Challenged; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 1299 words

HEADLINE: MEASURING RESILIENCE; 
For Many New Yorkers, a Tentative Normality

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT and MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
MAYBE it is willful ignorance, some suggest. Maybe it is the conviction that living in fear is no way to live. But one year after the attack on the World Trade Center, nearly half of all New York City residents say the event has not changed their lives.
 Those New Yorkers may find themselves thinking about it far more often than they would have imagined. They may even become teary-eyed at the memory. But most have lost no sleep, they feel comfortable in skyscrapers and they travel by subway. They say their daily routines are unchanged. 
 "I love the city, and I'm not about to hunker down in my apartment and not go anywhere," said Rebecca Press Schwartz, a 26-year-old graduate student and parent who was one of 1,008 adult New Yorkers questioned in a recent New York Times/CBS News poll. "And I honestly don't know that that would make a difference." 
"If there isn't another terrorist attack, then we're all fine," Ms. Schwartz, who lives in Washington Heights, added in an interview after the poll. "And if they smuggle a suitcase-size nuclear weapon into Manhattan, then we're all dead. Either way, I don't see much to be gained by sitting around in fear."
In the poll, conducted by telephone from Aug. 25 to 29, 48 percent of the people questioned said their lives had not changed as a result of Sept. 11. Seventy percent said their routines had returned to normal. Most said they no longer felt nervous or edgy, if they ever had, while about a quarter acknowledged that they remain anxious. Most said they had done nothing different in response to government warnings of possible new attacks.
Which is not to suggest that lives have not been touched. Sixty-one percent of those polled said that they or one of their friends knew someone who had been hurt or killed. Forty-seven percent said their lives had changed; they cited a wide variety of experiences, including the loss of jobs and income, feelings of fearfulness and a sense of new perspectives on life and a new closeness with neighbors.
While 11 percent called terrorism their biggest concern about living in the city, more than twice that many cited financial worries caused by things like the high cost of living, high rents and the economy. Among parents, 75 percent said their children had never been awakened by post-9/11 nightmares; half said theirs had never expressed concern about their own safety or that of anyone in the family.
C. R. Snyder, a professor of clinical psychology at the University of Kansas who specializes in the study of human motivation, hope, stress and coping, said the findings were consistent with some of his own. His observations of behavior after other traumatic events, he said, show that most people are remarkably resilient -- something he attributes not to denial but to hope.
"It's not that these people don't realize the depth of the tragedy and what's happened," he said in an interview. "But they realize that they have a life to live and that other people depend on them, and that there's a better use of their time than worrying about things that in all likelihood they can't control."
The poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points, found that 62 percent of New Yorkers described themselves as very concerned about another attack on the city, down from 74 percent in a poll last October. Only 35 percent said they felt safe. One in three reported thinking about Sept. 11 daily; one in five had talked about it weekly. Of those who had thought or talked about it, most said they became choked up at least some of the time.
Tony DiTomasso, a 49-year-old paramedic for New York Presbyterian Hospital, said two of his colleagues were killed at the World Trade Center that day. "I sometimes wonder what the heck made me different from those guys," he said in a follow-up interview. "And a woman parked in an ambulance next to mine: she's dead. What caused me to zig and her to zag?
"I still don't sleep well occasionally -- like last night, I woke up every half-hour. I'll look at everything every now and then, remembering the buildings coming down, and I feel it in my gut. Sometimes I'll get a pang in my heart, like when I miss the two guys that died. So whenever I'm at work, I'm still dealing with what happened."
For those less directly affected, life returned to normal more quickly. Nathan Berman, 80, a retired school principal and teacher who watched the smoke from the trade center billow up the East River toward his home on Roosevelt Island, said his everyday life had continued to be consumed by his family, his community and his work.
"It's a horrible, horrible thing," he said of Sept. 11. "But for someone who was in the Battle of the Bulge, it's not the end of the world."
Mike Davies, 56, an unemployed computer scientist who lives in Jackson Heights, Queens, said he flew to London the week after Sept. 11 and has deliberately adhered to his daily routine at home. The attack is a fait accompli, he said; nothing can be done about it. He conceded that perhaps he is blocking the memory out -- an observation others made about themselves.
"It makes it easier to go about my everyday life if I don't think about it," Ms. Schwartz said. "But it may also be that with terrorism, or the fears of terrorism, the danger is so diffuse. Maybe the fact that New York was struck once means it's a prominent target, but maybe it means that next time they'll strike somewhere else."
Thirty-three percent of those polled said they thought New York City would be a better place to live in 15 years -- down from 54 percent in October, but higher than the percentages in polls in the 1980's and 1990's. Twenty-three percent predicted that New York would be worse, up from 11 percent last fall but less than in earlier decades. Thirty-eight percent said it would be the same.
While New Yorkers remained fairly confident that the city's economy will recover from the effects of the attacks, those who said they were very confident dropped to 36 percent, down from 48 percent in June. Forty-nine percent said they believed the threat of terrorism was greater in New York than in other cities, down from 60 percent of people polled in June.
Perhaps not surprisingly, the attitudes of New Yorkers differ noticeably from those of people elsewhere in the country who were questioned as part of another New York Times/CBS News poll made public Sunday. For example, 47 percent of New Yorkers said they approved of the way President George W. Bush is handling his job, compared with 63 percent of people polled nationwide.
Fifty-seven percent of people nationally, compared with 48 percent of New Yorkers, said their life had not changed as a result of Sept. 11.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Aug. 25 to 29 with 1,008 adults across New York City. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a list of all city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each part of the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated at random to be the survey respondent.
The results have been weighted to account for household size and the number of telephone lines into each residence and to adjust for variations relating to race, Hispanic origin, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from those obtained by seeking out all adults in New York City. For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger.

HEADLINE: THE CHEF: BARBARA LYNCH; 
Pasta, the Irish-Italian Way

BYLINE:  By MARK BITTMAN; Barbara Lynch is the chef and owner of No. 9 Park in Boston.

 BODY:
HOW a working-class Irish girl from South Boston became a chef with a national reputation for making pasta is one of those virtually unanswerable nature-vs.-nurture questions. But to watch Barbara Lynch as she mixes dough with her hands and feeds it into an old pasta machine that's no bigger than a home model is to see a young woman with the soul of an Italian grandmother.
 Wouldn't she save time by using a food processor? 
 "I never tried it," she said. 
Ms. Lynch, 38, is the chef and owner of No. 9 Park in Boston, a four-year-old restaurant in a renovated 19th century mansion that sits directly across from the Massachusetts State House and Boston Common. It's a spare and stylish place, with a largely familiar, upscale country European menu: butter-poached lobster, herb-crusted lamb, crispy duck and the like. Reviews have been strong. Ms. Lynch has won a number of awards and, in Boston at least, she is a celebrity chef. 
What those reviews always mention, though, and what really keeps everyone I know who's been to No. 9 Park going back is the pasta. Ms. Lynch and her staff produce seven types of pasta most days, for specials and for regular menu items. Each is seductive, pliant and reflective of a bit of her past. Most are not only traditional pastas but also common ones: they will not sound like new recipes, nor should they. Instead it is the precise combination of ingredients in the doughs and sauces that set these dishes apart. 
For the tagliatelle here, Ms. Lynch piled flour on the counter. She mixed in a little salt, broke eggs into the center of the flour and began integrating flour and egg. The tools were: her countertop, a fork and a scraper for cleaning the counter.
But her hands did the real work, kneading, sprinkling more flour, shaping and rolling. They seemed to move unconsciously and almost effortlessly. She chatted as she worked. There was a cavalier quality to her movements that seemed to belie her gift. 
How Ms. Lynch developed this gift is not readily apparent. "I figured I'd own a sub shop or a bar in Southie," she said of her career prospects in the years following her near-graduation from high school in 1982. "I was three points shy and refused to go to summer school," she said. 
She had one favorite class, though: home economics. Her instructor had a job at a culinary school in Cambridge, and encouraged Ms. Lynch to go. She couldn't afford it, but went to a few classes anyway. Then she got a job as a server at the old-fashioned St. Botolph Club in Back Bay. At home, she found herself keeping up with the reading.
Kitchen work followed, as flowers do a bud. Ms. Lynch got a job at the Harvest, a Harvard Square restaurant that has spawned some of Boston's best chefs, including Chris Schlesinger, Lydia Shire and Jimmy Burke. From there, she went to Michaela's, where Todd English was emerging as a national "name" chef. 
"At that point," she said, "I was cooking all day, then staying up half the night reading cookbooks and trying to learn the drill." 
When Mr. English opened Olives, Ms. Lynch took some money she had saved and headed to Italy, where she cooked alongside local women in the home of a friend. It was there, she said, that "it all fell into place." 
Ms. Lynch spent three weeks abroad -- learning how to make pasta and sauces, baking bread in wood-fired ovens and roasting meats in them as the ovens cooled, preserving tomatoes and other foods but mostly, she said, "following the women around all day." 
The recipe here is one of the first she learned: an ultra-rich pasta dough cut into the ribbons known as tagliatelle, and served with a traditional Tuscan meat sauce that differs from other typical meat sauces in several ways, chief of which are its two key ingredients, chicken livers and sage.
"There must be chicken liver for this sauce to be authentic," she said, "and it must be cooked with sage." She adds to this base other meats, preferably equal amounts of ground pork, veal and lamb. Beef, she insisted, will not work: the flavor is wrong. And then she lets everything simmer.
The process of cooking is, in fact, very simple: some aromatic vegetables are sauteed in olive oil, followed by the liver and sage, some red wine that's allowed to reduce, the ground meats, stock and tomatoes. The result, with or without cream, is bold and rich, a sauce that requires a big pasta to stand up to it. 
As for that pasta -- as anyone who has made fresh pasta a few times but has not made it a daily habit -- things are not quite so simple. It takes time. As a result, I've given proportions here for making enough pasta for four people. Since the sauce will cover pasta for eight, you can make it to serve two pounds of dried pasta, or use some of the sauce on one occasion and one on another. Or you can double the fresh pasta recipe. 
Either way, if you're rolling out pasta for tagliatelle, it's best to follow Ms. Lynch's lead exactly: use your hands, and work with total confidence despite all appearances. It works.

TUSCAN MEAT SAUCE
Time: 90 minutes

1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil
1 medium onion, diced
1 celery stalk, diced
1 medium carrot, diced
5 ounces chicken livers, diced
1/4 cup chopped fresh sage
Salt and pepper
1 1/2 pounds ground meat, preferably 1/2 pound each of veal, pork and lamb
1 1/2 cups red wine
2 1/2 cups veal or chicken stock
1 1/2 cups chopped canned tomatoes
1/2 cup chopped fresh basil
1 cup heavy cream, optional
Freshly grated Parmesan cheese.
1. Put olive oil in a deep skillet and turn heat to medium-high; add onion, celery and carrot and cook, stirring occasionally, until vegetables begin to become tender. Add chicken livers and sage, sprinkle with salt and pepper and cook, stirring, until liver pieces lose their red color. 
2. Add ground meat in bits, along with more salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, again until redness is gone. Add the wine, raise heat to high, and cook until wine is almost all gone, about 15 minutes. Add stock, tomatoes and basil. Bring to a boil, then adjust heat so mixture simmers gently. Cook about 45 minutes, until mixture is dark and rich. 
3. Just before serving, stir in optional cream. Serve over tagliatelle or other pasta, topped with freshly ground black pepper and Parmesan cheese. 
Yield: 8 servings.

TAGLIATELLE
Time: 1 hour

About 2 cups all-purpose flour, more as needed
1 teaspoon salt, more for cooking noodles
2 whole eggs
3 egg yolks.
1. Combine 1 1/2 cups flour and the salt on a counter or large board, making a well in the middle. Break whole eggs into well and add the 3 yolks. Beat eggs with a fork, gradually incorporating a little flour. When mixture becomes too hard to stir with fork, use your hands. When all the flour has been mixed in, knead dough, pushing it against counter and folding it repeatedly until it is quite stiff and not at all sticky. Sprinkle with a little reserved flour. Clean your hands. Cover dough with plastic or a cloth and let it rest for about 1/2 hour. (You can store dough in refrigerator, wrapped in plastic, up to 24 hours, until you're ready to roll it out.)
2. Sprinkle counter lightly with flour. Cut off about one third of dough; wrap rest in plastic or cloth while you work. Roll dough lightly in flour, and use your hands to flatten it into a rectangle about the width of your pasta machine. Set machine to its highest (thickest) setting, and crank dough through. If it sticks, dust with more flour. Repeat. Set machine to its next thinnest setting and push dough through, adding flour again if pasta sticks. Repeat. 
3. Continue to work down the settings on machine. If dough tears badly, bunch it together and start again. Use as much flour as you need, but only in small amounts. 
4. Pass dough through machine's thinnest setting only once. (If pasta tears at thinnest setting, stop at the second-thinnest setting.) Flour dough lightly, cover it and set aside. 
5. Cut each sheet into rectangles roughly 16 inches long and as wide as the machine; trim ends to make it neat. Put pasta through machine once more, this time using the broadest (tagliatelle) cutter. Cook right away or hang strands to dry for up to a couple hours. 
6. To cook noodles, drop them into boiling salted water; they'll be done when tender, in less than 3 minutes. Toss with meat sauce and serve. 
Yield: 4 servings.

HEADLINE: $25 AND UNDER; 
In a Red Hook Diner, Cheeseburgers Are Not Enough

BYLINE:  By Sam Sifton

 BODY:
DEEP in Red Hook, Brooklyn, down Van Brunt Street, where you can smell the salt off New York Bay, there's a new diner, the Hope & Anchor. It's a neighborhood place in a neighborhood that doesn't have a lot of people, and it needs to serve a number of purposes at once.
 It's a standard-issue diner breakfast spot -- eggs served all day -- and a purveyor of lunchtime sandwiches to local artists, homesteaders and layabouts. It's also an art-world dinner spot, serving would-be Basquiats luxe tuna steaks on the cheap, and a wings-and-burgers joint for those on their way home from work or on their way out to a bar. It ought to be the sort of place where you could trade a painting, or your services as a plumber, for a nice dish of monkfish. 
 And who knows, it very well might be. The owners -- Dianna and Kenneth Munz, who also run Panino'teca 275 in Carroll Gardens, and Gary Rego -- seem always to be present in the airy, mirrored dining room. And they take seriously the notion that they should greet all those who would venture through the door and onto their black plywood floors. There is a lot of handshaking at the Hope & Anchor.
There is also a lot on the menu, both upscale and down, which can lead to amusing combinations. You might see cheeseburger baskets arrayed across a table of friends here, but these could very well be joined by a prodigious and excellent Cobb salad ($7) or homemade potato gnocchi in fresh tomato sauce ($11) or an incongruous plate of cumin-dusted hummus and pita ($6). A plate of delicious plain pirogi ($7), served with a darkly sweet compote of cherries, grilled onions and sour cream? Sure, that, too.
The restaurant's name honors the birthplace of one of the owners, Rhode Island. Its state flag, a miniature of which sits above the restaurant's bar, is adorned by a golden anchor, with a blue banner floating beneath it on a sea of white, reading, "Hope." 
As a starter that continues the theme, there are plump and bready Rhode Island clam cakes ($5), served with a thick mayonnaise-like dipping sauce. Hope & Anchor serves a credible, though hardly perfect, version of the dish. (As in Narragansett, so too in Brooklyn: each fritter is far more dough than clam.) 
For bistro-like verisimilitude, there are also perfectly breaded, imperfectly over-fried calamari ($7) on the starter menu, served with a piquant garlic aioli. And for what was once that dish's socio-economic antipode, a plate of hot wings ($6), deep-fried in batter and served with a blue cheese dipping sauce of the sort most often found in establishments with multiple televisions.
Feel like a flat-patty cheeseburger ($6), with golden shoestring fries and a tomato-onion-lettuce pile on the side? You'll do very well here. Likewise with a cheese steak ($7) on soft bread with onions and those same crunchy fries. 
Less assured is herb-roasted chicken ($10) with mashed potatoes. The chicken was bone-dry one night, which only highlighted the excellence of the whipped and buttery starch. Balsamic-glazed calf's liver ($9) is a deliciously tweaked version of a diner classic, here delivered with thick, juicy bacon and caramelized onions. Seared tuna steak ($12) comes wrapped in a thin sheet of ham -- yes, ham -- with lemon butter and a potato pancake, and is likely to start discussions among even the closest friends. It's either a clever rendition or a ridiculous one, and while smart money would bet "ridiculous," it would lose.
Best, perhaps, is a terrific bowl of seared monkfish ($12), served in a bright tomato broth run through with the low, humming acidity of olives and chorizo, supplemented by sliced calamari and garbanzos for heft. It's puttanesca with a Portuguese accent.
Dessert is what's available in the retro-kitsch spinning glass refrigerator in the corner of the dining room: chocolate pudding ($5) to take you back to grade school, for instance, or apple pie a la mode ($6).
Hope & Anchor is not a destination restaurant, to be sure. It's a locals-rule sort of spot. But imagine a perfect fall weekend morning and a bike ride along wide, empty streets down to the Red Hook waterfront. The sun glints off the water, the Statue of Liberty rises in the distance, a breeze sends leaves skittering down a block. Then it would be just the thing: a cheeseburger deluxe and a good dose of neighborhood cheer.

Hope & Anchor
347 Van Brunt Street (Wolcott Street), Red Hook, Brooklyn; (718) 237-0276.

BEST DISHES: Cobb salad, cheese steak, pirogi, clam cakes, balsamic-glazed calf's liver, seared tuna steak, monkfish.
PRICE RANGE: Breakfast, $3 to $6.50. Appetizers, $4 to $8; main dishes, $5 to $12.
CREDIT CARDS: All major cards.
HOURS: Sunday, 9 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Tuesday to Thursday, to 10; Friday and Saturday, to 11; closed Monday.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS: Restaurant is up one step; ramp available.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
History Lessons on Tax-Policy Strife

BYLINE:  By ALLAN SLOAN; Allan Sloan is the Wall Street editor of Newsweek.

 BODY:
THE GREAT TAX WARS
Lincoln to Wilson -- The Fierce Battles Over Money and Power That Transformed the Nation
By Steven R. Weisman
419 pages. Simon & Schuster. $27.
 Federal tax policy, normally relegated to the business pages, is hot news these days. 
 The sudden return of federal budget deficits has ignited a debate over the role that President Bush's 2001 tax cut has played in transforming huge projected surpluses into huge deficits. We are bombarded with revelations of how corporations and rich individuals are playing games, such as moving to Bermuda, to avoid taxes. And in the not-too-distant future questions of the fairness and adequacy of Social Security taxes will move front and center when the country finally confronts the gigantic gap between Social Security's commitments and its projected revenues. 
 "The Great Tax Wars: Lincoln to Wilson -- The Fierce Battles Over Money and Power That Transformed the Nation," by Steven R. Weisman, focuses on this timely topic. But this book does not really integrate those past battles with the current ones, which is unfortunate. We need a book that uses history to illuminate today, rather than leaving us to connect most of the dots ourselves. And Mr. Weisman, an editorial writer for The New York Times, could do a good job of writing such a book. He has written about business and economics for years, and has the ability to explain complicated subjects in ways that nonmavens can grasp. 
But "The Great Tax Wars" does perform a useful service by providing historical context, which is sorely lacking in most current discussions. The tax wars that Mr. Weisman writes about involved arguments over fairness, the taxation level at which people would no longer care to work and the differing ways that employment income and investment income are taxed. Sound familiar? Many of today's debates involve those very topics.
The book covers the period from 1860 to 1920. Unless you are a financial historian, the logic behind picking this period is not immediately apparent. Mr. Weisman starts his history shortly before Abraham Lincoln got a temporary federal income tax passed to help pay the North's Civil War expenses, and he ends during the Woodrow Wilson administration, when the income tax became entrenched a few years after the adoption of the 16th Amendment. That amendment overturned an 1895 United States Supreme Court decision -- at the time, as controversial as Bush v. Gore -- that declared the personal income tax illegal. It is no coincidence that the period Mr. Weisman writes about begins and ends with wars. Wars are expensive, and the country could not borrow enough to cover the whole bill. Hence the pressure for revenues from income taxes.
Mr. Weisman halfheartedly tries to tie his history into today's debate with a short introduction and a 19-page epilogue, but these read like afterthoughts. His real passion is making 60 years of economic debates read like newspaper articles, a project that he says he started thinking about six years ago.
What comes through clearly in "The Great Tax Wars" is that even though income taxes are accepted today and seem to have been around forever, they are a relatively recent development. For most of the 18th and 19th centuries and the early part of the 20th, the federal government depended not on income taxes, but rather on revenues from customs duties, liquor and tobacco. These are all consumption taxes, based on what people consume. They are the polar opposite of income taxes.
On a proportionate basis, high-income people are less affected by these consumption taxes than low-income earners because they spend a smaller proportion of their income on consumer goods. The opposite is true of income taxes, which affect high-income people much more than low-income ones. 
Mr. Weisman attributes the Union victory partly to the North's willingness to raise significant sums through an income tax, which the Confederacy did not do. The South, where most wealth consisted of slaves and agricultural property, was at a disadvantage compared with the North, where the rising merchant and manufacturing classes were better able to pay taxes than the asset-rich but cash-poor Southern gentry.
Mr. Weisman occasionally leavens his history with little anecdotal gems. For instance, he describes Mark Twain's brush with the tax man. Mr. Twain "reported in 1864 that he had paid an income tax of $36.82, plus a $3.12 fine for filing late," Mr. Weisman writes. He continues, "But this was all right with him, he said, because it made him feel 'important' that the government was finally paying attention to him." 
The consumption-versus-income-tax battle raged for decades, with income taxes periodically adopted and then dropped, and customs duties rising and falling, depending on political fashion. The Supreme Court outlawed the personal income tax in a controversial and confusing decision in 1895 that was overturned when the 16th Amendment was ratified in 1913. One result, Mr. Weisman writes, is that in 1913, "nearly 95 percent of federal revenues came from the purchase of commodities, which were paid disproportionately by families of modest means." He continues, "By 1930, by contrast, even after the tax reductions following the end of the war, two-thirds of federal revenues came from income and corporate taxes." 
The nation's income tax debate, nearly 150 years running, will probably continue indefinitely, with critics attempting to roll back President Bush's tax cut, which grows rapidly in future years and disproportionately benefits a few people with very high incomes. It especially benefits the heirs of the 2 percent of taxpayers whose estates are subject to the inheritance tax. The inheritance tax is scheduled to be repealed entirely in 2010, but to return in 2011. Mr. Bush pushes at every opportunity to make the cuts permanent.
It is a shame that Mr. Weisman did not fully incorporate contemporary tax battles into his book. But even in its current form, "The Great Tax Wars" is useful reading for anyone interested in understanding what tax debates are all about.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steven R. Weisman (Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Issues Report On a Fiasco In the Market 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
A government-appointed panel of inquiry concluded today that some officials had made errors in connection with the issuance of a trading proposal that set off a steep decline among penny stocks here, angering many investors.
 But the panel said that some of the errors were "understandable," and largely confined itself to suggesting ways to improve the regulatory structure instead of assigning personal responsibility for the fiasco. 
 After consulting with regulators, the Hong Kong stock exchange proposed on July 25 to delist stocks that traded below 50 Hong Kong cents (6.4 United States cents) for 30 consecutive trading days. The proposal did not say how investors would be able to buy or sell these shares after they were delisted. 
Hong Kong lacks an equivalent to the bulletin board, or "pink sheets," trading for very cheap or delisted stocks in the United States, so the proposal prompted a rout the next day that erased a tenth of the market value of penny stocks here, or $1.3 billion. The exchange soon withdrew the delisting proposal.
The fiasco prompted many calls for the resignation of Frederick Ma, who had just become the secretary for financial services and the treasury when the Hong Kong government reorganized its departments and senior administrators on July 1. There was also some criticism of Antony Leung, the territory's financial secretary and its third-ranking official, who shares regulatory policy responsibilities with Mr. Ma.
But though today's report largely steered clear of assigning blame to individuals, it did question a few of Mr. Ma's actions. "This inquiry should not be taken as a fault-finding exercise," said the document, which was produced by a two-member panel selected by Mr. Leung.
"We uncovered some instances of errors of judgment, some perhaps even understandable in the circumstances, a few mishaps, items of miscommunication and some systemic wrinkles here and there," the report said. "None of the shortcomings we have identified are in themselves major."
Mr. Ma, who acknowledged at a separate legislative hearing that he had been sent the proposal before its release but said he had not taken the time to read it, apologized today for his conduct. "I accept the criticism sincerely and pledge to do better in the future," he said at a news conference this afternoon.
Emily Lau, a member of Hong Kong's Legislative Council, popularly known as Legco, dismissed the report as inadequate. "I don't think they can really satisfy the public -- I have been a member of Legco since 1991 and I have not seen such a big deal," she said.
The legislature is scheduled to hold another hearing on Wednesday.
Today's report did provide a surprisingly long list of recommended changes to Hong Kong's regulatory structure. The report especially urged the government to redefine the responsibility for listing and delisting stocks.
In Hong Kong, the authority to decide what stocks are traded lies not with regulators, as it does in many important financial markets, but with the politically influential, for-profit company that runs the markets, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd.
Corporate governance experts have long criticized this arrangement for giving Hong Kong Exchanges an incentive to halt trading in low-volume, low-priced stocks, which are expensive for the stock exchange to administer.
The report also pointed out that Hong Kong Exchanges had strongly objected a few months earlier to having regulators share policy proposals with shareholders to gauge possible market reaction, except when Hong Kong Exchanges specifically approved such sharing. Today's report recommended better consultation in the future.
It also said that the panel had been unable to find any evidence that the fall in penny stocks had been caused by market manipulation, an explanation that the government and the stock exchange had initially favored after share prices tumbled.
In a statement tonight, Hong Kong Exchanges repeated its recent apologies for the steep fall in penny stocks. The company "acknowledges that there is room for improvement in a number of areas and accepts in principle the panel's recommendations," the statement said.
David Webb, the editor of the nonprofit Webb-site.com, which covers corporate governance and economic issues here, said that the report provided strong support for long-needed changes. "The recommendations make a lot of sense," he said.
Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, said this evening at a news conference that he welcomed all of the report's recommendations, but he did not say whether they would be adopted.
Despite the report's gentle conclusions, Mr. Tung seemed to be distancing himself from Mr. Ma and Mr. Leung. Each of the three men took turns holding news conferences late this afternoon at the government's central offices here, with each man entering and leaving with his own aides but not being seen or photographed with either of the others.
Mr. Tung was criticized a month ago for allowing Mr. Leung to choose the two members of the panel of inquiry, Robert G. Kotewall and Gordon C. K. Kwong.
Today's report also mentioned an unusual alternative to delisting stocks that had been considered and rejected before Hong Kong Exchanges issued the actual proposal. The Securities and Futures Commission had "suggested the possibility of allowing delisted companies to remain traded, but with a prefix '4,' commonly regarded as meaning 'dead' in Cantonese, to distinguish them," the report said.

HEADLINE: Europeans Curbing Their Appetite for Stocks 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
In the early 1990's, Edouard Winckler decided to bet on the future. A scholarship he landed to finish business school offered him a nest egg to invest. Beginning with low-risk money market funds, he gradually diversified into stock. The market was rising, and the French government, short of cash to balance its budget, was selling off chunks of nationalized industries like the oil company, the phone company and the national airline.
 After landing a job as a financial controller in the mid-1990's, Mr. Winckler kept buying stock. "Everybody was influenced by the Internet phenomenon," he said. "I decided to take more risks." 
 Now all bets are off. "I was really hit by the downturn," Mr. Winckler, 30, said recently.
The stock market slump, and the uncertainty it breeds in investors, is threatening Europe's fragile new faith in stocks as an investment.
In the booming 1990's, American-style stock ownership, long regarded in the Old World as too risky for most ordinary people, began to catch on among Europeans. In Europe's five biggest economies -- France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Britain -- stock's share of total invested assets grew to more than 46 percent by the end of 2000, according to Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. To be sure, that figure reflected the inflated share prices of the time, and it remained far below the 57 percent share in the United States, said Moneesh Puri, an analyst who helped compile the figures. But it was a big increase from the 38 percent of assets Europeans allocated to stock four years earlier.
Indeed, over the same period, the number of French households owning stock other than through mutual funds rose by half, to 20 percent in 2000 from 13 percent in 1996. In Germany, the number of people over 14 who owned stock, either directly or through funds, climbed to 20 percent of the total population by 2001, more than double the proportion of five years before. In Italy, it reached 11 percent, from 6.5 percent in 1998.
Yet Europeans have slowed their net new investment in stocks to a trickle in recent months. They poured a net 56 billion euros ($54.6 billion) into stock funds in the first quarter of 2000; in the period this year, the figure was only 6.5 billion euros. And the number of people holding stock has started to retreat again: it fell to 17.9 percent in Germany in the first half of 2002. Statistics for other countries are not yet available, but experts detect a similar trend across Europe.
"People are cautious," said Franz-Josef Leven, spokesman for the German Stock Institute in Frankfurt. "A lot has changed."
Mr. Leven said the stock euphoria of the 1990's was borne aloft in part by the successful efforts of newly privatized state companies, like Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom, to promote the idea of investing in stock. At the same time, companies began trying to motivate employees with generous employee share-ownership plans, often with share-price guarantees that assured employees a risk-free investment. Now that has changed.
In France, the big electrical equipment maker Alcatel introduced a stock purchase plan for employees in 2000, about 59,000 workers, or half the global payroll, signed up for the plan, including three-fifths of the company's workers in France. The board considered renewing the offer this year, but decided against it, in large part because the company's stock price has fallen by more than three-quarters since Jan. 1.
The Continental shift toward stock ownership in the 1990's reflected a growing sense among Europeans, whether Germans, French, Italians or Spaniards, that they were responsible for their own financial security. As governments stopped being able to afford cradle-to-grave social services, Europeans were urged to diversify their investments into stocks. The change was especially stark in Sweden, which last year began channeling a portion of social security contributions into mutual funds. In January, Germany began offering so-called Riester pensions, after Walter Riester, the social affairs minister who enacted them; the plans enable Germans to invest part of their pension contributions in stocks.
The Swedish plan is attracting a growing share of assets, but the Riester pension system has been slow to catch on in Germany. "Partly, it is too complicated," Mr. Leven said. "But there has been no great echo."
Continued weakness in stock markets has led European governments to shelve plans for more privatizations and for more programs to encourage citizens to invest in stock.
Online brokerages operations, which fanned out across Europe in the 1990's, are suffering from the change in mood. In Germany, the largest online brokerage market after Britain, the three largest players reported a cumulative loss of almost $560 million last year. Comdirect, controlled by Germany's third-biggest bank, Commerzbank, has closed affiliates in Italy and Spain and plans to lay off 308 of its 1,029 employees. Heavy losses at DAB Bank, a unit of the HypoVereinsbank group, have fueled speculation that it might be sold. Another rival, Consors, was forced recently into a deal with the French bank BNP Paribas to survive.
Many first-time stock investors were urged in by their banks, which began selling mutual funds over the counter in the 1990's. Ingrid Mosch, 66, a retiree in Zwickau in eastern Germany, was one who bought for the first time.
In late 1999, looking to invest some savings to supplement her monthly social security payments, Mrs. Mosch invested through her bank in DIT-Kapital Plus, a diversified $1.6 billion fund managed by Allianz Dresdner Asset Management. The fund posted a 15.4 percent gain in 1998 and rose 10 percent in 1999. But last year, it lost almost 3 percent, and by the end of June this year, a further 3.4 percent.
"It seemed clever and attractive," Mrs. Mosch said. "Now I really regret it."
Mrs. Mosch's adviser at the bank told her to hang on, that experience taught that the fund would recover. Asked whether she would increase her investment, she replied, "Oh, my lord, no."
Of course, not everyone is turning away. "There is still a lot of enthusiasm for the stock market," said Maurizio Dellocchio, a professor of finance at the Bocconi University School of Management in Milan. "Barring any extraordinary events, people will return."
Mr. Winckler agrees. "I want to hold on until it goes up again," he said.
"In France, the mentality has changed dramatically in the last 10 years," he said. For the older generation, it has to do with supplementing traditional social security payments. "That is certainly the reason for my father, and for the generation before me," he said.
But for younger people like him, he said, it is more a question of building trust in the economy. "I think we have no choice but to go with the market," he said. "If you're confident in the economy, you have to invest."
