HEADLINE: Securing Freedom's Triumph 

BYLINE:  By George W. Bush; George W. Bush is the 43rd president.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The Sept. 11 attacks moved Americans to grief and horror and moved our nation to war. They revealed the cruelty of our enemies, clarified grave threats to our country and demonstrated the character and decency of our people. At a moment of great testing, the spirit of men and women in New York City, at the Pentagon and aboard Flight 93 became the spirit of our country. Tonight in New York, I will be speaking of what our nation has lost, what we have discovered about ourselves and what lies ahead.
 The terrible illumination of these events has also brought new clarity to America's role in the world. In great tragedy, we have also seen great opportunities. We must have the wisdom and courage to seize these opportunities. 
 America's greatest opportunity is to create a balance of world power that favors human freedom. We will use our position of unparalleled strength and influence to build an atmosphere of international order and openness in which progress and liberty can flourish in many nations. A peaceful world of growing freedom serves American long-term interests, reflects enduring American ideals and unites America's allies. We defend this peace by opposing and preventing violence by terrorists and outlaw regimes. We preserve this peace by building good relations among the world's great powers and we extend this peace by encouraging free and open societies on every continent.
The defense of peace is a difficult struggle of uncertain duration. America, along with our allies, is relentlessly pursuing terrorist networks in every part of the world to disrupt their planning, training and financing. With our allies, we must also confront the growing threat of regimes that support terror, seek chemical, biological and nuclear weapons, and build ballistic missiles. On this issue, the consequences of inaction could be catastrophic. We must deny terrorists and their allies the destructive means to match their hatred.
At the same time, we have the best opportunity in generations to build a world where great powers cooperate in peace instead of continually prepare for war. The 20th century, in particular, was dominated by a series of destructive national rivalries that left battlefields and graveyards across the earth. Competition between great nations is inevitable, but armed conflict in our world is not. Sept. 11 revealed more clearly than ever that the world's great powers stand on the same side of a divide -- united by common dangers of terrorist violence and chaos, and moving toward common values.
The United States, Japan and our Pacific friends, our NATO allies and now all of Europe share a deep commitment to human freedom. Russia is now a nation in hopeful transition, a country reaching for a better future based on democracy and the free market and an important partner in the war on terror. Chinese leaders are discovering that economic freedom is the only source of national wealth. In time, they will find that social and political freedom is the only source of national greatness. America will continue to encourage the advancement of democracy and economic openness in both Russia and China because these shared commitments bring true friendship and peace.
Common interests and values among the great powers are also the basis for promoting peace and security around the globe. In the past, great-power rivals took sides in difficult regional problems, making divisions deeper and solutions more complicated and elusive. Today, from the Middle East to South Asia, we are gathering broad international coalitions to increase the pressure for peace. America needs partners to preserve the peace, and we will work with every nation that shares this noble goal.
As we preserve the peace, America also has an opportunity to extend the benefits of freedom and progress to nations that lack them. We seek a just peace where repression, resentment and poverty are replaced with the hope of democracy, development, free markets and free trade.
More than ever, we know that weak states, like Afghanistan, can pose a great danger to the peace of the world. Poverty does not transform poor people into terrorists and murderers. Yet poverty, corruption and repression are a toxic combination in many societies, leading to weak governments that are unable to enforce order or patrol their borders and are vulnerable to terrorist networks and drug cartels.
America is confronting global poverty. Free trade and free markets have proved their ability to lift whole societies out of poverty -- so the United States is working with the entire global trading community to build a world that trades in freedom and therefore grows in prosperity. Through the Millennium Challenge Account, the United States will deliver greater development assistance to poor nations that govern justly, invest in their people and encourage economic freedom. And we will continue to lead the world in efforts to reduce the terrible toll of AIDS and other infectious diseases.
America will also take the side of brave men and women who advocate human rights and democratic values, from Africa to Latin America, Asia and the Islamic world. In our diplomatic efforts, development aid, international broadcasting and educational assistance, the United States will promote moderation, tolerance and the nonnegotiable demands of human dignity -- the rule of law, limits on the power of the state, and respect for women, private property, free speech and equal justice.
Terrorism has not only challenged the world, it has clarified some fundamental values. Every nation now faces a choice between lawful change and chaotic violence; between joyless conformity and an open, creative society; and between the celebration of death in suicide and murder and the defense of life and its dignity.
Many governments are being forced to reexamine their own tolerance for fanaticism and their sponsorship of hateful propaganda. Even free nations have been forced to reexamine the nature of their commitment to freedom -- to determine if this commitment is a reflection of convention and culture or the universal demand of conscience and morality.
America's people and its government are responding decisively to the challenges of our changed world. We are committed to defending our society against current and emerging threats. And we are determined to stand for the values that gave our nation its birth. We believe that freedom and respect for human rights are owed to every human being, in every culture. We believe that the deliberate murder of innocent civilians and the oppression of women are everywhere and always wrong. And we refuse to ignore or appease the aggression and brutality of evil men.
Throughout history, freedom has been threatened by war and terror; it has been challenged by the clashing wills of powerful states and the designs of tyrants; and it has been tested by widespread poverty and disease. What has changed since Sept. 11 is our nation's appreciation of the urgency of these issues -- and the new opportunities we have for progress. Today, humanity holds in its hands the opportunity to further freedom's triumph over all its age-old foes. The United States welcomes its responsibility to lead in this great mission.

HEADLINE: Iran's Airlines Suffer From U.S. Embargo That Includes Planes 

BYLINE:  By NAZILA FATHI 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
Roxana Pourshapour was on a flight from Shiraz to Tehran last month when she smelled something burning. Then the oxygen masks dropped.
 "Ladies and gentlemen, please stay calm and use the oxygen masks only if you have to," the pilot said over the loudspeaker, without further explanation. "We are on our way back to Shiraz." 
 The passengers fell silent as the plane steadily lost altitude, a terrifying experience for many who recalled two major crashes in the past year. In February a Russian Tupolev crashed near Khorramabad, killing all 118 passengers. In the summer of 2001 a Russian Yak-40 went down near the Caspian Sea; the 21 dead included the transportation minister and seven members of Parliament.
Even though the authorities ascribed the crashes to human error, the incidents increased public mistrust of Iran's aging aircraft, especially Russian-made planes that are replacing American-made Boeings.
It took just half an hour for Ms. Pourshapour's flight to return to Shiraz. The problem, it seems, was a fire in the ventilation system.
The passengers then learned that they had been told not to use the oxygen masks unless absolutely necessary because the pressure in the tanks was so low that they hardly functioned. In fact, there was not enough oxygen for Ms. Pourshapour and the two other passengers in her row to breathe into their masks at the same time.
With the aging of Iran's air fleet, reports of similar incidents appear more often.
For example, newspapers reported last month that the emergency door of one plane flew open last month while the plane was trying to land and that another flight was delayed for hours while waiting for a tire to be delivered from here. 
Even President Mohammad Khatami's plane was delayed for three hours because of technical problems when he was returning from an official visit to Athens in March.
Most Iranians blame the sorry state of Iran's aircraft on the longstanding United States trade embargo. Only 15 of the 30 American-built Boeings that Iran had in 1979 are still flying.
Because the embargo bars American companies from doing business with Iran, the Boeings are being replaced with Russian or secondhand European planes. Iran Air, the leading government airline, and the five smaller airlines have leased dozens of Russian-built planes.
In 2000, Iran agreed to buy four new planes from Airbus. Rolls-Royce was to provide the engines. But because most of the Rolls-Royce engines are made in the United States, the deal was called off, Davoud Keshavarzian, Iran Air's managing director, announced last month.
Iranian officials argue that the ban endangers civilian lives.
Mahmoud Mehranpour, Iran Air's deputy managing director for corporate planning, said, "The cost of maintaining these planes has increased in Iran because of the embargo, and so have the risks." Spare parts bought from a third country are more expensive than those bought directly from the United States. Mr. Mehranpour said Iran had 30 years' experience with Boeings and so remained reluctant to replace them with other plane.
He added that if not for the embargo, Iran would be willing to buy even used aircraft of bankrupt American airlines because of the good reputation American planes have here.
Over the next five years Iran will need at least 100 more planes, Mr. Mehranpour said. "Iran is a good market now," he added.

HEADLINE: Stores Open in Vermont Town, but Squabbles Live On 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: WILLISTON, Vt. 

 BODY:
Best Buy, big box, shining in the night: won't you make your sign less bright?
 It seems a small request, and elsewhere the quick answer would be no, but here in Vermont, the question was more of a demand. It came from the state Environmental Board in October, complete with the threat of fines or even criminal charges against the developer of a mixed-use project planned as this town's second center. 
 The project is called Maple Tree Place, a 71-acre complex intended to have 299,000 square feet of retail stores, 100,000 square feet of office space and 50 rental apartments surrounding a modest patch of land that the developers describe as a town green. (Williston, a suburb of Burlington, has a small historic downtown area, but no town green.) Three decades in the making, it has been opening in pieces over the last year, starting with the so-called big box retail stores, the, perhaps, least loved but most profitable buildings. 
The idea of the development began in the 1970's, when Williston was a farming community of 1,000. The historic town center could not be expanded without ruining its aesthetics, so Williston set aside a commercial development zone two miles up the main street, Williston Road, beside a highway interchange. The town wanted to generate tax revenue to support the school system.
The Pyramid Companies of Syracuse proposed a 700,000-square-foot shopping mall, but Williston rejected that design and others over the next decade. Ben Frank, a local architect, joined the project along the way.
Eventually, a task force was formed with a community group called Citizens for Responsible Growth, and the concept of an open-air, mixed-use complex was developed. In the end, Mr. Frank could not secure a construction loan, and again the project stagnated.
"I think he got tired," said Michael J. Munson, the town planner. "They put in a decade pulling this together."
In 1997, when the zoning was approved, Pyramid sold a two-thirds share in the development to Starwood Ceruzzi, a development company based in Fairfield, Conn., for a little more than $15 million.
The town's motivation changed simultaneously. Vermont started a redistributive property tax system for education that effectively nullified any benefit to the town's schools from commercial development. Aesthetics became the only thing that mattered, Mr. Munson said.
"We have really tried to adhere to the specifics and to the intent of what the town wanted, to make this a vibrant part of Williston, to give it a downtown feel," said Stephen J. Berini, an executive vice president of Starwood Ceruzzi who is managing the project. The company closed on a construction loan in August 2000 and began building the big box retail stores, planning to spend $85 million on the entire project.
The big boxes are open, with Staples, Dick's Sporting Goods and Linens-N-Things on one side of the site and a Shaw's Supermarket on the other, and Best Buy and a Chili's restaurant in between. They pay about $20 a square foot in annual rent to the developer. They pay their own property taxes and other expenses.
With Mr. Munson largely satisfied and the community group all but disbanded, the state has stepped in to regulate the developers.
The environmental board has ordered Starwood to overhaul Best Buy by changing the illuminated sign, making a new entrance facing the town green and lowering the facade as much as nine feet in some places. Also, the board said, Chili's roof should be more steeply sloped. Starwood is complying.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service has rented 28,000 square feet of office space, while 24,000 square feet sit vacant. A total of 100,000 feet of office space is planned around the town green, as is a 10-screen movie theater.
The green itself is less than an acre of weed-filled grass, surrounded by lampposts. Mr. Berini said he would add a gazebo in the spring.
Steven Bradish, a former leader of Citizens for Responsible Growth, said, "We're in a mode of keeping a close eye on what they're doing, that they don't get the advantages of the big boxes they want and not provide the town center."
Mr. Berini said his company had an economic incentive to finish the town green. The linens, sporting goods and office supplies stores, he said, "are always going to be successful on their own."
"I'm not going to make my return on investment on those three stores. That's 20 percent of the deal."
Still, Mr. Berini added, "generating income during a protracted development process has helped a lot."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET-- Downtown Manhattan; 
A Big Victim Is Still Empty After a Year

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Only the magnitude of disaster a few yards away could have eclipsed the painful story of the former Federal Office Building at 90 Church Street.
 This imposing one-million-square-foot Art Deco structure was handsomely renovated in the late 1990's by Boston Properties, which holds the master lease. Until Sept. 11, it housed nearly 3,000 employees of the United States Postal Service, the New York City Housing Authority and the Legal Aid Society. Today, it is empty and sealed off. No one knows when it will reopen. 
 Though it looks undamaged to passers-by, the building was permeated by contaminants, including lead, mercury and asbestos, from the collapse of 7 World Trade Center and the twin towers. 
"It just rained down and in," said Dan Kessler, general services director for the Legal Aid Society, which had its headquarters and numerous divisions in the top three floors of the 15-story building, completed in 1935.
If there was anything resembling good news that morning, it was that no one who worked at 90 Church Street was killed or seriously injured.
Any hope that the building could be quickly reoccupied vanished in the months after the attack, as the degree of contamination became apparent.
"Levels of specific contaminants alone are a concern, and combined they form a contaminant cocktail that represents a significant health and liability risk," the Airtek Environmental Corporation said in a report prepared for the Legal Aid Society. Airtek found asbestos, lead dust, fungi, fiberglass dust, heavy metals, mercury, bacteria and decayed organic matter.
Apart from buildings like 1 Bankers Trust Plaza and 90 West Street, which were catastrophically damaged, 90 Church Street is the last of the big office towers around ground zero that remains vacant, according to Insignia/ESG, a commercial real estate company.
It is too early to gauge the economic consequences for the building, because it is not yet entirely clear how the structure will be cleaned and who will pay for doing so. There are no property taxes to pay because the building is owned by the Postal Service and leased to 90 Church Street Ltd., an affiliate of Boston Properties, the real estate investment trust.
Boston Properties and the tenants have been working on a cleaning plan and are "very close to an agreement," said Robert E. Selsam, the senior vice president and regional manager of Boston Properties. 
"We had to develop a clean-up approach from scratch because there is no standard for many of the contaminants we found," he said. "We've taken a very careful, measured and reasoned approach. The last thing I want is somebody back in the building if it's not safe."
The lobby, a luminously memorable space with 20-foot-high green marble columns under a ceiling of translucent glass panels, was used as a temporary morgue after the attack. It has since been cleaned, Mr. Selsam said, and hundreds of broken windows have been replaced.
Reclaiming the tenants' spaces will mean extensive interior demolition, because contaminants have been found behind walls, on ceiling tiles and inside office partitions. The cost will run into the tens of millions of dollars.
"Our most important value is the safety and health of our staff, clients and visitors," Daniel L. Greenberg, president of the Legal Aid Society, said. "We've been told by environmental specialists that the only way to be sure of safety is demolition to the walls. It obviously has large and profound insurance implications."
Work might begin this November, Mr. Selsam said, and take about three or four months. After the retesting of the spaces for contaminants, tenants could begin rebuilding their offices, meaning a possible return to 90 Church Street late next summer or early fall.
"We would rather do it better than quicker," said David L. Solomon, the Postal Service vice president for the New York metro area. The service operated a post office in the first four floors, with about 850 employees. Contaminants found in the post office space included mercury, lead, cadmium, asbestos and polychlorinated biphenyls, said Jamie Cohen, the facility activation coordinator at the Postal Service for the metro area.
As it stands, the Church Street station may not reopen until November 2003. Even that date is tentative, Mr. Cohen said, because it "requires so many time frames and pieces of the puzzle fitting together."
Customers at the Church Street station included the tenants of the World Trade Center and World Financial Center, the Parking Violations Bureau and numerous banks and insurance companies, Mr. Solomon said, some of whom receive their mail in five-ton trucks.
Most operations were moved to the James A. Farley Building across Eighth Avenue from Pennsylvania Station.
The Housing Authority, by far the largest tenant, occupied nearly 450,000 square feet on seven and a half floors. Some 1,500 to 1,700 people worked in design, construction, finance, human resources, computer services, tenancy administration and housing applications, in the adjudicatory division and welfare employee program and in other fields.
The authority has leased 100,000 square feet of space at 90 Fifth Avenue, at 14th Street. It has also moved employees to its headquarters at 250 Broadway and other existing offices, including 350 Livingston Street in Brooklyn and 23-02 49th Avenue in Long Island City, Queens.
It estimates the cost of damages and dislocation from 90 Church Street at $93 million, said a spokesman, Howard Marder. That includes cleaning and rebuilding, replacing lost property and destroyed vehicles, and counseling its employees, many of whom witnessed horrific scenes that morning.
"Initially, the instruction was not to leave," recalled Mr. Kessler of the Legal Aid Society. "People were falling. Pieces of the building were falling. Flaming debris was falling." Part of the jetliner that hit the north tower plummeted to the roof of 90 Church Street, directly over the juvenile rights division, knocking loose the entire suspended ceiling frame. No one was hurt.
Had the attack occurred a bit later, the office would have been full. About 400 people worked in administration, payroll, accounting and human resources and in divisions handling homeless rights, health law, immigration, law reform, civil appeals and death penalty cases.
In addition, the society's computer system -- 65 servers in all -- is at 90 Church Street, linking offices and courtrooms citywide.
Building engineers managed an orderly shutdown of the ventilating and electrical systems, Mr. Selsam said. But the collapse of 7 World Trade Center set numerous fires in 90 Church Street. The sprinkler tanks emptied, filling the structure with water, which coursed down elevator shafts, causing further damage.
"Then we weren't able to get into the building for a long time," Mr. Selsam said, "so mold developed and spread everywhere."
With the help of Boston Properties and an emergency generator, the Legal Aid Society was able to jury-rig a power supply to its computers about 10 days after the attack. They have been running since. In midwinter, the society removed 20,000 cartons of material to Linden, N.J., after cleaning it in makeshift decontamination chambers in the elevator lobbies at 90 Church Street.
Employees are scattered in the society's 22 offices, including 49 Thomas Street in Lower Manhattan. Headquarters are in 25,000 square feet at 1 Battery Park Plaza, on a sublease from the law firm of Pillsbury Winthrop. The society also plans to take space at 199 Water Street.
Factoring in the expense of stripping the space at 90 Church Street to the slab and rebuilding it, the society estimates the cost of recovering from the attack at $25 million to $30 million, said Theresa de Leon, the chief operating officer and chief financial officer.
"We didn't realize at each step how long it would be," she said. "We thought it would be a matter of six weeks, a short-term issue, that we would be back at our desks by the holidays."
They may yet. Thanksgiving 2003.

HEADLINE: A Group Seeks to Rescue Endangered Scholars 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Juan Carlos Vallejo, a law professor at the University of Medellin in Colombia who has done research on human rights, was teaching last February when he noticed an unfamiliar man at the back of the room taking copious notes. After class, the man approached Professor Vallejo, asking leading questions about whether he felt safe walking home alone and whether he had known a colleague who had been murdered.
 In the following weeks, the professor found himself being followed, and friends told him that three armed men were looking for him. He stopped sleeping at home, and eventually escaped to the United States. 
 Professor Vallejo, who is now temporarily in residence at the University of New Mexico, is one of five foreign scholars who came to this country or are being helped to stay with the help of the newly created Scholar Rescue Fund, which is based in New York City. 
Rescuing endangered intellectuals is not new. In the 1930's, when Hitler's rise put many European scholars in danger, educational institutions, philanthropists and foundations arranged the rescue of more than 600 intellectuals, including Hannah Arendt. Soviet repression in Hungary and Czechoslovakia prompted similar efforts.
But with the fall of the Soviet Union, there was a sense that the greatest danger had passed, and interest in such efforts lagged. Now, however, the Scholar Rescue Fund is among several groups grappling with the problem again, as scholars are being harassed, imprisoned and sometimes killed in countries like Colombia, Indonesia and Pakistan.
"A lot of us were operating with the faulty assumption that with the end of the cold war, scholars would make out O.K.," said Allan E. Goodman, president of the Institute of International Education and former executive dean of Georgetown's School of Foreign Service. 
"We got it wrong. What we have learned is that scholars around the world face the same risks as human rights activists and journalists, and that not only will they be harassed, but some will be killed."
The new rescue fund was created by the Institute of International Education, which manages the Fulbright exchange program and other international exchanges and played a central role in the rescues in the 1930's. Besides Professor Vallejo, a scholar the fund is helping this year is Qinglian He, a Chinese economist whose work criticizing China's economic program was banned. She is now at the College of Staten Island.
The others are a constitutional scholar from Bangladesh who was threatened by government agents because of his open opposition to government policies, and is at the University of California now; a Ukrainian marine biologist who is working at the State University of New York at Stony Brook; and an Ethiopian engineer who is at a university in Illinois.
Next month, the fund will select 15 to 20 more threatened intellectuals from among roughly 50 applications from countries like China, Ethiopia, Burma and Iraq. Some have already fled their countries, and others are still in danger.
"I'm amazed at the number of things you can get in trouble for," said Robert Quinn, director of the rescue fund, pointing to the case of the Ukrainian marine biologist who studies plankton who found that government officials were unhappy about his desire to share his data with people in other countries.
"It tends to be the social scientists and humanists who get in trouble for the content of their work," Mr. Quinn said, "and the scientists who get in trouble for wanting to share information. Many states find that objectionable."
Two years ago, a group of academics established Scholars at Risk, a network intended to help endangered scholars find host universities outside their own countries.
The network, which Mr. Quinn also directs, is at the University of Chicago and now includes about 70 colleges and universities, but has no financing to support scholars. About 10 universities have pledged to support people, and at least five, including Harvard and the University of Toronto, already have scholars in residence who were threatened in their countries.
Concerned about the crisis-driven, ad hoc nature of the rescue missions, Mr. Goodman proposed last year that the institute create an endowed rescue fund of at least $10 million so money would always be available.
"I thought we should have a permanent endowment, so that we don't have to wait for three scholars to be killed before we rescue the fourth," he said.
His trustees not only backed the idea, but wanted to start immediately.
"Since my family were middle European refugees who came here in the 1930's, the Rescue Fund was a natural for me," said Henry G. Jarecki, a psychiatrist and businessman and one of the institute board members who supported the project. He and others, including George Soros's Open Society Institute, contributed $2 million to start the project, which has also begun to seek money for an endowment.
Pointing to the Jewish lives lost during World War II while organizations dithered over how to save them, Dr. Jarecki said it was important to help people in danger now, even if details were not worked out and the endowment not in place.
The rescue fund provides up to $20,000 a year per scholar, and requires that each scholar have a host university that at least matches that amount. In choosing the scholars, it weighs their academic qualifications, the dangers they face, their ability to work in another country and the likelihood that they will be able to return home at some point. The scholars are helped for up to a year, with the possibility of renewing for another year.
Aiding scholars for a year or two may not sound like much, but Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, says it is often enough.
"Usually the danger against a scholar is not permanent," he said. "Typically, there is a moment of extreme tension when danger is at its height. If you can pull a scholar out of a country at the period of maximum threat, it often is possible for the scholar to return later."
Professor He, the Chinese economist at the College of Staten Island, whose book, "The Pitfalls of China," was a best seller in China until it was banned, said she hoped to return to China.
"That's my motherland," she said through a translator. "But the newspapers and publishing houses that published my work were reprimanded, and told that if they had articles written by me they can be closed down." 
"Under these circumstances," she said, "I have no chance to go back. If the Chinese Communist Party does not change its current policy toward intellectuals, I cannot go back. How long that will take, I have no idea."
For now, she is continuing her work on Chinese corruption, collaborating with Ming Xia, a professor at the College of Staten Island on a project about Chinese gangs and organized crime, and studying English.
Professor Vallejo, too, is studying English, while he works at the Latin American and Iberian Institute of the University of New Mexico. He is conducting research on human rights, writing articles and working with students interested in Latin America and human rights.
He says the rescue program is a "great humanitarian gesture" that has made it possible for him to survive. Still, exile weighs on him.
"I believe all exiles dream of going home to their country," he wrote in an e-mail note translated by Mr. Quinn.
"Every morning I awake, believing I am in my apartment in my country; I am late; I must run to give my classes, to see my students, my friends. But no. Reality is that I am not there, and what is worse, I cannot return."

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
A Mobile Clinic Delivers Good Health and Grades

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein 

DATELINE: CHULA VISTA, Calif. 

 BODY:
FOUR years ago Dennis Doyle, an assistant superintendent of schools in this town on the Mexican border, reviewed attendance and test score data at the elementary schools. Not unexpectedly, schools with low scores also had poor attendance. Dr. Doyle figured that achievement would rise if he could keep the children, many from low-income and non-English-speaking families, in class.
 Meanwhile, Britt Berrett, chief executive of Sharp Chula Vista Medical Center, worried about a related problem: his hospital's uncollected bills for children without regular health care, who used emergency rooms for nonurgent treatment. 
 At a meeting of the local Human Services Council, Dr. Doyle and Mr. Berrett discussed their troubles and devised a solution: a mobile clinic sponsored by the school district, the city, Sharp Chula Vista and another local hospital. The clinic, with a nurse, a nurse practitioner and a nurse assistant, began rotating among five schools with high absenteeism, treating problems that would otherwise have kept pupils at home, like asthma.
Now attendance has improved, and scores have risen.
That success also stems from the clinic's ties to other services. After a pupil has been treated at the clinic, volunteers introduce the child's mother to a family center on school grounds. There, mothers are recruited for English-language classes, and a paraprofessional tries to enroll their children in a health plan. Some, whose family income is too high for Medicaid but too low to afford private coverage, may be eligible for the federally subsidized Children's Health Insurance Program, enacted by Congress in 1997. Children who are not citizens may get coverage from a patchwork of less-well-known public and private programs.
Aida Meza, a paraprofessional at the family center adjoining the Vista Square Elementary School, says follow-up contacts are often needed because many mothers hesitate to enroll their children in the federal insurance program: although children born in the United States are eligible as citizens, their parents may be in the country illegally and fearful of government agencies. 
Because the plan requires parents to enroll personally, Ms. Meza must call them back to the center at each step of the application process, translating for them on a speaker phone to health department officials. The plan requires small monthly premiums and periodic re-enrollment; Ms. Meza helps those daunted by the paperwork to comply.
Then she must take care that the coverage is actually used. Many immigrants are unfamiliar with the concept of preventive care and seek treatment for children only after an illness becomes serious. So Ms. Meza calls parents often, to ensure that their children get regular checkups and treatment for minor illnesses before they progress.
Largely because of Ms. Meza's efforts, three-quarters of Vista Square pupils now have health insurance. Most of the rest get free care at the mobile clinic.
The family center also provides training for mothers who work as community liaisons throughout Chula Vista. The mothers conduct classes for neighbors on issues like the importance of prenatal care, watching for diabetes and identifying women in depression.
A mobile clinic at the school site creates more work, not less, for Vista Square's regular nurse. Medications must now be dispensed. Children with asthma now have inhalers to be administered. With children enrolled in health plans, they now have regular doctors with whom the school nurse can consult when she observes new symptoms.
The clinic, the family center and the school nurse all share a common purpose: to keep children healthy enough to attend school, and alert enough to do well. Asthma, for example, does not harm performance just by keeping pupils out of class. If they are awake at night wheezing, they are too tired to pay attention even if they do make it to school the next day.
These services cost an average of about $300 a pupil per year, paid by the two participating hospitals, San Diego County, the City of Chula Vista, Medicaid, private foundations and the school district. Dr. Doyle insists, and data seem to confirm, that this spending has contributed to gains in test scores and other measures of student learning.
In a report for the National Bureau of Economic Research, Janet Currie of the University of California at Los Angeles and Mark Stabile of the University of Toronto, both economists, estimated that among children whose mothers are not high school graduates, each incidence of serious disease or injury raises the chance of being in the bottom fifth of the test score distribution by 7 percent.
That is a bigger impact than most analysts have previously identified. But in Chula Vista, Dr. Doyle seems to have come to a similar conclusion, and acted upon it.

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
For Better And Worse, Life Goes On

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: SUMMIT, N.J. 

 BODY:
THAT morning, the controlled chaos of the New Jersey Turnpike turned haywire. Cars were abandoned. Doors were flung open.
People stood watching the horror across the marshland. Car radios narrated the nightmare. People snapped pictures of history, or the end of it. 
"There are thousands of people dying right now," one man said to me.
 "God help us," said another. 
 At that moment, it was distance that helped us. But in some ways, the divide between city and suburb had evaporated. The next day, Sept. 12, this town, which thrives on Wall Street money, was a representative suburb bracing for disaster. When the tallying was complete, Summit had lost eight people, a staggering toll that prompted an outpouring of support. 
Dan Confalone, who works in Lower Manhattan, was running errands that morning in Summit. Among the local victims was a friend with whom he had a tennis date for that day. "People just look at you, and you look at them, and you know they, too, have experienced a loss," he said then.
A year later, Summit represents a more complicated moment in time. For those not hit directly, for those in the shadow of the tragedy, there is the luxury of being able to choose whether to dwell or not dwell on it. Over the last year, whatever separates a community from Manhattan -- marsh, distance, water or other barrier -- has reasserted itself. 
"You still hear people saying that we will never be the same," said Rabbi William Horn. "The truth is, except for the economic level, things are pretty much the same."
The rabbi is not being callous. It is a measure of the country's comforts that life can take such a blow and spring back to a close approximation of its previous shape.
That is not necessarily a virtue. "We're spoiled Americans," said Linda Dellaert, who works at a decorating shop. "That's what I think. We take a lot for granted."
Darren Gerig, 27, a tile installer, said, "People who were rude and ignorant and didn't care still are ignorant and rude and don't care." But, he said, as grief over the tragedy recedes, others "are trying to pull the goodness out of it."
Mr. Confalone said the other day that the loss of his tennis friend and others affected him deeply, but he struggled to pinpoint how. "For the most part, we're the same people," he finally said, "but, for me, things that were usual are no longer usual."
It's small things, like kissing his children when he gets home late, even if it means waking them, or putting down the newspaper on the beach this summer and trying his kids' skim board. He's now a soccer coach and an Indian Princess chief. He's no hero, just another guy who can't forget the image of all those people who went to work one morning and never came home.
Carolyn Warren says many people she talks to at her busy store, the World of Music, have examined their lives, as you might after a funeral. "People come in and say, 'I'm going back to the piano, I'm going to take up an instrument, I'm going back to what's important in life,' " Ms. Warren said. "What's important has shifted."
BUT in the same store, a saleswoman, Mary Mahony, said, "I think we've gone back to our hectic lives."
Perhaps both are true. It depends on your distance from the tragedy, particularly in suburbs as seemingly plush and protected as this one.
Robyn and Rick Roberts are among many helping their neighbor Lucy Thompson, whose husband died Sept. 11. Dozens of friends surprised the family in November, when they were on vacation, by renovating the Thompsons' basement, complete with furniture and an entertainment center.
"Give to people who need help," is the lesson she said she hopes her children learn, though it's cold comfort for the loss of the irrepressibly funny and friendly Ian Thompson. 
Ms. Roberts' plans for today are much as they were for last Sept. 11: work at her home accountant office in Summit until her children come home from school, and then supervise homework and the home front. At night, her family will light a candle for Mr. Thompson. 
She said a friend recently noted that in Judaism, if a death occurs close to a planned wedding, just the music is canceled, not the ceremony.
"It doesn't mean you have to dance, but the wedding has to go on," she said. "That was so right. We don't have to be dancing, but life goes on."

HEADLINE: THE VICTIMS; 
Strangers, Dads, Sisters, Friends

 BODY:
 The human toll of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, is still unimaginable: 2,801 killed in the towers of the World Trade Center and in the two airplanes that were flown into them, 125 dead at the Pentagon and 59 aboard the plane that struck it, and 40 passengers and crew members aboard Flight 93 killed when that hijacked plane crashed into a field near Shanksville, Pa. In all, 3,025 victims united by a date -- Sept. 11. Here are those people.

HEADLINE: GROUND ZERO: CHARITY; 
A Flood of Money, Then a Deluge of Scrutiny for Those Handing It Out

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Never has so much money been raised with so little effort. The roughly $2.7 billion raised for charity in the months after Sept. 11 set a record for philanthropy.
 Within just 24 hours of the attacks, the American Red Cross raised more than $1 million, and ultimately almost 300 charities were created to address the disaster in some way. Many who gave had never given before. 
 But for all the good it has brought, the philanthropic response to Sept. 11 has perhaps forever changed the nature and expectations of charity, accelerating trends that were already developing and setting precedents that will most likely bring discord. 
"Sept. 11 produced the most overwhelming outpouring of sympathy, empathy, anger, anxiety, but most of all, generosity, that we have ever seen," said Vartan Gregorian, president of the Carnegie Corporation and informal adviser to big-league philanthropists like Walter H. Annenberg, Bill Gates and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York. "I wish that unprecedented outpouring of philanthropy had met a similar outpouring of gratitude instead of creating the acrimony that it has. Money brings out the worst in everyone."
The added attention has brought added pressure. "This was philanthropy in a fish bowl," said Victoria B. Bjorklund, a lawyer who sits on the board of the Robin Hood Relief Fund and who specializes in tax-exempt groups. "Never have the press, donors and regulators given such scrutiny to charity."
Several principles that have long served as the bedrock of American charity -- the notion that it should benefit the needy, that it should be distributed equitably, that it should not aid illegal activity -- were either scrapped or set aside in the rush. 
National tax law governing the collection and distribution of philanthropy was rewritten, expanding the limits of who could be helped and loosening regulations on who was raising the money. Power to effectively decide who would get the charitable money shifted in great degree from the charities to donors.
And, perhaps most important, the intense scrutiny devoted to charity after the attacks, and the array of embarrassing reports that resulted, began forcing tougher standards of accountability on volunteer boards and the executives they oversee.
"People are going to be much more chary about giving," said William Josephson, the assistant attorney general who runs the charities bureau in the New York State attorney general's office. "The combination of the economic downturn and donor disappointment with how the Red Cross and others handled their money in this disaster will force charities to work hard to restore public confidence."
Among some experts in the world of philanthropy and charity, however, the competing view is that while Sept. 11 was a momentous philanthropic event, its long-term impact could well be less than many expect, for good or bad. "I think we'll get past it," said Dr. Eugene R. Tempel, executive director of Indiana University's Center on Philanthropy. "Except for the fact that so many people responded electronically, I don't think we're going to point to that day and say, 'This forever changed philanthropy and charity in this country.' "
The American Red Cross might disagree. Perhaps no issue that cropped up after Sept. 11 had more effect than the organization's decision shortly after the attacks to set aside more than $200 million of the money raised for a new terrorism response program.
Donors, victims and regulators protested angrily. Even though the Red Cross quickly bowed to pressure, pledging to devote every cent given because of Sept. 11, $988 million so far, to the victims of the attacks and overhauling its system for handling donations, it is still struggling to recover. Surveys by the Brookings Institution show that confidence in the Red Cross continues to fall.
The results of demands that every last cent be spent on victims -- and quickly, regardless of what experienced charities thought prudent -- have led to jarring consequences. Charity is likely to make millionaires of some of the victims' families, while perhaps more far-reaching needs spawned by the attacks, like mental health counseling and job training, may face financial constraints. Philanthropic dollars flowed in equal amounts to families of victims who had sterling life insurance policies and benefits plans and to those whose loved ones worked off the books.
While charity is not always about the needy, as in the case of museums and arts groups, many people have now questioned the wisdom of disbursing money without better regulation of what people receive.
"My biggest concern is not so much with the administration of the money, but that so much money was being donated and spent so quickly that I wonder if we really, in the end, made the most of our charitable giving," said Jim Gabbe, whose family gave about $10,000 to Sept. 11 causes.
The Internal Revenue Service, which oversees tax-exempt organizations, has been praised for moving quickly to make the distribution of charitable money more efficient. It temporarily suspended requirements that nonprofits determine need before handing out money, eased restrictions on corporate assistance, and quickly granted tax-exempt status to almost 300 groups.
But those good intentions are proving troublesome, charity leaders say, although generally not publicly. "Now we find ourselves having to make the monthly lease payments on a Mercedes-Benz 600 for one family, but unable to help the family that owns a 10-year-old, fully-paid-for Ford that's still running thanks to string and duct tape," one charity executive grumbled last spring.
Of the 293 charities the I.R.S. granted preliminary tax-exempt status, only a quarter responded to repeated attempts by the Non-Profit Times, a trade paper for nonprofit managers, to get their financial information. The lack of response has suggested to some experts that the creation of bogus or seat-of-the-pants outfits might have been widespread.
Many supposed Sept. 11 charities refused to respond to queries, the paper reported, even though the insistence on greater accountability by nonprofit organizations was rising even before the disaster. "The demand for accountability has always been there, but it got much stronger after Sept. 11," said Rick Cohen, president of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy.
In general, Mr. Cohen's group and other watchdog agencies commend the efforts of the large Sept. 11 charities, noting that they were dealing not only with the stewardship of a staggering amount of money but also with trying to develop a response to a disaster that was unlike any other.
Pier 94 in Manhattan, where a smorgasbord of social service agencies set up tables and offered a variety of assistance, like cash and legal assistance as well as pets for victims to cuddle, is likely to become a model for disaster response. And some charities' Web sites, like those for the Robin Hood Relief Fund and the September 11 Fund, have provided a new model of accountability.
But the nonprofit world has failed to capitalize on its successes and has allowed its problems and failures to define it, according to many experts and officials. Sixty percent of the people responding to a survey by the Brookings Institution in December said they were following stories about the Red Cross and United Way "very" or "somewhat" closely. Only 34 percent said the same of the Enron scandal, and 33 percent of the death of George Harrison.
"There was a moment that really should have been a moment the nonprofit sector seized to make itself visible, to explain itself, but instead it got hammered and lost a critical opportunity to gain greater public support," said Paul C. Light, director of the Center for Public Service at Brookings, an expert on nonprofits.
For instance, nonprofit leaders are wringing their hands that they did not use Sept. 11 to explain to the public that the administration of charity has a price. Money to cover overhead expenses is the hardest to raise, yet many Sept. 11 charities rushed to assure donors that not one cent of contributions would be used for expenses. Foundations like Ford, Mellon and Carnegie generally picked them up, but the experience may cause donors to expect such largesse routinely of these foundations or others and then be disappointed.
The Independent Sector, a coalition of more than 700 nonprofit organizations, recently published a report called "Keeping the Trust," which contained the results of a July survey on the attitudes of more than 1,000 adults toward charitable organizations. Charity executives almost universally point to that survey and its finding that 64 percent of those interviewed said charities were "honest and ethical in their use of funds." From the survey, Independent Sector concluded that Sept. 11 has had no lasting effect on the public view of charities.
But researchers say that survey allowed too few different responses to accurately capture discontent with charities.
Brookings did its own surveys, and using the same questions as the Independent Sector but with an expanded, and more generally accepted, set of possible answers, it got different results. In its May 2002 survey, the percentage of respondents saying they had a lot of confidence in charities fell to 18 percent from 25 percent in December, when the same questions were asked. The percentage saying they had no confidence in charities rose to 19 percent from 8 percent.
"The charitable sector did not get the surge in confidence that everyone else -- police officers, firefighters, politicians, corporations, everyone -- got last fall," said Mr. Light. "And in fact, for federated organizations like the Red Cross and the United Way, they took a really big hit."
Sara Melendez, president and chief executive of the Independent Sector, said it was too early to provide definitive answers to the questions that Sept. 11 raised for charities, and she cautioned that some of them might prove unanswerable. "There is nothing black and white or right and wrong about many of the issues Sept. 11 posed," she said. "In many cases, it's a matter of choosing between values and degrees of good. We could sure use Solomon right now."

HEADLINE: The Strains Are Showing in Air Travel 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
The grace period for air travel has ended.
 Gone are the days of good will after the Sept. 11 attacks, when passengers, airlines and airports were willing to put up with all kinds of intrusive and time-consuming security measures. Gone, too, are the months when carriers desperately wooed frightened travelers by catering to their needs and when well-intentioned federal officials optimistically laid out new safety plans. 
 Now, airlines and airports are vigorously lobbying the government to scale back or modify many of the new safeguards. Passengers are clamoring for more consistent and less exasperating security procedures. And airlines are cutting back on passenger services and creating ticket restrictions they would not have dared put in place before last fall. 
Hartsfield Atlanta International, the world's busiest airport, is grappling with many of the industry's issues a full year after the terrorists struck, transforming air travel more than any aspect of daily life. The airport serves as a hub for Delta Air Lines, the nation's third-largest carrier, and AirTran Airways, a fast-growing low-fare carrier.
Hartsfield also became a symbol last November for the potentially nightmarish future of air travel, when the entire airport was shut for four hours because a passenger ran down an up-escalator to retrieve a camera bag.
No single industry was hit harder by the attacks than the airlines, which have lost about $10 billion in the last year. Business travelers are shunning expensive tickets, and only low-cost carriers like AirTran are making money again. Delta lost $1.3 billion in the last three quarters, while AirTran lost $12.1 million. In the most recent quarter, Delta lost $10.80 per thousand available seat miles, while AirTran made $3.40.
Besides resorting to drastic cost-cutting efforts to stay aloft, the airlines -- along with airports like Hartsfield -- are in a heated dispute with the 10-month-old Transportation Security Administration over what security measures should be trimmed because they are driving away passengers. Still, many people blame the airlines' hiring of cheap security contractors for the lax procedures before Sept. 11, and some experts say that several streamlining ideas by the carriers, like hastily creating a "trusted traveler" program to speed passengers and employees through checkpoints, could be costly and cumbersome.
The airlines are openly resentful of security measures that they say have scared away customers, especially on short-haul flights.
"The T.S.A. has the best intentions in the world," said Frederick W. Reid, Delta's president. "But unless you keep the law enforcement focus and add customer service and efficiency to it, you will kill aviation."
Delta has been one of the most outspoken airlines about scrapping certain security procedures, like searching carry-on bags at the boarding gate. The chief executive, Leo F. Mullin, made several trips to Washington over the summer to talk with federal officials about overhauling parts of the system. He is pushing for the government to drop, among other things, a security tax of $2.50 a flight leg that was added to tickets in February.
In addition, the airlines have told the government that they will not pay $750 million that federal officials had requested of them for next year's security budget. The industry actually came up with that figure last winter when Congress asked it for an estimate of certain security costs, but the airlines have since said they will pay only $300 million.
The companies have also banded together to support the idea of a "trusted traveler" card. Adm. James M. Loy, head of the federal security agency, said yesterday at a Senate hearing that he backed the concept. But such a program should be put in place slowly, some security experts say, and it could be costly for the taxpayer. Moreover, any watering down of current procedures -- including removing random checks -- could have dire consequences.
"I think the industry is being shortsighted if in fact that is their view," said Jeff Schlanger, chief operating officer of security services at Kroll Associates, an international risk assessment company. "A decrease of security in airports during preboarding might inevitably lead to additional situations."
Many experts agree that security is better now than a year ago but still has a long way to go before being truly effective. Mr. Schlanger recommended that guards be taught how to ask more probing questions of passengers and to watch for suspicious behavior.
George Novak, an airline safety consultant and program director at the Aviation Institute at George Washington University, said bag searches at the gate should be kept for now because there is a chance a bag could be switched or tampered with after the security checkpoint. But truly efficient measures will come only as technology slowly improves, allowing the government to use facial recognition, iris scans and rapid database searches to check passengers, he said.
Throughout the summer, embarrassing incidents revealed that people were still able to smuggle weapons past security guards, sometimes at airports where federal workers had already replaced contractors. On Aug. 25, a woman with a loaded .357-caliber handgun in her carry-on bag walked past private screeners in Atlanta and boarded a plane. The gun was found by guards in Philadelphia, where the woman was trying to catch a connecting flight.
Nearly 66 million passengers came through Hartsfield from September 2001 to July, a figure down more than 10 percent from the period the previous year. The airport is set up so almost all fliers go through a single security checkpoint with multiple screening gates. Lines in the weeks after last fall's attacks stretched hundreds of feet, with waits sometimes an hour or more.
Following advice from consultants, the airport created a single serpentine line that winds back on itself more than a dozen times, and the number of screening gates at the main checkpoint will be expanded to 20 from 18. Ben DeCosta, general manager of the airport, said waiting times were down to 10 minutes in slack periods, but waits of up to 20 minutes still occur at very busy times.
Travelers in Atlanta one recent afternoon had widely varying opinions on the new state of security.
"It's appropriate, definitely appropriate," said Joseph Rubano, a sales representative from New Jersey. "I'll take any hassle."
Caroline Britt, a retired research librarian from Oklahoma, said: "It seems I always get picked to take my shoes off. It's always the old grandmas."
John Kylen, a computer network manager for the Kansas Air National Guard, said, "I'd be better off with a Wal-Mart greeter."
The Transportation Security Administration has put in place 13,000 federal passenger screeners at 82 airports and wants to replace the work force at 347 more by Nov. 19. Hartsfield is expected to be under a full federal force this fall.
Mr. DeCosta and other airport managers criticize the federal agency's plan to install by the end of the year 1,240 minivan-size bomb detection machines for baggage screening and 5,000 smaller explosive-trace-detection devices, mostly in airport terminals. The installations will be costly in the long run and disrupt passenger flow, they say.
At Hartsfield, Mr. DeCosta said he had presented the agency with an alternative plan to put 26 of the larger machines on the lower level and in a parking garage to scan checked bags, rather than in any of the terminals. That would take 18 to 21 months, well past the date Congress specified, Mr. DeCosta said. He and 132 other airport directors sent a letter to the Senate last month asking it to push back the deadline.
The airports also want Congress to pay for any construction costs related to security. They are asking, too, that the government lift a rule that prevents unchecked cars from parking within 300 feet of a terminal. Hartsfield has managed to wrangle back two-thirds of the 3,100 parking spaces that were closed last fall, but it has lost $10 million to $12 million in parking revenue because of the rule, Mr. DeCosta said.
As for the policy of shutting the entire airport or entire terminals for a security breach, Mr. DeCosta said the federal agency's Hartsfield supervisor had agreed not to take such steps unless airport and airline officials were consulted first.
"We are constantly looking at many of our policies," said David Steigman, a spokesman for the Transportation Security Administration, "and the reason is we're trying to provide the best balance possible between world-class security and world-class customer service."
Intensified security has changed travel patterns in a way that has benefited airport concessionaires past the checkpoint but hurt those before it. Scared of being delayed at the checkpoint, passengers are waiting until they get past security to eat or shop. Mr. DeCosta said he might ask the city for rent relief for the beleaguered businesses.
"People tend to panic when they see the lines," said Lamont McKinnon, an assistant manager at the Museum Company, a gift shop.
The airlines are wrestling with their own steep decline in business. At Delta, revenue from May to July was 15 percent below what it was during the corresponding period of last year, and passenger volume is down 5 percent this year. Delta has deferred $3.7 billion in capital spending, including deliveries of new planes from Boeing. It took voluntary leaves or retirements from about 11,300 workers and is still in the process of laying off 1,400 pilots.
Desperate to make money again, many full-service carriers are imposing extra fees and restrictions that many travelers find horrendous and that would have been unthinkable in the period immediately after last year's attacks. Delta is charging $40 or more for checked bags beyond the second one, and $20 for a paper ticket. It announced last Thursday that it would not give credit to travelers with nonrefundable tickets who missed their flights and would charge those passengers an extra $100 to fly standby on most flights.
Those rules follow policies recently adopted by Delta's biggest rivals.
"The airlines are going down the wrong path," said Kevin P. Mitchell, president of the Business Travel Coalition. "They're taking so much away it's going to hurt them."
But whatever happens in the months ahead, the last year has already pounded an attitude of resignation into many travelers. "I laugh at people who are concerned when they get stopped by security," said Jim Price, a vice president for sales at JVC who was waiting for a flight to Phoenix. "Why get upset about what I don't have control over?"
