HEADLINE: The Wisdom of Imagining The Worst-Case Scenario 

BYLINE:  By Milton Viorst; Milton Viorst is author of the forthcoming "What Shall I Do With This People: Jews and the Fractious Politics of Judaism."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Like most Americans, I've reflected this week on the personal impact of the tragedy of Sept. 11, recalling most vividly the trauma of emptiness I felt in the pit of my stomach as I watched the towers of the World Trade Center vanish from my television screen. The feeling still periodically recurs. In a flash, the inconceivable had become real, the horror of the unbelievable had become part of my and every American's existence.
 During the cold war, the futurists who studied world conflict had devised a clever name for such an event: the "worst-case scenario." Implied in this phrase, however, was the sense that the event was unlikely to happen. Government and policy professionals hypothesized less severe outcomes, dismissing the doomsayers. But on Sept. 11 we all learned that even disasters can be of an unexpected magnitude. Forthrightness now demands that we gird not for some tepid end to our conflicts but for catastrophes hitherto unimaginable. 
 In preparing for a war against Iraq, President Bush urges us to overlook that lesson. Categorizing Saddam Hussein as "evil," he warns that the Iraqis have nuclear, chemical and biological weapons with which to attack us. Mr. Bush's concern is justified, though some responsible statesmen at home and abroad believe he overstates the danger. But in suggesting that our forces will dispose of Saddam Hussein in a war that is quick and painless, like the Persian Gulf war or the war in Afghanistan, the president is clearly choosing not to consider the worst-case scenario at all.
Mr. Bush asserts a new doctrine for America, the right of preemptive attack, to keep Saddam Hussein from using his weapons. Preemption, Mr. Bush tells us, is what the proposed war is all about. But the doctrine does not take Saddam Hussein's own efforts at pre-emption into account; it assumes that he will wait around for America to attack at its convenience.
Surely Saddam Hussein will not repeat the strategic mistake he made after swallowing Kuwait in 1990 when, in choosing not to invade Saudi Arabia, he allowed half a million allied troops to assemble over several months time for invasion. Saudi Arabia is hardly less vulnerable now. By moving into Saudi Arabia, Saddam Hussein would shift the battlefield far to the south, imposing on American forces a much heavier burden than just the capture of Baghdad. We should also recall that in the last war Saddam Hussein blew up almost all of Kuwait's oil wells; in the next he could blow up Saudi Arabian wells, with significant repercussions for the international economy.
That's one scenario. Another is that Saddam Hussein, prior to an American attack, goes after Israel with the chemical or biological weapons that Mr. Bush says Iraq possesses. Israel, if it survives, will retaliate, perhaps even with nuclear weapons. Such retaliation might indeed bring about the "regime change" Mr. Bush seeks, but it would not end the story.
Just over the horizon lies Pakistan, a Muslim country armed with nuclear weapons and permeated by extremists. Pervez Musharraf, its president, has joined America's war on terrorism but he is unlikely to survive politically should there be a nuclear attack by an American ally on Iraq's Muslims. Islamists, overthrowing him, would take control of Pakistan's nuclear arsenal; lacking the ability to launch missiles that would reach Israel, they would turn on India, their more proximate enemy. A nuclear attack would set off global chaos.
Before Sept. 11, I probably would not have written the above lines. I have covered the Middle East conflict as a journalist for several decades, but I would have considered such scenarios fantasy, if not madness. Now they seem to me at least plausible.
The responsibility of America's leadership is to prevent the plausible from becoming reality. The cold war is a useful precedent. Saddam Hussein's power, and perhaps his evil too, pale next to that of Stalin. Yet even when we had clear military superiority over Stalin we chose not to attack him.
All our presidents, Republican and Democratic alike, accepted the principle of avoiding a war that might wreck the planet. Mr. Bush is the first to question this principle, and his resolve is bolstered by Vice President Dick Cheney and Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, both of whom close their eyes to the potential ramifications of a war with Iraq.
 I raq, as a highly centralized tyranny dedicated to its own preservation, is not that different from the old Soviet Union, and it is no coincidence that the same deterrence that restrained the Kremlin has kept Iraq in line for a decade. The Soviet Union's ultimate fall with barely a whimper vindicated America's patience, and in time Saddam Hussein too will vanish. Is not Sept. 11 a compelling reminder that the steadfast vigilance exercised by our leaders for a half-century of cold war is wiser than rushing toward a worst-case outcome?

HEADLINE: Tragedy Kindles Dance of Hope 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
Eric Underwood was waiting for a dress rehearsal to begin at Purchase College in Westchester County on Sept. 11, 2001, when he heard about the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. He and other members of the Dance Theater of Harlem were preparing for a performance in the Evening Stars series in World Trade Plaza. The troupe piled into the company bus, which got as far as the Macombs Dam Bridge. No vehicle was allowed to enter Manhattan, so the dancers got out of the bus and continued on foot. "All these ballerinas and guys walking across the bridge to Manhattan," Mr. Underwood recalled. He made it home and began trying to reach his parents in Washington.
 Tai Jimenez, who will perform with the Harlem troupe tomorrow afternoon in this year's Evening Stars series in Battery Park in a ballet inspired by that day, heard the news as she drove into Manhattan from Queens for a business appointment. Traffic had come to a stop, as ambulances, police cars and fire trucks sped by. Eventually Ms. Jimenez was able to head south to be with a group of friends she calls her "Brooklyn hang." Together they went on to Fort Greene Park and joined others looking toward Lower Manhattan in an eerie quiet. 
 Arthur Mitchell, director of Dance Theater, was leaving his Manhattan apartment to drive to the company's headquarters, when the building superintendent cried out to him that someone had crashed a plane into the towers. Mr. Mitchell continued uptown, arriving to find that the little office television had gone dead. One phone line was functioning. "So everything was being represented to us by telephone," Mr. Mitchell said. "It brought me back to the 40's, when there was no television, and people huddled by the radio."
Liz Thompson, who directs the Evening Stars series, had just finished an early-morning business breakfast at Windows on the World. She left the elevator at the ground floor, still discussing the subject at hand, and "two sentences later" the first plane hit. She somehow made her way to a basement-level exit, forced not to panic by the hysteria of a pregnant security guard she encountered on the way. Outside, Ms. Thompson looked up and saw fire and falling glass and then the second plane crashing into the south tower. On her way uptown she met a friend who took her home with her. 
Michael Smuin was in his study at home in San Francisco reading through a Schubert score for a new ballet for his company, Smuin Ballets/SF, when an associate called and told him to turn on the television. He did, then left for a rehearsal. Mr. Smuin said he had told his dancers that they could go home if they liked, but that they would feel better if they worked. And they did. 
Out of those varied experiences has come Mr. Smuin's new "Stabat Mater," a dance about loss, memory and hope. The Latin title alludes to the sorrow of Mary as she watched her son dying on the cross. The ballet is set to the first section of Dvorak's Stabat Mater, which was created during a time when three of his children died. 
Mr. Smuin had long loved the music, he said, and he found himself playing it over and over in the days following the attack. Could he shift gears, he asked Carol Buck, the patron who had commissioned the Schubert ballet, and set the piece to Dvorak? Ms. Buck agreed. But the piece would not come. Then suddenly, the day before he was to begin rehearsals, he found the ballet's central image in the televised funeral of a New York fireman. 
"It was so symmetrical," Mr. Smuin recalled. "They had the casket in the center, and there was a couple at each corner. The men were standing behind their women. The widow and her children were at the top of the casket. And at one point this woman, downstage right as it were, lifted her head and fainted smack backwards, and the guy caught her at the last moment, before she hit the ground. And that was it. From then on I just sort of stepped back and kept out of the way because the damned ballet practically choreographed itself. I just let the music dictate what it was." All that he was sure of, he said, was that the ballet could not be danced in toe shoes. The piece needed to be earthy, not aerial. 
Mr. Mitchell had heard about "the 9/11 ballet" as people called it to Mr. Smuin's dismay. He watched a videotape of Mr. Smuin's company performing the piece last spring and knew he had to have it for Dance Theater and for the Evening Stars performance, which takes place a year to the day after the company was to dance in the series. Mr. Smuin, who has worked with the Harlem troupe on several projects, gave the dance to the company as a gift. And like all the Evening Stars roster, Dance Theater is performing free.
Mr. Mitchell recalled thinking, "Oh, yes," as he watched his dancers rehearsing "Stabat Mater." "It's the kind of piece that I would love to do in a cathedral with an orchestra and chorus," he said. "But it's so real, because it looks like people. Not a ballet-ballet." 
"Stabat Mater" is also not a "ballet-ballet" to Ms. Jimenez and Mr. Underwood, who play a woman and the ghost of someone she has loved. "The difference for me is that I don't feel like I'm giving a performance," Mr. Underwood said. "It's an interactive thing, because of the circumstances. I'm just a part of what is taking place."
Ms. Jimenez said she felt a particularly strong emotional connection to the piece. "I think people will be watching with a different kind of investment," she said, adding that she always made up a story for herself when she danced a role. In "Stabat Mater" Ms. Jimenez finds herself thinking of all that has been left unresolved with the beloved that she has lost. "This is the part where I feel I'm going to lose it," Ms. Jimenez said ruefully of tomorrow's performance. "Even when he comes back, I feel that her grief is so great that she wants to go with him, but she can't." 
There are four other couples in the ballet. "To me they symbolize members of the community coming together and, in my own personal story, my 'Brooklyn hang,' " Ms. Jimenez said. "There is one moment when the woman is sitting on the floor, and they're dancing around her. I look at them. That's Qasim. That's my friend Vipal. And Shahzad. And Petre. And Jyoti. And Swati and Michael and Laurie.
"We were all together on Sept. 11. And I also think of the community of dancers, who I love very much because they're my family, too. I think if one of us was gone, how we'd all come together." 
Mr. Underwood sees his immediate family in the dancers with whom he is to share the stage. He said he remembered "talking with my mother on Sept. 11, having her be so panicked that maybe I wasn't here."
Dancing the returning spirit in "Stabat Mater" is "like I'm looking in on the what-if," he said. "I dance for my family, and tell them that it's O.K. I tell them that I'm still here. Although I'm not here physically, I'm still here, with them." 
He also thinks of those lost on Sept. 11. "I feel like I could just go in and have some kind of out-of-body experience, for all those people that were missing," Mr. Underwood said. "Dance for them, and their families, as if I were that person missing." 
By February Ms. Thompson was back to planning this year's Evening Stars series and finding a location. "I thought it was really important, not only for me but as an expression of the resiliency of our city," she said. At first she operated on blind hope, given the difficulty of raising money in the city's post-Sept. 11 economy. But support began to flow in. 
"One of the first things I said," Ms. Thompson recalled, "was that performances of wonderful music and dance would be an 'alive' memorial." 

One Year Later
Dance Theater of Harlem will perform in the free Evening Stars festival of music and dance in Battery Park tomorrow at 4 p.m. in a program that includes Michael Smuin's "Stabat Mater," Geoffrey Holder's "Dougla" and "South African Suite," a ballet choreographed by Arthur Mitchell, Augustus van Heerden and Laveen Naidu.
Also performing in the series, at 7 p.m., are the Garth Fagan Dance Company (tonight), Parsons Dance Company (Tuesday), Trisha Brown Dance Company (Wednesday), the Kronos Quartet with Tony MacMahon on accordion (Thursday) and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company (next Friday.)
All performances are at Battery Park. Information: (212) 219-9401, Ext. 300, or www.lmcc.net.

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES 

BYLINE:  By Dave Kehr 

DATELINE: TORONTO 

 BODY:
Finding Magic Close to Home
 The Australian director Phillip Noyce has two very-well-received films here at the Toronto International Film Festival, both made outside of the Hollywood studio system that has been his home base for the last decade ("Patriot Games," "Clear and Present Danger") and both dealing with the moral quandaries of colonialism. 
 "Rabbit-Proof Fence" is based on the true story of three Aboriginal girls who, in 1931, escaped from a government re-education camp and walked back to their families 1,500 miles away. "The Quiet American" is an adaptation of the Graham Greene novel about a British journalist (Michael Caine) and his uneasy friendship with an idealistic O.S.S. agent (Brendan Fraser) in the Vietnam of the early 1950's.
"I grew up in Australia at a time, in the 1950's and 60's, when there was no Australian cinema," Mr. Noyce recalled, his 6-foot-4 frame folded into a rickety hotel room chair. "We were a colony of two masters, Britain historically and America economically and militarily." 
"But Hollywood is the most efficient colonizer the world has ever known," he said. "It controls both hearts and minds. It's convinced Eskimos sitting in their igloos that its version of experience is more valid to them than their own daily lives."
After Mr. Noyce made the successful thriller "Dead Calm" in 1989, he was invited to Hollywood. "I felt like the kid in the candy store," he said. "I settled down at Paramount and made 5 films in 10 years. I became a studio director, and I lived that dream in all its madness and all its glory. But after a while, I began to feel I was out of touch with Australia, and yet I clearly was not an American." When "The Sum of All Fears," which was to be the third of Mr. Noyce's adaptations of Tom Clancy thrillers starring Harrison Ford, fell apart because of Mr. Ford's reluctance to commit to the script, Mr. Noyce had had enough. "I had become a waiter," he said, "waiting on a star." 
Mr. Noyce remembered a story, "Rabbit-Proof Fence," that had intrigued him. "There I was," he said, "working on manipulating this overblown Hollywood product, trying to make the central character strong, give him more empathy for the audience, make his triumph at the end greater -- all the things I realized every morning were already there in this little story of three little children."
So Mr. Noyce returned to Australia to make "Rabbit-Proof Fence," and then went to Vietnam to film "The Quiet American," a longtime project of his that, after being rejected by Paramount, had finally come together as an independent production. (A version starring Michael Redgrave, was brought to the screen by Joseph L. Mankiewicz in 1957.)
"After we completed our rough cut and started screening it last year, we found that after 9/11 some of the aspects of the movie were a little bit hard for audiences to handle," Mr. Noyce said, referring to the terrorist incident that occurs at the film's climax. "We began to wonder if the film had arrived at the wrong moment in time. We're here in Toronto screening the film, putting our finger up and testing the wind to see if the wound is still as raw as it was. It was made about events in the early 50's, but suddenly some of the themes Graham Greene was investigating, his portrait of a young American political evangelist, have perhaps even more relevance today than they had then. In the short term, it's produced a certain nervousness. But maybe in the long term it means that, instead of the film being about ancient history, its about modern history."

Quagmire City
Terry Gilliam, the visionary director of "Brazil" and "The Fisher King," found himself in Toronto not as a filmmaker but as a film's subject. "Lost in La Mancha," directed by Keith Fulton and Louis Pepe, tells of Mr. Gilliam's stubborn, but ultimately futile attempt to film an adaptation of "Don Quixote" starring Johnny Depp and the French actor Jean Rochefort.
The film veers from black comedy to absurdist tragedy, with Mr. Gilliam as an unfailingly good-humored Job, to whom everything that can go wrong does go wrong. The project finally shut down after storms destroyed a set, Mr. Rochefort became ill and the insurance company seized the props and costumes. But for Mr. Gilliam, "The Man Who Killed Don Quixote," as his film was titled, is not over yet.
"We're negotiating right now with the insurance company at long last, talking real numbers," Mr. Gilliam reported. "They want it off their hands. I was told that they were also heavily into insuring the World Trade Center. So it's been a learning experience for them."
"But the props have all been sold and dispersed," he added. "So we'll just have to go back to prop shop and build them all over again. We were making a lot of stuff that was just beautiful, and now it's gone."
Mr. Gilliam dismissed the idea that the lost material could be recreated through digital effects. "Digital is fantastic, but it's got to be used very carefully," he said. "Otherwise, you end up with the last 'Star Wars' -- the first film I've seen that's all background and no foreground. None of it feels real or magical."
But Johnny Depp remains committed to the project, and Mr. Gilliam hopes he may be shooting again as early as October -- weather and windmills permitting.

George Loves Alfred
"Children of the Century," Diane Kurys's French feature about the famously tumultuous love affair between George Sand (played by Juliette Binoche) and Alfred de Musset (Benoit Magimel), had its North American premiere here two years ago. It is opening today in Manhattan (review, Page 16) in a new cut prepared by Ms. Kurys.
"I cut quite a few things at the start, and tightened things up," Ms. Kurys said by phone from her home in Paris, "so now it concentrates more completely on their love story and less on who they were before they met. I also shortened the ending, but the American distributor wanted me to keep the original. I like this version better than the French one. It gets more quickly to the essentials."
"They were quite exceptional people," Ms. Kurys said of her characters, "and I thought they deserved at least one film, which they haven't had up until now. There have been attempts to film George Sand's love affair with Chopin, but nothing about her romance with Alfred de Musset. But with Musset she was much younger and more passionate." 
Ms. Kurys drew much of the material of the film from her characters' books. "When two writers fall in love," she said, "they start to write. Their love nourished their work."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Family Tensions and Joy, Played but Not Spoken

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
At least by today's accelerated standards, the video artist Alix Pearlstein has taken her time maturing. Having exhibited in New York since 1988, she began as a sculptor, took up video in 1992, and has seven solo shows to her credit. But her work, while coherent, distinctive and entertaining, has usually left me waiting for more, and better. The centerpiece of her solo No. 8, Ms. Pearlstein's first show at Artemis Greenberg Van Doren Gallery, delivers just that: more, and better.
 "Episode," a 10-minute video installation using two wall projections, focuses on some of the basic tensions and joys of family life. Ms. Pearlstein's most ambitious and accomplished work to date, it treats human interaction with a resonance, subtlety and emotional depth that previously didn't seem a part of her game plan. Its opposing projections, filling the short walls of a longish gallery, activate real space, and the viewer within it, with post-minimalist flair. 
 Although the installation makes good on many elements that have long been part of Ms. Pearlstein's approach, it was never clear that she was even headed in the general direction of "Episode." Since turning from sculpture to video, this artist has brought something of a miniaturist's perfectionism to the early-1970's home-alone, me-and-my-Camcorder tradition associated with video pioneers like William Wegman, Bruce Nauman and Joan Jonas.
Working in front of seamless white paper that adds crisp outlines and a commercial-art note, Ms. Pearlstein extended this tradition with a distinctive combination of finish and casualness. She was aided by an innate understanding of video's implicit quirks, protocols, intimacy and illusionistic possibilities.
Ms. Pearlstein either starred in those videos -- maintaining her poise whether mimicking an Ingres odalisque or wearing a bunny suit -- or directed friends, performance artists and professional actors with the firm discreetness of a puppeteer. When her props exceeded what she had around the house or could make, she turned to magazines, cutting out pictures of street signs, dogs and even people, and working them into the tape, adding an endearing suggestion of collage.
The results were often wry greeting-card moments of emotional connection between people, torqued by visual puns, word-play pantomime, art references and perfectly timed sound effects. They had a familial sweetness and an urbane sense of economy, but they were often not quite funny enough -- more "Sesame Street" than New Yorker cartoon.
Until recently, all this suggested a very smart creative director, alert to the latest art tics, playing around in a magazine's photo studio on a Saturday. Or perhaps a hyper-organized gardener cultivating a small plot of land -- bonsai video.
In the last two years, it seems, something began to change. Ms. Pearlstein's people started appearing naked, interacting with the collaged images of other naked people; her camera assumed a state of constant motion and inconstant focus, becoming a kind of participant in the action, as has happened in current sitcoms. Her recent videos, even shorter than usual, had a dreamlike wooziness, not exactly charged but inflected with sexual longing.
"Episode" taps into those feelings -- in diffused and complicated form -- as the basic undercurrent of family life, powering the interactions of an average family's requisite four members, all superbly played by adult actors who run around barefoot in their at-home clothes. David Mazzeo plays the father, Catherine Curtin the mother. Emily Unterweger plays the daughter. As the son, James Urbaniak, who has worked with Ms. Pearlstein before, adds a scrawniness and rubbery face worthy of George Booth.
"Episode" consists of many short episodes and interactions. It's like a little play about family life, only pantomimed, with the cast's actions and feelings intermittently amplified or exaggerated by sound effects. Loose-limbed, sometimes to the point of seeming like rag dolls, the family members rush about with an improvisational energy, careering off camera and back on, making contact, pulling back, showing tenderness or rage. Life moves fast, and so does the camera, following them, coming close, then moving away, often at similarly careering tilts and angles.
Walking into the gallery can feel like stepping into someone's dance piece or into one of Richard Bellingham's photographs of his dysfunctional family, here scrubbed clean and brought to life. The double images, which you can't see simultaneously, are disorienting and continue a long tradition of split-vision video art and sculpture, dating back at least to Richard Serra's early work.
The device is especially important in video right now because it is one way moving images can physically involve the viewer, and this involvement is the main characteristic that separates video from the movies, and galleries containing video artworks from movie theaters.
Ms. Pearlstein's version is especially acrobatic. Her actors tumble about continuously, pursued by the camera, which is in the expert hands of the artist and Amy Epstein. In particular, she makes the viewer an extension of the camera, which is already functioning like a nosy neighbor, a referee or an extra relative in the unfolding events.
One quibble is that the interactions are a little too predictable: the father's excessive attention to the daughter, the mother's attempt to keep up with her son's taste in music, the kids' fighting and teasing and sometimes violent outbursts, the parents' little dance of antagonism and attraction. But there are moments of real tension, as when the father circles the three others in a classic display of paternal fury and then juts his face into the camera's lens. And there are comedic interludes, as when the son mimics his father preening ever so slightly before the mirror.
Admittedly, this family is exceptionally average -- straight, white and given to gender stereotype -- but the relationships and constantly shifting balances of power are beyond familiar. They are in our bones; just fill in the appropriate names and faces.
Ms. Pearlstein is also operating with her usual economy and precision, simply asking us, as before, to watch what her characters are doing. What they are doing is communicating extremely complicated situations without uttering a word, although the sound effects, sharp as ever, help. It is impressive to watch them achieve this with so little apparent effort, just as it is meaningful to grasp the finer nuances of feeling that emerge with repeated viewing.
Once you figure out that the two projections are not quite identical, and that Ms. Pearlstein hasn't wasted a second, a gesture or a glance, you may find yourself turning your head back and forth in rapid tennis-match style, or rotating in space to make sure you're not missing any bit of them. While the action remains pretty much the same on both walls, the details of expression and gesture don't.
As in life itself, the feelings keep changing, amplifying and elaborating on one another, weaving the ever-present web that is, in the words of the British psychoanalyst D. W. Winnicott, where we start from.

"Alix Pearlstein: Episode" remains at the Artemis Greenberg Van Doren Gallery, 730 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 445-0444, through Oct. 5.

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
In Alabama, Battling the Ghost Of a Golf Legend

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL ONEAL 

 BODY:
TUCKED around a corner -- near the bathroom of all places -- in the spacious, wood-beamed clubhouse of the Capitol Hill golf complex near Montgomery, Ala., hangs a large photograph of Robert Trent Jones Sr., America's pre-eminent golf-course architect, who died two years ago at 93.
 He's standing on the fairway of one of the signature holes along the Robert Trent Jones Golf Trail in Alabama. But if you didn't know better, you'd assume he had just emerged from a pub in the Scottish Highlands, far from the swampy heat of the American Deep South. His thick tweed jacket covers a rumpled cardigan. His compact frame leans heavily on a craggy blackthorn cane. Droopy eyes twinkle above a crooked half smile. The knot on his tie is slightly askew. 
In all, he looks like someone's kindly old uncle. So why was I gripped by a sudden urge to leap through the picture glass and throttle him? 
The answer lies somewhere between my eighth or ninth shot (who was counting at that point?) on that very same hole two days earlier. But before I go into that, let me say that I now understand why even the pros talk about Mr. Jones in the peculiar way they do. Legends from Ben Hogan to Jack Nicklaus have complained loudly about his designs. And after struggling mightily on Mr. Jones's menacing Spyglass Hill course in Pebble Beach, Calif., Lee Trevino once said: "They just ought to hang the man who designed this course. Ray Charles could have done better."
"Golfers complain a lot," Mr. Jones told Sports Illustrated in 1993 when asked about Mr. Trevino's remark. Count me among them. 
My golf buddy Brent Rumage and I -- high handicappers both -- went to Alabama looking for what is beginning to make the Robert Trent Jones Golf Trail, which includes Capitol Hill, famous: some of the best public golf you'll find anywhere in the world. Over a long -- very long -- weekend we visited four of the trail's eight multicourse golf complexes and played 126 of its 378 wrenching holes. 
We drove from Birmingham to Opelika to Montgomery to Mobile hoping to soak up some of the Old South along the way. That, unfortunately, proved to be elusive. While Southern charm and friendliness are abundant in Alabama, (so abundant it made a couple of New Yorkers a little nervous at first), suburban sprawl has much of the state in its clutches. The hotels offered in our golf package invariably dropped us in the middle of vast, neon-encrusted grids of Waffle Houses and Shoney's. They looked eerily the same from city to city and, for that matter, not much different than the strip malls outside of Cleveland or Pittsburgh. 
The golf courses, however, were exquisite and exquisitely difficult. I'd like to say we played them respectably, but I'd surely be lying. How can I put this delicately? After burning through all the golf balls we came with, we managed to lay waste to a bag of 48 used balls we bought out of desperation at the Wal-Mart in Auburn.
"These golf courses make you a better golfer," said Michael Barber, the assistant pro at the Grand National complex in Opelika. I'm still clinging to that.
Mr. Jones called the trail his last great masterpiece. He came out of retirement to design the courses in the early 1990's, commissioned by the quixotic, but powerful, Dr. David G. Bronner, the chief executive of the Retirement Systems of Alabama, the state's big public employees' pension fund.
Amid a storm of controversy, Dr. Bronner (as everybody calls him; he has a Ph.D. in higher education and administration) spent $145 million in public retirement funds to build 21 courses at eight sites stretching from the Appalachians in the north to the Gulf of Mexico in the south. His reasoning: "The stronger the Retirement Systems of Alabama can make Alabama, the stronger the retirement systems will be." 
If strengthening Alabama with public golf courses seems an odd tactic -- especially for a pension fund manager -- it's hard to find fault with the results so far. Having pulled in a profit of just $6 million last year, the golf courses themselves are only marginally profitable for the $25 billion retirement system. But they serve as the centerpiece of a roundly successful effort to bolster tourism and attract industry to Alabama over the last decade. They've even spawned state-financed imitators in Tennessee and Louisiana. Besides, Dr. Bronner said, they've done a "lot better than the stock market recently." 
They're also part of an increasingly conspicuous struggle to help the state live down its segregationist past. The painful trial of Bobby Frank Cherry, who was convicted last May in the 1963 bombing of a church in Birmingham, still stings in Alabama. But the first thing you see when heading for your bags in the Birmingham airport is a sign for the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute.
In Montgomery, where an Interstate named after Martin Luther King Jr. intersects with the Hank Williams "Lost Highway," the Rosa Parks Library and Museum opened with great fanfare in December 2000. Tourism related to the civil rights movement "has become part of the economy," said Jack E. Davis, a historian and civil rights specialist at the University of Alabama at Birmingham.
The golf trail addresses the race issue more pragmatically. Don't forget that only about a decade ago a national furor ignited when the Professional Golfers Association of America planned to hold the P.G.A. Championship at the all-white Shoal Creek Country Club near Birmingham. Protests by civil rights groups forced Shoal Creek to admit a black member and the P.G.A. to change how it chooses courses. These days at the trail's Oxmoor Valley complex across town, blacks and whites play golf alongside each other on courses that rival the best private country clubs. In the prime spring season, the most expensive round of golf on the trail is around $65 -- a pittance compared with greens fees that are more than double that at many comparable courses. In fact, the only thing exclusive about the golf trail is the tiny group of players who are consistently able to score par. 
That said, it occurred to me in my darker moments that opening up a Robert Trent Jones course to the public is really just equal-opportunity masochism. Unlike, say, a Tom Fazio course, or even one designed by Robert Trent Jones's son, Bobby Jones, these layouts are unforgiving in all respects. The elder Mr. Jones liked to challenge golfers to hit "heroic" shots, those that call for mastery, not chance. He often said that nobody remembers the easy courses. Consequently, his fairways are gorgeous but as narrow as a school hallway. His landings are precise and far away. His rough is long and as sticky as Velcro. His greens, as the younger Mr. Jones once quipped, are like "aircraft carriers on which to land the ball, surrounded by a sea of trouble." 
AND that gets me back to that photo of Mr. Jones Sr. hanging on the clubhouse wall. 
After flying into Birmingham our first night and savoring the delights of Jim 'N Nick's Bar-B-Q (pronounced Jimmynicks in Alabama), we began our tour at Oxmoor Valley southwest of town. "Hit 'em straight and hit 'em long, but don't hit too many of 'em," the starter drawled as we approached the first tee. We chuckled with him, blissfully ignorant of what lurked ahead. 
We played the Valley course in the morning and the Ridge course in the afternoon, and by the time we reached the 12th on the Ridge, I was tired but playing reasonably well. The 12th is one of Oxmoor's most beautiful holes and the setting for that photo of Mr. Jones. It's an impossibly long, up-and-down par 5 that demands a towering second shot over a creek followed by an equally powerful long iron to a pedestal green perched high on a cliff of exposed shale. Let's just say I managed none of that. 
Instead, I hit a short drive, dubbed my second shot and rolled my third into the creek, dropping for my first penalty. Pulling myself together, I uncorked a beauty to within a few feet of the hole -- only to find it buried in the deep, clinging 419 Bermuda rough that lay behind the green. Chopping at it with my wedge, I sent it whizzing dangerously past my partner and back down the cliff. This I followed with two unfortunate hacks against the shale and another shank into more of the 419. Walking to the cart, I tried to shake it all off, but the searing knowledge that my once-promising score lay in ruins had already begun to unhinge me. My next drive, naturally, plopped into the gorse and for a brief moment I was reduced to a sputtering, blathering idiot.
Episodes like this recurred more often than I would like to say as we traveled to courses near Montgomery, Opelika and Mobile the next few days. We tried to play two different courses a day and might have thought ourselves obsessive if not for the countless other pilgrims we encountered.
We did find some pleasant distractions, like a visit to Dr. King's old neighborhood in Montgomery, which looks not too different from the old newsreels), and a late-night saunter through Mobile's haunting old Dauphin Street district, where the heavy air, seedy bars and second-story balconies recall a mellower version of the French Quarter of New Orleans. But the weekend was really about golf and its uncanny ability to rouse our inner demons. 
Perhaps the game's greatest mystery is why this counts as fun. Well, I didn't tell you about the one or two birdies I managed to steal from Mr. Jones or those fleeting moments when the ball dropped safely on the emerald fairway and proudly reflected the slanting evening sun from a spot more than 200 yards in the distance. 
At those times -- rare as they were -- all was right with the world. I could even manage to laugh at the tale about Mr. Jones involving his remodeling of the Lower Course at the Baltusrol Golf Club in New Jersey. Members complained that Mr. Jones had made the par 3 fourth hole, which stretches over a pond, too difficult by lengthening it and creating a two-tier green. So the architect deigned to play it with two members and the club pro. Each player hit before Mr. Jones stepped to the members tee and nailed a four-iron to the green for a hole-in-one. "Gentlemen," he said, "the hole is eminently fair." 
Maybe so, but I'd still like a shot at him.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
A Long and Winding Road To the Perfect Clunker

BYLINE:  By SARA IVRY 

 BODY:
ONE day, one grand, one car. That was the challenge. Is it still possible, in 2002, to buy a car for $1,000?
 "You're dreaming," was the answer Tom Magliozzi, the co-host of "Car Talk" on National Public Radio, had to this question. "Everybody has a story about some old clunker that just runs and runs but looks like hell. This is mostly a fairy tale involving frogs and princes and ugly ducklings." 
 He wasn't finished. "You'll find cars that are maybe as old as 15 years," he wrote me in an e-mail message. "Is there a gem among them? Maybe. Can you find it? Maybe, if you want to make it your life's work." 
Bill Hower, the owner of Jim's Garage in Canaan, Conn., explained the economics. Back when the average new car cost $10,000, he said, picking up a $1,000 used car was "a real doable thing." But that was 10 years ago. "Now the average new car costs $20,000," Mr. Hower said. So $1,000 is a mere 5 percent of the original cost, not enough to buy much.
But I set out anyway, in a borrowed Volvo, on a road trip in rural New York and Connecticut (everything is cheaper in the country, right?) to look for a $1,000 car. The question was, "Can it be done?"
My first stop was McLean Ford-Mercury in Millerton, N.Y., near the Connecticut border, about 90 miles from Manhattan. A 1998 Mercury Sable, at $7,500, was among the cheapest cars on the lot. Its leather interior and sunroof were seductive, but the test drive was like trying on a pair of Prada shoes you know you'll never buy.
A salesman made a strong pitch for financing and monthly payments, but there was nothing here for $1,000.
Next was Amenia Motors in Amenia, N.Y. Chrysler PT Cruisers beckoned in front; the cheaper cars were parked in back. A 1990 Ford Escort, at $1,495, was at least close to the right price.
"George Bell brought it in on Friday, traded it in for a Neon," Dan Simmons, the sales manager, told me. "You know George Bell?"
I don't, but I tried out his old car, a four-door hatchback with a red interior. Going uphill, the car never ceased shuddering. On the way down, its brakes resisted doing their job. The air-conditioning was not working, making the snug car feel like the inside of a toaster oven.
Dealers may offer warranties on their newest used cars, a vital consideration. But since major parts tend to break down on older cars -- new brakes can cost $1,000, and transmission repairs, $4,000 -- there's not much margin left for a warranty on a $1,000 car. 
Mr. Hower had counseled that my best bet would be a car being sold by its owner, and my road trip was bearing this out.
I bought some local weekly papers and checked the classified ads. There was a 1988 Toyota for $1,200 -- still too much. A 1991 Nissan at $700 had to be a disaster, and my assignment allowed me $300 more.
A 1990 Subaru for $600 was even more unlikely, but I called the number in the ad anyway. The engine habitually shut off in middrive, the owner told me. This sounded like an honest admission, and disclosure is a big issue in the search for a cheap car.
On Route 44 just inside Connecticut, a man was hawking a 1984 Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme by the side of the road. He insisted he would be happy to have a mechanic check it out as a condition of sale. The catch was that the mechanic would have to make an on-site visit, which meant it would be impossible to examine the tires and chassis properly.
I noticed some rust on the rear tire rim. Rust is a peril, Hank Schieb, a mechanic in Winsted, Conn., had told me. He had a list of things to check in a car search: leaks of any kind, the condition of the tires, obvious body work, rust underneath the car or on the frame, any unusual noises, and smoke from the tailpipe.
Deeper into Connecticut, a ramshackle garage in East Canaan offered a musty 1992 Dodge Spirit for $1,500. It had scratched paint, a plush crimson interior and 123,000 miles on the odometer. It shivered deeply when I started the engine.
After this experience, Alfas Unlimited, a shop that specializes in Alfa Romeos in Norfolk, Conn., was too inviting to pass by. Maybe somebody needed to get rid of an Alfa fast. Not so, but the cars were lovely to look at. A repairman told me that the blood-red 1964 Giulia Super sedan parked in front, with a mere 25,000 miles on it, had cost the owner $6,000 plus the price of a ticket to France, where he bought it.
At the Auto Center, a dealership on Main Street in Winsted, I found a 1986 Toyota Corolla for $2,000. It seemed like a good bet for someone whose budget was plumper. Aside from Victor (he wouldn't give his last name), a mechanic at Troy's Garage in Adams, Mass., who had urged me to consider the Chrysler K-car, everyone I consulted before setting out on my search had recommended Japanese cars, particularly Toyotas and Hondas, no matter their age. 
What about shopping on the Internet? Cars for $1,000 or less are posted on Web sites like carfax.com and autotrader.com, both of which allow for searches by make, price range and location. If you have the time and patience, this is an option. But buying a used car through the Internet is not like picking up a chipped Hummel figurine on eBay. You still have to go and look, meet the owner, drive the car and have a mechanic check it.
In the end, luck smiled on me back where I started, in Millerton. Lots of Volvos -- an appealing sight -- were basking on the lot at Basil's, an independent dealer. They all turned out to be well over $1,000, but in the waiting room at Basil's sat Jay Lichtman from nearby Wassaic, N.Y. He began to talk about the 1986 Buick Skylark with 98,000 miles that he planned to sell by the end of this year for $1,000, exactly what he paid for it last November.
The Skylark is a granny car, he told me. "Old people drive it." That means retirees and no daily commuting, always a plus for keeping a car pristine.
Mr. Lichtman and I drove 20 minutes to his house. The Skylark was green, with the original fabric headliner now stapled up to keep it from falling on passengers' heads.
The car started smoothly and glided down the driveway. The power steering was effortless, and moving the wheel seemed to require little more than the twitch of a finger. The brakes squeaked, but only slightly. The previous owner, Mr. Lichtman said, had changed the oil every 1,000 miles, and he had passed along the receipts to prove it.
It had been a full day, but there it was. Come December, when Mr. Lichtman is really ready to sell, someone is going to get a good deal on a $1,000 car.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
On East Side, New Option for Elderly

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
When it is completed next month, Carnegie East House, a 19-story subsidized assisted-living residence on Second Avenue between 95th and 96th Streets, will represent a tale of perseverance in the face of bureaucratic roadblocks and rising costs.
 In 1987, Friedhilde Milburn, president of Health Advocates for Older People, sponsor of the project, began talking about putting up an assisted-living residence "where people could live out their last years with the support services they needed without having to be declared patients." 
 But planning and fund-raising did not begin in earnest until the mid-1990's and construction, by the Gotham Construction Company, until March 2001. The first tenants are expected in December. 
"Our mission is to let people age in place, and we intend to keep people unless they need high-tech or life-sustaining medical care or are so demented they disturb the peace of the house," Mrs. Milburn said. "If they are just old and feeble we will bring services in." 
"We experienced major delays because there is no easy funding stream for assisted living in New York State," she explained. "I had to marry tax-exempt bond financing from the New York State Housing Finance Agency with mortgage insurance from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development." After three years, she said, she found the Housing Finance Agency moving so slowly on the mortgage that she switched the application for funds to the city's Housing Development Corporation.
The mortgage was $30 million and HUD required the Housing Development Fund Company, the sponsor's development arm, to come up with $4.5 million, which it raised by offering organizations, foundations, religious institutions and individual donors sponsorships of apartments. 
Mrs. Milburn also established an endowment for which $2 million of a projected $3.5 million has been raised. It will be used to subsidize tenants who run out of money. 
Because the mortgage came from tax-exempt city bonds, 20 percent of the building's 104 apartments are reserved for people with incomes below $39,000 a year. More than 300 applications have been submitted for the 12 subsidized studios, which will rent for $1,905 a month, and the one-bedroom apartments, for $2,041. Candidates will be chosen through a lottery. Mrs. Milburn said that the rent at Carnegie East House will include three meals a day, recreation and social work. 
The market-rate rents at Carnegie House East, which was designed by Perkins Eastman Architects, are set at $3,900 to $4,200 for studios, $4,900 to $5,100 for one bedrooms and $6,150 to $7,900 for two bedrooms. All apartments have kitchenettes and 55-square-foot bathrooms with walk-in showers. Sixteen of the 83 market-rate apartments have been rented. 
Communal amenities will include solariums, a spa with whirlpool bath and laundry rooms on each floor, a garden, patio and space for crafts, computers and movies and a dining room for private parties. 
Mrs. Milburn estimated that tenants paying the market rate would need annual incomes of $50,000 to $100,000. She said, "If you look at the demographics of the Upper East Side, I do think there are enough people who can afford market rate." 
She said she would have preferred to put up something smaller and to put it on the same block as James Lenox house, a Mitchell Lama building on East 73rd Street between Park and Lexington Avenues for people over 55, where she is executive director. (With the rent for a one-bedroom unit there at $935 a month, there is a wait of 6 to 10 years.) 
"But economies of scale don't really permit you do to 20 to 40 beds in Manhattan," she said, "and because of zoning you can't do large buildings on mid-blocks on the East Side." 
Calling the project "a vertical village," she said she believed it would succeed where others had faltered. "One reason assisted living has run into problems is because they are put up in tranquil settings," she said. "But people don't want cows and green. They want the vibrations of the city and to stay with the few friends and neighbors they have left."

Twenty percent of the building's 104 apartments will be reserved for people with incomes below $39,000 a year. (Photographs by Librado Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Indonesia's Forests Go Under the Ax for Flooring 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: PEKANBARU, Indonesia 

 BODY:
On a verdant two-acre plot, where space has hastily been cleared for a few simple buildings, three heavy-duty band saws whine 24 hours a day, slicing huge logs into boards of varying lengths and widths. 
 Down the road another sawmill, with eight band saws and more than 200 workers, also cuts up logs 24 hours a day. The owners said they cannot keep up with the demand, a claim that's easily believed -- along a four-mile stretch of road, there are an estimated 50 sawmills. 
 After being cut into long planks, most of this wood is bought by traders in Malaysia and Singapore, and then, after being further cut, sanded, molded and grooved, sold around the world -- as flooring in China and Japan, office stationery in Europe and furniture in the United States.
Indonesia's timber industry is booming, good news for a country suffering widespread unemployment and mired in economic stagnation. There is a dark side, however: nearly all of these sawmills operate without a license, and overall, according to government figures, 80 percent of Indonesia's timber trade is illegal, which means that the trees are felled without a license or under a concession that had been secured with a bribe. 
The corruption is rampant. Senior government officials insist on payoffs, from companies and big-time traders, in exchange for concessions. Military commanders take a cut or even have their own operations. The local policeman demands a payment to allow the trucks, laden with illegally cut logs, on the way to illegal sawmills, to proceed along the road.
The upshot is that Indonesia's tropical forests, among the largest in the world, are rapidly disappearing. Vast tracts of once pristine forests have been reduced to barren and scarred wasteland. It is estimated that at least four million acres of forests -- an area roughly the size of Connecticut -- are being stripped of their trees every year, according to government statistics. It is estimated that the lowland natural forests here on the island of Sumatra, home to the endangered orangutan and the rare Sumatran tiger, will be gone within five years; those in Kalimantan, within 10.
"There are lots of reports telling the world about this," said Togu Manurung, professor of forestry at Bogor Agricultural University and director of Forest Watch Indonesia, a nongovernmental organization. "But it is still going on."
"Why?" he asked rhetorically. "Money, power and politics."
The world's consumers must also share some of the responsibility for the devastation, said Hapsoro, director of research at Telapak, an Indonesian environmental organization.
"It is a matter of fairness," Hapsoro said. "It's not fair for us in Indonesia if people in the United States are consuming a lot of wood products, paper and plywood from Indonesia."
The secretary general of Indonesia's Ministry of Forestry, Wahjudi Wardojo, said that stopping illegal logging is the agency's top priority. It will not be easy, though. Although they might look like parts of a thriving cottage industry, many of the sawmills are controlled by people who "have money and power," Mr. Wardojo said, and they can be highly profitable ventures.
At one unlicensed mill that deals in Kempas, a hardwood used in floors, the company buys logs for $90 a cubic meter, cuts them into boards, sands them on both sides, then sells the wood for $280 a cubic meter. As the owner described his operation, he sells his wares to traders in Singapore and Malaysia who market the wood products mostly in China and Taiwan.
In an effort to halt the environmental devastation Indonesia imposed a ban last year on the export of logs. It has had little impact. Once a log has been cut into planks, or simply had the bark shaved off with a chain saw, it is no longer consider a "log," and thus not subject to the ban.
Each day, 15 trucks loaded with logs pull into one of the small sawmills here. Many of the logs come from Tesso Nilo, a forest that environmentalists would like to see converted to an elephant refuges. The mill is unlicensed, as its owner readily admits. To get one, he said, he would have to pay a local official $3,000.
In June, the Malaysian government, embarrassed by news reports that it had become a transit point for Indonesia's illegal timber, banned the import of all logs from Indonesia. Once again, however, the law left a loophole big enough to ship tons of wood through -- the ban does not affect cut timber. 
"It is the same wood, coming in different shapes," said a man at the port in Kuala Linggi, Malaysia, as a forklift moved massive squared logs that had arrived from Indonesia.
With the wood trade in full swing, Ahmad Rashid, a 45-year old Indonesian who owns a couple of 24-foot wooden boats, is just as busy as he has always been. He said he hauls 60 tons of wood a month from Indonesia across the Strait of Malacca here to Port Klang, Malaysia.
Asked if the wood had been legally cut, Mr. Rashid just laughed. He said that initially he brought wood from his village in Indonesia, but that all the trees there had been cut. So now he buys from other villages.
In Indonesia, he pays $90 a ton for meranti, a medium-grade wood, which he sells to a broker in Malaysia for $160 a ton.
The broker, Ng Eng Hua, and his two sons, also traders, import about 2,000 tons of wood a month from Indonesia, Mr. Hua said, sitting in his small, dingy office, on the Aur River. They buy from more than 30 brokers in Indonesia, he said.
Asked if the wood he bought from Indonesia was legally cut or not, he said: "How would I know? They sell. I just buy."
He said that he in turn sells to a number of timber companies in Malaysia. One of them is Kian Huat Timber Trading Company, which is about six miles away.
On a recent day, forklifts were busy moving timber around the yard at Kian Huat. All of the wood comes from Indonesia, said Lim Been Feen, one of the owners. He does not know if it is legally or illegally cut. That is up to the broker he buys it from, he said.
Wood products are a major export for Malaysia, and the country is heavily dependent on logs from Indonesia. That's because a decade ago, in response to a strong campaign by the country's environmentalists, the Malaysian government enacted strict regulations on the cutting of its trees. Now, many of the country's forest areas are parks and reserves.
Many European buyers are saying that they will not buy wood products from Malaysia unless the seller can guarantee that the wood has been legally cut and in keeping with sound environmental practices, said Aimi Lee Abdullah, an officer with the Malaysian Timber Council, a government body that promotes Malaysia's wood exports.
But that is a near impossibility for the Malaysian buyers, she added.
"How do you tell if it is legal or not legal?" she asked. "If you ask the Indonesians to provide you with documents, they provide you with all the documents, you need." The documents, of course, are either forgeries or bought with bribes.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Illegal logging has turned large parts of Indonesia's rain forests into a scarred wasteland. (Raymond Bonner/The New York Times); (Togu Manurung) Map of Indonesia highlighting Pekanbaru: Tropical forests on the island of Sumatra have been denuded by illegal logging and sawmills. Satellite photos of one area southeast of Pekanbaru show how much of the lowland forests have been felled in only nine years.

HEADLINE: Trade and Job Figures Cast an Economic Shadow 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 

 BODY:
The deficit in the broadest measure of trade with foreign countries, the current account, grew sharply in the second quarter to a record level, the government said today.
 A separate report by the Labor Department said the number of Americans signing up for state unemployment benefits last week rose unexpectedly to the highest figure in more than four months. 
 In the trade report, the Commerce Department said the current account gap in the second quarter grew 15.6 percent, to $129.96 billion, up from $112.45 billion in the first quarter. The number far exceeded analysts' expectation: a $123.84 billion deficit. 
The overall deficit reflected a widening in the goods-and-services balance, to a record deficit of $110.61 billion. The deficit on investment income grew more than 562 percent, to a record $6.29 billion from $950 million the previous quarter.
Some analysts worry that the size of the deficit is unsustainable and is at risk of a sharp correction, perhaps setting off a fall in the dollar's values. But government officials, including Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, say the deficit is a sign of the economy's strength and its attractiveness to foreign investors.
In the unemployment report, the Labor Department said initial claims climbed 19,000, to a seasonally adjusted 426,000, for the week ended Sept. 7, the highest level since April 20, when claims hit 427,000.
The department said seasonal factors could account for volatility in the report. The four-week moving average, which irons out such fluctuations, rose to 409,500 last week, a number that also points to a lackluster employment picture. The number of workers remaining on state unemployment aid rose by 38,000, to 3.6 million, for the week ended Aug. 31, the latest figures available say.
The Labor Department also said today that import prices rose in August, lifted primarily by higher petroleum prices. Import prices rose by 0.3 percent last month, after gaining 0.4 percent in July, the department said. Excluding petroleum, import prices edged up 0.1 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Markets Stumble on Bad Economic News and Talk of War

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks slumped yesterday as investor sentiment crumbled under the weight of American saber-rattling on Iraq, a warning by the Federal Reserve chief on the ballooning government deficit and data showing a weak economy.
 Thrown into the fray were dour reports on the semiconductor equipment sector as well as on leading companies like McDonald's and Sun Microsystems, the network computing company. 
 "There is nothing for investors to sink their teeth into," said Uri Landesman, portfolio manager at Arlington Capital Management, adding, "Every rally in God knows how long has failed, and that is discouraging." 
"We won't rally until a few companies start telling us things are improving and orders are getting better," Mr. Landesman said. 
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 201.76 points, or 2.35 percent, to 8,379.41. The broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slid 22.54 points, or 2.48 percent, to 886.91. The Nasdaq index fell 35.77 points, or 2.72 percent, to 1,279.68.
Wall Street was rocked yesterday by a sharp rise in the nation's current account deficit, which showed that the economy pulled in imports at a record pace in the second quarter. The government also said the number of Americans signing up for state unemployment benefits rose unexpectedly last week to the highest level in more than four months.
Stocks dropped at the start of trading in reaction to that double dose of data, which heightened concerns over the outlook for the economy. Later, the markets reacted to comments from President Bush and the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan. Mr. Bush told the United Nations General Assembly that military "action will be unavoidable" against Iraq unless the United Nations forces Iraq to disarm. In remarks before Congress, Mr. Greenspan said the economy was holding up, but he warned that a return to spending discipline was vital for economic health.
"If you are a potential buyer of stock," said Gary Wedbush, head of trading at Wedbush Morgan, a regional investment bank based in Los Angeles, "and you have two world leaders talking about issues that could stall economic growth, you are going to be a lot more cautious."
McDonald's fell $1.03, to $20.31, a drop of 4.83 percent, ranking it among the largest percentage losers on the Dow. Salomon Smith Barney cut its price target and third-quarter earnings estimate for McDonald's, saying it was not doing enough to address complaints about employee rudeness and slow service. McDonald's is scheduled to give a midquarter update next week; its stock has been at multiyear lows.
Shares in Sun Microsystems dropped 15 cents, or 4.5 percent, to $3.22, after Salomon Smith Barney said profits would be difficult in the short term. Such a low is like those last seen in late 1996, when the stock dropped to $3.19. 
Semiconductor makers and related companies led stocks' downward march after negative news. Lehman Brothers said chip-equipment shares were likely to remain under pressure as third-quarter results and fourth-quarter forecasts fall below expectations. One chip equipment maker, Applied Materials, fell 95 cents, to $12.74. The chip maker Intel lost 92 cents, dropping to $15.70.
A. G. Edwards downgraded the drug giant Johnson & Johnson, and its shares dropped 2.7 percent, or $1.51, to $53.97.
Shares in the tobacco company UST sank $3.54, or 10.6 percent, to $29.84, as the company cut its earnings forecast for the second half of the year, citing sluggish sales volume growth at its largest unit, U.S. Smokeless Tobacco.
In the bond market, Treasury prices rose after Mr. Bush warned that if the United Nations failed to enforce its resolutions on Iraq, the United States would force Iraq to comply.
The price of the 10-year note rose 24/32 , to 103 10/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 3.97 percent from 4.06 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 1 point, to 108 17/32 , as the yield dropped to 4.82 percent from 4.88.

HEADLINE: U.S. Cites Russian Firms in Arms Sales to Lands Tied to Terror 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 

 BODY:
The Bush administration imposed penalties today on three Russian military contractors that sold weapons to countries that the State Department says support terrorism. 
 The companies, all government owned, are said to have sold conventional military equipment like missiles and rocket-fired grenades to Libya, Sudan and Syria, officials said. The penalties mean that the companies will not be able to do business with the United States government, sell their equipment here or buy certain equipment and services from American businesses. 
 The companies are the Tula Design Bureau of Instrument Building, which makes antiaircraft and antitank systems; the State Scientific Production Enterprise Bazalt, which makes bombs, grenades and other munitions; and Rostov Airframe Plant 168.
Although all three companies are state owned, no penalties are being imposed on the Russian government, a State Department official said. 
The sanctions are announced as the Bush administration is urging Russia to halt its sales of military equipment and advanced technology to countries that support terrorism, particularly Iran, Iraq and North Korea, the countries that President Bush has called "an axis of evil."
Russia maintains strong trade relations with all three, and Washington contends that Russian know-how and equipment may have helped them develop chemical, germ and nuclear weapons. 
The penalties involve less dangerous equipment sold to less threatening countries. The State Department said it had imposed the sanctions to send a message that despite good relations between Moscow and Washington, the administration is not always happy with Russian efforts to stop weapons proliferation to terrorists. 
"We have a new relationship here, and we're working with them," a State Department official said. "There is a sense that they are taking this seriously."
The director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control in Washington, Gary Milhollin, said the sanctions were virtually meaningless, because it is highly unlikely that the Russian companies conduct much, if any, business with the United States. Mr. Milhollin said the only way to crack down on such companies was to expand the punishment to include their subsidiaries or the Russian government itself. 
"These are pointless," he said. "We have to rethink our sanctions laws."
Mr. Milhollin said although the weapons that the Russian companies sold were not particularly powerful, any actions that helped arm terrorists or their state sponsors were potentially harmful to the United States.
Libya, Sudan and Syria are among the seven countries that the United States has designated as state sponsors of terrorism. The others are Cuba, Iran, Iraq and North Korea. 
Since the Sept. 11 attacks, Libya has curtailed its contacts with terrorist groups, the most recent State Department report on global terrorism said. Syria has not been implicated in terrorism acts since 1986. But it allows Hamas, the Palestinian militant group, to maintain offices in Damascus and Hezbollah to operate in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa in Lebanon, the report said. 
The report said Sudan had stepped up efforts to cooperate with the United States in fighting terrorism since Sept. 11. But the report said several international groups, including Al Qaeda and the Egyptian Islamic Jihad, continue to use Sudan as a safe haven.

HEADLINE: CUNY Reports a 5% Jump In Enrollment for Fall Term 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Enrollment at the City University of New York jumped 5 percent this fall, the largest increase since 1978, pushing the total number of students to 207,181, the highest level since 1994.
 The number of new freshmen also jumped 5 percent, to 27,000, at CUNY's 11 senior colleges and its 6 community colleges, according to a preliminary report issued this week. 
 The total enrollment gains are the third increase in a row after five years of declines during a tumultuous period when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and CUNY's trustees excoriated the university for not having standards that were high enough. In fall 1999, CUNY's enrollment dropped below 195,000. 
CUNY administrators say that the higher enrollment is a clear result of their efforts to raise standards. In 1999, CUNY's board approved a hotly debated policy to bar students from bachelor's degree programs if they could not score high enough on English and math exams (including the Regents tests and the SAT exams) to demonstrate that they were ready for college-level work. 
"Students are coming because the university's reputation has developed so that people think the degree is valued again," Matthew Goldstein, CUNY's chancellor, said yesterday. "The university has accomplished two objectives -- increasing enrollment and increasing standards -- that are often seen as contradictory." 
He acknowledged, however, that the plunging stock market, weaker economy and terrorist attacks have also made many families focus on public universities closer to home, raising enrollments at many state universities. Tuition at CUNY's senior colleges is $3,200 a year for New York State residents.
Last year, CUNY's enrollment rose 1.4 percent and the number of new freshmen increased nearly 8 percent at the senior colleges, where CUNY began to impose more restrictive admissions standards beginning in 1999.
Dr. Goldstein said that the enrollment numbers disproved the warnings by critics of the more restrictive admissions policy, who had predicted sharp declines in enrollment.
But one former critic said it was hard to tell what the real impact of the changed admissions standards was, and who was being kept out of the senior colleges. "Relative to some of the other public universities with big policy changes, like Texas and California, CUNY has never really released the kinds of data necessary for making that kind of policy assessment," said David E. Lavin, a sociologist at CUNY and co-author with David Hyllegard of "Changing the Odds: Open Admissions and the Life Chances of the Disadvantaged."
Another factor that makes it hard to assess the impact of more restrictive admissions is that the university has undergone other significant changes in the same period.
In the mid-1990's, CUNY seemed to be at war with itself. Its board meetings were often chaotic, as trustees argued among themselves and students and faculty members loudly protested board policies. Sometimes students and professors were ejected from board meetings.
Since 1999, when Dr. Goldstein became chancellor, the university has run more smoothly, board meetings have become routine again, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has worked with the university rather than suggesting it should be closed. 
Dr. Goldstein also began much more vigorous recruiting and introduced an honors program with generous merit scholarships, which has drawn high-caliber students and highlighted the university's strengths.
As more students enroll, some campuses, like Baruch, have limited their undergraduate enrollments because they are already so crowded. 
Other campuses, like Borough of Manhattan Community College, scrambled to accommodate the new demand. B.M.C.C., on Chambers Street, saw enrollment jump 10 percent to 17,396, and has had to put students in classrooms at City College and at the St. John's campus in Lower Manhattan. Fiterman Hall, one of its two primary classroom buildings, next to 7 World Trade Center, was severely damaged in last year's terrorist attack and the college has not been able to use it since. 
Dr. Goldstein said he hoped to decide soon whether to rehabilitate the badly damaged building or erect a new one when he learns how much money CUNY will receive from insurance policies and the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

HEADLINE: Feast Hopes to Recover From Its Famine 

BYLINE:  By LYDIA POLGREEN 

 BODY:
At times during lunch hour yesterday, the line at John's Italian Sausage at Mulberry and Grand Streets snaked around the corner, at least two dozen people long. The stand's namesake, 94-year-old John Fasullo, stood at his usual spot, tending huge steel spears loaded with sausage and braciola sizzling over glowing coals.
 "It's great to be back," he said, breaking out into a huge grin. 
 The Feast of San Gennaro began yesterday in Little Italy, returning after an absence last year, when it was canceled in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center, about a mile south of the neighborhood. The restaurateurs and other business owners who have struggled since the terrorist attack and the slowing of the economy are hoping the 10-day street festival helps them recover from a devastating year.
"We really need this," said Vinny Sabatino, proprietor of Vinny's Nut House. "Business has picked up, but we were completely dead from September to April."
When the festival was canceled last year, Mr. Sabatino was left with 200 pounds of torrone, white nougat with almonds imported from Italy. "I had to throw out so much stock it was crazy," he said. "We hope we can make up for it this year."
Even before the Sept. 11 attack, Little Italy's fortunes were waning. Hemmed in by a growing Chinatown and stylish neighborhoods to the north with little taste for the kitsch of red checkered table cloths and "Kiss me, I'm Italian" T-shirts, the neighborhood has become almost entirely dependent on tourists. The festival typically draws more than a million visitors each year, organizers said.
Even before the 2 p.m. opening of the festival, which honors the patron saint of Naples, people flooded Mulberry Street, snacking on cannoli, sausage and peppers, and scungilli. 
"We come every year on the first day," said Jeffrey Stromberg, between bites of a rib eye steak sandwich. He and his friend, Gary Shiffman, have been coming for five years. "We really missed it last year," Mr. Shiffman said.
Shortly after noon, lines formed at many stands, and traffic along Mulberry Street was heavy. But waiters at the dozens of restaurants lining the street struggled to lure diners to empty outdoor tables. "Buongiorno, how many for lunch?" was the cry, but it went largely unanswered.
Pellegrino Criscitelli, a festival organizer who owns two restaurants in the neighborhood, said the feast comes at a crucial time. "After 9/11, this neighborhood got hit pretty hard," he said. "Right now most places are still 35 to 40 percent down from the previous year."
Buddy Zeccardi, who owns Caffe Roma, a pastry shop at Mulberry and Broome Streets, said business was picking up, but slowly. "It's been quiet, but not as bad as right after Sept. 11," he said. "The festival brings people in, and I am hoping it will be a good year."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A cannoli-eating contest was held on the opening day of the Feast of San Gennaro in Little Italy yesterday. Organizers of the 10-day festival, which was canceled last year after the terrorist attack, hope it will drum up business in a neighborhood that is about a mile north of the trade center site. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ruling Buoys Challenger For California Governor 

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 

 BODY:
A state judge today threw out a $78 million civil fraud judgment against the family investment firm of Bill Simon Jr., the Republican candidate for governor, injecting a spark of life into a campaign that had appeared to be faltering. 
 The judge, James C. Chalfant of Superior Court, set aside a jury decision against Mr. Simon's investment company, William E. Simon & Sons, and awarded the firm $125,000 to cover the costs of fighting the accusations. The jury's decision, made in late July, badly damaged Mr. Simon's campaign to unseat Gov. Gray Davis, who has cited the case in speeches and advertisements as evidence that Mr. Simon is unqualified to be governor. 
 "Today is a new beginning for our campaign," Mr. Simon proclaimed this morning at a news conference in Los Angeles. "I've said all along this jury verdict was fundamentally flawed and would be overturned, and that's exactly what happened."
Mr. Simon acknowledged that the judgment against him, arising from an investment in a pay telephone venture, had been a distraction to his campaign, drowning out his themes of tax cuts, improvements in education and investment in infrastructure. 
But even after today's ruling, Mr. Simon, the surprise winner of the Republican primary last winter, faces significant hurdles, including continuing questions about a tax shelter investment, his role in the failure of a family-owned savings and loan, his refusal to fully disclose his income taxes and continuing campaign fund-raising problems.
"He may think he's out of the woods, but there's a bunch of trees still in his path," said Garry South, Governor Davis's chief political strategist.
As of the last reporting period, Mr. Davis had $31.6 million in cash, compared with $5 million for Mr. Simon, although Mr. Davis has spent much of his money in the past two months running negative advertisements about his opponent. One of them cites the jury verdict in the pay phone case and concludes, "Simon: If his partners can't trust him, how can we trust him with the fifth largest economy in the world?"
Mr. Simon called on the Davis campaign today to withdraw the advertisement. But Mr. South said that its assertion that a jury found Mr. Simon's firm guilty of fraud remained true and that the advertisement would run for a few more days. The Davis campaign also announced that it was broadcasting a new advertisement raising questions about the failure of Western Federal Savings and Loan, which was owned by the Simon family.
Mr. South said the Davis campaign still had plenty of Mr. Simon's errors and "ethical lapses to talk about." He also questioned Judge Chalfant's objectivity, saying that he had been appointed by then-Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, and had contributed to several Republican candidates.
The ruling today involved a 1998 investment that Mr. Simon's family company made with another firm in Pacific Coin, a failed pay telephone venture in Los Angeles. At the time of their $26 million investment, Mr. Simon and his partners did not know that the owner of Pacific Coin, Paul Edward Hindelang Jr., was a convicted marijuana smuggler who had used drug profits to start the pay phone venture, according to court documents. 
When the investors learned of Mr. Hindelang's criminal past, they fired him. Soon after, the company collapsed, in part because cellphone use had become widespread. Mr. Hindelang sued Mr. Simon's company and the other investors, saying they had deceived him about their plan to add debt and eventually take Pacific Coin public.
A Superior Court jury agreed, and on July 30 awarded Mr. Hindelang $78 million in compensatory and punitive damages.
But Judge Chalfant said today that in fact it was Mr. Simon and his partners who had been the victims of fraud.
"The centerpiece of this decision," he wrote, "is the immutable fact, established by overwhelming evidence, that Hindelang defrauded" Mr. Simon's group by not disclosing his criminal past or his negotiations with federal authorities to forfeit some $50 million in illicit drug proceeds.
Geoffrey L. Thomas, Mr. Hindelang's lawyer, said that his client would probably appeal the judge's ruling but that they had not decided. "We want to consider all our options," he said.
The ruling heartened California Republican leaders, many of whom have expressed open despair about the state of Mr. Simon's campaign and his chances of toppling Mr. Davis. Although Mr. Davis is not terribly popular, even among members of his own party, Mr. Simon has made few inroads in a state that has 1.5 million more registered Democrats than Republicans. Both candidates are viewed negatively by 50 percent of the electorate, according to the nonpartisan Field Poll.
Recent voter surveys show Mr. Davis with a lead of 7 to 11 percentage points, but Mr. Simon's supporters argue that voters have not begun to focus on the race and that the margin will narrow as the Nov. 5 election approaches.
"This is a tremendous day for the party and for all of us who have been faithful in our belief in the justice system," said Thomas A. Fuentes, chairman of the Orange County Republican Party. "This is a monumental reversal, and I anticipate the first of many new upticks for the Simon campaign."
