HEADLINE: Where Modern Life Began 

BYLINE:  By Lindsay Duguid; Lindsay Duguid is fiction editor of The Times Literary Supplement.

 BODY:
 LIVING AT THE EDGE
A Biography of D. H. Lawrence
and Frieda von Richthofen.
By Michael Squires and Lynn K. Talbot.
Illustrated. 501 pp. Madison:
University of Wisconsin Press. $34.95.
 IN March 1912, D. H. Lawrence, a schoolmaster, met Frieda von Richthofen Weekley, the wife of a university professor, at her house in Nottingham, England. Two months later, abandoning her children, they began their life together. Over the next 20 years, the couple moved from place to place, setting up short-lived households where the rent was cheap -- a cottage near London for six shillings a week, a Hampstead flat for $:36 a year, an Italian villa for $:14 for six months; the economics of the enterprise were based on loans, handouts and Lawrence's tiny literary earnings. They were prepared to wander the world to escape "the beastly, tight, Sunday feeling which is so blighting in England," the atmosphere of tentative modernism that hung around benefactors like Ford Madox Hueffer and Lady Ottoline Morrell. Former guests at rather precious country houses like Garsington, they wanted to find somewhere where they could make their own lives and write a new kind of novel. "Frieda and I are together," Lawrence wrote, "and the work is of me and her, and it is beautiful."
A pattern was soon established. They would settle -- full of optimism -- in a place with a strong local personality (Cornwall or Sicily, New Mexico or Ceylon), start their housekeeping and socializing; then some upset, often involving a third person -- John Middleton Murry in Cornwall, Mabel Dodge in Taos -- would see them packing up for the next move. Lawrence wrote of their brief Australian adventure in 1922, "I love trying things and discovering how I hate them," but the beginnings always offered a clean slate, a glorious opportunity. "You will love it," he wrote to a friend from Sussex in 1915, "it is so beautiful and white." A telegram to Frieda in Mexico in 1923 read simply: "Chapala paradise. Take evening train."
Part of the restlessness was money-driven; part had to do with Lawrence's need to find a climate that might ease his recurring coughs and colds, diagnosed as tuberculosis in 1925. Most of it was idealistic. Their desire for a new way of living, inspired by the libertarian beliefs of Frieda's former lover, Otto Gross, was further fired by their mutual passion -- half anger, half love -- that often erupted into fights. Against Lawrence's rhapsodic honeymoon poem, "Song of a Man Who Is Loved" ("Between her breasts is my home, between her breasts") and the glimpses we get of early domestic bliss given in "Living at the Edge" must be set Lawrence's fierce image (as Frieda once wrote, "We live so hard on each other, one day like the lions that ate each other, there will be nothing but two tails left") and Frieda's challenge to Mabel Dodge: "Try it then yourself, living with a genius, see what it is like and how easy it is."
The rages and infidelities are well documented in their many letters, along with the household routines and the new ideas. Lawrence wrote copiously to his friends, describing his poverty and his struggle to be published, telling them what was in his heart. And there are plenty of descriptions of the couple -- cooking, gardening, singing at the piano, shouting at each other. They were often sketched by fellow writers, inspired by malice or just the pleasure of pinning down the strangeness of this thin, red-bearded genius and his billowing, gaudily dressed wife. Katherine Mansfield provides a vivid picture of them: Lawrence sewing or "making little copies of pictures," Frieda standing "with big bowls of blue and white water round her wringing out check tablecloths."
The story of Lawrence and Frieda, engrossing in its detail, often seems to be prophetic, an exemplar of modern living. It is also the background to the creation of "Women in Love," "Lady Chatterley's Lover" and the other revolutionary works. Michael Squires and Lynn K. Talbot tackle all these aspects in "Living at the Edge." They cover the ground thoroughly, bringing together material from libraries and field trips, politely disagreeing with earlier biographers. As they follow their subjects' trail, it becomes clear that they share an uncomplicated belief that an author's books can be used to illuminate his life and vice versa ("as if Lawrence, unable to satisfy Frieda in life, will do so in fiction"). Their analysis of the work almost entirely in biographical terms has, at times, a doggedness, a lack of appreciation of style and form. Their grasp of background is also sometimes a little unworldly. The treatments of Taos and Hollywood are convincing, but descriptions of "Versailles, the opulent 17th-century palace built by Louis XIV" and "an old town house in Hampstead" sound uninformed.
Rather similar are their sometimes comical attempts to understand the Lawrences' relationship using the modern therapeutic template of the marriage counselor ("It was his midlife crisis"). "After about 1916," they tell us sadly, "almost no one records the Lawrences holding hands, kissing, hugging, or showing affection." They also feel that it is their duty, as modern biographers, to show whether a sexual act took place. "Was the affair consummated?" they ask about Lawrence's dalliance with Rosalind Baynes; "How far did their intimacy go?" of his infatuation with the young Cornish farmer William Henry Hocking; and there are pages devoted to hunting clues to anal penetration, impotence and homophobia. Instead of being enlightening, the effect of this is generally dispiriting.
The last section of this long, detailed book -- after Lawrence's death in a sanitarium in the south of France, the return of his ashes to Taos and the disputes over his will -- is the freshest. We get a compelling portrait of Frieda as a literary widow, haggling over film rights and the sale of Lawrence's handwritten manuscripts, publishing her own highly charged memoir, "Not I, but the Wind," and taking issue with Richard Aldington's biography. Until her death in 1956, she continued to live the complicated simple life, better financed now, with Angelo Ravagli, her third husband, the final unstable triangle of her long career. The photographs show a dumpy elderly lady smiling at the camera by the side of her gray-haired spouse. Squires, who teaches English at Virginia Tech, and Talbot, who teaches Spanish at Roanoke College, end with the passing of Lawrence's royalties to Ravagli's Italian children after their father's death in 1976, but perhaps the last word should be awarded to Frieda, who wrote in 1915 at the start of the great adventure: "You think I do not count besides Lawrence, but I take myself, my ideals and life quite as seriously as he does his." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: My Big Fat Greek Gender Identity Crisis 

BYLINE:  By Laura Miller; Laura Miller is an editor at Salon.com.

 BODY:
 MIDDLESEX
By Jeffrey Eugenides.
529 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.
 EVEN before she's born, Calliope Stephanides's gender is up for debate. Her parents, Milton and Tessie Stephanides of Detroit, want a girl, and a bachelor uncle convinces Milton, ostensibly on the authority of an article in Scientific American magazine, that if the couple have "sexual congress" 24 hours prior to ovulation "the swift male sperm would rush in and die off. The female sperm, sluggish but more reliable, would arrive just as the egg dropped." Tessie complies, despite her worries that "to tamper with something as mysterious and miraculous as the birth of a child was an act of hubris." Once Tessie is pregnant, Milton's mother, Desdemona -- a refugee with her husband, Lefty, from a Greek village on the slopes of Mount Olympus -- dangles a silver spoon tied to a string over the belly of her daughter-in-law and pronounces the child a boy. Her son storms in to protest the divination; the baby is a girl, he insists. "It's science, Ma."
They're both right, after a fashion. Callie will spend the 1960's and early 70's, the first years of her life, as the relatively unremarkable daughter of an entrepreneurial Greek-American family, only to discover at 14, in the office of a Manhattan physician, that she is a hermaphrodite -- or, more precisely, a pseudohermaphrodite, a sufferer of 5-alpha-reductase deficiency syndrome. "To the extent that fetal hormones affect brain chemistry and histology, I've got a male brain," explains Cal, the man Callie decides to become after she learns the truth and the narrator of "Middlesex," Jeffrey Eugenides's expansive and radiantly generous second novel. "But I was raised as a girl."
Eugenides's first novel, "The Virgin Suicides" (1993), was a dreamy, slender book about the gulf in understanding between the adolescent boys in a Michigan suburb and the five daughters of a strict Roman Catholic couple living in their neighborhood. The boys fill that gulf with romantic obsession, a beast that thrives in a vacuum, and the girls, stricken with a fatal loneliness, die by their own hands like a bevy of unlucky fairy tale princesses. "Middlesex" may be an entirely different sort of book -- it's longer, more discursive and funnier, for a start -- but it's equally preoccupied with rifts. There's the gap between male and female, obviously, but also between Greek and WASP, black and white, the old world and the new, the silver spoon and the sluggish sperm. Finally, there is the tug of war between destiny and free will -- an age-old concern of Greek storytellers, as every college freshman learns, reborn in the theories advanced by evolutionary psychology.
Evolutionary psychology, at least in its popular incarnation -- which seems to get more popular every day -- keeps chipping away at the garden-variety humanism espoused by most novelists. That's why it's surprising so few of them (at least within the genre of literary fiction) have bothered to take notice of it. Viewed through a sociobiological lens, infidelity, the novel's favorite meat, is transformed from the stuff of betrayal and moral failing to the mere playing out of a Darwinian reproductive imperative; despair springs from an inherited defect in the regulation of neurochemicals, not from an existential apprehension of the absurdity of the human condition. The tangled parks and gardens that have long been the novelist's stamping grounds are being bulldozed to make way for sleek, sterile industrial complexes where, in cataloging each molecule in the human genome, scientists may ultimately be able to tell us which gene caused Anna Karenina to cheat and gave Oliver Twist the nerve to ask for more gruel.
Cal isn't a faithful adherent of either the nature or the nurture camp; he eventually runs away to avoid undergoing surgery and hormone treatments at the hands of a doctor who thinks that 14 years of living as a girl must count more than the male identity Cal wants to embrace. Eugenides, after all, is an artist, not a polemicist, and the truth about what shapes us may never be settled. "Sing now, O Muse, of the recessive mutation on my fifth chromosome," Cal vamps in the book's opening pages. ("Sorry if I get a little Homeric at times. That's genetic, too.") By mimicking an ancient author equally preoccupied by the tension between preordained fate and self-determination, Cal telegraphs a very modern question: Is "Middlesex" -- or any novel, for that matter -- the story of its hero/ine or the history of a particular configuration of DNA? As Cal -- sometimes -- chooses to tell it, the novel describes the "roller coaster ride of a single gene through time," how it found its twin in the mingled gametes of Desdemona and Lefty, who, it turns out, are brother and sister as well as husband and wife, able with their freshly minted American identities to consummate a union they could never have gotten away with back in their home village. Practically the whole first half of "Middlesex," like a doorstop biography run amok, takes place before Cal is even born.
If all this makes "Middlesex" sound like a novel of ideas, well, it is; but it's several other things too. It's a saga that takes Desdemona and Lefty from the burning of Smyrna through Detroit's purgatorial assembly lines, the shadow economy of Prohibition and the founding of the family's legit businesses, first a bar and then a restaurant. The Stephanideses career through the Depression, World War II, the cataclysmic Detroit race riots of 1967, the counterculture, Watergate, the energy crisis.
"Middlesex" is also a coming-of-age story, albeit an exceptionally fraught one, as it gradually dawns on the adolescent Callie that there's something seriously odd about her body -- and that she's besotted with a female classmate. There's a bit of road novel as well, when, enlightened as to the actual state of his chromosomes, Cal hitchhikes to -- where else? -- San Francisco. And, finally, there's the sliver of a love story, as the now 41-year-old Cal, ensconced in a safely nomadic State Department career, gingerly courts a Japanese-American photographer, wondering if he can trust her with the surprise between his legs.
Eugenides pitches a big tent, but one of the delights of "Middlesex" is how soundly it's constructed, with motifs and characters weaving through the novel's various episodes, pulling it tight. The young Armenian doctor who saves Lefty in Smyrna and sees his own children butchered by Turkish soldiers becomes the aged, bleary-eyed family retainer who overlooks Callie's unusual anatomy. Middlesex, the modern house the Stephanideses manage to purchase in the exclusive suburb of Grosse Pointe (it's too peculiar and unfashionable to sell to WASPs) is "like communism, better in theory than reality." Which makes it also like the blank-slate notion of gender identity advanced by the doctor who wants to drag Cal under the knife. 
And while some of the odds and ends Eugenides tosses into the mix (a disquisition on Michael Dukakis, a supporting character's bizarre connection to the Nation of Islam) don't quite integrate, far more often than not the novel feels rich with treats, including some handsome writing. When the author describes the pulchritudinous teenage Desdemona's braids as "not delicate like a little girl's but heavy and womanly, possessing a natural power, like a beaver's tail," for example, the metaphor has an elemental eroticism worthy of Hardy.
Because it's long and wide and full of stuff, "Middlesex" will be associated by some readers with books by David Foster Wallace and Jonathan Franzen, brilliant members of Eugenides's cohort. Those writers, however, have more satirical, even self-lacerating inclinations; there can be an air of penance to their work (as there is to "The Virgin Suicides"). Here, at least, Eugenides is sunnier; the book's length feels like its author's arms stretching farther and farther to encompass more people, more life. His narrator is a soul who inhabits a liminal realm, a creature able to bridge the divisions that plague humanity, endowed with "the ability to communicate between the genders, to see not with the monovision of one sex but in the stereoscope of both." That utopian reach makes "Middlesex" deliriously American; the novel's patron saint is Walt Whitman, and it has some of the shagginess of that poet's verse to go along with the exuberance. But mostly it is a colossal act of curiosity, of imagination and of love.

HEADLINE: A Textbook Case 

BYLINE:  By Sylvia Nasar; Sylvia Nasar, the author of "A Beautiful Mind," teaches financial journalism at Columbia University and is working on a book on 20th-century economic thinkers.

 BODY:
 INVENTING AMERICA
A History of the United States.
By Pauline Maier, Merritt Roe Smith,
Alexander Keyssar and Daniel J. Kevles.
1,185 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $77.50.
 Remember those history textbooks of the 1950's extolling the miracles of modern science? They treated inventors as heroes and portrayed technology as the deux ex machina that would solve America's social ills. Then, perhaps because of the nuclear power's dark side or the specter of the collapsing ecosystem, succeeding generations of textbooks banished science and technology from their pages altogether. 
"Inventing America," by the historians Pauline Maier, Merritt Roe Smith, Alexander Keyssar and Daniel J. Kevles, was supposed to remedy that neglect by treating "science and technology as integral elements of American history." But those who hoped that this much-anticipated textbook would give college freshmen a better grasp of how bright ideas helped turn America into a global power, the world's richest nation and the undisputed leader in scientific discovery will be frustrated. 
Starting with an elegiac chapter on ancient America, the authors document successive waves of invention and provide examples of how new technologies, spread by businesses large and small, unsettled politics, altered work and lifestyles, triggered booms and busts and otherwise contributed to change. The book is packaged with two CD-ROM's containing archival and other materials. But "Inventing America" doesn't deliver what a textbook should. It neither introduces students to relevant concepts like productivity or life expectancy, nor helps them marshal evidence to distinguish between competing hypotheses.
The premise that inventiveness is somehow an "American" characteristic confounds invention with innovation. Long before the Industrial Revolution, other societies, including the Chinese and Islamic empires, displayed great technical virtuosity. But none of these societies unlocked the secret of turning inventions into economic growth. For millenniums, average output per person bobbled around $1 a day -- more or less what it takes to provide the minimum of necessary calories -- while the bulk of humanity was tethered to subsistence farming. When societies did corral extra resources, by trading, vanquishing new territories or subjugating other peoples, these were typically spent, as H. G. Wells lamented, "on the mere insensate multiplication of common life."
Telling the story of technology without highlighting its impact on growth is like producing "Hamlet" without the Prince of Denmark. Had the authors compared America's performance in the past 150 years with that of other societies and eras, what would have jumped out isn't just a list of inventions, but rather America's astounding track record of applying inventions, borrowed and homegrown, in an economically useful fashion.
Of course, the ultimate measure of technological success isn't productive prowess but quality of life. Fixated on the relative status of different social groups, "Inventing America" ignores basic yardsticks that show that, on average, American living standards have risen at least eightfold and that Americans now live one-third longer than in the mid-19th century. (An example of how the authors' mind-set distorts their account is the description of malaria -- a significant cause of desperate poverty in many parts of the globe today and in the American South before World War II -- as "the mosquito-borne disease that killed large numbers of European imperialists.")
The benefits of technology got spread around in two main ways. One is that everyday products became vastly cheaper. More important, though, is the proliferation of entirely new products. As David Landes reports in "The Wealth and Poverty of Nations," Nathan Meyer Rothschild -- the richest man in the world in the first half of the 19th century -- died of an infected abscess that $10 worth of antibiotics would have cured. In other words, most modern necessities weren't available at any price.
But after more than a thousand pages of "Inventing America," the sources of America's technological fecundity remain a mystery. As in those old 50's textbooks, necessity appears to breed invention, instead of the other way around. The authors note the birth of the modern corporation, the development of capital markets and the growing importance of corporate R & D but never connect the dots. And when they generalize, the results are frequently unconvincing. 
For example, they find that war and defense research has been the primary "incubator" of American technology. Defense research, inspired by the cold war, "made possible the creation of biotechnology, personal computers and the information economy." The implication is that without a few good wars Americans would still be flying around in propeller planes. But the Soviets had one of the greatest scientific establishments of all time and routinely devoted one-third to one-half of their output to military spending. Yet they lost their empire for want of microchips, washing machines and pantyhose. Japan, stripped of its military might after World War II, became a powerhouse of innovation.
In keeping with their dismissive attitude toward the nuts and bolts of business, the authors assign little importance to markets, property rights or the profit motive. At one point, they refer to Americans' "disquiet with the profit-maximizing practices of the marketplace": "Millions of Americans watched 'The Sopranos,' a TV series about an extended Mafia family in New Jersey whose members were absorbed with ordinary personal relationships at home while routinely conducting murder and mayhem in their business -- in all, a metaphor for how the conflicts and decencies of private life coexisted with the coldblooded indecencies that the marketplace often fostered." They don't consider that profit might play a role in motivating innovators to bring their inventions to market, or that competition might have a part in the "economic miracle" casually mentioned a few sentences later.
In short, the authors lack compelling explanations of why America has produced so much innovation and growth since 1870 and why so many other societies haven't. Twenty years ago, in "America Revised," Frances FitzGerald complained about the quality gulf between the haute cuisine served by leading history journals and the fast food dished out in most history textbooks. Judged from this perspective, "Inventing America" hasn't broken the mold.

HEADLINE: A Design for Living 

BYLINE:  By Gary Rosen; Gary Rosen is the managing editor of Commentary and the author of "American Compact: James Madison and the Problem of Founding."

 BODY:
 A BRILLIANT SOLUTION
Inventing the American Constitution.
By Carol Berkin.
310 pp. New York: Harcourt. $26.
 The American founders have been a hot property in recent years. Their writings were invoked by all sides during the Clinton impeachment and the election fiasco in Florida. Speculation about their romantic entanglements -- Jefferson with his slave Sally Hemings, Hamilton with the blackmailing Maria Reynolds -- has been the stuff of public controversy. Books about the founding generation have made the best-seller list, won the big nonfiction prizes, even been transformed into Ken-Burns-style documentaries. 
For academics who specialize in the period, this burst of interest has been a windfall, gaining them attention as never before. Inevitably, it has also led some of them to turn their work, for better and worse, in a more self-consciously popular direction. Carol Berkin's "Brilliant Solution," a lively account of the "inventing" of the American Constitution, is a case in point. 
Berkin -- a historian at the City University of New York and the author of several scholarly books on the revolutionary era -- begins her story in 1786, just three years after the conclusion of the War of Independence, at a moment when many wondered if the United States would survive. Not only was the economy deep in depression, with the sovereign states busily erecting trade barriers against one another, but civil order itself seemed at risk. Indebted farmers threatened armed rebellion from South Carolina to Massachusetts; Indian tribes waged guerrilla war against settlers on the frontier; and in the Mediterranean, Barbary pirates preyed on American merchants. For its part, the national government -- such as it was under the Articles of Confederation -- was broke, powerless and universally disdained. 
The stage thus set, Berkin introduces us to the American notables who, during the steamy Philadelphia summer of 1787, hammered out the new frame of government that brought an end to this crisis of national confidence and authority. Several of the faces are familiar, like the scholarly master strategist James Madison, "small and somber looking in his habitual black suit," and the brash Alexander Hamilton, whose "genius for analysis" allowed him to solve the most complex economic and political problems "with apparent ease." But we also meet lesser lights: Pierce Butler, "the peacock of the convention," in his powdered wig and lace-trimmed coat; Luther Martin, "an alcoholic given to eccentric, often antisocial behavior"; and the obese, high-spirited Gunning Bedford Jr., "the most jovial member" of the group. 
Almost all of the 55 delegates agreed on the need for a much more effective central government. But there was no consensus on what powers it should have, what form it should take or how representation should be handled. The stickiest of these questions involved the role of the states. Would each one continue to have an equal voice, as under the Articles of Confederation, or would seats in the two houses of Congress be distributed solely on the basis of population? The convention ultimately split the difference, of course, but, as Berkin reminds us, there was nothing automatic about this compromise. The most committed nationalists spent half the summer fighting for a government based entirely on proportional representation. If they'd won, we would not now have a Senate in which 600,000 North Dakotans carry the same weight as 34 million Californians. 
Berkin is at her best in describing the exhausting and seemingly endless politicking of the convention, and in pointing to the various roads not taken. Madison, for instance, wanted a Congress with the power to veto any state law it considered harmful to the union. As for the presidency, Elbridge Gerry argued that an executive triumvirate would be safer and more representative than a single official, and Benjamin Franklin urged that the chief executive serve without pay, so as to free him of any taint of corruption. These proposals didn't get far, but the debate over how to arrange the executive branch continued right up to the convention's end. Under one popular but ultimately unsuccessful scheme, George W. Bush would now be two years into his single seven-year term -- assuming that the House and Senate had elected him in the first place -- and would be properly addressed not as "Mr. President" but as "Your Excellency." 
"A Brilliant Solution" is that rarest of achievements -- civic education that manages to entertain. But Berkin's eagerness to breathe life into the often dry proceedings sometimes gets the better of her. Given the scarcity of sources, one wonders how she knows that Madison "cringed" upon hearing an impolitic speech by Gouverneur Morris, or that George Washington "wrestled with his memories" on a ride through Valley Forge. Her portrait of Hamilton is certainly vivid enough without the observation that his "wavy chestnut hair, fair complexion and surprisingly sensitive mouth suggested Apollo." Nor does there seem to be any compelling reason to conclude the book with a detailed account of the first presidential inauguration, except that ceremony and pageantry lend themselves to drama. 
More disappointing is Berkin's obvious reluctance to muddy her narrative with discussion of the ideas behind the Constitution. Her occasional nod to the delegates' fears about the abuse of power is no substitute for an excursion into the classic essays of "The Federalist," which get only passing mentions. Where is Madison arguing that "ambition must be made to counteract ambition," or Hamilton defending the proposition that "energy in the executive is a leading character in the definition of good government"? 
Berkin might also have provided at least a taste of the longstanding debate about the ultimate aims of the American experiment. Were the founders reborn republicans of the Roman mold, concerned above all with citizen virtue, or were they thoroughly modern men, defenders of a bourgeois order defined by private property and individual rights? What made them -- or the American people, for that matter -- even think they were entitled to fashion a government? 
By steering clear of the rival philosophies behind our philosophy-suffused founding, Berkin makes "A Brilliant Solution" feel superficial at times, like a script for the History Channel. But that's not entirely a bad thing. Personalities and action are more easily digested than ideas, and this dramatic, well-informed account deserves to reach a wide audience.

HEADLINE: Nascar-Lovin 

BYLINE:  By Matt Bai; Matt Bai is a contributing writer for the magazine. His last article was a profile of the Wisconsin gubernatorial candidate Ed Thompson.

 BODY:
Lincoln Davis is running for Congress in central Tennessee, in the district where they've been distilling Jack Daniel's whiskey since 1866. Davis is a Democrat, and he knew from the start that if he was going to win the race for an open seat, he was going to have to get past the wine-and-cheese stereotype that Democrats carry in rural America.
 "We've allowed our opponents to define us as people with no normal values," Davis, a state senator, told me. "We don't like guns, we don't pray, we don't believe in Christ. And I said from the start, 'Nobody in this campaign is going to outgun me, outpray me or outfamily me."' 
 True to his word, Davis came out in favor of posting the Ten Commandments in public, and he got help in his primary campaign from the National Rifle Association. He won the nomination easily. Publicly, the Democratic Party in Washington touts his campaign as one of its best chances to pick up a much-needed House seat in November. 
But when strategists from the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee recently met with Davis's consultants, he said, they strongly advised him to tone down his talk about God and guns. "We were told by the D.C.C.C.: 'You're running this election wrong. You're running it on values, and you're going to lose,"' Davis told me. "When I heard that, I just giggled at them."
Control of Congress will probably come down to some 50 close House and Senate races in November, many of them in rural districts and states. And like Davis, a lot of Democrats in those races are running away from their own party, and hard. 
Theoretically, the Democratic message should play well in small-town America at a time when the economy lags and corporate scandals are decimating retirement plans. But now, more than ever, Democratic candidates face a cultural problem in these districts; they must overcome the perception that they're in league with effete urban liberals, people who wouldn't know a Moon Pie or an RC Cola if it whacked them in the head. The party of Jefferson and Jackson, which not long ago owned the nation's back roads and general stores, is seen in much of the country as disconnected from -- if not contemptuous of -- the people who spend their weekends hunting, at church or watching stock cars.
This divide, long a source of concern within the party, has lately become a burning preoccupation. Since the 2000 election map highlighted a deep cultural tension between the cities (the blue states) and the sticks (the red states), some Democrats in Washington have been calling on the party to concentrate its efforts on rural voters. Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota, chairman of the Democratic Policy Committee in the Senate, says that the party's standing in rural states is in serious peril, after years of neglect. "They will not see senators and congressmen elected 20 years from now in those states unless they give a damn about helping to build a political base once again," he says. "You ask, 'What do people think of the Democratic Party?' Frankly, I don't think much of it."
But the people who run the party, many of them from the urban political machines, insist that the party's appeal in rural America is in fact growing; they point out that Democrats control most of the statehouses in the South and hold both Senate seats in West Virginia, Georgia and both Dakotas. From their point of view, the only thing Democrats need to do in remote areas is talk louder about the economic issues -- like Social Security and health care -- that define the party. 
Into this widening breach step a pair of new-breed political consultants: Steve Jarding and Mudcat Saunders. Jarding, who once plucked chickens in South Dakota, his native state, and his sidekick, Saunders, a self-described "hillbilly" from Virginia, helped win a surprising victory for the party in the Virginia governor's race last year. Their unconventional rural strategy centered on issues that aren't usually the focal point of Democratic campaigns, like taking vocational education and broadband technology to remote areas. But what really drew attention was how they got their message out: the campaign featured a bluegrass band, a race truck and their very own hunting brigade. 
Since then, Jarding and Saunders have taken their tactics on the road, aspiring to create a whole new army of what might be called Nascar Democrats. They have advised Democrats in several key Congressional and gubernatorial races this fall, from Colorado to New Hampshire to Texas. And now John Edwards, the North Carolina senator whom many view as the party's next great hope, has hired Jarding -- with Saunders in tow -- to run his fledgling presidential campaign, which means their rural strategy is about to go national.
'Democrats have the wuss problem," Mudcat Saunders tells me. "Rural white guys think we're all a bunch of wusses." His given name is David, but everyone calls him Mudcat, and he is probably the only political operative in America whose title is "rural strategist" -- or, as he likes to put it, "Bubba coordinator." 
A lifelong N.R.A. member with a deep mountain drawl, Saunders, 53, spends weekends "gobble hunting" and fishing at a cabin by a creek. And yet he is not exactly your average Bubba. He dresses in Ralph Lauren button-down shirts and does as much dealing on a cellphone as any Hollywood agent. He made good money developing real estate and selling farms in Virginia, where he also lobbied the Legislature on behalf of clients. He represents a leading Nascar team, the Wood Brothers, and helps broker business deals for a bluegrass label -- rural culture is not only a political tool for Saunders; it's a business as well. 
Saunders teamed up with Jarding in 2001, when he joined Mark R. Warner's campaign for the governorship of Virginia, which Jarding was managing. The 44-year-old Jarding is a bulldog of a man who uses so many expletives that you'd never guess he almost became a priest. As a paperboy in Mitchell, S.D., he used to deliver George McGovern's daily newspaper. But Jarding knows Washington as well as he knows the Plains. He has run campaigns for Bob Kerrey and Tom Daschle, among others, and between 1995 and 1997 helped steer the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, which is about as inside as you can get. He has a reputation within the party as a smart and aggressive tactician.
When he took on the Virginia governor's race last year, Jarding decided that Warner could win, but only if he carried a significant portion of the state's rural districts. To a lot of Democrats, that was a little like saying that Warner could be Superman, if only he could learn to fly. Since the 1960's, when rural white voters, especially in the South, abandoned the party over its support of civil rights, Democrats have increasingly had to depend on their base of urban voters, minority groups and organized labor; in national elections, rural votes have been difficult, if not impossible, to come by.
Lee Atwater, the Republican strategist, tried to sever relations between Democrats and rural America completely in the 1980's by turning every campaign into a war over social issues like affirmative action, abortion, gun control and school prayer -- wedge" issues that separated liberal Democrats from small-town voters. It worked. By the 1990's, scores of Democratic officeholders in the South were defecting to the G.O.P.
Democratic presidential candidates didn't help the situation. Chosen by the party's urban base, candidates in the 80's tended to embarrass themselves stumping in rural America, when they bothered to travel there at all. "I remember when Michael Dukakis came to Georgia to campaign," recalls Senator Zell Miller of Georgia, a Democrat. "He went to this event down in Dodge County, and his advance team had scattered hay bales all around. To me, that was worse than him riding in that tank."
Nowhere did Democrats lose more ground than in Virginia, where by 2001 Republicans controlled the Statehouse, both branches of the Legislature and both Senate seats. Looking to change that, Jarding and Saunders spent $28,000 to have Warner -- a high-tech, Harvard-educated millionaire -- sponsor a local Nascar team. They also commissioned a bluegrass campaign song that became a popular single on country radio. (Saunders wrote the lyrics, which included the line "Get ready to shout it from the coal mines to the stills/Here comes Mark Warner, the hero of the hills.") They put together a "Sportsmen for Warner" organization, with trademark orange signs planted in front yards around the state, and touted Warner's pro-gun position so aggressively that the National Rifle Association took the unusual step of staying out of a governor's race.
Once Warner shed the image of a Washington Democrat, he was able to talk to voters in the more remote southern part of the state about their economic crisis: namely, a disappearing job base that forces children to leave home in search of education or work. Rural voters responded enthusiastically. But when Warner rolled out seven rural policy positions and campaigned more than 40 times in southern Virginia, national party leaders grumbled that he was wasting too much time there.
On Election Day, Warner carried an impressive 51 percent of Virginia's rural vote, easily giving him the margin needed to capture the Statehouse.
It's a nice success story, but a lot of Democrats aren't impressed. For one thing, it's not entirely clear that Warner's rural strategy is what got him elected: he spent a lavish $18.5 million on the campaign, much of it for TV ads.
And some Democrats worry that Warner's strategy, taken to a national level, could compromise the party and cost them critical votes in the suburbs. In trying to stave off attacks from the right over guns and abortion -- he came out in favor of gun owners' rights, and though he declared himself pro-choice, he refused to campaign on the issue -- Warner infuriated state party leaders, gun-control advocates and abortion-rights groups. These issues are among the party's core principles, and they're important to a lot of the suburban voters and minority groups who are critical to the Democrats' formula for winning elections. 
On gun control, for example, Sergio Bendixen, a pollster, has found that while the party's stand may alienate rural voters, it appeals strongly to Latino voters -- arguably the most important new bloc of swing voters. That's why gun-control groups insist that they help the party far more than they hurt it. "If the Democratic Party thinks its future lies with rural white males, they're crazy," says Michael Barnes, a former Democratic congressman who now heads the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence. "That's not how you win state elections, and it's not how you win national elections."
As they travel the country on behalf of Edwards's presidential campaign ("My Johnny ain't no wuss," Saunders growls), Jarding and Saunders have become apostles in a rental car, preaching the new rural strategy at every stop. They are winning converts. In New Hampshire, Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, now a Senate candidate, has modeled her own sportsmen's support group after Warner's, right down to the graphics on the sign. In Texas, Tony Sanchez, a gubernatorial candidate, sought out Jarding and Saunders to help reach hunters and racing fans. 
This does not necessarily mean that the rural strategy, as Jarding and Saunders envision it, is taking hold. At least some of the candidates copying Warner are looking for cheap gimmicks to get the attention of rural voters, but without a real policy agenda behind them. If it's not accompanied by substantive ideas, the consultants say, a stock car with your name on it isn't a whole lot different from a few bales of hay.
No democratic senator has been more critical of his own national party than Zell Miller. Last year, Miller wrote publicly that when Terry McAuliffe, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, speaks, it sounds to him like "fingernails across a blackboard." When I spoke to Miller in his office recently, he told me that he has never seen the national party so estranged from rural Americans.
Then Miller asked -- apropos of nothing, it seemed to me -- whether I knew who Bill Elliott was. I didn't.
Nodding, Miller led me to his photo wall and pointed to a picture of a racer. "Bill Elliott won the Pennsylvania 500 last Sunday," he said. "They run stock-car races on Sunday, and they go from one city to another. This last week they were in Pennsylvania. A few weeks ago, they were in New Hampshire. They'll go all the way to California." He said all this in the same sympathetic tone I might have used to describe the concept of the Super Bowl to a first grader.
"This here is Dale Earnhardt," he went on slowly. "He's the guy who got killed."
In his very Southern way, Miller was making a point about culture. Rural voters bristle at the fact that in urban America, their chosen pastimes are considered backward, the punch lines to redneck jokes. And so the amorphous concept of respect, in rural America, has become a genuine political issue. African-American voters, long bound to the Democratic Party by issues like affirmative action and affordable housing, don't demand that a candidate embrace hip-hop. But to rural voters, an appreciation for stock-car racing, hunting and bluegrass is a critical show of faith -- and it has to precede any serious discussion of Social Security or tax cuts.
Mark Penn, the centrist Democratic pollster who coined the term "soccer moms," has argued in recent speeches that the party should now focus on "office-park dads" -- married suburban men between 25 and 50 who work for corporate America and are concerned mainly with economic issues. But Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster who grew up in Montana, disagrees; in her view, which has been largely ignored by the party, "Nascar dads" are the most important emerging voting bloc. "We were the party of the state fair, and we ought to be the party of the Nascar race," she says.
Last year, after the Warner campaign, Jarding and Saunders thought they had a killer idea. Through his Nascar connections, Saunders arranged for the Democratic National Committee to sponsor its own Nascar team, to be called Donkey Power, which would include five trucks constantly touring the country. Some of the unions that support the party, Jarding and Saunders figured, could bear the cost, for about $250,000 each. (The United Auto Workers already spends far more than that to sponsor its own Nascar team.) They even had the truck designed, complete with the logo of a snarling donkey, smoke emanating from its nostrils, over the motto "Racing for Rural America." ("That ain't no wuss donkey," Saunders says.)
But Jarding was unable even to get a meeting with McAuliffe. Instead, he spoke by phone with Gail Stoltz, the party's political director, who rejected the idea. When I asked about that decision, a party official told me: "We don't think that's the best way to deliver the Democratic message. Right now, something that deals with the issues has more impact than something like Nascar."
When I asked McAuliffe, the Democrats' most visible spokesman over the last few months, if the party does in fact have a "wuss problem" in rural America, he shook his head immediately. "Absolutely not," he replied.
A Syracuse native who made millions as an entrepreneur, McAuliffe is a legendary fund-raiser, boisterous and hard to dislike. He said that he has been more aggressive in rural America than any of his recent predecessors, which is true; he has made appearances this year in several rural states, and when he invited a group of Southern senators to the party's D.C. headquarters, it was the first time some of them had even been inside. But McAuliffe also insists that the Democrats' strength remains in the cities.
"I'd like every vote in America," McAuliffe said. "But I'm also realistic. I'm not going to get every vote in America. And listen, most of the population, as you know, is living within 50 miles of the coastline."
This, too, explains why party leaders aren't eager to make a national blueprint of the Warner strategy. Although they won't say so on the record, some Democratic strategists believe that since rural areas are shrinking anyway, the party shouldn't waste critical resources appealing to them. It's not an especially convincing argument; much of that fading rural population is relocating not to suburbs but to the fast-growing "exurbs" -- communities like Forsyth, Ga., 60 miles outside Atlanta, and Collin, Tex., 30 miles from Dallas -- which often retain a rural sensibility, and which tilted heavily for Bush in 2000. 
"Sure it's true that there aren't as many farmers as there used to be," says Bruce Reed, president of the Democratic Leadership Council. "But there is a huge influx of people into places you've never heard of. They're not suburban, because they're not next to cities. But they have a significant amount of voters, and we write them off at our own peril."
John Edwards spoke recently in Washington at what was billed, despite its setting, as the first stop on his "Tour for Rural America." The event, put together by Jarding and Saunders, was a fund-raiser for Ben Jones, who is running for Congress in rural Virginia and who played Cooter in the bygone "Dukes of Hazzard." You can't get more country than that.
The question hanging over Edwards is whether a new-style Nascar Democrat, courting rural voters, can actually win the party's old-style presidential primaries. Edwards doesn't feel like speculating. "I understand why, from a purely political perspective, to someone like you or me, this would seem strategic," Edwards told me. "On the other hand, from my perspective, it's the most natural thing in the world. These are the people that I grew up with, and I have a natural connection with them, and it doesn't matter to me what anybody thinks." 
But skeptics -- some within Edwards's own camp -- point out that voters in the early Democratic primaries tend to be more liberal and urban. "You can't be against gun control and win the Democratic nomination," says a high-ranking party official. "If Edwards wants to try, he's welcome to it."
Edwards already has his name on the side of a stock car in Iowa, which just happens to be driven by a Democratic state legislator. He'll soon have his own song, recorded by the Lonesome River Band, a big-time bluegrass group that has signed on as the campaign's official musical act. And early next year, Edwards plans to introduce in the Senate the first pieces of a legislative agenda for rural America, including a housing bill.
Some will inevitably accuse the Edwards campaign of pandering, which causes Jarding to lapse into more expletives. "I'm sorry, but what is politics?" he demands. "Any time you talk to a voter or listen to a voter, you're pandering." 
For decades, Jarding argues, Democrats have happily pandered to urban and suburban voters, showing up at art galleries and shopping malls, while rural folks have been ignored. "Nascar is a part of America's culture," he says. "Hunting is part of America's culture. There are lots of parts of America's culture, and I'm just suggesting that Democrats got hoodwinked for a long time into believing that we could neglect some of them. I'll go head to head with any Republican. You want to talk about hunting and fishing? Fine. Now you're on my turf. And I'm a Democrat."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Americans in Europe Find Dollars Weaker

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT 

 BODY:
NINE months after euro banknotes and coins became legal tender through much of Europe, the currency has become such a part of life here that the mark, the franc and the lira -- not to mention the punt and the schilling -- seem as quaint as the castles along the Rhine.
 Sadly, for Americans contemplating a trip to Europe, the reign of the dollar over the euro, which made France, Italy, Spain and the nine other euro-zone countries seem cheap, is also fading into memory. 
 As the United States economy has stumbled, the dollar has lost its swagger. After trading as high as 1.21 euros to the dollaron Oct. 26, 2000, it briefly fell below the euro in July, and has settled at a rate of roughly 1.02 euros to the dollar. To the glee of Europeans who keep score in these matters, they have achieved parity, give or take a penny. 
But that means much of Europe is nearly 10 percent more expensive for Americans than it was at the beginning of 2002, when the euro was introduced (it has traded as a "virtual currency" since 1999). And that is worrying news for a tourism industry already reeling from an estimated 10 percent-plus decline in visitors from the United States from May through August because of the faltering economy and terrorism fears.
"We're going to be hurt if the euro goes back above the U.S. dollar," said Peter Hoogs, the vice president for sales and marketing at SRS World Hotels in Stockholm, which represents 400 hotels in 65 countries. "Americans have gotten used to Europe being a little bit cheaper."
It is hard to tell how much the euro has contributed to the decline in visitors this year. Given all the other reasons Americans stayed home, some tourism-industry experts say its effect may have been slight.
"The euro began reaching parity after most people made their decision to go to Europe this summer," said Neil S. Martin, a marketing consultant for the European Travel Commission. 
"In our experience, a strong dollar is a bigger inducement to consider a trip to Europe than a weak dollar is a disincentive," he said.
Still, in Europe's most heavily trafficked tourist destinations, the absence of Americans is palpable. In Venice, the gondoliers are begging for business, as the city's tourist board estimates there was an 18 percent decline in visitors in June, compared with the same month last year. 
Marshall Horowitz, a lawyer from Los Angeles who visited northern Portugal with his family last month, said, "We were the only Americans we saw in our whole week in the Douro Valley." Mr. Horowitz stayed at Casa das Torres de Oliveira, a manor house nestled in the vineyards above the Douro River. The owners told him only 4 percent of their guests came from the United States.
Interviews with retailers and hotel managers from Nice to Heidelberg paint a mixed picture. Some say the strengthening euro has had little measurable impact on their business, while others say it has altered buying patterns of those who do come.
"The American traveler is spending less and has lowered his choice to a less luxurious range of products," said Paul Roll, the general director of the Paris Convention and Visitors Bureau.
At Galeries Lafayette, the celebrated Paris emporium, the sales director, Jean-Michel Hallez, said the number of American shoppers and their purchases had declined about 7 percent this year.
But he added, "The link between the value of the euro and the drop in American consumption is not relevant."
Andreas Cordier, manager of the Romantik Hotel Zum Ritter St. Georg in Heidelberg, said: "I can't see any influence. Even with a weaker dollar, Heidelberg is still inexpensive for American tourists."
Tourism experts agree, however, that any further erosion in the dollar would dampen traffic. "It will become a problem if it contributes to a feeling that Europe is expensive," Mr. Martin said.
While predicting currency trends is difficult, economists believe the fragility of the American economy and fears of war against Iraq could keep the dollar weak for the near future. If that puts Paris and Rome out of reach, it might help historically expensive cities like Oslo and Stockholm.
Norway and Sweden did not enter the monetary union, and a strong euro could close the price gap between them and the rest of Europe. While Denmark also did not join, its currency, the Danish krone, is linked to the euro.
Some tourism-industry experts say Sweden is already benefiting. "People are coming to Sweden because it is relatively cheaper than other euro-zone countries," Mr. Hoogs said.
Within the union, the single currency has narrowed the cost differences among northern and southern countries -- for example, Germany and Spain -- especially in areas like taxis and public transportation. Analysts say it has also helped propel the growth of Europe-wide budget airlines, like Ryanair and easyJet.
Mr. Martin and other tourism promoters are trying to put a good face on the rising euro. They point out that the dollar is still worth 15 percent more against the euro than in 1999. And besides, they say, countries with robust non-euro currencies, like Britain, still attract tourists.
They note that the introduction of 13 billion euro notes and 56 billion coins -- a logistical challenge that people here anticipated with some dread -- came off without a hitch. Travel agents say American visitors are delighted not to have to change their money at every border crossing.
For the accidental tourists of the world, one could even argue that the euro's equivalency to the dollar makes traveling in Europe not that different from traveling at home.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Package Deals In Tough Times

BYLINE:  By MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON; MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON is a freelance writer.

 BODY:
THE continuing struggles of companies selling tours to Europe -- the economy, security issues and uncertainty in the airline business -- translate into some alluring deals for Americans this fall and winter.
 Last fall was so calamitous that the European Travel Commission is using 2000 as a basis for comparison when predicting visitor arrivals this fall from the United States, "Last year can't be used as a barometer," said Neil Martin, a commission spokesman. 
 And compared to 2000, the commission expects a drop of 5 to 15 percent for the months of October through December. 
This follows a summer season that looks to be down about 15 percent from the previous summer, Mr. Martin said. 

A Continent of Choices
 In the following look at some deals for the coming months, prices are per person, based on double occupancy, and generally with midweek departures and arrivals; from mid-December to early January, holiday supplements apply. The least expensive programs usually use a tourist-class hotel, with upgrades possible. Most packages do not include airport taxes and surcharges, which range from $68 to $110 a person.
Sceptre Tours, which specializes in travel to Ireland, is offering a $399 package that includes round-trip air travel from New York or Boston on Aer Lingus and six nights' vouchers for bed-and-breakfasts, plus a week's car rental with unlimited mileage. Those arriving in Shannon rather than Dublin are upgraded to a hotel the first night; other possible upgrades include a car with automatic transmission ($36 a person a week) or to B & B's with private bath (also $36 a week). 
The Emerald Package, as it is called, is available Oct. 16 to March 31, with added costs from Chicago, $90, and Los Angeles, $200. Sceptre also offers a similar package but with one night's stay in a castle and the private bath upgrade, beginning at $499. Visit www.sceptretours.com, or call (800) 221-0924.
IMTC has packages called Starter Smart Packs to 12 European cities --including Vienna, Prague, Innsbruck, Budapest, Salzburg, Paris and Berlin -- from 10 cities in the United States starting from $499 ($689 from the West Coast). These prices include round-trip air fare and three nights' lodging. While prices vary by destination city, all include breakfast, and hotel service charges and taxes. This offer is good from Nov. 1 to March 31. A similar package that adds a week's car rental begins at $519.
IMTC also lets you pair three nights in Vienna with three nights in either Bucharest, Istanbul, Amsterdam, Venice or Florence, with stays in four- or five-star hotels. The Bucharest-Vienna package begins at $699 at the four-star hotels, and $1,299 at the five-stars. Air fare between the cities is included. Go to www.imtc-travel.com, or call (800) 790-4682 for more information.
France Vacations has a package to Paris that includes round-trip air from New York and five nights' hotel stay starting at $479 from Nov. 1 to March 31. A program combining three nights in Paris and three nights in Florence, with round-trip air fare from the East Coast and between the European cities, starts at $769 for the same period, and a Paris-and-Rome package starts at $699. A six-night Paris-and-London package, with travel between cities by second-class Eurostar train, begins at $679. Information: www.francevacations.net or (800) 332-5332.
Similar offerings come from Europe Express. Packages include a six-night London-Paris trip, departing from New York and including rail travel between the destination cities, starting at $615, from Nov. 1 to March 25. A six-night package in Vienna, including air, hotel, breakfast and service charges, begins at $639. The company's Amsterdam Winter Escape, starting at $546, includes four nights in Amsterdam and round-trip air fare. Visit www .europeexpress.com or call (800) 927-3876.
TourCrafters has attractive packages to Italy. For $599, one includes a round trip on Alitalia from Newark, J.F.K., Chicago, Boston or Miami, plus five nights in either Rome, Naples, Florence or Venice. Lodging is in three-star hotels in all cities except Venice, where the hotel is "two-star superior," and includes daily buffet breakfast, plus hotel service charges and taxes. Departures are Nov. 16 through March 15 (except Venice, for which bookings are Nov. 11 to Feb. 21). For more information, call (800) 621-2259 or visit www .tourcrafters.com.
If you can leave on a Tuesday or Wednesday, Virgin Vacations, the inclusive-tour arm of Virgin Atlantic, is offering a six-night London package from just $399. This includes round-trip flights from Newark, J.F.K. or Boston; rail transportation between the London airport and the city center; six nights in a hotel (the $399 lodging is Central House, a budget-class hotel near Victoria Station); daily breakfast, hotel taxes and service charges; and a London guidebook and coupons for discounted dining and wine tasting. The package is for travel Nov. 1 to Dec. 14, and must be booked before Nov. 26. Go to www.virgin.com/vacations, or call (888) 937-8474.
Northwest Airlines WorldVacations is combining round-trip air fare to Paris, Frankfurt, Amsterdam, Rome or London, with two nights' hotel and daily Continental breakfast, starting at $439 from New York, Newark or Boston, including taxes and departure fees. This fall special is good for travel through Oct. 31, and reservations must be made by Oct. 24. Winter packages for the same cities begin at $369, with departures Dec. 2 through March 31. For more information, visit the Web site nwaworldvacations.com (click on Cyberdeals, then Europe), or call (800) 800-1504.

For Surfers
No discussion of deals these days is complete without the Internet, and American Airlines has a Web-only offer for travel to Paris or London this fall and winter. I tried booking a sample trip, and while several dates were unavailable, eventually I booked six nights, Sept. 25 to Oct. 1, in Paris at the tourist-class Hotel du Centre in the Ninth Arrondissement. With a round-trip flight from J.F.K. the cost was $714.70 a person, excluding airport surcharges. The six-night stay also included a three-course meal in the hotel restaurant, with wine and coffee, for each person, and 3,000 bonus AAdvantage miles. 
American's three-night packages to Paris begin at $484 a person through Oct. 31 (these must be booked by Oct. 17), and $381 a person from Nov. 1 to 15 or Nov. 22 to Dec. 14. Go to www.aavacations.com and click on Deals and then What's Hot.
For comparison, I went to www.expedia.com and searched for a package to Paris for the same dates. Expedia nearly matched American's offer through Delta Air Lines, with a six-night package on the same dates that included a slightly better, three-star hotel. The price of $803.82 a person included airport taxes and surcharges. On Delta's site, www.deltavacations.com, I found a similar package for $805.

HEADLINE: In New Jersey, The Newest Pot of Gold 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER 

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY 

 BODY:
A cloud of super-cold air rises as researchers in the Rutgers University cell and DNA repository open a tank filled with ampules of cryogenically frozen cells. The tanks in this laboratory hold cells from more than 30,000 people with a family history of genetic disease including autism, schizophrenia and diabetes.
 Scientists at Rutgers grow cells from DNA and parcel them out to researchers around the world who will mine it for clues that may lead to cures. 
 Dr. Jay Tischfield, director of the repository and head of Rutgers's genetics department, said the laboratory was financed with more than $6 million in federal funds -- just a tiny drop in a huge government spending push to support medical research. These days the federal government as well as many states are pouring billions into medical research to find new treatments for disease. 
Moreover, in the anemic afterglow of the 90's, when states were flush and budgets were being met, the infusion of huge amounts of government funds are serving as a much-needed economic development tool, generating thousands of new jobs and millions of dollars in additional tax revenue.
"I've been at this for 30 years, and I've seen some very lean times," said Dr. Tischfield. "This is by far the best it has ever been."
Public investment in medical research is expected to ripple throughout the economy like the government-financed military-industrial complex of the 1950's and 60's, which created new technologies -- including a primitive Internet -- while bolstering both the Pentagon and military contractors during the cold war.
In this latest marriage of federal largesse and private brainpower, scientists in New Jersey are working on futuristic medical technologies that may result in designer drugs tailored to patients' genetic makeup, artificial skin and bone, or tiny chips that can be embedded in the body to deliver time-released medication.
"The analogy to defense is true," said Bill Stephenson, vice president for research at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. "These days a great deal of start-up activity is in the biomedical arena, and I think it is absolutely the case that federal spending for research spurs the growth of new companies."
While most of the new public money is going to academic research, it is also seeping into projects at private companies trying to cross the bridge from pure science to commercial applications. Many of these companies are even being run by former professors, or some simply on leave, who have morphed into entrepreneurs.
When it comes to private spending on research, New Jersey draws $10 billion a year -- the most for any state on a per capita basis and among the top five in total dollars -- according to the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology. Of that, more than half flows into medical research spending, mostly from giant American and European drug manufacturers with operations in New Jersey.
Despite its vast private research infrastructure, New Jersey lags behind many states in financing from the National Institutes of Health, the largest pot of public money. The Clinton administration set out to double the institutes' budget from 1998 to 2003, and it has grown since 1998 at a rate of 15 percent a year to $27.24 billion this year. Of that, cancer research received the largest chunk, $5.5 billion in the budget for 2003
New Jersey ranks 24th among the states in financing from N.I.H. -- just behind Oregon and one rung above Iowa -- with 588 awards totaling $182 million. California comes in first with nearly $2.5 billion followed by Massachusetts with $1.7 billion.
Michael Breton, associate vice president for research and sponsored programs at Rutgers, said the main reason that New Jersey fell somewhere in the middle was that despite its affluent, well-educated population, New Jersey had only three medical schools and few large teaching hospitals. At each end of the state, in New York and Philadelphia, prestigious medical centers siphon off New Jersey patients and researchers.
"It's not as if the region lacks these major super research institutions," Dr. Breton said. "They're just not physically within the borders of New Jersey."
The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey is the state's largest recipient of money from the institutes, with 267 grants totaling $89.2 million, ranking 55th among all institutions receiving the federal funds.
Rutgers ranked 100th with 139 grants totaling $38.4 million and Princeton was 105th with $35.3 million in grants. Neither institution has a medical school, which frequently spawn faculty research grants.
Nonetheless, all three institutions are pushing medical initiatives, and the future could be quite lucrative in terms of grant revenue, long-term royalties and creating educated employees for the state's work force.
In 1970 the State Legislature created the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, which is now the nation's largest health sciences university with 4,500 students. It has three medical schools under its umbrella -- New Jersey Medical School, Robert Wood Johnson Medical School and the School of Osteopathic Medicine -- as well as five other health-care schools including dentistry and nursing.
Dr. Stephenson, of U.M.D.N.J., said that in its first years the university focused on the basics. "We were intent on building the educational structure and the health-delivery structure, and we just didn't pay a lot of attention to the research side," he said.
But four years ago the university began a major push to improve its research capabilities, including programs in cancer, cardiovascular disease, neuroscience and injury caused by trauma. In all, the university will spend $236 million on research this year, and it has embarked on a $518 million building program to house new research, classroom and clinical space.
"We were bursting at the seams," said Dr. Stephenson. "You can't grow your own, or hire superstars, unless you put together new space."
The university has already completed the International Center for Public Health, a $78 million building in Newark, and a $7 million annex to existing research centers in Piscataway.
A new $37 million behavioral health science building is set to open in Newark next spring, and U.M.D.N.J. is building a new $45 million research tower for molecular biology in Piscataway.
Just this summer, the university broke ground on a $100 million, seven-story cancer center in Newark that will include a hospital complex along with cancer research labs. It is also tripling the size of its cancer facility in New Brunswick with a $71 million, 150,000-square foot building. In addition, the university's Cancer Institute of New Jersey will receive $20 million in financing from the state's tobacco settlement fund.
The buildings are to be financed through $95 million in state bonding authorized by the Whitman administration and an additional $280 million in bonds underwritten by the university alone. Dr. Stephenson said the university would finance the rest of the construction with gifts to the university and other internal funds.
University revenue could grow by $30 million to $40 million a year, said Dr. Stephenson, if one or more of its licensing deals with start-up companies resulted in a major new drug coming to market. By comparison, the university earned earned a meager $1 million on royalties this year.
His optimism is based on more than just good feelings. In the past six years, the university has spun off 12 companies commercializing its technology, and Dr. Stephenson said that in two to five years one may have a drug coming to market.
In addition, Dr. Stephenson said the new buildings would also help the university increase its business in lucrative clinical trials for the drug industry.
"Quite frankly, we have not served the pharmaceutical industry right here in New Jersey as adequately as we might," he said.
For now, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey is now running clinical trials valued at $30 million, though it aims to increase that to $100 million to $200 million in the next several years, Dr. Stephenson said.
"This is in a state where the pharmaceutical industry is probably spending $3 billion to $5 billion a year running clinical trials around the world," he said. "What that's telling you is we're not providing a very attractive location for doing trials."
Rutgers spent $242 million on research last year, up from $96 million in 1990. In medical research, the university has been focusing on neuroscience, including spinal cord injuries, biomaterials and molecular biology. In addition, Rutgers has spun off 40 companies developing ideas discovered there. The university has plans for two new medical research buildings -- a $28 million complex that will house Dr. Tischfield's genetics programs and biomaterials research, and a $23.8 million center for biomedical engineering. Both buildings, financed by state higher education funds, a bond offering and Rutgers's own capital campaign, are to open in 2004.
Dr. Tischfield said the new buildings were essential to lure top graduate students who might also be considering schools like the University of California at San Diego, where new lab space was continually cropping up.
"Rutgers has a long way to go, but it has come a long way in a short amount of time," said Dr. Tischfield, who was recruited to Rutgers from Indiana University in 1999.
A native New Yorker, Dr. Tischfield said he had little or no opinion of New Jersey before he took the job at Rutgers. Then, as he drove around while house-hunting, he kept running into huge pharmaceutical research and development facilities.
"As unfair as it may be, New Jersey tends to be ignored in research," he said. "But from the point of view of economic activity -- with Big Pharma here -- New Jersey is the place."
At Princeton, the Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics is expected to move into a new $45 million building -- designed by the architect Rafael Vinoly and financed by Carl Icahn, a 1957 graduate -- in November. Created in 2000 in response to the explosion in genomics research and to give the academic community access to high-tech tools available in industry, the institute is bound to grow and prosper, since its director is Shirley M. Tilghman, who is now the president of the university.
James R. Broach, acting director, said the Lewis-Sigler institute drew on faculty from many departments, including mathematics, engineering and chemistry, to help biologists make sense of all the data being generated by new genetic research tools.
"In the post-genomics era we are not so much data-limited as we are limited by our ability to handle the data," said Dr. Broach.
The institute was founded with a $35 million gift from Peter B. Lewis, a Princeton trustee and chief executive of the Progressive Corporation, an automobile insurance company, and named for him and Mr. Lewis's Princeton roommate, Paul Sigler, a structural biologist who was on the faculty at Yale University until his death in 2000.
In addition to the federal money available for medical research that is currently being done, the state has financial programs to help foster that research. The state's largest grant-making agency in that field is the New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology, which is budgeted to spend $14 million this year, of which more than $6 million is aimed at biomedical research. That is the same level of spending as last year, though down from $25 million in 2000.
John Tesoriero, executive director of the commission, said the agency had financed $30 million in biomedical research over the past five years. This year the commission opened five technology incubators, publicly financed labs where companies can rent space to work on ideas in the early stages without investing in equipment or committing to a long-term lease. After closing two others, the state now has 10 incubators, many of them occupied by small biotechnology start-up comnpanies.
Still, Mr. Tesoriero said New Jersey's state support for medical research was tiny compared with that in many other states.
"It is the fashion right now to develop every urban center into a center for biotechnology," he said. "They see it as the next savior of these urban economies."
Mr. Tesoriero said it was hard to justify spending taxpayer dollars to stimulate medical research in a state whose pharmaceutical companies, with their rich salary structure, were already the envy of most other states' economic development officials.
"Nonetheless, we have to keep our university infrastructure in such a way that it would support this industry base," he said. "We need programs or these biotech companies can just as easily go to Pennsylvania, or San Diego or Boston."
For his part, Mr. Tesoriero said his program filled a need that went unmet by the state's large drug industries, financing research in the early stages with the promise of commercialization -- a niche that has been harder to fill as private venture capital has dried up.
"We're not funding the very far-out kind of basic research," he said. "Our applicants have to demonstrate the business potential or importance of all of the work that goes on in the projects we fund."
Jon Shure, president of the New Jersey Policy Perspective, said government business incentives would inevitably shift toward new technology.
"People realize the future is not in bringing in more factories," he said. "It is in high-tech, biotech and other cutting edge areas. But whether the incentive is for medical research or building cars, there's still a need to find out some basic things, like do they really need the incentive to come here? How many jobs are they actually going to create? What will those jobs pay?"
And he asked: "If you want to have high-end, good-paying modern technology businesses in the state, is the best way to give them pots of money or is it to make sure we have good schools and good transportation, a clean environment and all the other things government is supposed to do?"
The payoff for public investment in research is that ideas pondered in academic laboratories will grow from ideas to commercial products. 
Stuart Peltz, founder of PTC Therapeutics Inc., in South Plainfield, is building his company on discoveries he made as a researcher at Robert Wood Johnson Medical School.
Dr. Peltz said New Jersey did lag behind other biotech hotbeds in private capital networks and state support. For instance, he said that other states were using pension funds and more of their tobacco fund settlement to stimulate medical research.
"New Jersey could think about how to be creative to help educate and get people to start doing this in a bigger way," he said. "Massachusetts, San Francisco, San Diego -- there's not better science there, it's just more entrepreneurial."
Still, despite these obstacles, New Jersey does have its advantages.
Karen Giroux, chief executive of Polymerix Corporation, a startup company in Piscataway that is developing a plasticlike form of aspirin based on technology from Rutgers, said being in New Jersey might help it forge rich licensing and partnership deals with large drug makers.
"New Jersey is ground zero for the drug industry," said Bob Butz, president of Polymerix who has worked in North Carolina, San Diego and San Franciscco.
"When I was in San Francisco I was always on airplanes heading east," he said. "Here, you can drive to your meetings."
Despite greater acceptance of entrepreneurial science, there remains a line between public, academic interests and free-market science. Dr. Breton, of Rutgers, said that until the State Legislature changed conflict-of-interest rules for state employees in 1991, scientists could not have an interest in a company that did business with the university, like leasing lab space or licensing technology. The change has made it much easier for university scientists to branch out with commercial programs.
But he said the university still preferred that scientists took a leave, or did not serve as an officer of outside companies in which they had a financial stake.
"There's been a general change in attitude since the 1980's," Dr. Breton said. "It's O.K. for faculty members to be involved in commercial projects, within certain limits. It used to be the ivory tower approach."
For instance, when Dr. Tischfield finished graduate school at Yale, he was offered a job at a pharmaceutical company, but his academic mentor at the time said he would never speak to him again if he took the job.
Now, in addition to his academic research, Dr. Tischfield sits on the boards of several start-up companies and runs his DNA repository like a business. He said private companies had tried to run similar operations but went out of business, leaving researchers in the lurch, whereas from his position in academia, he answered to no shareholders.
Pointing to one tank filled with frozen cells, he said, "I only have to answer to these people and their families."
