HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
FendingOff Babel In a Global Village

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN B. LEVINE 

 BODY:
ROBERT BISHOP grew up next door to one of Australia's immigrant hostels after World War II and remembers marveling at the creative talents of his Spanish, Greek and Latvian neighbors. Many of the women were educated professionals, a rarity in those days, and their children almost always rose to the top of their classes.
 Taught as a child that Aussies were the best, he was rocked by this evidence to the contrary. It was his first inkling of the core principle of his career: "No country has a monopoly on good ideas." 
 Mr. Bishop, now chief executive of Silicon Graphics Inc., has become the quintessential global manager. Over 35 years, he and his Japanese wife, Yoshimi, have lived and worked on four continents as he built operations in 30 countries for three American high-technology companies. He has taught at business schools from Stockholm to Milan and counseled governments in Malaysia and Australia. Currently, Mr. Bishop, 59, is based at Silicon Graphics headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., while his wife maintains their home in Geneva and their three adult daughters pursue careers in Switzerland, England and the United States.
Mr. Bishop's continent-straddling profile is a prized commodity. In a recent study of 100 mostly non-American international executives chosen as exemplary by their companies, half had multicultural backgrounds, like having parents of different nationalities or being raised in more than one country. "There's no single kind of global manager," said Morgan W. McCall Jr., co-author of "Developing Global Executives" (Harvard Business School Press, 2002) and professor of management at the University of Southern California. "But the person who begins with global roots has a big advantage."
It was once enough to build international businesses by moving employees overseas or hiring local nationals, said Susan C. Schneider, a management professor at the University of Geneva and co-author of "Managing Across Cultures" (Prentice Hall, 1997). But no more.
Management structures are shifting from country and regional sales units to worldwide product development and manufacturing organizations. And home-office staffs are usually a melange of nationalities requiring managers with broad cultural understanding. "We've long had a borderless economy," Dr. Schneider said. "It's no surprise that we now have an elite corps of executives with borderless careers."
The most attuned managers have what she calls the "global mind-set" that allows them to pick up on local differences and leverage them around the world. It rarely develops without living in foreign cultures.
Mr. Bishop gained such a mind-set by seeking experience in three major markets: the United States, Japan and Europe. He found radically different management values but quickly learned to harness them wherever he went. To this day, he shares frank details of Silicon Graphics operations with all employees in quarterly teleconferences, a legacy of his years in Germany.
In Japan, he learned to hew to a long-term strategy, no matter the short-term demands of investors. "I continually get hazed by Wall Street, but I've learned not to blink," he said. After 10 quarters of losses, cash flow recently turned positive at Silicon Graphics, which appears to be back on track with robust sales of three-dimensional visualization applications to the military.
Another hallmark of the global executive is people skills -- a challenge if you are dealing with people from a half-dozen cultures, Dr. McCall said. And, he warned, you can't assume that lessons learned in one foreign experience will apply to others.
Ask Sidney A. Taylor, president of Incal Pipeline Rehabilitation Inc. Since 1992, Mr. Taylor has honed his cultural sensibilities by running Incal, an oil pipeline maintenance company based in Houston, from Paris.
When he entered the Algerian market a few years ago, he expected the same high-caliber technical expertise of his client there that he had experienced elsewhere in the region. But for weeks, a midlevel Algerian manager held up approval of a urethane coating for no apparent reason. Mr. Taylor soon realized that the manager was terrified of losing his well-paying job -- a rare prize in most developing countries -- over a wrong decision but lacked the technical skills necessary to make it. So Mr. Taylor simplified his pitch and won him over. "You learn to psychoanalyze people to get under the surface of what they're saying," he said.
TO get a feel for the local psyche, Mr. Bishop, the son of a longshoreman, visits shipping docks and railroad yards wearing street clothes to talk with ordinary workers. "Understanding the underside of society in the struggle between rich and poor helps me develop empathy for the people of a country," he said. In turn, that builds trust with employees and customers.
His most gratifying "foreign" experience came in the 1970's in Atlanta as a senior executive at the Digital Equipment Corporation. A management rivalry between the Atlanta office and Boston headquarters had grown bitter and taken on overtones of a North-South conflict. But because he was an Australian, with an Australian accent and Australian mannerisms, he was able to avoid being identified with either camp. Acting as an neutral broker, he said, he mended the split and went on to lead his region to record-breaking sales.
The Internet does not diminish managers' need to understand local cultures, in Mr. Bishop's view. While global communications have simplified mundane tasks like local pricing, they have also freed management to spend more time on global manufacturing, marketing and financing strategies, he says, and those new duties will require more acute cultural antennae, not less. Mr. Bishop himself, in other jobs before coming to Silicon Graphics in 1999, made two round-the-world trips every quarter to visit local managers and customers. "The complexities aren't going away," he said. "There's no substitute for being there."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 22, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about executives with work experience in several countries misstated the tenure of one such manager, Robert Bishop of Silicon Graphics Inc. He joined the company in 1986 and returned in 1999 from a four-year hiatus to become chairman and chief executive; that was not his starting year.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
When the News Serves as a Business Textbook

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
LIKE nearly every graduate business school in the country, Long Island University offers a course in ethics. At the university's Southampton College branch, the course fills up quickly. "That's mainly because it's required," said Herbert Sherman, who teaches it.
 In the last year business ethics has grown even more interesting, as scandals involving companies like Enron, WorldCom, ImClone and Global Crossing became front page news. This semester, which started for most business school students just after Labor Day, that interest is likely to continue and increase. 
 The spate of corporate scandals that have helped put the brakes on economic recovery have also pushed topics like ethics, auditing management and nonstandard accounting systems to the forefront of the classroom discussion, not to mention onto the front pages of the nation's newspapers and the top of the nightly newscasts.
"Students take the recent scandals very seriously, and as a result the ethics course is much more fun to teach," Professor Sherman said. "Students have plenty of their own ethics stories to tell. Some of them are pretty scathing."
At Adelphi University last semester, Rakesh Gupta, who teaches management and business policy and is an associate dean of the School of Business, moderated a discussion on business ethics featuring professors from other departments as panelists. One was Stephen Greenfield, a philosophy instructor, who suggested that Plato and other ancient philosophers had dealt effectively with similar questions about decision making, integrity and fair dealing many centuries ago.
"The discussion veered toward what you might call situational ethics," Professor Gupta said. "I believe people can have a personal moral code that allows for dealing with different situations using different sets of ethics. When you're dealing with law, however, it's more cut and dried."
Professor Gupta said he believed the discussion introduced many students to a more nuanced approach to the question of values versus morals. "Someone from Germany or India may have other ways of dealing with moral issues, but that doesn't mean they are less ethical," he said.
By way of example, Dean Gupta said he encourages classroom debate about the morality of giving (or taking) baksheesh, accepted as a way of doing business in many Eastern countries but categorized as bribery in the United States, and hence illegal. 
As subjects like off-balance-sheet loans, auditing controls and insider trading have become cocktail party fodder, business professors find that students who in past years sat quietly through their lectures, perhaps discreetly dozing on some occasions, are now scrutinizing every word.
Mark Holtzman said that over the summer he prepared to teach his fall semester accounting class at Hofstra by following news coverage as the scandals proliferated, posting some of those accounts on the Web site he maintains as a classroom resource. "I try to encourage students to look beyond the statements issued by companies and see the potential for earnings manipulation," he said. "I try to focus on the gray area between manipulation and possible fraud."
Professor Holtzman acknowledged that the subject might seem a little dry. "Perhaps it is a little specialized," he said. "But when you deal with a company like WorldCom and a situation involving $7 billion in nonexisting assets, the subject suddenly gets more interesting to more people."
The recent scandals have not yet made it into textbooks. Case studies dealing with the scandals -- articles about business situations written by academics that are reprinted and distributed as study guides -- have just begun to appear.
Faculty members at the Island's six graduate business schools said the lack of textbooks was hardly the hindrance it would have been a few years ago, before corporate financial information became readily available on the Web.
"You really don't have to wait for the textbook or the case study to be published," Professor Holtzman said. "It's all in the business press, and it's all on the Internet."
Robert Berman, a marketing professor at Hofstra and a co-author of "Retail Management: A Strategic Approach" (Prentice Hall, 2002), now in its ninth edition, said that the recent business news had touched many lives. "It affects so many businesses and so many people," he said. "Huge retailers like Kmart have recently had to restate earnings." 
This year, Professor Berman and Joel Evans, his colleague at Hofstra and co-author, added a chapter to their book dealing with methods of accounting for unsold merchandise. It is a chapter, they said, very much inspired by recent events. Issues like returning discounts from vendors based on unmet sales projections is increasingly relevant, he said, if sometimes a challenge to those without accounting backgrounds.
"Some of this is so technical we don't really go into it with our marketing students," Professor Berman said. "I might mention it and say, 'This is an area you should be cognizant of.' "
It will probably be another semester or two before the accounting and financial issues now roiling the corporate world find their way into textbooks. "The academic world doesn't turn on a dime," said David R. Decker, the dean of the School of Management at the New York Institute of Technology's Old Westbury campus. "And it doesn't need to. Our curriculum already incorporates ethical considerations in six of the 14 courses taught." 
The scandals "have heightened awareness of the issues and provided a great deal of food for thought and fodder for the classroom," said Jerry Trapnell, the dean of the College of Business and Public Affairs at Clemson University in South Carolina and the chairman of the curriculum committee of the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business in St Louis.
"Clearly these issues cannot be ignored," he said. "But they aren't dominating the classroom either. It's important to maintain balance."
Because many of the Island's M.B.A. candidates are middle managers or rising executives at local companies, classroom discussions may hit close to home, Professor Holtzman of Hofstra said. To avoid making any student uncomfortable, he sticks to the facts and avoids speculation, he said, and insists students do so as well.
"Computer Associates has been in that troublesome gray area for years in terms of its accounting methods, and last year we did bring up C.A. in a class discussion," Professor Holtzman said. "There were a couple of C.A. employees in my class. I've had Symbol employees in my class, too," referring to Symbol Technologies, another local company whose internal practices have come under scrutiny.
"It wasn't uncomfortable," he said. "I was especially careful what I said about those companies, so I wouldn't make a fool of myself. Whatever I might know about a company, its employees know more than I do."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Middletown Armory To Become a Hotel

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WHEN John Adams visited Middletown, Conn., in 1771, he pronounced it "the most beautiful town of all." But after the collapse of its maritime industry in the early 19th century and the loss of its textile mills in the 20th century, it fell on some tough times.
 Over the last four years, however, most of the storefronts on Middletown's Main Street have filled up, a 12-screen theater has opened in the downtown and there has been a restaurant boom, bringing dozens of dining establishments to the business district. 
 Now a Long Island developer is preparing to start a $10.2 million project to turn the old city armory into Middletown's only downtown hotel, with 100 rooms, a restaurant and lounge that would accommodate up to 160 people, and 3,000 square feet of office and meeting space.
"I've tended to be interested in these secondary cities," said Robert B. Friedman, a partner in Friedman, Gordon, Smith & Klee, a partnership in Woodbury, N.Y., which is to begin work on the project this month and expects to finish the hotel next July. "I took a trip up there and really fell in love with the city. I think its downtown has enormous potential." 
Richard C. Kearney, Middletown's economic development specialist, noted that Wesleyan University will invest $1 million in a new arts center in the downtown and that there is a proposal for a riverfront project that would bring housing, stores and a conference center to a site on the Connecticut River, just a few blocks from Main Street. The hotel will add another dynamic to what is becoming a flourishing downtown, he said.
"It will act as an anchor on Main Street; it will bring 100 to 150 people a night down to Main Street on an overnight basis, which will add some pedestrian traffic and business at the restaurants and services in that neighborhood," Mr. Kearney said. "It will make it seem like a different kind of city."
Munro W. Johnson, the city's community development specialist, said the only lodging for travelers currently available in Middletown is in two motels, both on the edge of town. The armory project will be the first hotel in the business district.
"The significance of that from a downtown development point of view just can't be overstated," Mr. Johnson said. "We have the new streetlights on Main Street, a streetscape plan is in place -- there are a whole lot of things that really make us feel like we're on the way up."
Larry McHugh, president of the Middlesex County Chamber of Commerce, also noted that the armory would be convenient to Route 9, the limited access highway that passes through Middletown. "This will be the only hotel on Route 9 from Interstate 84 in New Britain to Interstate 95 in Old Saybrook, which will give it a tremendous advantage," Mr. McHugh said. Some 60,000 cars a day pass through the city on Route 9 every day, he said.
John R. Watkinson, a prominent merchant in Middletown in the early 19th century, built the original part of the armory in 1810 as a home, said Dione Longley, director of the Middlesex County Historical Society.
"It would have been fairly grand for Middletown at that time," Ms. Longley said. "And interestingly, it was built about the time that Middletown began its economic slide with the decline of the maritime business."
Middletown was the state's most populous and prosperous community at the time the first wing of the armory was built, because its location on the Connecticut River made it a hub for maritime trade. 
When the state acquired the property for use as an armory in 1919, it moved the original structure 90 degrees, built a duplicate of it to face it and connected them by a drill shed that now faces Main Street. The state discontinued its use of the armory about 10 years ago.
The city used $190,000 in federal grants to restore the facade of the building in 1995 and 1996, originally in the hope that it would be used as a community center or youth center, but those plans never came to fruition. A local businessman, Gerard Weitzman, purchased the armory in 1997. Mr. Weitzman, whose family has owned Pelton's Pharmacy in Middletown since 1800, died in 1999 in a car accident.
Mark Masselli, chief executive of the Community Health Center on Main Street, said Mr. Weitzman's death spurred local business and political leaders and the president and vice president of Wesleyan College to form a committee that would seek a developer for the property. 
"We were really thinking of some way to memorialize his long-term commitment to Main Street, to commerce and really, very specifically, to the armory project," Mr. Masselli said. 
IN the early 1990's, the city had hired the Boston-based Pinnacle Group to make a feasibility study of the hotel market in the downtown. At that time, Pinnacle recommended against it. But the committe approached Pinnacle to take a second look.
"When they came back this time, they said, 'Middletown is absolutely ripe for a hotel,' " Mr. Masselli said. 
What has changed, the project's supporters say, is that the downtown has slowly filled up over the years. Today, there are almost none of the empty storefronts that characterized the city on Pinnacle's first visit, and there are a number of new projects that are bringing more and more people downtown, from the Kids City Museum, which is undergoing a $3 million expansion, to a nine-unit artists' co-operative that will open next month in the north end, with a gallery, cafe and pottery studio.
The marketing study attracted interest from about 10 reputable developers throughout the Northeast, Mr. Masselli said. "Most of them barely knew where Middletown was, but they knew Pinnacle, and they knew if Pinnacle said the area could support a hotel they wanted to be here," Mr. Masselli said.
Mr. Kearney said there are two major sources of business for a hotel in Middletown: Wesleyan, which draws visitors from all over the world for college functions and arts conferences; and Pratt & Whitney's aircraft division, which does business internationally. 
Mr. Masselli said the committee met with all the developers but was most impressed with Mr. Friedman, who had developed the Nathan Hale Inn at the University of Connecticut in Storrs and the Comfort Suites in Norwich. 
Mr. Friedman said he would use the same team for the armory as for his first two hotel projects: Group One of Boston as the architect; O. Ahlborg & Sons of Cranston, R.I., as a general contractor; and International Hotels and Resorts as the manager when the project it is finished.
About 8,000 square feet of the existing armory, including the entire facade, will be retained, he said, while a 60,000-square-foot, five-story addition will rise to the rear of the building for guest space.
The city and Wesleyan will put another $750,000 into the armory project; private investors in the city will put up additional funding; and the Weitzman family will lease the site to the developers, retaining a stake as well.
"About one-third of the project cost is coming from the community," Mr. Friedman said. "That's important because they feel like they have a stake in its success. If people have their money on the table, they're more likely to support it."
The project was ready to go last year, but the slowing economy and then the terrorist attacks of last Sept. 11 derailed it.
"It literally took thousands of phone calls to get it back on track," Mr. Masselli said. "The banks were reluctant at first, but then they were encouraged by the broad community support for this project, and for the broad economic support -- Mr. Friedman and his backers are putting more than $1 million of their own money into the armory."
MR. WEITZMAN'S stepson, Neil A. Alan, said his stepfather "really wanted to do something special for the community." He added: This was a project he would have loved to see happen. It was the reason he purchased the building. This is exactly the kind of thing he wanted to do."
Mr. Alan said he supported the selection of Mr. Friedman to develop the project as well.
"I think he's become a big fan of Middletown as well," Mr. Alan said. "We wanted someone who was going to create an independent hometown style inn for us, something that would fit into the Middletown fabric. This is not going to have a cookie-cutter, chain feel to it. But where better to build a Main Street hotel than Main Street, U.S.A.?"

HEADLINE: Meriden Takes Another Shot at Revival 

BYLINE:  By MARK PETERS 

 BODY:
JOHN CLEMENTS is leery of the planners and the politicians who talk about redevelopment in downtown Meriden. Past efforts have forced his family to move its jewelry store, left customers without parking and caused businesses to shut down.
 But even as Mr. Clements bemoaned almost four decades of plans and projects, he agreed that something had to be done to help the city's failing downtown area. 
 "There definitely is a need; just drive down main street," he said, pointing to the street that runs in front of his store.
This summer, a plan was proposed to end the years of empty storefronts and deserted streets. The idea is winning the support of elected officials and business leaders in this midsize city in the center of the state.
The plan, called the City Center Initiative, would drastically change the shape of downtown, realigning main roads and moving hundreds of residents.
Supporters say that within a decade they expect a vibrant, growing city center to exist, ending a history of redevelopment flops that have left residents cynical about the downtown area's future.
The City Center Initiative, which was released in late July, calls for $40 million in public spending and
$90 million in private investments to create three retail centers, two office buildings, several restaurants, a multiplex theater, 1,000 new parking spaces and a downtown park.
What is scheduled to be replaced are an outdated federal housing project, a neighboring condominium complex and the Meriden Hub, a near-empty mall that was built as part of a city redevelopment project in the late 1960's.
"It is comprehensively solving an overall problem," said Wayne D'Amico, a consultant for the Meriden Economic Resource Group Inc., which commissioned the plan with other private, nonprofit development groups.
The plan, created by BL Companies in Meriden, relies on the use of public money to solve nagging problems like poor highway access and chronic flooding. The end result is what is being called a one-of-a-kind site in Connecticut: about 40 acres of developable land in an urban center with frontage on Interstate 691.
"I don't know of anything close," said Robert Landino, president of BL Companies, comparing the Meriden initiative with Hartford's redevelopment project. "As an example, Adriaen's Landing is one-third the size."
From this central site, the plan stretches west to what is traditionally known as the center of downtown and east to the neighborhood surrounding city hall. Ideas for the later stages include an art district, a community college campus and a new industrial park.
Saulo Sfroza can already envision the new buildings and the tree-lined boulevards. Thirty-two years ago his barber shop was the first business to open at the Meriden Hub, which was considered to be a key to downtown redevelopment at the time. Now, Mr. Sfroza's is one of only three businesses left in the dilapidated mall.
"I hope they do it," he said over the buzz of electric shears. "I don't know when. It would be good for Meriden."
Although he is optimistic, some of his customers on a recent Saturday were not as excited.
Vincent Cassarino, who grew up a short walk from Mr. Sforza's shop, said he had lived through redevelopment in the late-1960's and a smaller project in the late-1980's and considered them both costly failures.
"Look around," he said. "Most of the places are empty."
Like many older residents, Betty Calvi, 74, can remember the bustling downtown of her youth where everyone went on the weekend to shop, eat and be entertained.
Since the plan has been released, its supporters have tried to exorcise the ghosts of past projects, while also trying to convince residents that the long-term plan could return the downtown area to what it was.
"They are looking to the past," said Stephen T. Zerio, the City Council majority leader.
Many residents and even some elected officials, however, cannot forget the $27 million the city spent to make downtown improvements starting in 1989. The project included a parking garage, a new courthouse and police complex, red brick sidewalks and decorative lighting. It did little to stimulate interest downtown.
Mayor Mark D. Benigni said residents needed to understand that the city's approach has changed. The philosophy before was what is being label as a "field of dreams" approach in which the city made millions of dollars in improvements and then waited for businesses to come. This time, however, construction will not begin until there are commitments from retail developers.
"I really want our citizens to be excited, to look at this as an opportunity," Mr. Benigni said.
The idea for a comprehensive redevelopment plan grew out of a series of meetings last year in which business and political leaders realized there were too many competing ideas for downtown.
"Everyone wanted to gentrify or rejuvenate something," Mr. D'Amico said.
The group concluded that the state government and developers would not support a plan if there were no clear goal. The solution was to back one initiative.
Since the plan's release, several business leaders have backed the plan, but the opinions from the City Council have wavered.
Some council members say that residents are opposed to the initiative because they fear the city will raise taxes to pay for it. A vote last month to approve further work on the plan passed by a 10-2 count with one Democrat and one Republican dissenting.
"I am just very leery of the fact I think the taxpayers will pick-up a large portion of this project," said Deputy Mayor Walter A. Shamock Jr., a Republican.
Those who are pushing the plan say that the city is more than a year away from starting any construction, and with tough votes on housing and property acquisitions ahead, support will continue to be tested.
"The plan will change tens, if not hundreds, of times before it is finalized," Mr. Zerio said.
The initiative needs state money to move forward. Private groups that have financed it thus far are not prepared to commit further dollars, and there is little political support for the city to spend any money on the initiative at this point. 
The state Bond Commission meeting, which is scheduled for Sept. 27, will be a crucial test for the initiative, since the commission will consider allocating $250,000 for further planning.
During a stop earlier this month, Gov. John G. Rowland, who sets the commission's agenda, promised the city would get the money.
There is also a second plan emerging for downtown. A local developer, Joseph F. Carabetta, is pitching a plan that focuses on building a new high school, a community college, a sports stadium and a park in the same area. The idea is based on his belief retail will not work downtown.
Those who support the City Center Initiative concede there are hundreds of reasons for the plan to fall apart, but they also see no other choice: waiting for change will do nothing to revitalize downtown.

Below, a mall parking lot that is scheduled to be transformed as part of a long-term plan.; Wayne D'Amico, a consultant, on the roof of a building in downtown Meriden overlooking an area where a redevelopment project is in the works. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Making Estimates Add Up

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
VIRTUALLY every consumer who borrows money to finance a house or apartment is provided with a pair of documents known as the "Good Faith Estimate of Settlement Charges" and the "Truth-in-Lending Disclosure." The forms -- mandated by federal law since the mid-1970's -- are intended to provide borrowers with tools for comparing the costs of similar loans being offered by different lenders. 
 But lenders, lawyers and mortgage finance experts say the documents -- which have been unchanged for nearly three decades -- are confusing to consumers and may not accurately reflect the differences in loans. In fact, in July the Department of Housing and Urban Development proposed new regulations under the Real Estate Settlement and Procedures Act -- the law that mandates the good faith estimate and truth-in-lending forms -- in the hope of "simplifying and improving" the mortgage process. 
 "The original premise behind the good faith estimate was that it would help protect the public from unscrupulous lenders," said Ellen Bitton, president of Park Avenue Mortgage Group, a Manhattan mortgage broker. "Unfortunately, it has been hugely successful at confusing people." 
Ms. Bitton explained that the theory behind the good faith estimate was to provide a mortgage applicant with a single document containing estimates of all the costs associated with the transaction. Armed with that document, she said, a consumer would be able to compare various loans and ultimately decide which would be best.
But the good faith estimate is not always a very good indicator of the actual costs of a particular mortgage. And since lenders use different strategies for preparing estimates, Ms. Bitton said, there may be big differences in estimated closing costs.
"Some lenders will put in the lowest estimates possible," she said. "But with my clients, I would prefer to overestimate an item than to underestimate it. I prefer that they are happily surprised that it will cost less than they expected."
Stephen Ornstein, a Washington lawyer who specializes in mortgage finance law, said the good faith estimate must be provided within three days of the borrower's applying for a mortgage. Costs included on the form, he said, include the appraisal, the credit report, the lender's application fee and the number of "points" the borrower will pay for the loan. A point -- 1 percent of the mortgage -- is basically the lender's charge for agreeing to make the loan.
Other items in the good faith estimate are various "title charges," including the cost of a title search, notary fees, lender's attorney fees and title insurance for the lender. (What may not be included in the "title charges" section, however, are the fees charged by the borrower's lawyer and the cost of the owner's title insurance policy.) 
Ms. Bitton of Park Avenue Mortgage Group said there are a number of other items on the good faith estimate that can be confusing to borrowers.
For example, she said, lenders often require borrowers to pay one-twelfth of the annual cost of hazard insurance and real estate taxes along with the monthly mortgage payment. And typically, Ms. Bitton said, the lender will also require two or more months of escrows to be paid in advance. Since some lenders do not require those reserves at all -- leaving it up to the borrower to make tax and insurance payments directly -- monthly escrow payments might appear on one lender's disclosure form but not on another's. (Of course, the borrower pays the money in either case.)
Other items that may or may not appear on a good faith estimate relate to taxes imposed on the sale or financing of property. For example, Ms. Bitton said, while there is a 1 percent tax in New York on the entire sales price for properties sold for $1 million or more -- known as the "mansion tax" -- some lenders disclose the tax while others, inadvertently, may not. 
"And many lenders are unaware of the Peconic Tax," she said, referring to a 2 percent local tax on certain properties in Suffolk County on sale amounts exceeding $250,000.
Another item that causes significant confusion in New York, Ms. Bitton said, relates to the state's mortgage recording tax. That tax, which can range from 0.75 percent to 1.875 percent depending on the location of the property and the amount of the mortgage, is typically reported on the good faith estimate. 
It is sometimes possible, however, for a borrower -- particularly one who is refinancing a mortgage -- to arrange to have an existing mortgage either modified or assigned to a new lender, thereby avoiding the tax on the balance of the old mortgage. When that is being considered, she said, another item often appears on the good faith estimate -- the "consolidation, extension and modification" charge. Since there is no guarantee the assignment will be done, however, the lender also includes the estimate for the mortgage recording tax. As a result, there will be two estimates on the form: one that reflects the cost to avoid the tax and another for the tax itself.
Oded Ben-Ami, a senior loan officer of the Sterling National Mortgage Company in Great Neck, N.Y., said one of the most confusing pieces of information consumers are provided with is the annual percentage rate reflected on the initial truth-in-lending disclosure form that lenders send to applicants for loans. This is because the A.P.R. is almost always higher than the interest rate the borrower believes he is paying. 
Mr. Ben-Ami explained that most people shopping for a mortgage focus on at the interest rate being charged. An interest rate of, say, 7 percent obviously appears more attractive than a mortgage with an interest rate of, say, 7.25 percent. However, Mr. Ben-Ami said, the lender offering the 7 percent rate might charge two points for that mortgage while the lender offering the higher rate might charge only one point or even none. The difficulty for the borrower, of course, is determining which mortgage ends up being the less expensive over the long run.
What The annual percentage rate attempts to do, he said, is quantify the difference between those two mortgages. And it does so by taking into consideration the costs of the loan. In other words, if the interest rate being charged is 7 percent, the effective annual percentage rate of the loan might be 7.3 percent when the costs of obtaining the loan are taken into consideration.
But while the annual percentage rate calculation takes into consideration some of the costs of obtaining the mortgage, it does not take into consideration all of them. 
For example, Mr. Ben-Ami said, the A.P.R. calculation does not include the appraisal, the credit report, title insurance or the borrower's legal fees. 
And when the loan being applied for is an adjustable rate loan, he said, the A.P.R. is basically useless because there is no way of knowing what the new rate will be after the initial interest rate period expires.
John C. Weicher, assistant secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Washington, acknowledged that the current disclosure laws offer less-than-perfect protection for consumers. "We've been hearing these kind of complaints for a while," Mr. Weicher said. "And we agree that the good faith estimate is nowhere near as useful as it should be."
To remedy some problems, he said, HUD has proposed amendments to the regulations that would require lenders to be more precise with their estimates of closing costs and honor those estimates through the date of closing. Under the proposed amendments, for example, for categories of costs where the lender is providing the services, the amount the lender actually charges can be no more than the good faith estimate, Mr. Weicher said. He added that for estimates of costs for services provided by third parties -- like title insurance charges -- the actual amount paid cannot be more than 10 percent higher than the estimate.
In addition, he said, the proposed amendments require lenders to include all governmental charges and taxes on the good faith estimate. Amounts that the lender should have included but did not, he said, would have to be paid by the lender. 
"We're trying to make the process as simple as we can so the consumer has the total cost of the transaction in a single figure," Mr. Weicher said, adding that while the final version of the regulations may still change -- depending on comments received during the public comment period, which ends Oct. 28 -- the department expects the final regulations to be in place by next spring.

HEADLINE: The Arts Take a Hit, and Regroup 

BYLINE:  By KATHERINE ZOEPF 

 BODY:
IT has not been a good year for Westchester's fine arts and performing arts institutions. 
 An ailing economy, a number of corporate donors moving out of the county, audiences who stayed home more in the months after Sept. 11, along with the usual pressures of competing with Manhattan's larger and better-financed arts organizations, have combined in the past year to create an unusually difficult fund-raising climate. 
 Across the county, the managers of Westchester's arts institutions have been looking into their coffers and assessing the shortfalls, then deciding how best to raise money in the months ahead and how to present exciting seasons given their current straitened circumstances. 
"We're all shaking in our boots," said John Raymond, the managing director of the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck. "Fund-raising is always hard, no matter when you do it. But this year has been terrible." 
There has already been a casualty. The Westchester Symphony, which was founded in White Plains in 1924 and was once a staple of Westchester cultural life, folded in January, citing a dwindling subscriber base and a lack of corporate support. Taken as a cautionary tale, the symphony's demise sent shudders through the county's arts organizations. 
"Twenty years ago there were seven professional orchestras in Westchester," said Elaine Carroll, the executive director of the Westchester Philharmonic, which, now that the Westchester Symphony has left the scene, is the only professional symphony orchestra left in the county. "If people are serious about having quality arts here in Westchester, we need their support now." 
Sept. 11 left the arts in an awkward position. Ticket sales and museum admissions dropped sharply, as did subscriptions and corporate donations. 
Nearly all managers of arts institutions are quick to say that they expected the arts to lose out for a time to other charitable appeals. "Because of Sept. 11, people were asked to give to so many of the social service agencies and, well they should!" Mr. Raymond said. "The arts obviously take a back seat to that type of appeal. But for us in the arts, it's not a comfortable place to be." 
As the post-Sept. 11 gloom became more prolonged, and reports of a recession emerged, Mr. Raymond and his cohorts at other local arts institutions began to realize that ticket sales and donations would not be bouncing back as quickly as they had hoped. 
Janet T. Langsam, is the executive director of the Westchester Arts Council, an organization based in White Plains that redistributes grants from foundations and others to artists and acts as a lobbyist on behalf of the county's arts institutions and works to build a sense of community among them. Ms. Langsam said that though the arts are suffering, they are by no means alone. 
"It's no question that this has been an exceptionally difficult year," Ms. Langsam said. "But no one has singled out the arts. It's just a very stressful time all around, and we're all stretching our imaginations and resources to maintain funding." 
Dr. Lucinda H. Gedeon, director of the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, said that the stock market and shrinking portfolios among the Neuberger's donor base have been far worse for fund-raising this spring than the aftershocks of the terror attacks, but pointed out that it is hard to separate the two. "Fear has increased, and in that way Sept. 11 has had a tremendous effect on the market and on people's giving," Dr. Gedeon said. "Giving has decreased markedly because portfolios have gone down, and people don't have that surplus anymore."
Dr. Gedeon said that more than half the Neuberger's yearly operating budget, about $3.5 million for 2002-2003, came from fund-raising, a figure that is not unusual among arts institutions in the county. 
This season, the Neuberger, in its brown brick fortresslike building on the Purchase College campus, is mounting some ambitious new exhibitions. An exhibit of African shields is already on view, and a show of Chuck Close prints is set to open in a few weeks. "We've seen a loss of interest on our endowment, and we haven't been getting gifts of appreciated stock like we used to," said Dr. Gedeon. "But individual giving has remained steady, and our memberships went up last year. People do seem to find solace in the arts during times of trial. And as a museum, we're cheap entertainment."
Though for some arts institutions all forms of giving have fallen, fund-raisers say, corporate giving has fallen most steeply. The organizations which relied most heavily on corporate donations have been the hardest hit. 
"There has been a downturn in philanthropic giving in the corporate sector," said Ilene Lieberman, the director of development for the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College. "Gifts are smaller this year." 
Though corporate giving has fallen sharply this year, it has been on the decline for some time. Susan Shine, director of development for Caramoor, said corporate giving has been falling for more than a decade. "It used to be, 10 or 15 years ago, that there was a sense of corporate responsibility to the neighborhood. These days, many of the major corporations prefer to support sports events. We're simply not big enough. 
"The need to be a good corporate neighbor, that has been declining," she said. "When you're talking about corporate sponsorships, then you're dealing with bang for the buck. Sports has been our largest competition for those types of gifts. I just can't deliver the same numbers as the U.S. Open." 
That corporate neighborhood is also in flux. In the last decade, Texaco, Clairol, Philip Morris and Kodak, all generous patrons of the arts, have left the county. 
"What has happened on the corporate side has been very difficult," Ms. Langsam said. "And then last year the New York State Council on the Arts cut its funding by 10 percent across the board. It's been very stressful, and it's been worst for the smaller, younger organizations, that don't have the long-term constituency to fall back on."
For their part, the major corporations that have stayed in Westchester say that their commitment to supporting area arts institutions is unchanged. Kendra Collins, a spokeswoman for I.B.M., said that the company gives an annual grant of $25,000 to the Westchester Arts Council and that this year it gave an additional grant of nearly $50,000 to the council to finance the council's new building, a former bank in White Plains built in the 1920's now known as the Arts Exchange, which has offices, galleries, studio and performance space for local artists. The council is in the process of raising $5 million to renovate the building and endow its programs. 
Richard Detwiler, a spokesman for PepsiCo, said that the company provides upward of $80,000 annually in support of the arts in Westchester, primarily through the Arts Council. "We also provide a great deal of support for the Music America festival at the Westchester Philharmonic," he said.
According to Susan Russ, a spokeswoman for Readers Digest, the Readers Digest Foundation provides an annual $5,000 grant to the Westchester Arts Council, and additional grants to organizations including the Hudson River Museum, and the Hudson Valley Writers Center. "The focus is on education, literacy programs, library services," she said. "We support the arts when there's a nice link there." 

Falling Subscriptions Hinder Season Plans
After a decline in contributed income -- outright gifts from individuals, corporations, the government or foundations -- most Westchester arts institutions cite falling subscriptions as their biggest worry for the coming season. 
Dan Montez, the general director of the Taconic Opera, based in Yorktown Heights, said that falling subscriptions have made it more difficult to plan the coming fall season. "When someone subscribes, that gives us money up front," he said. "It helps us decide how many singers we can hire, what quality of production we can put on. Single ticket sales usually come pouring in the week of the show, which makes budgeting and planning very difficult."
Ms. Carroll said that she and her colleagues at the Westchester Philharmonic, which performs in Purchase at the Performing Arts Center, have found that ticket sales are rarely enough to cover the loss of subscribers. "People always say they'll just buy individual tickets, but you never sell as many seats that way," she said. "If it rains, or they just don't feel like it, they won't come. When people subscribe to an organization, they feel that in some way they are a part of it. So when we lose subscribers, we are losing people who feel they have that sense of ownership in the philharmonic." 
The Westchester Philharmonic has seen a 9 percent drop in subscriptions between Labor Day 2001 and the present, Ms. Carroll said, to 1,408 subscribers from 1,590. The philharmonic's most popular subscription, which includes five shows, costs $200, she said. A single adult ticket in that same seating category costs $60. Corporate gifts to the Philharmonic have also dropped, from about $201,512 in 1999-2000 to $180,998 in 2001-2002. 

Teaching Children The Arts Closer to Home
Although subscribers are dwindling, many county arts institutions report a surge of interest in their education programs -- which also seems to be related to the terror attacks.
"We've seen tremendous growth in our school program, which we attribute to Sept. 11," Dr. Gedeon said. "Parents prefer to keep their children closer to home. The schools are not taking as many big bus trips into the city." 
Mary Hastings, the director of education initiatives for the Westchester Philharmonic, said that increased interest in the philharmonic's schools program, "Mozart and Me," has been a mixed blessing. 
"We have seen an increase in the number of schools that have expressed interest in our educational programs," Ms. Hastings said. Yet at the same time, she said, they have lost a large chunk of funding for education programs.
Ms. Hastings said that this decline, which is almost entirely due to a drop in corporate donations, means a diminished ability to help finance classical music programs for poor schools. "I haven't started doling out the funding for this school year, but in another three weeks I'll be clutching my chest," she said. "My biggest worry is the Yonkers school district. The buses alone represent an incredible hardship for a poor school, and we are used to fully scholarshipping all our Yonkers schools. It's going to be very hard to tell them that we can't do that this year." 

Belt Tightening And Seeking New Avenues
As they prepare for the fall season, the managers and development directors of Westchester's arts organizations have been asking themselves why one of the wealthiest counties in America is struggling so hard to pay for its love of the arts. Did the boom years of the 1980's and 90's give rise to more arts organizations than Westchester can comfortably support in the long run? If not, then how can struggling arts groups cut operating expenses and through what new avenues should they seek financing? 
For now, the managers of Westchester arts institutions say, they are tightening their belts and hoping the money drought ends very soon. 
"We're looking very closely at our exhibitions," Dr. Gedeon said. "We're planning fewer new exhibitions, and lengthening the time that exhibitions are up. Were looking at every line item in the budget, being creative in terms of doing with less." 
Mr. Raymond of the Emelin, which is celebrating its 30th anniversary this year, said that the theater has cut back on its operating expenses.
"We're not going to be bringing in as many of the big companies with the big fees," he said. 
"We try to get people in the tri-state area -- that's one way we've been able to keep our cost down. One thing we're doing this year is a collaboration with the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton. They had a wonderful production of 'National Anthems,' by Dennis McIntyre. It won't be as expensive as if we had to mount it from beginning to end."
This year, the Taconic Opera, which is celebrating its fifth anniversary, has hired professional fund-raisers for the first time, to improve direct-mail contacts. "They're more aware of where the wealth is in Westchester," said Mr. Montez. The opera is holding a gala on Oct. 3 and is staging a new performance of "Rigoletto" under Mr. Montez's direction.
Westchester's arts institutions are also taking more aggressive steps to attract new, and younger, audiences. This year, the Westchester Philharmonic has introduced both a new family pricing system, offering $5 tickets for children under 16, and a new subscription program for young adults (five concerts for $20). Both programs, Ms. Carroll said, are growing slowly: "Price is not the only problem in attracting young people to the fine arts," she pointed out.
The Performing Arts Center, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary this season, reports success with its innovative program of smaller, more specialized subscriptions. The center offers about 14 different subscription series, which range from international classical music to a Motown series this year. "One year we did a folk series, and another year we did a 70's rock series," said Ms. Lieberman. "Ticket sales have been strong, and we attribute that to the varied program."
Stephen Apkon, the executive director of the year-old Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville, said that, recession notwithstanding, the Burns Center has been much more successful than anticipated. He attributed the success in part to the center's diverse offerings, which attract audiences of all ages. 
Denise Bessette, a producer for the four-year-old Hudson Stage Company in Croton-on-Hudson, said that in spite of financial worries, the company is proceeding with its plans to produce a new musical, "True Home," starring Cass Morgan and written by Ms. Morgan and a group of her songwriter friends. 
"We're going ahead with our fall production even though we're severely undercapitalized," Ms. Bessette said. "Our biggest challenge right now is finding the money. I'm sure there's money out there with private sources -- we just have to discover each other." 
Ms. Shine of Caramoor agreed. "I continue to believe that the audiences and the donors are out there," she said. "Most of us in the classical music world live on a very close budget. You can't be a fund-raiser without being optimistic."
